Encounters by Michael Frayn review \u2013 heartfelt pen portraits", "standfirst": "<p>The playwright\u2019s evocative series of essays profiles some of the brightest figures he\u2019s met in his life, from Alan Bennett and Bamber Gascoigne to childhood friends and first loves</p>", "trailText": "The playwright\u2019s evocative series of essays profiles some of the brightest figures he\u2019s met in his life, from Alan Bennett and Bamber Gascoigne to childhood friends and first loves", "byline": "Tim Adams", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"2a30799846a44ed813a2f134b06f3a338f100fd2\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/2a30799846a44ed813a2f134b06f3a338f100fd2/0_448_6720_4032/1000.jpg\" alt=\"\u2018Eye-bright Michael Frayn at home in London, April 2020.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Antonio Olmos/The Observer</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>There is a generation of writers who were schooled by the war and the more egalitarian freedoms of its aftermath, and who borrowed intellectual and moral authority from both. A great capacity for friendship helped, and the porosity of an establishment that for the first time allowed state-educated \u2013 mostly grammar school \u2013 boys and girls a more equal voice with the fee-paying class. Michael Frayn, now 89, was \u2013 and is \u2013 a shining star in that firmament. This book, a collection of short essays on some of the other fixed points in his constellation, becomes a thoughtful and often moving portrait of a disappearing world in which a generous kind of bookish rigour and worldly wit created fleeting incandescence at the heart of British cultural life.</p> <p>Frayn did his national service alongside Alan Bennett, studying Russian at the Joint Services School for Linguists, a cold war initiative to steep the brightest undergraduates in military intelligence (it proved to be a kind of theatrical fame academy \u2013 Peter Hall and Dennis Potter were also alumni). The Cambridge branch of that school was presided over by Prof Elizabeth Hill, one of the few women who gets a look in here \u2013 the absence, Frayn notes in his introduction, is both circumstantial (he grew up in single-sex schools, and almost entirely male barrack rooms and university colleges and newspaper offices) and mannerly (lovers\u2019 secrets should remain intact). Hill acted as a kind of formidable Slavic matriarch for Frayn\u2019s cohort; she addressed them \u201c<em>Gospoda</em>!\u201d (\u201cgentlemen!\u201d), \u201ccoaxing the Russian out of you by the sheer brightness of her eyes\u201d, and they duly grew into the role.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>As the book progresses, the sense of the precariousness of fate, of roads not taken, takes over</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>Like several of the friends here, Hill was characterised by brilliant longevity. The last time Frayn saw her, at 95, she was rising at six in Cambridge after a party to catch a bus to London to put in a full day\u2019s work at the British Library. She is matched for enduring eye-bright curiosity not only by Frayn himself, but in portraits of several of his closest pals: Neal Ascherson, his former <em>Observer</em> colleague, still writing as eruditely as ever; Michael Blakemore, the director of 10 of Frayn\u2019s plays, who revived the last of them, <em><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2018/aug/24/copenhagen-review-michael-frayn\">Copenhagen</a></em>, on the eve of his own 90th birthday in 2018; and Bamber Gascoigne, who opens this book and establishes something of its presiding spirit: a golden lad at Cambridge, who remains endearingly \u201clucky and loved\u201d to his end in 2022.</p> <p>The brightness of some of these young things is sharpened in Frayn\u2019s memory by the close knowledge of alternative narrative arcs. There are among the success stories inevitably several tragic notes. His piece on playwright Peter Nichols feels like one; early success that trails tragedy and intermittent despair. Equally honest and poignant is Frayn\u2019s account of the bipolar extremes of the famed <em>Observer</em> journalist John Gale, who took his own life at 49, and of Frayn\u2019s childhood friend David, who used his imagination to escape from a tyrannical father, but was psychologically undone by that bullying decades later.</p> <p>As the book progresses, that sense of the precariousness of fate, of roads not taken, takes over. Frayn\u2019s discretion in excluding lost loves was finally overcome, he suggests, at the insistence of his wife, Claire Tomalin. His penultimate chapter here \u2013 before a valedictory letter to his most constant companion, his own body \u2013 is a recollection of his first overwhelming romance, with Liza Mrosovsky, whom he met in the spring of 1957, his graduation year, and with whom he spent part of a magical summer in Rome. He has kept the 56 letters she sent him during those six months of their grand affair, and reinhabits the intensity of their rise and fall together, the talk of undying love and marriage, and then not.</p> <p>It was he who ended things, on the brutal grounds, apparently, that she was not part of his \u201cintellectual world\u201d \u2013 can he really have offered that \u201cpompous put-down\u201d, he wonders, 65 years on? When he tries to find a trace of her, he discovers a life lived very happily without him, one that ended in 2016. He\u2019d always promised to write, he says, and now, in this poised, heartfelt book, he has fulfilled that obligation.</p> <p><em>\u2022 Among Others: Friendships and Encounters </em>by Michael Frayn is published by Faber (\u00a325). To support the <em>Guardian</em> and <em>Observer</em> order your copy at <a href=\"https://guardianbookshop.com/among-others-9780571378609\">guardianbookshop.com</a>. Delivery charges may apply</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "There is a generation of writers who were schooled by the war and the more egalitarian freedoms of its aftermath, and who borrowed intellectual and moral authority from both. A great capacity for friendship helped, and the porosity of an establishment that for the first time allowed state-educated \u2013 mostly grammar school \u2013 boys and girls a more equal voice with the fee-paying class. Michael Frayn, now 89, was \u2013 and is \u2013 a shining star in that firmament. This book, a collection of short essays on some of the other fixed points in his constellation, becomes a thoughtful and often moving portrait of a disappearing world in which a generous kind of bookish rigour and worldly wit created fleeting incandescence at the heart of British cultural life. Frayn did his national service alongside Alan Bennett, studying Russian at the Joint Services School for Linguists, a cold war initiative to steep the brightest undergraduates in military intelligence (it proved to be a kind of theatrical fame academy \u2013 Peter Hall and Dennis Potter were also alumni). The Cambridge branch of that school was presided over by Prof Elizabeth Hill, one of the few women who gets a look in here \u2013 the absence, Frayn notes in his introduction, is both circumstantial (he grew up in single-sex schools, and almost entirely male barrack rooms and university colleges and newspaper offices) and mannerly (lovers\u2019 secrets should remain intact). Hill acted as a kind of formidable Slavic matriarch for Frayn\u2019s cohort; she addressed them \u201cGospoda!\u201d (\u201cgentlemen!\u201d), \u201ccoaxing the Russian out of you by the sheer brightness of her eyes\u201d, and they duly grew into the role.\nLike several of the friends here, Hill was characterised by brilliant longevity. The last time Frayn saw her, at 95, she was rising at six in Cambridge after a party to catch a bus to London to put in a full day\u2019s work at the British Library. She is matched for enduring eye-bright curiosity not only by Frayn himself, but in portraits of several of his closest pals: Neal Ascherson, his former Observer colleague, still writing as eruditely as ever; Michael Blakemore, the director of 10 of Frayn\u2019s plays, who revived the last of them, Copenhagen, on the eve of his own 90th birthday in 2018; and Bamber Gascoigne, who opens this book and establishes something of its presiding spirit: a golden lad at Cambridge, who remains endearingly \u201clucky and loved\u201d to his end in 2022. The brightness of some of these young things is sharpened in Frayn\u2019s memory by the close knowledge of alternative narrative arcs. There are among the success stories inevitably several tragic notes. His piece on playwright Peter Nichols feels like one; early success that trails tragedy and intermittent despair. Equally honest and poignant is Frayn\u2019s account of the bipolar extremes of the famed Observer journalist John Gale, who took his own life at 49, and of Frayn\u2019s childhood friend David, who used his imagination to escape from a tyrannical father, but was psychologically undone by that bullying decades later. As the book progresses, that sense of the precariousness of fate, of roads not taken, takes over. Frayn\u2019s discretion in excluding lost loves was finally overcome, he suggests, at the insistence of his wife, Claire Tomalin. His penultimate chapter here \u2013 before a valedictory letter to his most constant companion, his own body \u2013 is a recollection of his first overwhelming romance, with Liza Mrosovsky, whom he met in the spring of 1957, his graduation year, and with whom he spent part of a magical summer in Rome. He has kept the 56 letters she sent him during those six months of their grand affair, and reinhabits the intensity of their rise and fall together, the talk of undying love and marriage, and then not. It was he who ended things, on the brutal grounds, apparently, that she was not part of his \u201cintellectual world\u201d \u2013 can he really have offered that \u201cpompous put-down\u201d, he wonders, 65 years on? When he tries to find a trace of her, he discovers a life lived very happily without him, one that ended in 2016. He\u2019d always promised to write, he says, and now, in this poised, heartfelt book, he has fulfilled that obligation. \u2022 Among Others: Friendships and Encounters by Michael Frayn is published by Faber (\u00a325). Delivery charges may apply", "attributes": {}, "published": true, "createdDate": "2023-04-17T06:00:33Z", "firstPublishedDate": "2023-04-17T06:00:33Z", "publishedDate": "2023-04-17T06:00:33Z", "lastModifiedDate": "2023-04-06T15:12:28Z", "contributors": [], "elements": [{"type": "text", "assets": [], "textTypeData": {"html": "<p>There is a generation of writers who were schooled by the war and the more egalitarian freedoms of its aftermath, and who borrowed intellectual and moral authority from both. A great capacity for friendship helped, and the porosity of an establishment that for the first time allowed state-educated \u2013 mostly grammar school \u2013 boys and girls a more equal voice with the fee-paying class. Michael Frayn, now 89, was \u2013 and is \u2013 a shining star in that firmament. This book, a collection of short essays on some of the other fixed points in his constellation, becomes a thoughtful and often moving portrait of a disappearing world in which a generous kind of bookish rigour and worldly wit created fleeting incandescence at the heart of British cultural life.</p> \n<p>Frayn did his national service alongside Alan Bennett, studying Russian at the Joint Services School for Linguists, a cold war initiative to steep the brightest undergraduates in military intelligence (it proved to be a kind of theatrical fame academy \u2013 Peter Hall and Dennis Potter were also alumni). The Cambridge branch of that school was presided over by Prof Elizabeth Hill, one of the few women who gets a look in here \u2013 the absence, Frayn notes in his introduction, is both circumstantial (he grew up in single-sex schools, and almost entirely male barrack rooms and university colleges and newspaper offices) and mannerly (lovers\u2019 secrets should remain intact). Hill acted as a kind of formidable Slavic matriarch for Frayn\u2019s cohort; she addressed them \u201c<em>Gospoda</em>!\u201d (\u201cgentlemen!\u201d), \u201ccoaxing the Russian out of you by the sheer brightness of her eyes\u201d, and they duly grew into the role.</p>"}}, {"type": "pullquote", "assets": [], "pullquoteTypeData": {"html": "As the book progresses, the sense of the precariousness of fate, of roads not taken, takes over", "role": "supporting"}}, {"type": "text", "assets": [], "textTypeData": {"html": "<p>Like several of the friends here, Hill was characterised by brilliant longevity. The last time Frayn saw her, at 95, she was rising at six in Cambridge after a party to catch a bus to London to put in a full day\u2019s work at the British Library. She is matched for enduring eye-bright curiosity not only by Frayn himself, but in portraits of several of his closest pals: Neal Ascherson, his former <em>Observer</em> colleague, still writing as eruditely as ever; Michael Blakemore, the director of 10 of Frayn\u2019s plays, who revived the last of them, <em><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2018/aug/24/copenhagen-review-michael-frayn\">Copenhagen</a></em>, on the eve of his own 90th birthday in 2018; and Bamber Gascoigne, who opens this book and establishes something of its presiding spirit: a golden lad at Cambridge, who remains endearingly \u201clucky and loved\u201d to his end in 2022.</p> \n<p>The brightness of some of these young things is sharpened in Frayn\u2019s memory by the close knowledge of alternative narrative arcs. There are among the success stories inevitably several tragic notes. His piece on playwright Peter Nichols feels like one; early success that trails tragedy and intermittent despair. Equally honest and poignant is Frayn\u2019s account of the bipolar extremes of the famed <em>Observer</em> journalist John Gale, who took his own life at 49, and of Frayn\u2019s childhood friend David, who used his imagination to escape from a tyrannical father, but was psychologically undone by that bullying decades later.</p> \n<p>As the book progresses, that sense of the precariousness of fate, of roads not taken, takes over. Frayn\u2019s discretion in excluding lost loves was finally overcome, he suggests, at the insistence of his wife, Claire Tomalin. His penultimate chapter here \u2013 before a valedictory letter to his most constant companion, his own body \u2013 is a recollection of his first overwhelming romance, with Liza Mrosovsky, whom he met in the spring of 1957, his graduation year, and with whom he spent part of a magical summer in Rome. He has kept the 56 letters she sent him during those six months of their grand affair, and reinhabits the intensity of their rise and fall together, the talk of undying love and marriage, and then not.</p> \n<p>It was he who ended things, on the brutal grounds, apparently, that she was not part of his \u201cintellectual world\u201d \u2013 can he really have offered that \u201cpompous put-down\u201d, he wonders, 65 years on? When he tries to find a trace of her, he discovers a life lived very happily without him, one that ended in 2016. He\u2019d always promised to write, he says, and now, in this poised, heartfelt book, he has fulfilled that obligation.</p> \n<p><em>\u2022 Among Others: Friendships and Encounters </em>by Michael Frayn is published by Faber (\u00a325). When I notified it of AJ\u2019s death back in September it closed his account and promised a cheque for his credit balance would be posted to me. This eventually arrived in November but was made payable to \u201cMiss AJ\u201d. My father\u2019s bank accounts are frozen and he was never a \u201cMiss\u201d, so I requested a replacement made payable to me and sent to my address (I live more than five hours drive from my dad\u2019s flat). I was promised a new cheque would be issued, which it eventually was, but again it was made payable to \u201cMiss AJ\u201d and sent to his address! When I closed his account, a new one had been set up called \u201cexecutors of AJ\u201d, with me as the named contact. However, even though the company knew he had died, I received emails addressed to \u201cDear AJ\u201d which I found very upsetting. The farce continued when it sent a \u00a3127 refund cheque for the executors account, which was double the amount owed. However, as it was made payable to \u201cexecutors of AJ\u201d, and there is no bank account with that name, it was useless. It then sent payment demands for the overpayment, even though I had not been able to pay the cheque into a bank account. Eventually, after being threatened with debt collection and credit default notices, I paid the amount it claimed was due, so they now owe me more money. It has also since emerged that the executors\u2019 account was closed the day after I opened it, and another account set up in my name, at his address, with bills based on estimated usage sent to the unoccupied flat. I only discovered this when I started to get payment demands, including texts from debt collectors. However, when I supplied the meter readings the account was \u00a371 in credit. I have lost count of the hours I have spent writing emails, on the phone and writing up notes in an attempt to keep track of progress with the different accounts. I raised a complaint in November last year and in January I asked for it to be escalated. But I am getting nowhere. On the basis of the statements and correspondence, Scottish Power still owes my family about \u00a3365 and I feel that some acknowledgment of its failings is warranted given the impact on me after the loss of my father. MJ, Monyash The ineptitude displayed by Scottish Power in handling the closure of your late father\u2019s account at times borders on parody. To send cheques to your father\u2019s female alter ego not once, but twice, as well as sending emails addressed to him, is distressing. But to then chase you for money that you do not owe is shocking. The good news, however, is that with our help this sorry saga is now finally over. Scottish Power says: \u201cWe\u2019re very sorry for the distress and frustration MJ experienced, and the unacceptable delays in resolving this for him at such a difficult time. This is not the standard of customer service we aim to provide.\u201d It continues: \u201cWe cancelled all previous cheques and sent him cheques issued in his name and to his address, covering the final credit balance owed. \u201cWe refunded the energy bill support payments he was entitled to for his late father\u2019s property, and remained in touch to ensure the cheques were received and cashed before closing the accounts concerned. \u201cWe then agreed and issued a goodwill payment in recognition of the distress caused.\u201d After some wrangling it increased its compensation offer to \u00a3500, which your family has accepted. You are glad it is finally all over but feel that by repeating mistakes, such as issuing useless cheques to \u201cMiss AJ\u201d, it demonstrated considerable incompetence and insensitivity. It made you glad to receive an apology and a level of compensation that you think begins to reflect the seriousness of its failures in this case. To you, it seemed that Scottish Power\u2019s procedures and systems for dealing with the death of a customer had been designed with a level of incompetence comparable to Basil Fawlty. The hope here is that by highlighting your experience, other people dealing with the loss of a loved one will have a better experience. Let\u2019s hope so. This is not the standard of customer service we aim to provide.\u201d</p> <p>It continues: \u201cWe cancelled all previous cheques and sent him cheques issued in his name and to his address, covering the final credit balance owed.</p> <p>\u201cWe refunded the energy bill support payments he was entitled to for his late father\u2019s property, and remained in touch to ensure the cheques were received and cashed before closing the accounts concerned.</p> <p>\u201cWe then agreed and issued a goodwill payment in recognition of the distress caused.\u201d</p> <p>After some wrangling it increased its compensation offer to \u00a3500, which your family has accepted.</p> <p>You are glad it is finally all over but feel that by repeating mistakes, such as issuing useless cheques to \u201cMiss AJ\u201d, it demonstrated considerable incompetence and insensitivity.</p> <p>It made you glad to receive an apology and a level of compensation that you think begins to reflect the seriousness of its failures in this case.</p> <p>To you, it seemed that Scottish Power\u2019s procedures and systems for dealing with the death of a customer had been designed with a level of incompetence comparable to Basil Fawlty.</p> <p>The hope here is that by highlighting your experience, other people dealing with the loss of a loved one will have a better experience.</p> <p>Let\u2019s hope so.</p> <p><em>We welcome letters but cannot answer individually. Submission and publication of all letters is subject to <a href=\"http://theguardian.com/letters-terms\">our terms and conditions</a></em></p>", "bodyTextSummary": "I am contacting you in desperation about the serious problems I am having dealing with Scottish Power after the death of my father last year. When I notified it of AJ\u2019s death back in September it closed his account and promised a cheque for his credit balance would be posted to me. This eventually arrived in November but was made payable to \u201cMiss AJ\u201d. My father\u2019s bank accounts are frozen and he was never a \u201cMiss\u201d, so I requested a replacement made payable to me and sent to my address (I live more than five hours drive from my dad\u2019s flat). I was promised a new cheque would be issued, which it eventually was, but again it was made payable to \u201cMiss AJ\u201d and sent to his address! When I closed his account, a new one had been set up called \u201cexecutors of AJ\u201d, with me as the named contact. However, even though the company knew he had died, I received emails addressed to \u201cDear AJ\u201d which I found very upsetting. The farce continued when it sent a \u00a3127 refund cheque for the executors account, which was double the amount owed. However, as it was made payable to \u201cexecutors of AJ\u201d, and there is no bank account with that name, it was useless. It then sent payment demands for the overpayment, even though I had not been able to pay the cheque into a bank account. Eventually, after being threatened with debt collection and credit default notices, I paid the amount it claimed was due, so they now owe me more money. It has also since emerged that the executors\u2019 account was closed the day after I opened it, and another account set up in my name, at his address, with bills based on estimated usage sent to the unoccupied flat. I only discovered this when I started to get payment demands, including texts from debt collectors. However, when I supplied the meter readings the account was \u00a371 in credit. I have lost count of the hours I have spent writing emails, on the phone and writing up notes in an attempt to keep track of progress with the different accounts. I raised a complaint in November last year and in January I asked for it to be escalated. But I am getting nowhere. On the basis of the statements and correspondence, Scottish Power still owes my family about \u00a3365 and I feel that some acknowledgment of its failings is warranted given the impact on me after the loss of my father. MJ, Monyash The ineptitude displayed by Scottish Power in handling the closure of your late father\u2019s account at times borders on parody. To send cheques to your father\u2019s female alter ego not once, but twice, as well as sending emails addressed to him, is distressing. But to then chase you for money that you do not owe is shocking. The good news, however, is that with our help this sorry saga is now finally over. Scottish Power says: \u201cWe\u2019re very sorry for the distress and frustration MJ experienced, and the unacceptable delays in resolving this for him at such a difficult time. This is not the standard of customer service we aim to provide.\u201d It continues: \u201cWe cancelled all previous cheques and sent him cheques issued in his name and to his address, covering the final credit balance owed. \u201cWe refunded the energy bill support payments he was entitled to for his late father\u2019s property, and remained in touch to ensure the cheques were received and cashed before closing the accounts concerned. \u201cWe then agreed and issued a goodwill payment in recognition of the distress caused.\u201d After some wrangling it increased its compensation offer to \u00a3500, which your family has accepted. You are glad it is finally all over but feel that by repeating mistakes, such as issuing useless cheques to \u201cMiss AJ\u201d, it demonstrated considerable incompetence and insensitivity. It made you glad to receive an apology and a level of compensation that you think begins to reflect the seriousness of its failures in this case. To you, it seemed that Scottish Power\u2019s procedures and systems for dealing with the death of a customer had been designed with a level of incompetence comparable to Basil Fawlty. The hope here is that by highlighting your experience, other people dealing with the loss of a loved one will have a better experience. Let\u2019s hope so. We welcome letters but cannot answer individually. Email us at consumer.champions@theguardian.com or write to Consumer Champions, Money, the Guardian, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU. Why would I want anyone to assume I am younger? | Viv Groskop", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2023/apr/17/i-turn-50-soon-why-would-i-want-anyone-to-assume-i-am-younger", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/commentisfree/2023/apr/17/i-turn-50-soon-why-would-i-want-anyone-to-assume-i-am-younger", "fields": {"headline": "I turn 50 soon. Why would I want anyone to assume I am younger?", "standfirst": "<p>The obsession with agelessness puts pressure on us to look and act forever young. But it\u2019s far more liberating to be old and cheerfully weary</p>", "trailText": "The obsession with agelessness puts pressure on us to look and act forever young. But it\u2019s far more liberating to be old and cheerfully weary, says Viv Groskop", "byline": "Viv Groskop", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"7952718fda1246e1f3f7a88f20f4e4ea42921e2e\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/7952718fda1246e1f3f7a88f20f4e4ea42921e2e/0_0_6000_4000/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Pedro Pascal\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Pedro Pascal \u2026 touted as a poster boy for late bloomers, but his age is irrelevant.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: John Salangsang/Rex/Shutterstock</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>Who wants to be ageless? Not me. I am old. Hear me creak. To be old and to be able to participate, even if with increasing cynicism and decrepitude, in the unpredictable verb of \u201cageing\u201d is surely a blessing. It is a gift famously more attractive than the perennially unpopular alternative. I will turn 50 this year and I have realised that I couldn\u2019t care less if people think I am 70 or 80, let alone 50. I\u2019m just happy to be around. I don\u2019t need anyone to think I\u2019m not 50, and I certainly don\u2019t need them to believe I\u2019m any younger. What would be the point? If people think you\u2019re younger than you are (or, worse, that you \u201clook good for your age\u201d), there\u2019s a pressure there. It might be manageable this month. But how are you going to maintain that over the next five years? Or 10 years? Let\u2019s be optimistic. Better to act like you\u2019re 90 now. I mean, you might never get there in reality. So channel that age. Get the practice in.</p> <p>The thing is, we are monumentally spoilt, even with the latest alarming news of the UK\u2019s stagnant life expectancy, which is <a href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/3d25b1c9-33bf-448a-bb07-6a0fc3a8a603\">slowly creeping downwards from the upper 80s</a>, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies. Because only 2,000 years ago, it was completely normal to expect to die a horrible death between the age of 20 and 35. Old people were outliers. It was only from around 1800 that average life expectancy in Europe pushed up to 40, and only in the past 200 years that it has moved beyond all previous imagining and we had to invent stupid sayings like \u201cAge is just a number\u201d and \u201c60 is the new 50.\u201d But if it really were just a number, then no one would need to say that it\u2019s just a number. And if it\u2019s all just numbers, then no number needs to be the new version of another number.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>If success is ageless then you can pressure everyone to \u2018keep grinding\u2018 until they drop dead</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>This double-think struck me in <a href=\"https://www.esquire.com/entertainment/tv/a43518988/pedro-pascal-the-last-of-us-interview-2023/\">the current circus surrounding actor Pedro Pascal</a>. I am a fully paid-up member of this circus, dedicated to celebrating and championing the career of my close coeval and imaginary boyfriend Pedro Pascal, break-out star of the hit TV series <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2023/jan/16/the-last-of-us-review-one-of-the-finest-tv-shows-you-will-see-this-year\">The Last of Us </a>and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/the-mandalorian\">The Mandalorian</a>. I will happily tend the elephants in this circus, and I will do so with no requests for remuneration. However, I object to one of the circus\u2019 mantras: that Pedro Pascal\u2019s age is significant. Pascal just turned 48, and somehow this is supposed to give us all hope: that it\u2019s never too late to have a late-blooming acting career as a bounty hunter with paternal instincts, and that somehow success is \u201cageless\u201d. But Pascal is hardly late-blooming. He has been very happily having a busy and successful life in dozens of films and TV shows since his early 20s. It just so happens that the limelight of extreme, obsessive celebrity has fallen on him at this particular moment. It\u2019s not inspiring that he\u2019s old; it\u2019s just a fact and a coincidence. Success and celebrity are not \u201cageless\u201d. They are subjective and fickle.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2023/apr/04/carol-vorderman-60s-renaissance-political-hero\">Carol Vorderman\u2019s later-life renaissance gives us just the kind of political hero we need | Gaby Hinsliff</a> </p> </aside>  <p>The obsession with agelessness is becoming so pervasive that people are now even embracing it before puberty. I recently boggled at <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/reel/Cq8SuZ2gb6r/?igshid=YmMyMTA2M2Y%3D\">a nine-year-old \u201cfashion influencer\u201d</a>, with more than 350,000 followers on Instagram, expressing the view that \u201cfashion has no age\u201d. I mean, who would disagree? But how convenient. If fashion is ageless then you can market to consumers from the moment they exit the womb. If success is ageless then you can pressure everyone to \u201ckeep grinding\u201d until they drop dead. Far more liberating? Just be old and cheerfully weary and do things in the manner of an old, cheerfully weary person. We need to see all kinds of people represented in society, and the way things are going, even with the life expectancy wobble, there are only going to be more of the old and cheerfully weary around.</p> <p>We feel obliged to bang on repeatedly about the fact that ageing doesn\u2019t matter. But, the fact is, if age really had no meaning then: (a) we would not bang on about it not mattering, because when things really don\u2019t matter they don\u2019t get mentioned, and (b) digital algorithms would not repeatedly segment us according to our date of birth. The algorithm knows the truth: we\u2019re not getting any younger.</p> <ul> <li><p>Viv Groskop is a writer, broadcaster and standup comedian</p></li> </ul>", "newspaperPageNumber": "3", "wordcount": "744", "commentCloseDate": "2023-04-17T16:45:00Z", "commentable": "true", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T06:00:32Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-18T08:44:29Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-17T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnvce", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/7952718fda1246e1f3f7a88f20f4e4ea42921e2e/0_52_6000_3600/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Who wants to be ageless? Not me. I am old. Hear me creak. To be old and to be able to participate, even if with increasing cynicism and decrepitude, in the unpredictable verb of \u201cageing\u201d is surely a blessing. It is a gift famously more attractive than the perennially unpopular alternative. I will turn 50 this year and I have realised that I couldn\u2019t care less if people think I am 70 or 80, let alone 50. I\u2019m just happy to be around. I don\u2019t need anyone to think I\u2019m not 50, and I certainly don\u2019t need them to believe I\u2019m any younger. What would be the point? If people think you\u2019re younger than you are (or, worse, that you \u201clook good for your age\u201d), there\u2019s a pressure there. It might be manageable this month. But how are you going to maintain that over the next five years? Or 10 years? Let\u2019s be optimistic. Better to act like you\u2019re 90 now. I mean, you might never get there in reality. So channel that age. Get the practice in. The thing is, we are monumentally spoilt, even with the latest alarming news of the UK\u2019s stagnant life expectancy, which is slowly creeping downwards from the upper 80s, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies. Because only 2,000 years ago, it was completely normal to expect to die a horrible death between the age of 20 and 35. Old people were outliers. It was only from around 1800 that average life expectancy in Europe pushed up to 40, and only in the past 200 years that it has moved beyond all previous imagining and we had to invent stupid sayings like \u201cAge is just a number\u201d and \u201c60 is the new 50.\u201d But if it really were just a number, then no one would need to say that it\u2019s just a number. And if it\u2019s all just numbers, then no number needs to be the new version of another number. This double-think struck me in the current circus surrounding actor Pedro Pascal. I am a fully paid-up member of this circus, dedicated to celebrating and championing the career of my close coeval and imaginary boyfriend Pedro Pascal, break-out star of the hit TV series The Last of Us and The Mandalorian. I will happily tend the elephants in this circus, and I will do so with no requests for remuneration. However, I object to one of the circus\u2019 mantras: that Pedro Pascal\u2019s age is significant. Pascal just turned 48, and somehow this is supposed to give us all hope: that it\u2019s never too late to have a late-blooming acting career as a bounty hunter with paternal instincts, and that somehow success is \u201cageless\u201d. But Pascal is hardly late-blooming. He has been very happily having a busy and successful life in dozens of films and TV shows since his early 20s. It just so happens that the limelight of extreme, obsessive celebrity has fallen on him at this particular moment. It\u2019s not inspiring that he\u2019s old; it\u2019s just a fact and a coincidence. Success and celebrity are not \u201cageless\u201d. They are subjective and fickle. The obsession with agelessness is becoming so pervasive that people are now even embracing it before puberty. I recently boggled at a nine-year-old \u201cfashion influencer\u201d, with more than 350,000 followers on Instagram, expressing the view that \u201cfashion has no age\u201d. I mean, who would disagree? But how convenient. If fashion is ageless then you can market to consumers from the moment they exit the womb. If success is ageless then you can pressure everyone to \u201ckeep grinding\u201d until they drop dead. Far more liberating? Just be old and cheerfully weary and do things in the manner of an old, cheerfully weary person. We need to see all kinds of people represented in society, and the way things are going, even with the life expectancy wobble, there are only going to be more of the old and cheerfully weary around. We feel obliged to bang on repeatedly about the fact that ageing doesn\u2019t matter. But, the fact is, if age really had no meaning then: (a) we would not bang on about it not mattering, because when things really don\u2019t matter they don\u2019t get mentioned, and (b) digital algorithms would not repeatedly segment us according to our date of birth. "bodyHtml": "<p>Who wants to be ageless? Not me. I am old. Hear me creak. To be old and to be able to participate, even if with increasing cynicism and decrepitude, in the unpredictable verb of \u201cageing\u201d is surely a blessing. It is a gift famously more attractive than the perennially unpopular alternative. I will turn 50 this year and I have realised that I couldn\u2019t care less if people think I am 70 or 80, let alone 50. I\u2019m just happy to be around. I don\u2019t need anyone to think I\u2019m not 50, and I certainly don\u2019t need them to believe I\u2019m any younger. What would be the point? If people think you\u2019re younger than you are (or, worse, that you \u201clook good for your age\u201d), there\u2019s a pressure there. It might be manageable this month. But how are you going to maintain that over the next five years? Or 10 years? Let\u2019s be optimistic. Better to act like you\u2019re 90 now. I mean, you might never get there in reality. So channel that age. Get the practice in.</p> <p>The thing is, we are monumentally spoilt, even with the latest alarming news of the UK\u2019s stagnant life expectancy, which is <a href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/3d25b1c9-33bf-448a-bb07-6a0fc3a8a603\">slowly creeping downwards from the upper 80s</a>, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies. Because only 2,000 years ago, it was completely normal to expect to die a horrible death between the age of 20 and 35. Old people were outliers. It was only from around 1800 that average life expectancy in Europe pushed up to 40, and only in the past 200 years that it has moved beyond all previous imagining and we had to invent stupid sayings like \u201cAge is just a number\u201d and \u201c60 is the new 50.\u201d But if it really were just a number, then no one would need to say that it\u2019s just a number. And if it\u2019s all just numbers, then no number needs to be the new version of another number.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>If success is ageless then you can pressure everyone to \u2018keep grinding\u2018 until they drop dead</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>This double-think struck me in <a href=\"https://www.esquire.com/entertainment/tv/a43518988/pedro-pascal-the-last-of-us-interview-2023/\">the current circus surrounding actor Pedro Pascal</a>. I am a fully paid-up member of this circus, dedicated to celebrating and championing the career of my close coeval and imaginary boyfriend Pedro Pascal, break-out star of the hit TV series <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2023/jan/16/the-last-of-us-review-one-of-the-finest-tv-shows-you-will-see-this-year\">The Last of Us </a>and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/the-mandalorian\">The Mandalorian</a>. I will happily tend the elephants in this circus, and I will do so with no requests for remuneration. However, I object to one of the circus\u2019 mantras: that Pedro Pascal\u2019s age is significant. Pascal just turned 48, and somehow this is supposed to give us all hope: that it\u2019s never too late to have a late-blooming acting career as a bounty hunter with paternal instincts, and that somehow success is \u201cageless\u201d. But Pascal is hardly late-blooming. He has been very happily having a busy and successful life in dozens of films and TV shows since his early 20s. It just so happens that the limelight of extreme, obsessive celebrity has fallen on him at this particular moment. It\u2019s not inspiring that he\u2019s old; it\u2019s just a fact and a coincidence. Success and celebrity are not \u201cageless\u201d. They are subjective and fickle.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2023/apr/04/carol-vorderman-60s-renaissance-political-hero\">Carol Vorderman\u2019s later-life renaissance gives us just the kind of political hero we need | Gaby Hinsliff</a> </p> </aside>  <p>The obsession with agelessness is becoming so pervasive that people are now even embracing it before puberty. I recently boggled at <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/reel/Cq8SuZ2gb6r/?igshid=YmMyMTA2M2Y%3D\">a nine-year-old \u201cfashion influencer\u201d</a>, with more than 350,000 followers on Instagram, expressing the view that \u201cfashion has no age\u201d. I mean, who would disagree? But how convenient. If fashion is ageless then you can market to consumers from the moment they exit the womb. If success is ageless then you can pressure everyone to \u201ckeep grinding\u201d until they drop dead. Far more liberating? Just be old and cheerfully weary and do things in the manner of an old, cheerfully weary person. We need to see all kinds of people represented in society, and the way things are going, even with the life expectancy wobble, there are only going to be more of the old and cheerfully weary around.</p> <p>We feel obliged to bang on repeatedly about the fact that ageing doesn\u2019t matter. But, the fact is, if age really had no meaning then: (a) we would not bang on about it not mattering, because when things really don\u2019t matter they don\u2019t get mentioned, and (b) digital algorithms would not repeatedly segment us according to our date of birth. The algorithm knows the truth: we\u2019re not getting any younger.</p> <ul> <li><p>Viv Groskop is a writer, broadcaster and standup comedian</p></li> </ul>", "bodyTextSummary": "Who wants to be ageless? Not me. I am old. Hear me creak. To be old and to be able to participate, even if with increasing cynicism and decrepitude, in the unpredictable verb of \u201cageing\u201d is surely a blessing. It is a gift famously more attractive than the perennially unpopular alternative. I will turn 50 this year and I have realised that I couldn\u2019t care less if people think I am 70 or 80, let alone 50. I\u2019m just happy to be around. I don\u2019t need anyone to think I\u2019m not 50, and I certainly don\u2019t need them to believe I\u2019m any younger. What would be the point? If people think you\u2019re younger than you are (or, worse, that you \u201clook good for your age\u201d), there\u2019s a pressure there. It might be manageable this month. But how are you going to maintain that over the next five years? Or 10 years? Let\u2019s be optimistic. Better to act like you\u2019re 90 now. I mean, you might never get there in reality. So channel that age. Get the practice in. The thing is, we are monumentally spoilt, even with the latest alarming news of the UK\u2019s stagnant life expectancy, which is slowly creeping downwards from the upper 80s, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies. Because only 2,000 years ago, it was completely normal to expect to die a horrible death between the age of 20 and 35. Old people were outliers. It was only from around 1800 that average life expectancy in Europe pushed up to 40, and only in the past 200 years that it has moved beyond all previous imagining and we had to invent stupid sayings like \u201cAge is just a number\u201d and \u201c60 is the new 50.\u201d But if it really were just a number, then no one would need to say that it\u2019s just a number. And if it\u2019s all just numbers, then no number needs to be the new version of another number.\nThis double-think struck me in the current circus surrounding actor Pedro Pascal. I am a fully paid-up member of this circus, dedicated to celebrating and championing the career of my close coeval and imaginary boyfriend Pedro Pascal, break-out star of the hit TV series The Last of Us and The Mandalorian. I will happily tend the elephants in this circus, and I will do so with no requests for remuneration. However, I object to one of the circus\u2019 mantras: that Pedro Pascal\u2019s age is significant. Pascal just turned 48, and somehow this is supposed to give us all hope: that it\u2019s never too late to have a late-blooming acting career as a bounty hunter with paternal instincts, and that somehow success is \u201cageless\u201d. But Pascal is hardly late-blooming. He has been very happily having a busy and successful life in dozens of films and TV shows since his early 20s. It just so happens that the limelight of extreme, obsessive celebrity has fallen on him at this particular moment. It\u2019s not inspiring that he\u2019s old; it\u2019s just a fact and a coincidence. Success and celebrity are not \u201cageless\u201d. They are subjective and fickle.\nThe obsession with agelessness is becoming so pervasive that people are now even embracing it before puberty. I recently boggled at a nine-year-old \u201cfashion influencer\u201d, with more than 350,000 followers on Instagram, expressing the view that \u201cfashion has no age\u201d. I mean, who would disagree? But how convenient. If fashion is ageless then you can market to consumers from the moment they exit the womb. If success is ageless then you can pressure everyone to \u201ckeep grinding\u201d until they drop dead. Far more liberating? Just be old and cheerfully weary and do things in the manner of an old, cheerfully weary person. We need to see all kinds of people represented in society, and the way things are going, even with the life expectancy wobble, there are only going to be more of the old and cheerfully weary around. We feel obliged to bang on repeatedly about the fact that ageing doesn\u2019t matter. But, the fact is, if age really had no meaning then: (a) we would not bang on about it not mattering, because when things really don\u2019t matter they don\u2019t get mentioned, and (b) digital algorithms would not repeatedly segment us according to our date of birth. The algorithm knows the truth: we\u2019re not getting any younger. </figure>", "body": "<p><strong>Q</strong> My partner and I are starting to plan for retirement and we are not sure what options we might have for our home when it comes to the time. The property is currently worth \u00a3330,000 and, all being well, will be owned outright by the time we retire. </p> <p>We have no dependants and won\u2019t have anyone to pass any inheritance on to, and so we would like to release as much cash from our home to use ourselves in retirement while remaining in the property.</p> <p>We\u2019d like to know what options we have to release equity from the property. We\u2019re aware that an equity release mortgage is one option but the values that you seem to be able to release seem very small compared with the overall value of the property. There must be other options out there but we aren\u2019t sure where to start.</p> <p>Our retirement is some way off yet but understanding what options are available and how much equity might be released will affect what other actions we take now in preparation for the future.<br><strong>GE</strong></p> <p><strong>A</strong> As you want to remain in your home, the cheapest way to release equity \u2013 which is to downsize \u2013 is not an option for you. What is an option, as you are aware, is an equity release mortgage \u2013 also known as a lifetime mortgage \u2013 which you can take out once the younger of you reaches the age of 55. As you are not bothered about leaving money to anyone, the fact that the interest charged on the mortgage \u2013 which is typically higher than on a conventional mortgage \u2013 is rolled up and added to the amount you borrowed is not going to be a problem. However, what might be a problem for you is the fact that the most you can typically borrow is 60% of the value of your home.</p> <p>Once you get to the age of 65, the equity release alternative to a lifetime mortgage is a home reversion plan. This is where you sell between 25% and 100% of your home to a home-reversion-plan provider for a cash lump sum, regular income or both while carrying on living there. The major downside to this sort of scheme is that you can expect to be offered between 20% and 60% of your property\u2019s true value. Because you will be getting less than market value for any share you sell a provider, it\u2019s a less attractive option than a lifetime mortgage. Whichever equity release route you go down, the cash you get is tax free but having a large lump sum in the bank will affect any state benefits.</p>", "wordcount": "438", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T06:00:32Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T06:16:29Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nmmp8", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/9a56aa0b09458128d0b72347a8f847723781169e/41_1654_5797_3480/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Q My partner and I are starting to plan for retirement and we are not sure what options we might have for our home when it comes to the time. The property is currently worth \u00a3330,000 and, all being well, will be owned outright by the time we retire. We have no dependants and won\u2019t have anyone to pass any inheritance on to, and so we would like to release as much cash from our home to use ourselves in retirement while remaining in the property. We\u2019d like to know what options we have to release equity from the property. We\u2019re aware that an equity release mortgage is one option but the values that you seem to be able to release seem very small compared with the overall value of the property. There must be other options out there but we aren\u2019t sure where to start. Our retirement is some way off yet but understanding what options are available and how much equity might be released will affect what other actions we take now in preparation for the future. GE A As you want to remain in your home, the cheapest way to release equity \u2013 which is to downsize \u2013 is not an option for you. What is an option, as you are aware, is an equity release mortgage \u2013 also known as a lifetime mortgage \u2013 which you can take out once the younger of you reaches the age of 55. As you are not bothered about leaving money to anyone, the fact that the interest charged on the mortgage \u2013 which is typically higher than on a conventional mortgage \u2013 is rolled up and added to the amount you borrowed is not going to be a problem. However, what might be a problem for you is the fact that the most you can typically borrow is 60% of the value of your home. Once you get to the age of 65, the equity release alternative to a lifetime mortgage is a home reversion plan. This is where you sell between 25% and 100% of your home to a home-reversion-plan provider for a cash lump sum, regular income or both while carrying on living there. The major downside to this sort of scheme is that you can expect to be offered between 20% and 60% of your property\u2019s true value. Because you will be getting less than market value for any share you sell a provider, it\u2019s a less attractive option than a lifetime mortgage. Whichever equity release route you go down, the cash you get is tax free but having a large lump sum in the bank will affect any state benefits.", "charCount": "2333", "shouldHideReaderRevenue": "false", "showAffiliateLinks": "true", "bylineHtml": "<a href=\"profile/virginiawallis\">Virginia Wallis</a>", "showTableOfContents": "false"}, "tags": [{"id": "money/series/expertsproperty", "type": "series", "sectionId": "money", "sectionName": "Money", "webTitle": "Ask the experts: homebuying", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/money/series/expertsproperty", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/money/series/expertsproperty", "references": [], "description": "Muddled about mortgages? "bodyHtml": "<p><strong>Q</strong> My partner and I are starting to plan for retirement and we are not sure what options we might have for our home when it comes to the time. The property is currently worth \u00a3330,000 and, all being well, will be owned outright by the time we retire. </p> <p>We have no dependants and won\u2019t have anyone to pass any inheritance on to, and so we would like to release as much cash from our home to use ourselves in retirement while remaining in the property.</p> <p>We\u2019d like to know what options we have to release equity from the property. We\u2019re aware that an equity release mortgage is one option but the values that you seem to be able to release seem very small compared with the overall value of the property. There must be other options out there but we aren\u2019t sure where to start.</p> <p>Our retirement is some way off yet but understanding what options are available and how much equity might be released will affect what other actions we take now in preparation for the future.<br><strong>GE</strong></p> <p><strong>A</strong> As you want to remain in your home, the cheapest way to release equity \u2013 which is to downsize \u2013 is not an option for you. What is an option, as you are aware, is an equity release mortgage \u2013 also known as a lifetime mortgage \u2013 which you can take out once the younger of you reaches the age of 55. As you are not bothered about leaving money to anyone, the fact that the interest charged on the mortgage \u2013 which is typically higher than on a conventional mortgage \u2013 is rolled up and added to the amount you borrowed is not going to be a problem. However, what might be a problem for you is the fact that the most you can typically borrow is 60% of the value of your home.</p> <p>Once you get to the age of 65, the equity release alternative to a lifetime mortgage is a home reversion plan. This is where you sell between 25% and 100% of your home to a home-reversion-plan provider for a cash lump sum, regular income or both while carrying on living there. The major downside to this sort of scheme is that you can expect to be offered between 20% and 60% of your property\u2019s true value. Because you will be getting less than market value for any share you sell a provider, it\u2019s a less attractive option than a lifetime mortgage. Whichever equity release route you go down, the cash you get is tax free but having a large lump sum in the bank will affect any state benefits.</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "Q My partner and I are starting to plan for retirement and we are not sure what options we might have for our home when it comes to the time. The property is currently worth \u00a3330,000 and, all being well, will be owned outright by the time we retire. There must be other options out there but we aren\u2019t sure where to start. Our retirement is some way off yet but understanding what options are available and how much equity might be released will affect what other actions we take now in preparation for the future. However, what might be a problem for you is the fact that the most you can typically borrow is 60% of the value of your home. {"syndicatable": "true", "subscriptionDatabases": "true", "developerCommunity": "true"}, "section": {"id": "money", "webTitle": "Money", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/money", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/money", "editions": [{"id": "money", "webTitle": "Money", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/money", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/money", "code": "default"}, {"id": "uk/money", "webTitle": "Money", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/uk/money", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/uk/money", "code": "uk"}, {"id": "us/money", "webTitle": "Money", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/us/money", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/us/money", "code": "us"}, {"id": "au/money", "webTitle": "Money", "webUrl": "money/2023/apr/17/how-to-buy-the-right-laptop-best-price-upgrade", "type": "article", "sectionId": "money", "sectionName": "Money", "webPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T06:00:31Z", "webTitle": "How to buy the right laptop for you at the best price", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/money/2023/apr/17/how-to-buy-the-right-laptop-best-price-upgrade", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/money/2023/apr/17/how-to-buy-the-right-laptop-best-price-upgrade", "fields": {"headline": "How to buy the right laptop for you at the best price", "standfirst": "<p>Tech experts on how to work out want you need, set a budget and find the perfect device \u2013 or upgrade an existing one</p>", "trailText": "Tech experts on how to work out want you need, set a budget and find the perfect device \u2013 or upgrade an existing one", "byline": "Sandra Haurant", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"2d835ef04660948d52abd7d438e29a2c4d46125f\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/2d835ef04660948d52abd7d438e29a2c4d46125f/0_0_2560_1536/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Money Hacks Laptop\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Do you want a laptop mainly for general family use, professional use or gaming?</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Illustration: Jose Roda</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<h2><strong>Know what you need</strong></h2> <p>\u201cThe first question we\u2019d ask is: \u2018What are you going to be using it for?\u2019\u201d John Webster, the managing director of Digital Doctors in Brighton, says. \u201cThat is ultimately what guides us in terms of recommending what a person wants to buy.\u201d</p> <p>Webster says there are three main categories \u2013 general family use, professional use and gaming. For a family device, a Chromebook may suffice \u2013 and with models below \u00a3300, these will usually cost less than a Windows laptop. \u201cThe Chromebook is a very distinct environment. Many schools use Google Classroom, and it just locks into that. It\u2019s a straightforward, simplified way of doing things.\u201d</p> <p>For professional use, Webster says, \u201cwe will be steering them towards Windows computers with an Intel-based central processing unit (CPU).\u201d Broadly speaking, an Intel Core i5 CPU is a minimum, with i7 as a better (though more expensive) option, as it gives \u201clongevity and the best value for money\u201d. If the device may be used for gaming, though, Webster says: \u201cLook at laptops that have dedicated graphics cards.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"bdb0d81ba3c091bddd15ca2487c7e1fb621ce4d1\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/bdb0d81ba3c091bddd15ca2487c7e1fb621ce4d1/20_18_2953_1772/1000.jpg\" alt=\"The Google logo is seen alongside a Chromebook laptop at a Currys and PC World store\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">John Webster of Digital Doctors says: \u2018For a family device, a Chromebook may suffice.\u2019</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Bloomberg/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2><strong>Don\u2019t underestimate your needs</strong></h2> <p>Nick Dutch, a director of the Real Computer Shop, based in Sheffield and Matlock, says it can be a mistake to \u201cbuy a really cheap laptop, with an entry-level Intel Celeron processor, 4GB of RAM and a 64GB hard drive. But people buy one thinking they\u2019ll be able to use Spotify or to go on the internet, and it\u2019s just not designed for that. It\u2019s designed for very, very light use.\u201d</p> <p>George Cook, the chief executive of Computers 4 Charity, agrees: \u201cMake sure it\u2019s got enough RAM \u2013 don\u2019t think you can run Windows 10 with 4GB of RAM. You could accept an i3 processor for extremely light use; i5 is middling; i7 and above are really good \u2013 and they will run Windows 11.\u201d</p> <p>To avoid a false economy and a lot of frustration, Dutch recommends looking for models that have Intel i3 or AMD Ryzen 3, a minimum 8GB of RAM, and a 256GB hard drive. And a solid-state drive (SSD) as opposed to a hard disk drive (HDD) will increase the speed \u2013 although it is more costly.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"464e3330c7a7d650051047af84bfb665d3165982\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/464e3330c7a7d650051047af84bfb665d3165982/14_261_1436_1135/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A young couple use a laptop at home\" width=\"1000\" height=\"790\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Does your laptop have enough RAM?</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: PeopleImages/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2><strong>Set a budget</strong></h2> <p>When it comes to buying a new laptop, \u201c\u00a3500-\u00a3600 will get you something that will give you good performance today, and also a bit of headroom so that you\u2019ve got future capability when the next operating system comes out, or as software develops,\u201d Webster says. \u201cWith something suitable for a gamer, you\u2019re looking at about \u00a3700-plus. And about \u00a3300 will get you a real entry-level kind of machine.\u201d</p> <p>As an example, the Real Computer Shop has a starter laptop with Intel i3, 11th gen processor, 8GB of RAM, 256GB solid-state hard drive and 16in screen for \u00a3349.</p> <h2><strong>Keep credit costs low</strong></h2> <p>If you intend to spread the cost of your laptop through credit, make sure you get the lowest interest rate available \u2013 preferably interest-free. At the time of writing, Currys, for example, offered interest-free credit over 24 months on certain products but also had a flexible credit option with a far less attractive 24.9% APR (rising to 29.9% for products bought after the end of April).</p> <h2><strong>Compare and contrast</strong></h2> <p>It goes without saying that before you take the plunge you need to do your research. Read about the models you are interested in: the Guardian <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/technology/laptops+tone/reviews\">regularly publishes reviews</a>, or you can consult laptop best buy guides, such as the one produced by the consumer group Which?.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>One way to save money is to look out for \u2018open box\u2019 items being sold at reduced prices</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>Once you have decided on the model you want to buy, start to compare the price across large high street chains such as Currys and John Lewis as well as online stores and local independents. At this point, consider how important things such as a longer guarantee or IT support in a store are to you.</p> <p>One way to save money is to look out for \u201copen box\u201d items being sold at reduced prices. These products have been returned by a customer, which means the device is now open box, and the manufacturer will sell it on at a discount. Experts say they can be up to 15% cheaper than the brand-new one.</p> <h2><strong>Get set up</strong></h2> <p>You can buy a laptop and set it up yourself but if this feels daunting and you want your new computer to be ready to use as soon as you get home, you can pay extra to have all the necessary elements installed. John Lewis charges \u00a345 for a basic setup \u2013 including two user accounts, activating inbuilt anti-virus software, and a 15-minute demo \u2013 or \u00a380 for an advanced setup, including data transfer from another device and setting up Microsoft Office (which you buy separately). The Real Computer Shop charges \u00a360 for a similar service, including installation of Avast anti-virus, which costs about \u00a340 alone.</p> <h2><strong>Buy refurbished</strong></h2> <p>Independent shops often have reconditioned models for sale, while on eBay\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.ebay.co.uk/b/Refurbished/bn_7117653182\">certified refurbished hub</a>, you can find a range of devices that have been professionally reconditioned. And Back Market, a French company that now operates in countries all over the world, also sells refurbished products that have been checked, cleaned, tested and, where necessary, repaired \u201cby certified professionals\u201d. Back Market says a refurbished tech device can cost up to 70% less than a new model. At the time of writing, a refurbished <a href=\"https://www.backmarket.co.uk/en-gb/p/macbook-pro-2020-13-inch-with-m1-8-core-and-8-core-gpu-8gb-ram-ssd-2tb-qwerty-english-uk/8948b82c-f746-4be0-a8b0-0758b1dc4acc#l=12\">2020 MacBook Pro</a> (8GB, 256GB SSD) in \u201cfair\u201d condition was on the site priced at \u00a3851.49, compared with \u00a31,199 on the <a href=\"https://www.currys.co.uk/products/apple-macbook-pro-13.3-2020-m1-256-gb-ssd-space-grey-10216304.html\">Currys website</a> for an almost identical \u2013 but new \u2013 model.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"b4bbb372ffa612ae8a097b4cfe90ca7a0d8da98d\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/b4bbb372ffa612ae8a097b4cfe90ca7a0d8da98d/556_8_2434_1460/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Ebay logo on a smartphone\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">You can find various devices that have been professionally reconditioned on eBay\u2019s certified refurbished hub.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Mateusz S\u0142odkowski/Sopa Images/Rex/Shutterstock</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>\u201cA lower budget doesn\u2019t have to mean lower quality features or functionality. Refurbished laptops offer up to 40% off compared with new, with great specs,\u201d Mark Monte-Colombo, the head of refurbished at eBay, says. \u201cWhen they\u2019re buying refurbished, shoppers should check to ensure the products are from reputable sellers. On eBay, we have products that have been expertly restored by either the brand themselves, including Apple and Samsung, or qualified sellers, and vetted to work like new.\u201d</p> <p>Check the device is working well as soon as you receive it \u2013 and pay particular attention to things such as the battery health, screen, camera and audio. Back Market offers a one-year warranty, and eBay a one-year seller\u2019s guarantee \u2013 and, Cook says, that\u2019s a minimum requirement. \u201cThere are loads of refurbishers out there who offer one year\u2019s full warranty. You should not accept any less.\u201d</p> <h2><strong>Give something back</strong></h2> <p>Computers 4 Charity has an online charity shop selling refurbished laptops and desktop computers. \u201cBy selling refurbished laptops to people who support our cause, we can give away a proportion of machines free of charge to those who are most desperately in need, including women\u2019s refuges, unemployed veterans and homeless charities,\u201d Cook says.</p> <p>The charity receives used machines from companies that can no longer use them, and these are refurbished in the workshop; then some are sold to individuals or organisations, and others donated to charities.</p> <p>\u201cOne advantage, I think, of buying refurbished over new is that these have been thoroughly tried and tested,\u201d Cook says. \u201cWith new [computers], every manufacturer accepts a percentage of about 3% to 5% that are dead on arrival and just won\u2019t work. With refurbished, we have a 99%-plus works-on-arrival percentage, which is better than new.\u201d</p> <h2><strong>Upgrade your existing laptop</strong></h2> <p>Before you jump into buying a new one, find out if upgrading your existing machine is a viable option. In some cases it\u2019s not, Webster says: \u201cIf it\u2019s running slow and taking a long time to boot up, then the first question is, what CPU do you have? Because that bit can\u2019t be upgraded \u2013 it\u2019s just not economical.\u201d</p> <p>But if it\u2019s the hard drive causing the problem, for example, that might be repairable. \u201cSomeone came in with a laptop I sold five years ago and it had a spinning hard disk, so today we\u2019re putting in a solid-state hard drive. It will make it quicker, more usable, more responsive \u2013 that\u2019s a really good upgrade. If the device may be used for gaming, though, Webster says: \u201cLook at laptops that have dedicated graphics cards.\u201d Don\u2019t underestimate your needs Nick Dutch, a director of the Real Computer Shop, based in Sheffield and Matlock, says it can be a mistake to \u201cbuy a really cheap laptop, with an entry-level Intel Celeron processor, 4GB of RAM and a 64GB hard drive. But people buy one thinking they\u2019ll be able to use Spotify or to go on the internet, and it\u2019s just not designed for that. It\u2019s designed for very, very light use.\u201d George Cook, the chief executive of Computers 4 Charity, agrees: \u201cMake sure it\u2019s got enough RAM \u2013 don\u2019t think you can run Windows 10 with 4GB of RAM. You could accept an i3 processor for extremely light use; i5 is middling; i7 and above are really good \u2013 and they will run Windows 11.\u201d To avoid a false economy and a lot of frustration, Dutch recommends looking for models that have Intel i3 or AMD Ryzen 3, a minimum 8GB of RAM, and a 256GB hard drive. And a solid-state drive (SSD) as opposed to a hard disk drive (HDD) will increase the speed \u2013 although it is more costly. Set a budget When it comes to buying a new laptop, \u201c\u00a3500-\u00a3600 will get you something that will give you good performance today, and also a bit of headroom so that you\u2019ve got future capability when the next operating system comes out, or as software develops,\u201d Webster says. \u201cWith something suitable for a gamer, you\u2019re looking at about \u00a3700-plus. And about \u00a3300 will get you a real entry-level kind of machine.\u201d As an example, the Real Computer Shop has a starter laptop with Intel i3, 11th gen processor, 8GB of RAM, 256GB solid-state hard drive and 16in screen for \u00a3349. Keep credit costs low If you intend to spread the cost of your laptop through credit, make sure you get the lowest interest rate available \u2013 preferably interest-free. At the time of writing, Currys, for example, offered interest-free credit over 24 months on certain products but also had a flexible credit option with a far less attractive 24.9% APR (rising to 29.9% for products bought after the end of April). Compare and contrast It goes without saying that before you take the plunge you need to do your research. Read about the models you are interested in: the Guardian regularly publishes reviews, or you can consult laptop best buy guides, such as the one produced by the consumer group Which?. Once you have decided on the model you want to buy, start to compare the price across large high street chains such as Currys and John Lewis as well as online stores and local independents. At this point, consider how important things such as a longer guarantee or IT support in a store are to you. One way to save money is to look out for \u201copen box\u201d items being sold at reduced prices. These products have been returned by a customer, which means the device is now open box, and the manufacturer will sell it on at a discount. Experts say they can be up to 15% cheaper than the brand-new one. Get set up You can buy a laptop and set it up yourself but if this feels daunting and you want your new computer to be ready to use as soon as you get home, you can pay extra to have all the necessary elements installed. John Lewis charges \u00a345 for a basic setup \u2013 including two user accounts, activating inbuilt anti-virus software, and a 15-minute demo \u2013 or \u00a380 for an advanced setup, including data transfer from another device and setting up Microsoft Office (which you buy separately). The Real Computer Shop charges \u00a360 for a similar service, including installation of Avast anti-virus, which costs about \u00a340 alone. Buy refurbished Independent shops often have reconditioned models for sale, while on eBay\u2019s certified refurbished hub, you can find a range of devices that have been professionally reconditioned. And Back Market, a French company that now operates in countries all over the world, also sells refurbished products that have been checked, cleaned, tested and, where necessary, repaired \u201cby certified professionals\u201d. Back Market says a refurbished tech device can cost up to 70% less than a new model. At the time of writing, a refurbished 2020 MacBook Pro (8GB, 256GB SSD) in \u201cfair\u201d condition was on the site priced at \u00a3851.49, compared with \u00a31,199 on the Currys website for an almost identical \u2013 but new \u2013 model. \u201cA lower budget doesn\u2019t have to mean lower quality features or functionality. Refurbished laptops offer up to 40% off compared with new, with great specs,\u201d Mark Monte-Colombo, the head of refurbished at eBay, says. \u201cWhen they\u2019re buying refurbished, shoppers should check to ensure the products are from reputable sellers. On eBay, we have products that have been expertly restored by either the brand themselves, including Apple and Samsung, or qualified sellers, and vetted to work like new.\u201d Check the device is working well as soon as you receive it \u2013 and pay particular attention to things such as the battery health, screen, camera and audio. Back Market offers a one-year warranty, and eBay a one-year seller\u2019s guarantee \u2013 and, Cook says, that\u2019s a minimum requirement. \u201cThere are loads of refurbishers out there who offer one year\u2019s full warranty. You should not accept any less.\u201d Give something back Computers 4 Charity has an online charity shop selling refurbished laptops and desktop computers. \u201cBy selling refurbished laptops to people who support our cause, we can give away a proportion of machines free of charge to those who are most desperately in need, including women\u2019s refuges, unemployed veterans and homeless charities,\u201d Cook says. The charity receives used machines from companies that can no longer use them, and these are refurbished in the workshop; then some are sold to individuals or organisations, and others donated to charities. \u201cOne advantage, I think, of buying refurbished over new is that these have been thoroughly tried and tested,\u201d Cook says. \u201cWith new [computers], every manufacturer accepts a percentage of about 3% to 5% that are dead on arrival and just won\u2019t work.
