At the time of writing, a refurbished <a href=\"https://www.backmarket.co.uk/en-gb/p/macbook-pro-2020-13-inch-with-m1-8-core-and-8-core-gpu-8gb-ram-ssd-2tb-qwerty-english-uk/8948b82c-f746-4be0-a8b0-0758b1dc4acc#l=12\">2020 MacBook Pro</a> (8GB, 256GB SSD) in \u201cfair\u201d condition was on the site priced at \u00a3851.49, compared with \u00a31,199 on the <a href=\"https://www.currys.co.uk/products/apple-macbook-pro-13.3-2020-m1-256-gb-ssd-space-grey-10216304.html\">Currys website</a> for an almost identical \u2013 but new \u2013 model.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"b4bbb372ffa612ae8a097b4cfe90ca7a0d8da98d\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/b4bbb372ffa612ae8a097b4cfe90ca7a0d8da98d/556_8_2434_1460/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Ebay logo on a smartphone\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">You can find various devices that have been professionally reconditioned on eBay\u2019s certified refurbished hub.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Mateusz S\u0142odkowski/Sopa Images/Rex/Shutterstock</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>\u201cA lower budget doesn\u2019t have to mean lower quality features or functionality. Refurbished laptops offer up to 40% off compared with new, with great specs,\u201d Mark Monte-Colombo, the head of refurbished at eBay, says. \u201cWhen they\u2019re buying refurbished, shoppers should check to ensure the products are from reputable sellers. On eBay, we have products that have been expertly restored by either the brand themselves, including Apple and Samsung, or qualified sellers, and vetted to work like new.\u201d</p> <p>Check the device is working well as soon as you receive it \u2013 and pay particular attention to things such as the battery health, screen, camera and audio. Back Market offers a one-year warranty, and eBay a one-year seller\u2019s guarantee \u2013 and, Cook says, that\u2019s a minimum requirement. \u201cThere are loads of refurbishers out there who offer one year\u2019s full warranty. You should not accept any less.\u201d</p> <h2><strong>Give something back</strong></h2> <p>Computers 4 Charity has an online charity shop selling refurbished laptops and desktop computers. \u201cBy selling refurbished laptops to people who support our cause, we can give away a proportion of machines free of charge to those who are most desperately in need, including women\u2019s refuges, unemployed veterans and homeless charities,\u201d Cook says.</p> <p>The charity receives used machines from companies that can no longer use them, and these are refurbished in the workshop; then some are sold to individuals or organisations, and others donated to charities.</p> <p>\u201cOne advantage, I think, of buying refurbished over new is that these have been thoroughly tried and tested,\u201d Cook says. \u201cWith new [computers], every manufacturer accepts a percentage of about 3% to 5% that are dead on arrival and just won\u2019t work. With refurbished, we have a 99%-plus works-on-arrival percentage, which is better than new.\u201d</p> <h2><strong>Upgrade your existing laptop</strong></h2> <p>Before you jump into buying a new one, find out if upgrading your existing machine is a viable option. In some cases it\u2019s not, Webster says: \u201cIf it\u2019s running slow and taking a long time to boot up, then the first question is, what CPU do you have? Because that bit can\u2019t be upgraded \u2013 it\u2019s just not economical.\u201d</p> <p>But if it\u2019s the hard drive causing the problem, for example, that might be repairable. \u201cSomeone came in with a laptop I sold five years ago and it had a spinning hard disk, so today we\u2019re putting in a solid-state hard drive. It will make it quicker, more usable, more responsive \u2013 that\u2019s a really good upgrade. And that starts at about \u00a399,\u201d Dutch says. \u201cAnd if someone has cracked a screen, you can replace it from about \u00a3109.\u201d</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "Know what you need \u201cThe first question we\u2019d ask is: \u2018What are you going to be using it for?\u2019\u201d John Webster, the managing director of Digital Doctors in Brighton, says. \u201cThat is ultimately what guides us in terms of recommending what a person wants to buy.\u201d Webster says there are three main categories \u2013 general family use, professional use and gaming. For a family device, a Chromebook may suffice \u2013 and with models below \u00a3300, these will usually cost less than a Windows laptop. \u201cThe Chromebook is a very distinct environment. Many schools use Google Classroom, and it just locks into that. It\u2019s a straightforward, simplified way of doing things.\u201d For professional use, Webster says, \u201cwe will be steering them towards Windows computers with an Intel-based central processing unit (CPU).\u201d Broadly speaking, an Intel Core i5 CPU is a minimum, with i7 as a better (though more expensive) option, as it gives \u201clongevity and the best value for money\u201d. If the device may be used for gaming, though, Webster says: \u201cLook at laptops that have dedicated graphics cards.\u201d\nDon\u2019t underestimate your needs Nick Dutch, a director of the Real Computer Shop, based in Sheffield and Matlock, says it can be a mistake to \u201cbuy a really cheap laptop, with an entry-level Intel Celeron processor, 4GB of RAM and a 64GB hard drive. But people buy one thinking they\u2019ll be able to use Spotify or to go on the internet, and it\u2019s just not designed for that. It\u2019s designed for very, very light use.\u201d George Cook, the chief executive of Computers 4 Charity, agrees: \u201cMake sure it\u2019s got enough RAM \u2013 don\u2019t think you can run Windows 10 with 4GB of RAM. You could accept an i3 processor for extremely light use; i5 is middling; i7 and above are really good \u2013 and they will run Windows 11.\u201d To avoid a false economy and a lot of frustration, Dutch recommends looking for models that have Intel i3 or AMD Ryzen 3, a minimum 8GB of RAM, and a 256GB hard drive. And a solid-state drive (SSD) as opposed to a hard disk drive (HDD) will increase the speed \u2013 although it is more costly.\nSet a budget When it comes to buying a new laptop, \u201c\u00a3500-\u00a3600 will get you something that will give you good performance today, and also a bit of headroom so that you\u2019ve got future capability when the next operating system comes out, or as software develops,\u201d Webster says. \u201cWith something suitable for a gamer, you\u2019re looking at about \u00a3700-plus. And about \u00a3300 will get you a real entry-level kind of machine.\u201d As an example, the Real Computer Shop has a starter laptop with Intel i3, 11th gen processor, 8GB of RAM, 256GB solid-state hard drive and 16in screen for \u00a3349. Keep credit costs low If you intend to spread the cost of your laptop through credit, make sure you get the lowest interest rate available \u2013 preferably interest-free. At the time of writing, Currys, for example, offered interest-free credit over 24 months on certain products but also had a flexible credit option with a far less attractive 24.9% APR (rising to 29.9% for products bought after the end of April). Compare and contrast It goes without saying that before you take the plunge you need to do your research. Read about the models you are interested in: the Guardian regularly publishes reviews, or you can consult laptop best buy guides, such as the one produced by the consumer group Which?.\nOnce you have decided on the model you want to buy, start to compare the price across large high street chains such as Currys and John Lewis as well as online stores and local independents. At this point, consider how important things such as a longer guarantee or IT support in a store are to you. One way to save money is to look out for \u201copen box\u201d items being sold at reduced prices. These products have been returned by a customer, which means the device is now open box, and the manufacturer will sell it on at a discount. Experts say they can be up to 15% cheaper than the brand-new one. Get set up You can buy a laptop and set it up yourself but if this feels daunting and you want your new computer to be ready to use as soon as you get home, you can pay extra to have all the necessary elements installed. John Lewis charges \u00a345 for a basic setup \u2013 including two user accounts, activating inbuilt anti-virus software, and a 15-minute demo \u2013 or \u00a380 for an advanced setup, including data transfer from another device and setting up Microsoft Office (which you buy separately). The Real Computer Shop charges \u00a360 for a similar service, including installation of Avast anti-virus, which costs about \u00a340 alone. Buy refurbished Independent shops often have reconditioned models for sale, while on eBay\u2019s certified refurbished hub, you can find a range of devices that have been professionally reconditioned. And Back Market, a French company that now operates in countries all over the world, also sells refurbished products that have been checked, cleaned, tested and, where necessary, repaired \u201cby certified professionals\u201d. Back Market says a refurbished tech device can cost up to 70% less than a new model. At the time of writing, a refurbished 2020 MacBook Pro (8GB, 256GB SSD) in \u201cfair\u201d condition was on the site priced at \u00a3851.49, compared with \u00a31,199 on the Currys website for an almost identical \u2013 but new \u2013 model.\n\u201cA lower budget doesn\u2019t have to mean lower quality features or functionality. On eBay, we have products that have been expertly restored by either the brand themselves, including Apple and Samsung, or qualified sellers, and vetted to work like new.\u201d Check the device is working well as soon as you receive it \u2013 and pay particular attention to things such as the battery health, screen, camera and audio. Back Market offers a one-year warranty, and eBay a one-year seller\u2019s guarantee \u2013 and, Cook says, that\u2019s a minimum requirement. \u201cThere are loads of refurbishers out there who offer one year\u2019s full warranty. In some cases it\u2019s not, Webster says: \u201cIf it\u2019s running slow and taking a long time to boot up, then the first question is, what CPU do you have? Because that bit can\u2019t be upgraded \u2013 it\u2019s just not economical.\u201d</p> \n<p>But if it\u2019s the hard drive causing the problem, for example, that might be repairable. \u201cSomeone came in with a laptop I sold five years ago and it had a spinning hard disk, so today we\u2019re putting in a solid-state hard drive. It will make it quicker, more usable, more responsive \u2013 that\u2019s a really good upgrade. And that starts at about \u00a399,\u201d Dutch says. \u201cAnd if someone has cracked a screen, you can replace it from about \u00a3109.\u201d</p>"}}]}], "totalBodyBlocks": 1}, "rights": data-media-id=\"5e1129b33f8038a7d1dac07793a38d07ebaeaed5\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/5e1129b33f8038a7d1dac07793a38d07ebaeaed5/118_418_5206_3124/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Philips Hue Go table lamp\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The Philips Hue Go has a colour-changing bulb that looks great on a side table or for alfresco dining.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Samuel Gibbs/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>The latest Philips Hue Go smart light aims to be a great indoor table lamp that you can just pick up and head out into the garden with for impromptu illumination wherever you need it.</p> <p>It costs \u00a3140 ($160), which makes it fairly expensive for a rechargeable lamp, although in line with fancier designs. It joins the smaller, dish-shaped \u00a380 Hue Go in the company\u2019s portable lineup.</p> <p>What sets the Go table lamp apart is its integration with the rest of the Hue smart light system, behaving like a small regular table lamp until you pick it up from its charging base. It has a minimalist aesthetic, made of metal with a reassuring heft. It has a removable rubber grip on the shaft and is splash-resistant in case it rains.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"e121f121f6a3c07bd133911d3a421eed7becc414\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/e121f121f6a3c07bd133911d3a421eed7becc414/0_0_6531_3632/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Button and base\" width=\"1000\" height=\"556\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A rubber button (left) on the top turns the lamp on and off and cycles through various pre-set colours and scenes, such as a flickering candle or fire effect. The charging base is pictured on the right.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Samuel Gibbs/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The lamp has a colour-changing LED that shines downwards from the solid shade, providing a nice ambient or accent light. It shines at 370 lumens when turned on, which is the equivalent of a 4W LED or 25W tungsten bulb, but hits 530 lumens (6W LED, 35W tungsten) at its brightest setting. That\u2019s enough to illuminate a small table, making it ideal for alfresco dining.</p> <p>Full controls including brightness and a spectrum of colours are available through the Hue Android or iPhone app. The lamp can be used on its own, controlled via Bluetooth from the phone. But it is best when connected to the <a href=\"https://www.philips-hue.com/en-gb/p/hue-bridge/8719514342583\">Hue Bridge</a> and grouped with other smart lights for various fancy features such as schedules and automations, party modes and voice control via smart speakers.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"19e3c078eeae2d6211e0948db80f0207162e11c6\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/19e3c078eeae2d6211e0948db80f0207162e11c6/87_0_5042_3025/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Hue app on iPhone next to table lamp\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The Hue app has a range of scenes, colours and brightnesses to choose from.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Samuel Gibbs/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2>Specifications</h2> <ul> <li><p><strong>Dimensions</strong> 35 x 14.2cm</p></li> <li><p><strong>Weight</strong> 973g</p></li> <li><p><strong>Water resistance</strong> IP54 (splash)</p></li> <li><p><strong>Connectivity</strong> Hue bridge and Bluetooth</p></li> <li><p><strong>Max brightness</strong> 530 lumens</p></li> <li><p><strong>Battery life</strong> 5-48 hours, depending on brightness</p></li> </ul> <p>When used on its little circular power base, the lamp draws electricity straight from the mains, bypassing the battery to avoid it wearing out. Pick the lamp up and it switches to battery power, lasting up to 48 hours at its dimmest setting or about five at its brightest. That\u2019s long enough for most outdoor evenings in the summer, but it isn\u2019t the kind of lamp you\u2019d take on a camping trip. I put it in the middle of the table for a dinner party in winter, synched it to Spotify for some music-linked lighting effects, and used it to light a night of cards, all of which worked very well.</p> <p>The one thing you can\u2019t do is see how long is left on the battery, which seems like an oversight. A full charge of the battery takes about four hours.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"04d96481ec38acb39598bf7c5a544c7564ac4bec\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/04d96481ec38acb39598bf7c5a544c7564ac4bec/0_0_4000_2400/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A composite image showing various different colours of light from the Hue Go table lamp.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The lamp will produce light of almost any colour and can cycle through them with presses of its top button.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Samuel Gibbs/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2>Sustainability</h2> <p>Philips Hue\u2019s parent company, Signify, rates the battery in the lamp for at least 800 full charge cycles, with at least 80% of its original capacity and the bulb for at least 20,000 hours or at least five years of typical use. The battery can be removed, but replacement options are not yet available. When used on the base, the lamp is lit directly from the mains, bypassing the battery and prolonging its life.</p> <p>The company commits to a minimum of five years of <a href=\"https://www.philips-hue.com/en-gb/support/legal/end-of-support-policy\">software support</a>, but has a track record of much longer. Signify publishes annual sustainability <a href=\"https://www.signify.com/global/sustainability/annual-report\">reports</a>.</p> <h2>Price</h2> <p>The Philips Hue Go portable table lamp costs <a href=\"https://www.philips-hue.com/en-gb/p/hue-white-and-colour-ambiance-hue-go-portable-table-lamp/8719514404571\">\u00a3139.99</a> (<a href=\"https://www.philips-hue.com/en-us/p/hue-white-and-color-ambiance-hue-go-portable-table-lamp/046677576455\">$159.99</a>) and is available in black or white with different-coloured grips.</p> <p>For comparison, the Philips Hue Go 2 costs <a href=\"https://www.philips-hue.com/en-gb/p/hue-white-and-colour-ambiance-go-portable-light--latest-model-/7602031PU\">\u00a379.99</a>, rechargeable camping lights of a similar brightness start about \u00a340, and rechargeable table lamps typically cost from \u00a380.</p> <h2>Verdict</h2> <p>The Philips Hue Go portable table lamp is a good example of a dual-use product: one that works equally well indoors and out, potentially replacing two devices with a multi-purpose one.</p> <p>It is a good small indoor table lamp, ideal for mood lighting when used on its base. It is very handy to be able to pick it up and add impromptu light to a table or carry it outdoors for summer evenings.</p> <p>It feels well made, but its minimalist design might not fit with everyone\u2019s decor, and the inability to tell how much charge is left in the battery is irritating. It could do with more onboard controls, too. Its integration with the Hue smart light system and all its trappings is the killer feature, for which privilege you are paying roughly \u00a340 extra. If you\u2019ve ever wanted to take a fancy smart light outdoors, this is it. There isn\u2019t anything else quite like it.</p> <p>But if you are not already a Hue user, it is an expensive colour-changing lamp and far less appealing.</p> <blockquote> <p><strong>Pros</strong> Dual-use indoor/outdoor product, multicolour, integration with full Hue smart system, control via Hue app, smart design saves battery when docked, splash-resistant.</p> <p><strong>Cons</strong> Expensive, battery life could be longer at brightest settings, can\u2019t check battery life in app, top button can\u2019t dim light or be customised.</p> </blockquote>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"d6018e5e563fbbbba9b47b363f2fb6e0cd47521c\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/d6018e5e563fbbbba9b47b363f2fb6e0cd47521c/54_255_5315_3188/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Table lamp light shade\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The bottom of the shade is a solid plate through which the LED gives a nice diffuse glow.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Samuel Gibbs/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "starRating": "4", "wordcount": "798", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T06:00:31Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T06:16:29Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nmmg9", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/5e1129b33f8038a7d1dac07793a38d07ebaeaed5/118_418_5206_3124/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "The latest Philips Hue Go smart light aims to be a great indoor table lamp that you can just pick up and head out into the garden with for impromptu illumination wherever you need it. That\u2019s enough to illuminate a small table, making it ideal for alfresco dining.</p> <p>Full controls including brightness and a spectrum of colours are available through the Hue Android or iPhone app. The lamp can be used on its own, controlled via Bluetooth from the phone. But it is best when connected to the <a href=\"https://www.philips-hue.com/en-gb/p/hue-bridge/8719514342583\">Hue Bridge</a> and grouped with other smart lights for various fancy features such as schedules and automations, party modes and voice control via smart speakers.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"19e3c078eeae2d6211e0948db80f0207162e11c6\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/19e3c078eeae2d6211e0948db80f0207162e11c6/87_0_5042_3025/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Hue app on iPhone next to table lamp\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The Hue app has a range of scenes, colours and brightnesses to choose from.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Samuel Gibbs/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2>Specifications</h2> <ul> <li><p><strong>Dimensions</strong> 35 x 14.2cm</p></li> <li><p><strong>Weight</strong> 973g</p></li> <li><p><strong>Water resistance</strong> IP54 (splash)</p></li> <li><p><strong>Connectivity</strong> Hue bridge and Bluetooth</p></li> <li><p><strong>Max brightness</strong> 530 lumens</p></li> <li><p><strong>Battery life</strong> 5-48 hours, depending on brightness</p></li> </ul> <p>When used on its little circular power base, the lamp draws electricity straight from the mains, bypassing the battery to avoid it wearing out. Pick the lamp up and it switches to battery power, lasting up to 48 hours at its dimmest setting or about five at its brightest. That\u2019s long enough for most outdoor evenings in the summer, but it isn\u2019t the kind of lamp you\u2019d take on a camping trip. I put it in the middle of the table for a dinner party in winter, synched it to Spotify for some music-linked lighting effects, and used it to light a night of cards, all of which worked very well.</p> <p>The one thing you can\u2019t do is see how long is left on the battery, which seems like an oversight. A full charge of the battery takes about four hours.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"04d96481ec38acb39598bf7c5a544c7564ac4bec\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/04d96481ec38acb39598bf7c5a544c7564ac4bec/0_0_4000_2400/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A composite image showing various different colours of light from the Hue Go table lamp.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The lamp will produce light of almost any colour and can cycle through them with presses of its top button.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Samuel Gibbs/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2>Sustainability</h2> <p>Philips Hue\u2019s parent company, Signify, rates the battery in the lamp for at least 800 full charge cycles, with at least 80% of its original capacity and the bulb for at least 20,000 hours or at least five years of typical use. The battery can be removed, but replacement options are not yet available. When used on the base, the lamp is lit directly from the mains, bypassing the battery and prolonging its life.</p> <p>The company commits to a minimum of five years of <a href=\"https://www.philips-hue.com/en-gb/support/legal/end-of-support-policy\">software support</a>, but has a track record of much longer. Signify publishes annual sustainability <a href=\"https://www.signify.com/global/sustainability/annual-report\">reports</a>.</p> <h2>Price</h2> <p>The Philips Hue Go portable table lamp costs <a href=\"https://www.philips-hue.com/en-gb/p/hue-white-and-colour-ambiance-hue-go-portable-table-lamp/8719514404571\">\u00a3139.99</a> (<a href=\"https://www.philips-hue.com/en-us/p/hue-white-and-color-ambiance-hue-go-portable-table-lamp/046677576455\">$159.99</a>) and is available in black or white with different-coloured grips.</p> <p>For comparison, the Philips Hue Go 2 costs <a href=\"https://www.philips-hue.com/en-gb/p/hue-white-and-colour-ambiance-go-portable-light--latest-model-/7602031PU\">\u00a379.99</a>, rechargeable camping lights of a similar brightness start about \u00a340, and rechargeable table lamps typically cost from \u00a380.</p> <h2>Verdict</h2> <p>The Philips Hue Go portable table lamp is a good example of a dual-use product: one that works equally well indoors and out, potentially replacing two devices with a multi-purpose one.</p> <p>It is a good small indoor table lamp, ideal for mood lighting when used on its base. It is very handy to be able to pick it up and add impromptu light to a table or carry it outdoors for summer evenings.</p> <p>It feels well made, but its minimalist design might not fit with everyone\u2019s decor, and the inability to tell how much charge is left in the battery is irritating. It could do with more onboard controls, too. Its integration with the Hue smart light system and all its trappings is the killer feature, for which privilege you are paying roughly \u00a340 extra. If you\u2019ve ever wanted to take a fancy smart light outdoors, this is it. There isn\u2019t anything else quite like it.</p> <p>But if you are not already a Hue user, it is an expensive colour-changing lamp and far less appealing.</p> <blockquote> <p><strong>Pros</strong> Dual-use indoor/outdoor product, multicolour, integration with full Hue smart system, control via Hue app, smart design saves battery when docked, splash-resistant.</p> <p><strong>Cons</strong> Expensive, battery life could be longer at brightest settings, can\u2019t check battery life in app, top button can\u2019t dim light or be customised.</p> </blockquote>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"d6018e5e563fbbbba9b47b363f2fb6e0cd47521c\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/d6018e5e563fbbbba9b47b363f2fb6e0cd47521c/54_255_5315_3188/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Table lamp light shade\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The bottom of the shade is a solid plate through which the LED gives a nice diffuse glow.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Samuel Gibbs/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "bodyTextSummary": "The latest Philips Hue Go smart light aims to be a great indoor table lamp that you can just pick up and head out into the garden with for impromptu illumination wherever you need it. It joins the smaller, dish-shaped \u00a380 Hue Go in the company\u2019s portable lineup. data-atom-id=\"bd44c173-e4e4-45f5-9d97-329d7ac1c46d\" data-atom-type=\"media\"> \n  <div>\n   <iframe frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" src=\"https://www.youtube-nocookie.com/embed/Z3OAZQiJwns?showinfo=0&amp;rel=0\"></iframe>\n  </div>\n </gu-atom> \n</figure>", "body": "<p>At least four people were killed, including a high school football player, in a shooting that erupted during a birthday party held inside a dance studio in the small town of Dadeville, Alabama, state police and local news media said.</p> \n<p>More than 28 people were injured, some critically, during the shooting about 60 miles (100km) north-east of the state capital of Montgomery, authorities said. The shooting started shortly after 10.30pm on Saturday.</p> \n<p>Law enforcement officers did not immediately say if a suspect was in custody or if investigators knew about any motivation. The police called for people to come forward with information.</p> \n<p>\u201cWe\u2019re going to continue to work in a very methodical way to go through this scene, to look at the facts, and ensure that justice is brought to bear for the families,\u201d said Jeremy Burkett, a sergeant with the Alabama law enforcement agency, during a news conference on Sunday.</p> \n<p>\u201cWe\u2019ve got to have information from the community,\u201d Burkett said during a Sunday evening news conference.</p> \n<p>President Joe Biden said in a statement on Sunday: \u201cWhat has our nation come to when children cannot attend a birthday party without fear?\u201d Biden called the rising gun violence in the US \u201coutrageous and unacceptable\u201d, and urged Congress to pass laws that would make firearms manufacturers more liable for gun violence, ban assault weapons and high-capacity ammunition magazines, and require safe storage of firearms and background checks for gun sales.</p> \n<p>Philstavious \u201cPhil\u201d Dowdell, a Dadeville high school senior who had signed with Jacksonville State University, was celebrating at his sister Alexis\u2019s party before he was fatally shot, his grandmother Annette Allen told the <a href=\"https://www.montgomeryadvertiser.com/story/news/crime/2023/04/16/gunman-opens-fire-at-teens-birthday-party-in-dadeville/70119091007/\">Montgomery Advertiser</a>.</p> \n<p>\u201cHe was a very, very humble child. Never messed with anybody. Always had a smile on his face,\u201d Allen told the newspaper, calling it \u201ca million-dollar smile\u201d.</p> \n<p>Dowdell\u2019s mother was among those hurt in the shooting. \u201cEverybody\u2019s grieving,\u201d Allen said.</p> \n<p>Pastor Ben Hayes, who serves as the chaplain for the Dadeville police department and for the local high school football team, said most of the victims were teenagers. Dowdell was within weeks of graduation and faced a bright future, Hayes told the Associated Press.</p> \n<p>\u201cHe was a strong competitor on the field,\u201d Hayes said. \u201cYou didn\u2019t want to try to tackle him or get tackled by him. But when he came off the field, he was one of the nicest young men that you could ever meet, very respectful and well respected by his peers.\u201d</p> \n<p>Hayes said worried families swarmed the local hospital on Saturday night trying to find the condition of their children. He said serious crime was rare in Dadeville, and the small city was \u201csad, traumatized, in shock\u201d.</p> \n<p>This is at least the second time in recent years that multiple people were shot in Dadeville. Five people were wounded in July 2016 during a shooting at an American Legion hall, and a man was later charged with five counts of attempted murder, news outlets reported.</p> \n<p>Investigators believed an altercation led to the shooting at the Mahogany Masterpiece studio, WRBL reported.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"dc3ddf1143e4f48653c23c770f735a8b4382082f\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/dc3ddf1143e4f48653c23c770f735a8b4382082f/0_0_6000_4000/1000.jpg\" alt=\"At least four people were killed in a shooting at a dance studio in Dadeville, Alabama.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">At least four people were killed in a shooting at a dance studio in Dadeville, Alabama.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Cheney Orr/Reuters</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>Jonathan Floyd, chief of the Dadeville police, said at a news conference: \u201cWhat we\u2019ve dealt with is something that no community should have to endure. I just ask for your patience. It\u2019s going to be a long process, but I do earnestly solicit your prayers.\u201d</p> \n<p>More than 12 hours after the shooting, investigators continued filing in and out of the Mahogany Masterpiece dance studio on Sunday.</p> \n<p>City and county officials milled about the Tallapoosa county courthouse less than a block away, where officials lowered the American and Alabama flags to half-staff.</p> \n<p>\u201cThis morning, I grieve with the people of Dadeville and my fellow Alabamians,\u201d Kay Ivey, the governor of Alabama, said <a href=\"https://twitter.com/GovernorKayIvey/status/1647590312871591940\">on Twitter</a>.</p> \n<p>\u201cViolent crime has NO place in our state, and we are staying closely updated by law enforcement as details emerge.\u201d</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/politics-alabama-law-enforcement-e1319c637d42c070eea7b416098e7854\">In 2022</a> Ivey signed a bill into law that ended the requirement for a person to obtain a permit to legally carry a concealed handgun in public. The National Rifle Association (NRA) had lobbied for it.</p> \n<p>In <a href=\"https://twitter.com/kayiveyforgov/status/1525192250636087302?lang=en\">an ad</a> for her re-election campaign last year, Ivey was shown withdrawing a handgun from her purse as she touted her gun-friendly approach, describing the second amendment as \u201csacred\u201d.</p> \n<p>Alabama has the third-highest rate of gun deaths in the US, according to a <a href=\"https://maps.everytownresearch.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Every-State-Fact-Sheet-2.0-042720-Alabama.pdf\">2020 report</a> by Everytown, an organization that works to improve gun safety and end gun violence.</p> \n<p>Biden asked what was wrong \u201cwhen parents have to worry every time their kids walk out the door to school, to the movie theater, or to the park? Guns are the leading killer of children in America, and the numbers are rising \u2013 not declining. This is outrageous and unacceptable.\u201d</p> \n<p>Biden called on Congress to \u201crequire safe storage of firearms, require background checks for all gun sales, eliminate gun manufacturers\u2019 immunity from liability, and ban assault weapons and high-capacity magazines\u201d.</p> \n<p>The latest shooting comes as two people were killed in a shooting in Louisville, Kentucky, on Saturday night, days after a gunman <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/apr/11/louisville-shooting-assault-style-rifle\">shot and killed</a> five people in the city. Associated Press <a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/louisville-fatal-park-crowd-shooting-3bc5936845a3b87094a213effa593003\">reported</a> that an unidentified suspect fired a gun into a crowd of hundreds in Chickasaw Park in Louisville, killing two people and wounding four others.</p> \n<p>On Monday five people were killed when a man opened fire with an assault-style rifle at the Louisville bank where he worked. Eight others were wounded.</p> \n<p>\u201cThis has been an unspeakable week of tragedy for our city,\u201d Louisville mayor Craig Greenberg on Saturday night. \u201cOn Monday, we lost five of our fellow citizens to a horrific act of workplace gun violence,\u201d Greenberg said. \u201cAnd now, five days later, we\u2019re at another scene of a reckless act of gun violence.\u201d</p>", "newspaperPageNumber": "20", "wordcount": "950", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-16T14:01:00Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T05:49:35Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-17T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "US", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnbjc", "shouldHideAdverts": "true", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/d5552141c55ed20450f44d428477d3d8360dace9/0_112_6000_3600/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "At least four people were killed, including a high school football player, in a shooting that erupted during a birthday party held inside a dance studio in the small town of Dadeville, Alabama, state police and local news media said. More than 28 people were injured, some critically, during the shooting about 60 miles (100km) north-east of the state capital of Montgomery, authorities said. The shooting started shortly after 10.30pm on Saturday. Law enforcement officers did not immediately say if a suspect was in custody or if investigators knew about any motivation. The police called for people to come forward with information. \u201cWe\u2019re going to continue to work in a very methodical way to go through this scene, to look at the facts, and ensure that justice is brought to bear for the families,\u201d said Jeremy Burkett, a sergeant with the Alabama law enforcement agency, during a news conference on Sunday. \u201cWe\u2019ve got to have information from the community,\u201d Burkett said during a Sunday evening news conference. President Joe Biden said in a statement on Sunday: \u201cWhat has our nation come to when children cannot attend a birthday party without fear?\u201d Biden called the rising gun violence in the US \u201coutrageous and unacceptable\u201d, and urged Congress to pass laws that would make firearms manufacturers more liable for gun violence, ban assault weapons and high-capacity ammunition magazines, and require safe storage of firearms and background checks for gun sales. Philstavious \u201cPhil\u201d Dowdell, a Dadeville high school senior who had signed with Jacksonville State University, was celebrating at his sister Alexis\u2019s party before he was fatally shot, his grandmother Annette Allen told the Montgomery Advertiser. \u201cHe was a very, very humble child. Never messed with anybody. Always had a smile on his face,\u201d Allen told the newspaper, calling it \u201ca million-dollar smile\u201d. Dowdell\u2019s mother was among those hurt in the shooting. \u201cEverybody\u2019s grieving,\u201d Allen said. Pastor Ben Hayes, who serves as the chaplain for the Dadeville police department and for the local high school football team, said most of the victims were teenagers. Dowdell was within weeks of graduation and faced a bright future, Hayes told the Associated Press. \u201cHe was a strong competitor on the field,\u201d Hayes said. \u201cYou didn\u2019t want to try to tackle him or get tackled by him. But when he came off the field, he was one of the nicest young men that you could ever meet, very respectful and well respected by his peers.\u201d Hayes said worried families swarmed the local hospital on Saturday night trying to find the condition of their children. He said serious crime was rare in Dadeville, and the small city was \u201csad, traumatized, in shock\u201d. This is at least the second time in recent years that multiple people were shot in Dadeville. Five people were wounded in July 2016 during a shooting at an American Legion hall, and a man was later charged with five counts of attempted murder, news outlets reported. Investigators believed an altercation led to the shooting at the Mahogany Masterpiece studio, WRBL reported. Jonathan Floyd, chief of the Dadeville police, said at a news conference: \u201cWhat we\u2019ve dealt with is something that no community should have to endure. I just ask for your patience. It\u2019s going to be a long process, but I do earnestly solicit your prayers.\u201d More than 12 hours after the shooting, investigators continued filing in and out of the Mahogany Masterpiece dance studio on Sunday. City and county officials milled about the Tallapoosa county courthouse less than a block away, where officials lowered the American and Alabama flags to half-staff. \u201cThis morning, I grieve with the people of Dadeville and my fellow Alabamians,\u201d Kay Ivey, the governor of Alabama, said on Twitter. \u201cViolent crime has NO place in our state, and we are staying closely updated by law enforcement as details emerge.\u201d In 2022 Ivey signed a bill into law that ended the requirement for a person to obtain a permit to legally carry a concealed handgun in public. The National Rifle Association (NRA) had lobbied for it. In an ad for her re-election campaign last year, Ivey was shown withdrawing a handgun from her purse as she touted her gun-friendly approach, describing the second amendment as \u201csacred\u201d. Alabama has the third-highest rate of gun deaths in the US, according to a 2020 report by Everytown, an organization that works to improve gun safety and end gun violence. Biden asked what was wrong \u201cwhen parents have to worry every time their kids walk out the door to school, to the movie theater, or to the park? Guns are the leading killer of children in America, and the numbers are rising \u2013 not declining. This is outrageous and unacceptable.\u201d Biden called on Congress to \u201crequire safe storage of firearms, require background checks for all gun sales, eliminate gun manufacturers\u2019 immunity from liability, and ban assault weapons and high-capacity magazines\u201d. The latest shooting comes as two people were killed in a shooting in Louisville, Kentucky, on Saturday night, days after a gunman shot and killed five people in the city. Associated Press reported that an unidentified suspect fired a gun into a crowd of hundreds in Chickasaw Park in Louisville, killing two people and wounding four others. On Monday five people were killed when a man opened fire with an assault-style rifle at the Louisville bank where he worked. Eight others were wounded. \u201cThis has been an unspeakable week of tragedy for our city,\u201d Louisville mayor Craig Greenberg on Saturday night. \u201cOn Monday, we lost five of our fellow citizens to a horrific act of workplace gun violence,\u201d Greenberg said. \u201cAnd now, five days later, we\u2019re at another scene of a reckless act of gun violence.\u201d", "charCount": "5744", More than 28 people were injured, some critically, during the shooting about 60 miles (100km) north-east of the state capital of Montgomery, authorities said. The shooting started shortly after 10.30pm on Saturday. Law enforcement officers did not immediately say if a suspect was in custody or if investigators knew about any motivation. The police called for people to come forward with information. \u201cWe\u2019re going to continue to work in a very methodical way to go through this scene, to look at the facts, and ensure that justice is brought to bear for the families,\u201d said Jeremy Burkett, a sergeant with the Alabama law enforcement agency, during a news conference on Sunday. \u201cWe\u2019ve got to have information from the community,\u201d Burkett said during a Sunday evening news conference. President Joe Biden said in a statement on Sunday: \u201cWhat has our nation come to when children cannot attend a birthday party without fear?\u201d Biden called the rising gun violence in the US \u201coutrageous and unacceptable\u201d, and urged Congress to pass laws that would make firearms manufacturers more liable for gun violence, ban assault weapons and high-capacity ammunition magazines, and require safe storage of firearms and background checks for gun sales. Philstavious \u201cPhil\u201d Dowdell, a Dadeville high school senior who had signed with Jacksonville State University, was celebrating at his sister Alexis\u2019s party before he was fatally shot, his grandmother Annette Allen told the Montgomery Advertiser. \u201cHe was a very, very humble child. Never messed with anybody. Always had a smile on his face,\u201d Allen told the newspaper, calling it \u201ca million-dollar smile\u201d. Dowdell\u2019s mother was among those hurt in the shooting. \u201cEverybody\u2019s grieving,\u201d Allen said. Pastor Ben Hayes, who serves as the chaplain for the Dadeville police department and for the local high school football team, said most of the victims were teenagers. Dowdell was within weeks of graduation and faced a bright future, Hayes told the Associated Press. \u201cHe was a strong competitor on the field,\u201d Hayes said. \u201cYou didn\u2019t want to try to tackle him or get tackled by him. But when he came off the field, he was one of the nicest young men that you could ever meet, very respectful and well respected by his peers.\u201d Hayes said worried families swarmed the local hospital on Saturday night trying to find the condition of their children. He said serious crime was rare in Dadeville, and the small city was \u201csad, traumatized, in shock\u201d. This is at least the second time in recent years that multiple people were shot in Dadeville. Five people were wounded in July 2016 during a shooting at an American Legion hall, and a man was later charged with five counts of attempted murder, news outlets reported. Investigators believed an altercation led to the shooting at the Mahogany Masterpiece studio, WRBL reported.\nJonathan Floyd, chief of the Dadeville police, said at a news conference: \u201cWhat we\u2019ve dealt with is something that no community should have to endure. I just ask for your patience. It\u2019s going to be a long process, but I do earnestly solicit your prayers.\u201d More than 12 hours after the shooting, investigators continued filing in and out of the Mahogany Masterpiece dance studio on Sunday. City and county officials milled about the Tallapoosa county courthouse less than a block away, where officials lowered the American and Alabama flags to half-staff. \u201cThis morning, I grieve with the people of Dadeville and my fellow Alabamians,\u201d Kay Ivey, the governor of Alabama, said on Twitter. \u201cViolent crime has NO place in our state, and we are staying closely updated by law enforcement as details emerge.\u201d In 2022 Ivey signed a bill into law that ended the requirement for a person to obtain a permit to legally carry a concealed handgun in public. The National Rifle Association (NRA) had lobbied for it. In an ad for her re-election campaign last year, Ivey was shown withdrawing a handgun from her purse as she touted her gun-friendly approach, describing the second amendment as \u201csacred\u201d. Alabama has the third-highest rate of gun deaths in the US, according to a 2020 report by Everytown, an organization that works to improve gun safety and end gun violence. Biden asked what was wrong \u201cwhen parents have to worry every time their kids walk out the door to school, to the movie theater, or to the park? Guns are the leading killer of children in America, and the numbers are rising \u2013 not declining. This is outrageous and unacceptable.\u201d Biden called on Congress to \u201crequire safe storage of firearms, require background checks for all gun sales, eliminate gun manufacturers\u2019 immunity from liability, and ban assault weapons and high-capacity magazines\u201d. The latest shooting comes as two people were killed in a shooting in Louisville, Kentucky, on Saturday night, days after a gunman shot and killed five people in the city. Associated Press reported that an unidentified suspect fired a gun into a crowd of hundreds in Chickasaw Park in Louisville, killing two people and wounding four others. "global-development/2023/apr/17/from-bad-to-worse-drought-puts-kenyas-hospitals-under-pressure", "type": "article", "sectionId": "global-development", "sectionName": "Global development", "https://content.guardianapis.com/global-development/2023/apr/17/from-bad-to-worse-drought-puts-kenyas-hospitals-under-pressure", "fields": {"headline": "\u2018From bad to worse\u2019: drought puts Kenya\u2019s hospitals under pressure", "standfirst": "<p>New mothers at a rural hospital running out of water and power tell of their struggles as health workers leave for safer areas</p><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2023/apr/17/a-future-at-risk-drought-forces-kenyas-camel-herders-to-leave-their-homes-a-photo-essay\">Read more: A future at risk: drought forces areas", "byline": "Caroline Kimeu in Garissa County", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"1308740c22566a9d3091f73979d430f91438c1b6\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/1308740c22566a9d3091f73979d430f91438c1b6/0_268_7756_4656/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Qureisha Juma, 17, brings her niece Suheyba Faisal for a screening at Iftin hospital in class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>The morning rounds at Modogashe hospital in Lagdera do not take long. Most of the rooms opening on to its narrow hallway are empty. \u201cWe don\u2019t get that many patients these days,\u201d says Saveria Njoki, the head of nursing. Only three patients were on the ward that day, and none would be staying very long.</p> <p>According to a local official, patient numbers in Lagdera \u2013 a district in Garissa County, in the east of Kenya \u2013 have dropped from nearly 12,000 in 2019 to just over 8,000 last year, as people move away in search of water.</p> <p>Kenya, Ethiopia and Somalia are experiencing their worst drought in 40 years, with their <a href=\"https://www.unhcr.org/news/briefing/2023/2/63fdbcee4/horn-africa-drought-enters-sixth-failed-rainy-season-unhcr-calls-urgent.html\">sixth consecutive failed rainy season</a>. The number of people in Kenya facing severe hunger is expected to rise to <a href=\"https://www.oxfam.org.uk/media/press-releases/hunger-soars-in-east-africa-as-sweeping-aid-cuts-and-another-failed-rainy-season-looms/\">5.4 million this year</a>, particularly in the north of the country, where about <a href=\"https://www.oxfam.org/en/press-releases/one-five-persons-dont-have-enough-water-drought-stricken-east-africa\">95%</a> of surface water sources have dried up. Garissa County is among the worst-hit regions and hordes of people have moved from the countryside to Garissa town, which sits on the Tana River.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"56063804fa05358367ff3fbaf9a3371fd841212c\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/56063804fa05358367ff3fbaf9a3371fd841212c/0_0_7720_5149/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Usba Hussein, 20, walked for more than two hours to reach Modogashe hospital with her daughter Fatima who was suffering from malnutrition.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Usba Hussein, 20, walked for more than two hours to reach Modogashe hospital with her daughter Fatima, who was suffering from malnutrition.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Water has always been a problem at Modogashe hospital, which is located along a dusty, windy road. But the situation has got much worse over the past three years as the nearby rivers that provided it with some water have dried up. It is now reliant on water being delivered by road \u2013 which can be infrequent because there are not enough trucks.</p> <p>Lack of water and electricity has already forced the hospital to close its operating theatre and neonatal unit.</p> <p>Usuba Hussein, 20, brought her baby to the hospital because she was malnourished. Hussein fetches a 20-litre barrel of water from the hospital storage tank and uses her feet to shuffle it back to the ward. \u201cThis water needs to last me and my baby for four days,\u201d she says. That includes drinking and washing.</p> <p>\u201cThings have gone from bad to worse,\u201d says Njoki. \u201cI stay because it\u2019s very difficult to move elsewhere when you\u2019re employed by the government, so I can only wait for retirement.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"22fbd74b1cc6e44369361951aefce3dacceb3256\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/22fbd74b1cc6e44369361951aefce3dacceb3256/0_0_7966_5313/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Head nurse Saveria Njoki checks on Athar Khalif, 22, at Modogashe hospital. Khalif gave birth on her way there.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Head nurse Saveria Njoki checks on Athar Khalif, 22, at Modogashe hospital. Khalif gave birth on her way there.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>In the maternity ward, Athar Khalif, 22, lies on a bed recovering. She gave birth to her daughter on her way here. She wanted to be at the hospital because she bled heavily last time she had a baby and needed to be near trained medics. But she had to wait for a water truck to arrive at home. Women giving birth at Modogashe hospital usually bring a jerrycan of water with them, because the facility will probably not have enough.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2023/apr/05/water-ban-in-drought-stricken-tunisia-adds-to-growing-crisis\">Water ban in drought-stricken Tunisia adds to growing crisis</a> </p> </aside>  <p>In times of extreme water shortages, like now, health workers ask mothers help out. \u201cI was rushing with my children to get water, then I felt some sharp pains. I knew I wouldn\u2019t get to the hospital in time,\u201d says Khalif.</p> <p>With no water, Njoki has sometimes had to use saline solutions from IV drips to stop infections during deliveries and manage postpartum haemorrhage, the leading cause of maternal deaths. Garissa County has the highest maternal mortality rate in the country: 641 deaths for every 100,000 live births, according to <a href=\"https://www.knbs.or.ke/download/2019-kphc-analytical-report-on-mortality-vol-vii/\">2019 data</a> by Kenya\u2019s National Bureau of Statistics.</p> <p>\u201cPut yourself in that situation,\u201d says Njoki. \u201cThere\u2019s no water, the mother is bleeding, and you are there and have to do something. Sometimes you have two deliveries without water and a third one on the way. Your only aim is to see the mother and the child alive.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"f72fc8d71e78a50c2834815d811723922a1da18c\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/f72fc8d71e78a50c2834815d811723922a1da18c/0_0_7925_5286/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Nurse Morrice Mugambi at Afwein dispensary in Garissa.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Nurse Morrice Mugambi at Afwein dispensary in Garissa. Unicef says says many hospitals in the area are operating under conditions that place patients at risk.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Mohamed Abdullahi, the chief of Unicef\u2019s Garissa office, says many hospitals in the area are operating under conditions that place patients at risk. \u201cThey may be admitted with one issue but pick up an infection while being treated,\u201d he says.</p> <p>Modogashe has had to cancel some of its critical outreach work because nearly half the community health volunteers who run the programme have left because of drought, leaving the service overstretched.</p> <p>\u201cThings are really bad,\u201d says Mohammed Sede Dif, 60, a community health worker. \u201cMany [volunteers] have moved to other places. When it rains, they\u2019ll come back, but for now, there\u2019s a big problem. There are so many households that need us and just a few of us left. We receive one call from this side, and another call from the other, so we do what we can but we can\u2019t respond to everything.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"55262d53e29717b36547d839af13e52c23e0f9d9\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/55262d53e29717b36547d839af13e52c23e0f9d9/0_0_6539_4361/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Usba Hussein, 20, rolls a jerrycan of water at Modogashe hospital. Patients are asked to bring their own water to help with their care.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Usba Hussein, 20, rolls a jerrycan of water at Modogashe hospital. Patients are asked to bring their own water to help with their care.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Many of the people who have left the countryside have gone to Garissa town, about 150km (90 miles) south of Lagdera. The town\u2019s three hospitals have reported an increase in patient numbers in recent months, but at least the facilities have underground boreholes, running water and storage facilities \u2013 for now.</p> <p>Unicef said about 3,000 men, women and children have arrived in the town this year from Wajir, another northern region severely affected by the drought. The UN agency estimates that about 80% were unwell or had injuries when they arrived.</p> <p>\u201cWe are now seeing internally displaced people within Kenya for the first time in this crisis,\u201d says Abdullahi. \u201cThis is placing an enormous pressure on hospitals in the main towns in drought-affected regions, which are responding to influxes of patients from a widening area.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"3241a9e98d3a32ff7a284d1bb208ed088c2f25b6\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/3241a9e98d3a32ff7a284d1bb208ed088c2f25b6/0_0_7065_4712/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Fatuma Aden, 26, holds her four-month-old son Qamar Mohamud as he is examined at Modogashe hospital.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Fatuma Aden, 26, holds her four-month-old son Qamar Mohamud as he is examined at Modogashe hospital. </span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>At Garissa town\u2019s Iftin hospital, the waiting areas are full and workers bustle around the corridors. A line of patients wait outside the malnutrition centre.</p> <p>\u201cResources are getting finished earlier than expected \u2013 we are really feeling the pinch,\u201d says Bishar Hassan, the hospital chief. \u201cFor now we are able to handle it, but we are concerned that the cases of waterborne diseases may flare up.\u201d</p> <p>Garissa is still battling a cholera outbreak, which began in October, trigged by the severe drought. The World Health Organization says <a href=\"https://www.afro.who.int/photo-story/reaching-vulnerable-populations-kenyas-cholera-outbreak\">7,800 cases have been recorded</a> in the country.</p> <p>Kenya\u2019s Ministry of Health has launched an <a href=\"https://www.health.go.ke/oral-cholera-vaccination-campaign-launches-to-protect-2-2-million-individuals/\">oral vaccine</a> campaign to reach 2.2 million people.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"9b0678e6e97a86d18bcd8fce0a8eefde9887b264\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/9b0678e6e97a86d18bcd8fce0a8eefde9887b264/0_0_8192_5464/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A nurse distributes ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF) at Iftin hospital. \" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A nurse distributes ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF) at Iftin hospital. Many child patients are badly malnourished.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Unicef has also rehabilitated 21 boreholes in Garissa and begun prospecting for underground water sources in a number of northern counties. This involves using specialist equipment to more accurately track where water might be found and improve drilling rates.</p> <p>\u201cThe key is to build the capacity of county governments to manage scarce water resources in ways that suit the environment and climate,\u201d says Abdullahi. \u201cThe anticipation of future needs is vital.\u201d</p>", "wordcount": "1032", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T05:30:31Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T06:17:30Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nyxbf", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/1308740c22566a9d3091f73979d430f91438c1b6/0_268_7756_4656/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "The morning rounds at Modogashe hospital in Lagdera do not take long. Most of the rooms opening on to its narrow hallway are empty. \u201cWe don\u2019t get that many patients these days,\u201d says Saveria Njoki, the head of nursing. Only three patients were on the ward that day, and none would be staying very long. According to a local official, patient numbers in Lagdera \u2013 a district in Garissa County, in the east of Kenya \u2013 have dropped from nearly 12,000 in 2019 to just over 8,000 last year, as people move away in search of water. Kenya, Ethiopia and Somalia are experiencing their worst drought in 40 years, with their sixth consecutive failed rainy season. The number of people in Kenya facing severe hunger is expected to rise to 5.4 million this year, particularly in the north of the country, where about 95% of surface water sources have dried up. Garissa County is among the worst-hit regions and hordes of people have moved from the countryside to Garissa town, which sits on the Tana River. Water has always been a problem at Modogashe hospital, which is located along a dusty, windy road. But the situation has got much worse over the past three years as the nearby rivers that provided it with some water have dried up. It is now reliant on water being delivered by road \u2013 which can be infrequent because there are not enough trucks. Lack of water and electricity has already forced the hospital to close its operating theatre and neonatal unit. Usuba Hussein, 20, brought her baby to the hospital because she was malnourished. Hussein fetches a 20-litre barrel of water from the hospital storage tank and uses her feet to shuffle it back to the ward. \u201cThis water needs to last me and my baby for four days,\u201d she says. That includes drinking and washing. \u201cThings have gone from bad to worse,\u201d says Njoki. \u201cI stay because it\u2019s very difficult to move elsewhere when you\u2019re employed by the government, so I can only wait for retirement.\u201d In the maternity ward, Athar Khalif, 22, lies on a bed recovering. She gave birth to her daughter on her way here. She wanted to be at the hospital because she bled heavily last time she had a baby and needed to be near trained medics. But she had to wait for a water truck to arrive at home. Women giving birth at Modogashe hospital usually bring a jerrycan of water with them, because the facility will probably not have enough. In times of extreme water shortages, like now, health workers ask mothers help out. \u201cI was rushing with my children to get water, then I felt some sharp pains. I knew I wouldn\u2019t get to the hospital in time,\u201d says Khalif. With no water, Njoki has sometimes had to use saline solutions from IV drips to stop infections during deliveries and manage postpartum haemorrhage, the leading cause of maternal deaths. Garissa County has the highest maternal mortality rate in the country: 641 deaths for every 100,000 live births, according to 2019 data by Kenya\u2019s National Bureau of Statistics. \u201cPut yourself in that situation,\u201d says Njoki. \u201cThere\u2019s no water, the mother is bleeding, and you are there and have to do something. Sometimes you have two deliveries without water and a third one on the way. Your only aim is to see the mother and the child alive.\u201d Mohamed Abdullahi, the chief of Unicef\u2019s Garissa office, says many hospitals in the area are operating under conditions that place patients at risk. \u201cThey may be admitted with one issue but pick up an infection while being treated,\u201d he says. Modogashe has had to cancel some of its critical outreach work because nearly half the community health volunteers who run the programme have left because of drought, leaving the service overstretched. \u201cThings are really bad,\u201d says Mohammed Sede Dif, 60, a community health worker. \u201cMany [volunteers] have moved to other places. When it rains, they\u2019ll come back, but for now, there\u2019s a big problem. There are so many households that need us and just a few of us left. We receive one call from this side, and another call from the other, so we do what we can but we can\u2019t respond to everything.\u201d Many of the people who have left the countryside have gone to Garissa town, about 150km (90 miles) south of Lagdera. The town\u2019s three hospitals have reported an increase in patient numbers in recent months, but at least the facilities have underground boreholes, running water and storage facilities \u2013 for now. Unicef said about 3,000 men, women and children have arrived in the town this year from Wajir, another northern region severely affected by the drought. The UN agency estimates that about 80% were unwell or had injuries when they arrived. \u201cWe are now seeing internally displaced people within Kenya for the first time in this crisis,\u201d says Abdullahi. \u201cThis is placing an enormous pressure on hospitals in the main towns in drought-affected regions, which are responding to influxes of patients from a widening area.\u201d At Garissa town\u2019s Iftin hospital, the waiting areas are full and workers bustle around the corridors. A line of patients wait outside the malnutrition centre. \u201cResources are getting finished earlier than expected \u2013 we are really feeling the pinch,\u201d says Bishar Hassan, the hospital chief. \u201cFor now we are able to handle it, but we are concerned that the cases of waterborne diseases may flare up.\u201d Garissa is still battling a cholera outbreak, which began in October, trigged by the severe drought. The World Health Organization says 7,800 cases have been recorded in the country. Kenya\u2019s Ministry of Health has launched an oral vaccine campaign to reach 2.2 million people. Unicef has also rehabilitated 21 boreholes in Garissa and begun prospecting for underground water sources in a number of northern counties. This involves using specialist equipment to more accurately track where water might be found and improve drilling rates. \u201cThe key is to build the capacity of county governments to manage scarce Patients are asked to bring their own water to help with their care.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Many of the people who have left the countryside have gone to Garissa town, about 150km (90 miles) south of Lagdera. The town\u2019s three hospitals have reported an increase in patient numbers in recent months, but at least the facilities have underground boreholes, running water and storage facilities \u2013 for now.</p> <p>Unicef said about 3,000 men, women and children have arrived in the town this year from Wajir, another northern region severely affected by the drought. The UN agency estimates that about 80% were unwell or had injuries when they arrived.</p> <p>\u201cWe are now seeing internally displaced people within Kenya for the first time in this crisis,\u201d says Abdullahi. \u201cThis is placing an enormous pressure on hospitals in the main towns in drought-affected regions, which are responding to influxes of patients from a widening area.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"3241a9e98d3a32ff7a284d1bb208ed088c2f25b6\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/3241a9e98d3a32ff7a284d1bb208ed088c2f25b6/0_0_7065_4712/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Fatuma Aden, 26, holds her four-month-old son Qamar Mohamud as he is examined at Modogashe hospital.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Fatuma Aden, 26, holds her four-month-old son Qamar Mohamud as he is examined at Modogashe hospital. </span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>At Garissa town\u2019s Iftin hospital, the waiting areas are full and workers bustle around the corridors. A line of patients wait outside the malnutrition centre.</p> <p>\u201cResources are getting finished earlier than expected \u2013 we are really feeling the pinch,\u201d says Bishar Hassan, the hospital chief. \u201cFor now we are able to handle it, but we are concerned that the cases of waterborne diseases may flare up.\u201d</p> <p>Garissa is still battling a cholera outbreak, which began in October, trigged by the severe drought. The World Health Organization says <a href=\"https://www.afro.who.int/photo-story/reaching-vulnerable-populations-kenyas-cholera-outbreak\">7,800 cases have been recorded</a> in the country.</p> <p>Kenya\u2019s Ministry of Health has launched an <a href=\"https://www.health.go.ke/oral-cholera-vaccination-campaign-launches-to-protect-2-2-million-individuals/\">oral vaccine</a> campaign to reach 2.2 million people.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"9b0678e6e97a86d18bcd8fce0a8eefde9887b264\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/9b0678e6e97a86d18bcd8fce0a8eefde9887b264/0_0_8192_5464/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A nurse distributes ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF) at Iftin hospital. \" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A nurse distributes ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF) at Iftin hospital. Many child patients are badly malnourished.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Unicef has also rehabilitated 21 boreholes in Garissa and begun prospecting for underground water sources in a number of northern counties. This involves using specialist equipment to more accurately track where water might be found and improve drilling rates.</p> <p>\u201cThe key is to build the capacity of county governments to manage scarce water resources in ways that suit the environment and climate,\u201d says Abdullahi. \u201cThe anticipation of future needs is vital.\u201d</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "The morning rounds at Modogashe hospital in Lagdera do not take long. Most of the rooms opening on to its narrow hallway are empty. \u201cWe don\u2019t get that many patients these days,\u201d says Saveria Njoki, the head of nursing. Only three patients were on the ward that day, and none would be staying very long. According to a local official, patient numbers in Lagdera \u2013 a district in Garissa County, in the east of Kenya \u2013 have dropped from nearly 12,000 in 2019 to just over 8,000 last year, as people move away in search of water. Kenya, Ethiopia and Somalia are experiencing their worst drought in 40 years, with their sixth consecutive failed rainy season. The number of people in Kenya facing severe hunger is expected to rise to 5.4 million this year, particularly in the north of the country, where about 95% of surface water sources have dried up. Garissa County is among the worst-hit regions and hordes of people have moved from the countryside to Garissa town, which sits on the Tana River.\nWater has always been a problem at Modogashe hospital, which is located along a dusty, windy road. But the situation has got much worse over the past three years as the nearby rivers that provided it with some water have dried up. It is now reliant on water being delivered by road \u2013 which can be infrequent because there are not enough trucks. Lack of water and electricity has already forced the hospital to close its operating theatre and neonatal unit. Usuba Hussein, 20, brought her baby to the hospital because she was malnourished. Hussein fetches a 20-litre barrel of water from the hospital storage tank and uses her feet to shuffle it back to the ward. \u201cThis water needs to last me and my baby for four days,\u201d she says. That includes drinking and washing. \u201cThings have gone from bad to worse,\u201d says Njoki. \u201cI stay because it\u2019s very difficult to move elsewhere when you\u2019re employed by the government, so I can only wait for retirement.\u201d\nIn the maternity ward, Athar Khalif, 22, lies on a bed recovering. She gave birth to her daughter on her way here. She wanted to be at the hospital because she bled heavily last time she had a baby and needed to be near trained medics. But she had to wait for a water truck to arrive at home. Women giving birth at Modogashe hospital usually bring a jerrycan of water with them, because the facility will probably not have enough.\nIn times of extreme water shortages, like now, health workers ask mothers help out. \u201cI was rushing with my children to get water, then I felt some sharp pains. I knew I wouldn\u2019t get to the hospital in time,\u201d says Khalif. With no water, Njoki has sometimes had to use saline solutions from IV drips to stop infections during deliveries and manage postpartum haemorrhage, the leading cause of maternal deaths. Garissa County has the highest maternal mortality rate in the country: 641 deaths for every 100,000 live births, according to 2019 data by Kenya\u2019s National Bureau of Statistics. \u201cPut yourself in that situation,\u201d says Njoki. \u201cThere\u2019s no water, the mother is bleeding, and you are there and have to do something. Sometimes you have two deliveries without water and a third one on the way. Your only aim is to see the mother and the child alive.\u201d\nMohamed Abdullahi, the chief of Unicef\u2019s Garissa office, says many hospitals in the area are operating under conditions that place patients at risk. \u201cThey may be admitted with one issue but pick up an infection while being treated,\u201d he says. Modogashe has had to cancel some of its critical outreach work because nearly half the community health volunteers who run the programme have left because of drought, leaving the service overstretched. \u201cThings are really bad,\u201d says Mohammed Sede Dif, 60, a community health worker. \u201cMany [volunteers] have moved to other places. When it rains, they\u2019ll come back, but for now, there\u2019s a big problem. There are so many households that need us and just a few of us left. We receive one call from this side, and another call from the other, so we do what we can but we can\u2019t respond to everything.\u201d\nMany of the people who have left the countryside have gone to Garissa town, about 150km (90 miles) south of Lagdera. The town\u2019s three hospitals have reported an increase in patient numbers in recent months, but at least the facilities have underground boreholes, running water and storage facilities \u2013 for now. Unicef said about 3,000 men, women and children have arrived in the town this year from Wajir, another northern region severely affected by the drought. The UN agency estimates that about 80% were unwell or had injuries when they arrived. \u201cWe are now seeing internally displaced people within Kenya for the first time in this crisis,\u201d says Abdullahi. \u201cThis is placing an enormous pressure on hospitals in the main towns in drought-affected regions, which are responding to influxes of patients from a widening area.\u201d\nAt Garissa town\u2019s Iftin hospital, the waiting areas are full and workers bustle around the corridors. A line of patients wait outside the malnutrition centre. \u201cResources are getting finished earlier than expected \u2013 we are really feeling the pinch,\u201d says Bishar Hassan, the hospital chief. \u201cFor now we are able to handle it, but we are concerned that the cases of waterborne diseases may flare up.\u201d Garissa is still battling a cholera outbreak, which began in October, trigged by the severe drought. The World Health Organization says 7,800 cases have been recorded in the country.
