drought forces Kenya\u2019s camel herders to leave their homes \u2013 a photo essay", "standfirst": "<p>Pastoralists in the north of the country are watching their animals die as they journey further south in a desperate search for water and better grazing</p><ul><li>Photographs by Patrick Meinhardt</li></ul>", "trailText": "Pastoralists in the north of the country are watching their animals die as they journey further south in a desperate search for water and better grazing", "byline": "Caroline Kimeu in Garissa County", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"ec05547c0ffb33abccadeaf230db0a2365c201be\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/ec05547c0ffb33abccadeaf230db0a2365c201be/0_0_7210_4809/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Men try to lift a camel too weak to stand on its own\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Men try to lift a camel too weak to stand near a camp for internally displaced people (IDPs) on the outskirts of Garissa, Kenya</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>At a roadside camp in Garissa, a group of pastoralists try to lift a camel from the ground using a large tree branch. Weakened by the drought in the north of Kenya, the camel needs help to get back on its feet to find pasture.</p> <p>Kenya is facing its <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2021/dec/17/all-i-can-think-about-is-the-childrens-future-drought-devastates-kenya\">worst drought in decades</a>, and the north \u2013 a region that has been marginalised for a long time \u2013 is disproportionately affected.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"65865089766f6bdc3f5d2262df1c4d0a7f3c6914\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/65865089766f6bdc3f5d2262df1c4d0a7f3c6914/0_0_7695_5133/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Ali Hillow Hassan\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Ali Hillow Hassan at an IDP camp on the outskirts of Garissa, Kenya, March 2023.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <ul> <li><p>Ali Hillow Hassan photographed in March at the IDP camp on the outskirts of Garissa</p></li> </ul> <p>Ali Hillow Hassan, 74, a pastoralist, has lost nearly 80 camels this year. He has only two left, and is doing whatever he can to help them through the drought. On the margins of a camp for people who have left their homes in search of water and support, the smell of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/gallery/2021/dec/17/kenyan-nomads-age-old-way-of-life-falls-victim-to-worst-drought-in-memory-in-pictures\">dead carcasses</a> fills the air. Witnessing their camels, one of the world\u2019s most resilient animals, die is a sign of extremely difficult times, say the pastoralists.</p> <p>Hillow migrated to Garissa County from Wajir, about 185 miles to the north, in hope of finding better water and pasture for his livestock. Garissa is experiencing the highest number of new arrivals from northern states, according to<a href=\"https://kenya.iom.int/sites/g/files/tmzbdl926/files/documents/2023-03/DTM%20INFOSHEET%20September%202022-February%202023%20%28final%29.pdf\"> International Organization for Migration</a><em><strong><a href=\"https://kenya.iom.int/sites/g/files/tmzbdl926/files/documents/2023-03/DTM%20INFOSHEET%20September%202022-February%202023%20%28final%29.pdf\"> </a></strong></em><a href=\"https://kenya.iom.int/sites/g/files/tmzbdl926/files/documents/2023-03/DTM%20INFOSHEET%20September%202022-February%202023%20%28final%29.pdf\">data</a>. The county is hard-hit by the drought, but <a href=\"https://ndma.go.ke/index.php/resource-center/national-drought-bulletin/send/39-drought-updates/6868-national-monthly-drought-updates-march-2023\">less so</a> than other regions \u2013 categorised by government agencies as being on \u201calert\u201d rather than in states of \u201calarm\u201d or \u201cemergency\u201d, such as those farther north.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--halfWidth\" data-media-id=\"4ba82fb049999efc88a1f5201cf2b92f85980369\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/4ba82fb049999efc88a1f5201cf2b92f85980369/0_0_8106_5407/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A water trucks makes a delivery to an IDP camp on the outskirts of Garissa, Kenya\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A water truck makes a delivery to an IDP camp on the outskirts of Garissa, Kenya, March 2023. Dozens of people suffering from the drought in Wajir have set camp near Garissa. In the holy month of Ramadan private individuals donate food and water.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--halfWidth\" data-media-id=\"3830a83394441037416b8889ba4c87dddf7b729d\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/3830a83394441037416b8889ba4c87dddf7b729d/0_0_7724_5152/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A camel grazes near an IDP camp on the outskirts of Garissa\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A camel grazes near an IDP camp on the outskirts of Garissa, Kenya.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <ul> <li><p>A water truck makes a delivery to an IDP camp on the outskirts of Garissa; a camel grazes near the camp</p></li> </ul> <p>But for Hillow, things are only marginally better in Garissa. Many of his animals died on the journey south or soon after. He and the other pastoralists settled in a camp along the Garissa-Modogashe road, in an area not too far from Garissa town, which they describe as being \u201ccloser to the government\u201d \u2013 with better accessibility to services and community aid.</p> <p>Local officials say that the drought is driving high rates of displacement and migration.</p> <p>\u201cWe\u2019re seeing communities with no support systems come down to Garissa, which places some burden on existing communities,\u201d said Ahmednadhir Omar, a health official with the Garissa County government.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--immersive\" data-media-id=\"8d7b8453fdd24b18d95d63359506c7360e278892\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/8d7b8453fdd24b18d95d63359506c7360e278892/0_0_8047_5367/1000.jpg\" alt=\"People wait as food is distributed at the Garissa IDP camp\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">People wait during a food distribution at an IDP camp in the outskirts of Garissa, 15 March 2023.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <ul> <li><p>People wait as food is distributed at the Garissa IDP camp</p></li> </ul> <p>With the high number of pastoralists moving into the county, the area is also reporting the highest number of livestock deaths. Pastoralists say the health of their livestock has deteriorated, <a href=\"https://ndma.go.ke/index.php/resource-center/national-drought-bulletin/send/39-drought-updates/6868-national-monthly-drought-updates-march-2023\">affecting trade</a>.</p> <p>A healthy camel can sell for more than 100,000 Kenyan shillings (\u00a3595).</p> <p>\u201cMany of the pastoralists were rich one day, and poor the next,\u201d says Omar Mohamed, 28, a camp resident. He adds that six consecutive failed rains have pushed pastoralists further to the margins. Some have opted to take up jobs as cab or motorcycle taxi drivers, he says. \u201cThe future of all the people here \u2013 or at least, the one they know \u2013 is at risk.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Women assemble at a water point at Afwein in Garissa, March 2023.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A woman pushes a jerry can full of water back to the camp at Garissa</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <ul> <li><p>Clockwise from top left: women assemble at a water point at Afwein in Garissa; food supplies are delivered to people who have fled drought in Wajir; rolling a jerry can full of water back to camp; waiting for aid to be distributed</p></li> </ul> <p>New arrivals say they have not met with any tensions from local communities in Garissa town. Some have been met by wellwishers offering food.</p> <p>Sporadic rains last month led to flash floods in some parts of the country, but they were not enough to ease the drought, which still remains critical in most of the country.</p> <p>Just over <a href=\"https://www.ndma.go.ke/index.php/resource-center/send/87-2022/6833-2022-short-rains-assessment-national-report\">500,000 people</a> in the county are in need of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2022/dec/06/famine-development-secretaries-urge-increase-aid-east-africa\">humanitarian aid</a>, and the number of people requiring assistance has increased by 125% in the past two years, according to data from health officials.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--immersive\" "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "At a roadside camp in Garissa, a group of pastoralists try to lift a camel from the ground using a large tree branch. Weakened by the drought in the north of Kenya, the camel needs help to get back on its feet to find pasture. Kenya is facing its worst drought in decades, and the north \u2013 a region that has been marginalised for a long time \u2013 is disproportionately affected. Ali Hillow Hassan photographed in March at the IDP camp on the outskirts of Garissa Ali Hillow Hassan, 74, a pastoralist, has lost nearly 80 camels this year. He has only two left, and is doing whatever he can to help them through the drought. On the margins of a camp for people who have left their homes in search of water and support, the smell of dead carcasses fills the air. Witnessing their camels, one of the world\u2019s most resilient animals, die is a sign of extremely difficult times, say the pastoralists. Hillow migrated to Garissa County from Wajir, about 185 miles to the north, in hope of finding better water and pasture for his livestock. Garissa is experiencing the highest number of new arrivals from northern states, according to International Organization for Migration data. The county is hard-hit by the drought, but less so than other regions \u2013 categorised by government agencies as being on \u201calert\u201d rather than in states of \u201calarm\u201d or \u201cemergency\u201d, such as those farther north. A water truck makes a delivery to an IDP camp on the outskirts of Garissa; a camel grazes near the camp But for Hillow, things are only marginally better in Garissa. Many of his animals died on the journey south or soon after. He and the other pastoralists settled in a camp along the Garissa-Modogashe road, in an area not too far from Garissa town, which they describe as being \u201ccloser to the government\u201d \u2013 with better accessibility to services and community aid. Local officials say that the drought is driving high rates of displacement and migration. \u201cWe\u2019re seeing communities with no support systems come down to Garissa, which places some burden on existing communities,\u201d said Ahmednadhir Omar, a health official with the Garissa County government. People wait as food is distributed at the Garissa IDP camp With the high number of pastoralists moving into the county, the area is also reporting the highest number of livestock deaths. Pastoralists say the health of their livestock has deteriorated, affecting trade. A healthy camel can sell for more than 100,000 Kenyan shillings (\u00a3595). \u201cMany of the pastoralists were rich one day, and poor the next,\u201d says Omar Mohamed, 28, a camp resident. He adds that six consecutive failed rains have pushed pastoralists further to the margins. Some have opted to take up jobs as cab or motorcycle taxi drivers, he says. \u201cThe future of all the people here \u2013 or at least, the one they know \u2013 is at risk.\u201d Clockwise from top left: women assemble at a water point at Afwein in Garissa; food supplies are delivered to people who have fled drought in Wajir; rolling a jerry can full of water back to camp; waiting for aid to be distributed New arrivals say they have not met with any tensions from local communities in Garissa town. Some have been met by wellwishers offering food. Sporadic rains last month led to flash floods in some parts of the country, but they were not enough to ease the drought, which still remains critical in most of the country. Just over 500,000 people in the county are in need of humanitarian aid, and the number of people requiring assistance has increased by 125% in the past two years, according to data from health officials. On the margins of a camp for people who have left their homes in search of water and support, the smell of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/gallery/2021/dec/17/kenyan-nomads-age-old-way-of-life-falls-victim-to-worst-drought-in-memory-in-pictures\">dead carcasses</a> fills the air. Witnessing their camels, one of the world\u2019s most resilient animals, die is a sign of extremely difficult times, say the pastoralists.</p> <p>Hillow migrated to Garissa County from Wajir, about 185 miles to the north, in hope of finding better water and pasture for his livestock. Garissa is experiencing the highest number of new arrivals from northern states, according to<a href=\"https://kenya.iom.int/sites/g/files/tmzbdl926/files/documents/2023-03/DTM%20INFOSHEET%20September%202022-February%202023%20%28final%29.pdf\"> International Organization for Migration</a><em><strong><a href=\"https://kenya.iom.int/sites/g/files/tmzbdl926/files/documents/2023-03/DTM%20INFOSHEET%20September%202022-February%202023%20%28final%29.pdf\"> </a></strong></em><a href=\"https://kenya.iom.int/sites/g/files/tmzbdl926/files/documents/2023-03/DTM%20INFOSHEET%20September%202022-February%202023%20%28final%29.pdf\">data</a>. The county is hard-hit by the drought, but <a href=\"https://ndma.go.ke/index.php/resource-center/national-drought-bulletin/send/39-drought-updates/6868-national-monthly-drought-updates-march-2023\">less so</a> than other regions \u2013 categorised by government agencies as being on \u201calert\u201d rather than in states of \u201calarm\u201d or \u201cemergency\u201d, such as those farther north.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--halfWidth\" data-media-id=\"4ba82fb049999efc88a1f5201cf2b92f85980369\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/4ba82fb049999efc88a1f5201cf2b92f85980369/0_0_8106_5407/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A water trucks makes a delivery to an IDP camp on the outskirts of Garissa, Kenya\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A water truck makes a delivery to an IDP camp on the outskirts of Garissa, Kenya, March 2023. Dozens of people suffering from the drought in Wajir have set camp near Garissa. In the holy month of Ramadan private individuals donate food and water.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--halfWidth\" data-media-id=\"3830a83394441037416b8889ba4c87dddf7b729d\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/3830a83394441037416b8889ba4c87dddf7b729d/0_0_7724_5152/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A camel grazes near an IDP camp on the outskirts of Garissa\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A camel grazes near an IDP camp on the outskirts of Garissa, Kenya.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <ul> <li><p>A water truck makes a delivery to an IDP camp on the outskirts of Garissa; a camel grazes near the camp</p></li> </ul> <p>But for Hillow, things are only marginally better in Garissa. Many of his animals died on the journey south or soon after. He and the other pastoralists settled in a camp along the Garissa-Modogashe road, in an area not too far from Garissa town, which they describe as being \u201ccloser to the government\u201d \u2013 with better accessibility to services and community aid.</p> <p>Local officials say that the drought is driving high rates of displacement and migration.</p> <p>\u201cWe\u2019re seeing communities with no support systems come down to Garissa, which places some burden on existing communities,\u201d said Ahmednadhir Omar, a health official with the Garissa County government.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--immersive\" data-media-id=\"8d7b8453fdd24b18d95d63359506c7360e278892\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/8d7b8453fdd24b18d95d63359506c7360e278892/0_0_8047_5367/1000.jpg\" alt=\"People wait as food is distributed at the Garissa IDP camp\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">People wait during a food distribution at an IDP camp in the outskirts of Garissa, 15 March 2023.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <ul> <li><p>People wait as food is distributed at the Garissa IDP camp</p></li> </ul> <p>With the high number of pastoralists moving into the county, the area is also reporting the highest number of livestock deaths. Pastoralists say the health of their livestock has deteriorated, <a href=\"https://ndma.go.ke/index.php/resource-center/national-drought-bulletin/send/39-drought-updates/6868-national-monthly-drought-updates-march-2023\">affecting trade</a>.</p> <p>A healthy camel can sell for more than 100,000 Kenyan shillings (\u00a3595).</p> <p>\u201cMany of the pastoralists were rich one day, and poor the next,\u201d says Omar Mohamed, 28, a camp resident. He adds that six consecutive failed rains have pushed pastoralists further to the margins. Some have opted to take up jobs as cab or motorcycle taxi drivers, he says. \u201cThe future of all the people here \u2013 or at least, the one they know \u2013 is at risk.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--halfWidth\" data-media-id=\"5360cfc73d237b158f0ac14c0ecd351dd20e9b80\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/5360cfc73d237b158f0ac14c0ecd351dd20e9b80/0_0_7759_5175/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Women assemble at a water point at the Garissa camp, March 2023.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Women assemble at a water point at Afwein in Garissa, March 2023.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--halfWidth\" data-media-id=\"cd9f86bcbf84ece779b73f8ed0c7baa746711181\"> <img height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Food is distributed to the dozens of people who have fled the drought in Wajir in the IDP camp on the outskirts class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A woman pushes a jerry can full of water back to the camp at Garissa</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: in Garissa town. Some have been met by wellwishers offering food.</p> <p>Sporadic rains last month led to flash floods in some parts of the country, but they were not enough to ease the drought, which still remains critical in most of the country.</p> <p>Just over <a href=\"https://www.ndma.go.ke/index.php/resource-center/send/87-2022/6833-2022-short-rains-assessment-national-report\">500,000 people</a> in the county are in need of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2022/dec/06/famine-development-secretaries-urge-increase-aid-east-africa\">humanitarian aid</a>, and the number of people requiring assistance has increased by 125% in the past two years, according to data from health officials.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--immersive\" data-media-id=\"8fe4f28bee90bb701daa33b8ecb7fbc5c7d478f8\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/8fe4f28bee90bb701daa33b8ecb7fbc5c7d478f8/0_0_8124_5419/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A man walks across the dried up bed of the Modogashe River in Garissa, Kenya, March 2023.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A man walks across the dried up bed of the Modogashe River in Garissa, Kenya, March 2023.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Patrick Meinhardt/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <ul> <li><p>A man walks across the dry bed of the Modogashe River in Garissa</p></li> </ul>", "bodyTextSummary": "At a roadside camp in Garissa, a group of pastoralists try to lift a camel from the ground using a large tree branch. Weakened by the drought in the north of Kenya, the camel needs help to get back on its feet to find pasture. Kenya is facing its worst drought in decades, and the north \u2013 a region that has been marginalised for a long time \u2013 is disproportionately affected.\nAli Hillow Hassan photographed in March at the IDP camp on the outskirts of Garissa Ali Hillow Hassan, 74, a pastoralist, has lost nearly 80 camels this year. He has only two left, and is doing whatever he can to help them through the drought. On the margins of a camp for people who have left their homes in search of water and support, the smell of dead carcasses fills the air. Witnessing their camels, one of the world\u2019s most resilient animals, die is a sign of extremely difficult times, say the pastoralists. Hillow migrated to Garissa County from Wajir, about 185 miles to the north, in hope of finding better water and pasture for his livestock. Garissa is experiencing the highest number of new arrivals from northern states, according to International Organization for Migration data. The county is hard-hit by the drought, but less so than other regions \u2013 categorised by government agencies as being on \u201calert\u201d rather than in states of \u201calarm\u201d or \u201cemergency\u201d, such as those farther north.\nA water truck makes a delivery to an IDP camp on the outskirts of Garissa; a camel grazes near the camp But for Hillow, things are only marginally better in Garissa. Local officials say that the drought is driving high rates of displacement and migration. \u201cWe\u2019re seeing communities with no support systems come down to Garissa, which places some burden on existing communities,\u201d said Ahmednadhir Omar, a health official with the Garissa County government.\nPeople wait as food is distributed at the Garissa IDP camp With the high number of pastoralists moving into the county, the area is also reporting the highest number of livestock deaths. Shell complete, sights are now set on interiors. Now, as the sale of Waystar Royco looms, the manoeuvring takes on a dark new hue. <strong>Jack Seale</strong></p> <h2>Murderville</h2> <h2>10.15pm, BBC Three</h2> <p>This committed but not entirely convincing US remake of Tom Davis\u2019s massively superior crime spoof Murder in Successville gets a BBC airing. class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Diego Fedele/AAP</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>Major Victorian infrastructure projects, the public service and community health funding will be slashed in a state budget one government source says will be<strong> </strong>unlike any other the Labor government has delivered.</p> <p>As the government works to get the state\u2019s finances back on track post-Covid, Daniel Andrews on Sunday warned Victorians there would be \u201cvery difficult measures\u201d in the May budget. This is despite Labor committing to delivering <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/nov/24/daniel-andrews-on-the-defensive-as-80-of-local-victorian-election-promises-benefit-labor-electorates\">billions of dollars worth of promises</a> made in the lead-up to November\u2019s state election.</p> <ul> <li><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/oct/29/email-newsletters-guardian-australia-best-daily-news-emails-newsletter-free-sign-up-inbox-subscribe-headlines?CMP=copyembed\">Sign up for Guardian Australia\u2019s free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup</a></strong></p></li> </ul> <p>\u201cIt will not be a budget we are used to seeing in Victoria,\u201d a senior government source, who is not authorised to speak publicly about budget deliberations, told Guardian Australia.</p> <p>A Labor MP said recent language used by the government regarding the budget was not a case of expectation management.</p> <p>\u201cIt\u2019s going to be bad. They\u2019re not over-egging it,\u201d they said.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/06/astonishing-cost-of-inland-rail-doubles-to-30bn-as-review-savages-coalition-over-project\">\u2018Astonishing\u2019: cost of Inland Rail doubles to $30bn as review savages Coalition over project</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Both sources said it is expected the brakes will be slammed on major infrastructure projects, singling out the Geelong Fast Rail and Melbourne Airport Rail. It follows reports the New South Wales government is also considering pausing projects due to cost blowouts.</p> <p>According to Treasury\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.dtf.vic.gov.au/2022-23-state-budget/pre-election-budget-update\">pre-election budget update</a>, Victoria\u2019s net debt is forecast to surge from $116bn in 2022-23 to $166bn by 2025-26, which is equivalent to 26.5% of gross state product.</p> <p>Interest payments on state debt was forecast to total $7.5bn in 2025-26, up from $3.9bn in 2022-23. At the same time, revenue from the GST and property stamp duties is likely to dip.</p> <p>\u201cOur budget will be delivering on all the election commitments that we made. Beyond that, it will have to have some very difficult measures within it because for the best of reasons at the worst of times, we went and borrowed billions and billions of dollars to get us through a one-in-100-year event,\u201d Andrews said on Sunday.</p> <p>\u201cWe need to make some really difficult choices.\u201d</p> <p>Almost $672m was allocated to the Melbourne Airport rail project in last year\u2019s state budget for early works, as part of a $5bn commitment that was matched by the federal government.</p> <p>A further $123m was allocated to the Geelong Fast Rail, of which the state and federal governments have committed $2bn each.</p> <p>The latter was announced by the then prime minister, Scott Morrison, on the eve of the 2019 election, but it is not known how much the Albanese government intends to contribute to the project.</p> <p>On Monday the state\u2019s transport infrastructure minister, Jacinta Allan, said the two governments were \u201cstill in the process of making final decisions\u201d on the projects, but that there was \u201csignificant pressure\u201d on meeting the 2029 deadline for Melbourne Airport Rail.</p> <p>She said if there were \u201cchanges\u201d to projects, it was her expectation any federal funds would \u201cstay within Victoria\u201d.</p> <p>Guardian Australia also understands the secretary of the Department of Treasury and Finance, David (CPSU) estimates this could lead to 6,000 job cuts.</p> <p>\u201cIt insults people\u2019s intelligence to play this frontline versus others game as if there\u2019s some second-class job that can be Albanese government intends to contribute to the project.</p> \n<p>On Monday the state\u2019s transport infrastructure minister, Jacinta Allan, said the two governments were \u201cstill in the process of making final decisions\u201d on the projects, but that there was \u201csignificant pressure\u201d on meeting the 2029 deadline for Melbourne Airport Rail.</p> \n<p>She said if there were \u201cchanges\u201d to projects, it was her expectation any federal funds would \u201cstay within Victoria\u201d.</p> \n<p>Guardian Australia also understands the secretary of the Department of Treasury and Finance, David Martine, has written to other department heads ordering them to detail plans to cut their budgets by 10% without harming \u201cfrontline services\u201d.</p> \n<p>The Community and Public Sector Union (CPSU) estimates this could lead to 6,000 job cuts.</p> \n<p>\u201cIt insults people\u2019s intelligence to play this frontline versus others game as if there\u2019s some second-class job that can be cut because it\u2019s in a supporting role to others that directly deliver the service,\u201d the CPSU\u2019s Victorian secretary, Karen Batt, told Guardian Australia.</p> \n<p>\u201cIt means government will exempt every politically sensitive area but they\u2019ll impose the cut in the support roles, which wipes out the service delivery anyway as more so-called \u2018frontliners\u2019 spend more time doing those support roles.\u201d</p> \n<p>The government is expected to spend about $33.5bn on wages this financial year, the equivalent of about 40% of its revenue.</p> \n<p>The government has also <a scheme</a>, given benefits paid to injured workers exceed the premiums paid by business to fund the scheme by about $1.1bn a year.</p> \n<p>On Friday 45 community health services were told to brace </figure>", "body": "<p>One in eight Britons have paid for private health services in the last year, amid frustration with delays in getting NHS treatment and a growing willingness to buy care using salary or savings.</p> <p>New research by YouGov found that another 27% of people had considered going private, for themselves or a loved one, but decided against it, often because they couldn\u2019t afford it.</p> <p>Added to the 13% who did pay for care for themselves or someone they live with, that means that two in five people have either resorted to using medical care at private clinics and hospitals or thought about doing so.</p> <p>NHS campaigners said they feared that the findings show that it is becoming a \u201ctwo-tier\u201d health service and blamed underfunding and staff shortages for leaving it unable to provide timely care.</p> <p>\u201cWorsening NHS services related directly to a lack of planning, workforce shortages and underinvestment inevitably force some patients to seek care faster from the private sector,\u201d said Dr John Puntis, a retired consultant paediatrician who is the co-chair of the campaign group Keep Our NHS Public.</p> <p>\u201cThis option is available to those who can afford to pay, but excludes the vast majority of the population as over a third of people in the UK have less than \u00a31,000 in cash to cover unexpected expenses, thereby increasing health inequalities,\u201d he added.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/charts/embed/apr/2023-04-14-05:12:56/embed.html\" data-alt=\"Bar chart: use of private healthcare\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/charts/embed/apr/2023-04-14-05:12:56/embed.html\">Interactive</a> </figure>  <p>YouGov\u2019s survey of a representative sample of 1,164 Britons found that:</p> <ul> <li><p>33% of those who had used private healthcare instead of the NHS had done so for the first time.</p></li> <li><p>53% went private \u201cso I could be seen more quickly\u201d.</p></li> <li><p>most (48%) paid for non-urgent care, such as a diagnostic test or operation.</p></li> </ul> <p>Among the 13% who had paid for private care, 29% had used disposable income but others had used a work-based private health scheme (25%), savings (24%), private medical insurance (14%) or money they had borrowed from friends of family (6%).</p> <p>The body that represents private health firms said that YouGov\u2019s findings may show that, with NHS delays so common, use of services run by such providers is becoming normalised.</p> <p>\u201cPeople feel the independent sector can help them, and we could be seeing the beginning of a significant behavioural shift with people feeling it\u2019s perfectly normal and sensible to use private healthcare when they need it, in addition to, or separate from, their NHS care\u201d, said David Hare, the chief executive of the Independent Healthcare Provider Network.</p> <p>The \u201crelatively modest\u201d average \u00a3500 spend \u201cdemonstrates that private healthcare is an option for smaller procedures, consultations, scans or diagnostics, so it\u2019s not just about significant surgical operations \u2013 and may be more affordable than people assume\u201d, Hare added.</p> <p>The findings come as the \u201celective recovery taskforce\u201d that Rishi Sunak set up to tackle the 7.2m-strong backlog of people in England awaiting hospital care is reportedly finalising plans to give patients greater choice in where they have their care, paid for by the NHS. The move is likely to lead to the private sector treating more NHS-funded patients.</p> <p>In a hint of its recommendations, the prime minister said recently that: \u201cWe should be using the independent sector to provide choice, to provide competition, drive up quality. It\u2019s worked in the past and we are going to do more of that going forward.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/charts/embed/apr/2023-04-14-05:13:52/embed.html\" data-alt=\"Bar chart: how people paid for private healthcare\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/charts/embed/apr/2023-04-14-05:13:52/embed.html\">Interactive</a> </figure>  <p>Tom Powell, YouGov\u2019s research director, said: \u201cLooking at the 13% who used private healthcare in the last year for either themselves or another member of their household, 33% of this group said it was the first time they used private healthcare rather than using the NHS. A further 48% said it wasn\u2019t the first time they used private but typically they would use the NHS.</p> <p>\u201cThis means that around eight in 10 of those who used private healthcare last year were people who previously would have always or typically used the NHS.\u201d</p> <p>Among those who paid, the average spend was \u00a3500. However, 23% had spent between \u00a31,001 and \u00a35,000 while another 4% had spent between \u00a35,001 and \u00a310,000.</p> <p>A Department of Health and Social Care spokesperson said: \u201cThe NHS is working hard to cut waiting lists and we are making progress on our elective recovery plan, despite winter pressures on the NHS and industrial action.</p> <p>\u201cThe longest waits for treatment have fallen for the third month in a row and there were a record 2.1m diagnostic tests carried out in January thanks to our 100 community diagnostic centres, which have delivered over 3.4m tests, checks and scans in total.\u201d</p> <p>The NHS is spending at least \u00a361m a year on private ambulance services to attend emergencies such as car crashes and heart attacks in England because it cannot answer all 999 calls itself, new research by the union Unison found.</p> <p>The South Central ambulance service is spending the most \u2013 \u00a319m a year \u2013 freedom of information requests show. But the North West ambulance service is spending \u00a315m and the East Midlands ambulance service \u00a39.5m, Unison found.</p>", "newspaperPageNumber": "2", "wordcount": "819", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:34Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T05:00:34Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-17T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nncbn", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/e410c1a53f0ff9cc6f09b2753c472f90d5607caa/0_252_3780_2268/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "One in eight Britons have paid for private health services in the last year, amid frustration with delays in getting NHS treatment and a growing willingness to buy care using salary or savings. New research by YouGov found that another 27% of people had considered going private, for themselves or a loved one, but decided against it, often because they couldn\u2019t afford it. Added to the 13% who did pay for care for themselves or someone they live with, that means that two in five people have either resorted to using medical care at private clinics and hospitals or thought about doing so. NHS campaigners said they feared that the findings show that it is becoming a \u201ctwo-tier\u201d health service and blamed underfunding and staff shortages for leaving it unable to provide timely care. \u201cWorsening NHS services related directly to a lack of planning, workforce shortages and underinvestment inevitably force some patients to seek care faster from the private sector,\u201d said Dr John Puntis, a retired consultant paediatrician who is the co-chair of the campaign group Keep Our NHS Public. \u201cThis option is available to those who can afford to pay, but excludes the vast majority of the population as over a third of people in the UK have less than \u00a31,000 in cash to cover unexpected expenses, thereby increasing health inequalities,\u201d he added. YouGov\u2019s survey of a representative sample of 1,164 Britons found that: 33% of those who had used private healthcare instead of the NHS had done so for the first time. 53% went private \u201cso I could be seen more quickly\u201d. most (48%) paid for non-urgent care, such as a diagnostic test or operation. Among the 13% who had paid for private care, 29% had used disposable income but others had used a work-based private health scheme (25%), savings (24%), private medical insurance (14%) or money they had borrowed from friends of family (6%). The body that represents private health firms said that YouGov\u2019s findings may show that, with NHS delays so common, use of services run by such providers is becoming normalised. \u201cPeople feel the independent sector can help them, and we could be seeing the beginning of a significant behavioural shift with people feeling it\u2019s perfectly normal and sensible to use private healthcare when they need it, in addition to, or separate from, their NHS care\u201d, said David Hare, the chief executive of the Independent Healthcare Provider Network. The \u201crelatively modest\u201d average \u00a3500 spend \u201cdemonstrates that private healthcare is an option for smaller procedures, consultations, scans or diagnostics, so it\u2019s not just about significant surgical operations \u2013 and may be more affordable than people assume\u201d, Hare added. The findings come as the \u201celective recovery taskforce\u201d that Rishi Sunak set up to tackle the 7.2m-strong backlog of people in England awaiting hospital care is reportedly finalising plans to give patients greater choice in where they have their care, paid for by the NHS. The move is likely to lead to the private sector treating more NHS-funded patients. In a hint of its recommendations, the prime minister said recently that: \u201cWe should be using the independent sector to provide choice, to provide competition, drive up quality. It\u2019s worked in the past and we are going to do more of that going forward.\u201d Tom Powell, YouGov\u2019s research director, said: \u201cLooking at the 13% who used private healthcare in the last year for either themselves or another member of their household, 33% of this group said it was the first time they used private healthcare rather than using the NHS. A further 48% said it wasn\u2019t the first time they used private but typically they would use the NHS. \u201cThis means that around eight in 10 of those who used private healthcare last year were people who previously would have always or typically used the NHS.\u201d Among those who paid, the average spend was \u00a3500. However, 23% had spent between \u00a31,001 and \u00a35,000 while another 4% had spent between \u00a35,001 and \u00a310,000. A Department of Health and Social Care spokesperson said: \u201cThe NHS is working hard to cut waiting lists and we are making progress on our elective recovery plan, despite winter pressures on the NHS and industrial action. \u201cThe longest waits for treatment have fallen for the third month in a row and there were a record 2.1m diagnostic tests carried out in January thanks to our 100 community diagnostic centres, which have delivered over 3.4m tests, checks and scans in total.\u201d The NHS is spending at least \u00a361m a year on private ambulance services to attend emergencies such as car crashes and heart attacks in England because it cannot answer all 999 calls itself, new research by the union Unison found. The South Central ambulance service is spending the most \u2013 \u00a319m a year \u2013 freedom of information requests show. to tackle the 7.2m-strong backlog of people in England awaiting hospital care is reportedly finalising plans to give patients greater choice in where they have their care, paid for by the NHS. The move is likely to lead to the private sector treating more NHS-funded patients.</p> <p>In a hint of its recommendations, the prime minister said recently that: \u201cWe should be using the independent sector to provide choice, to provide competition, drive up quality. It\u2019s worked in the past and we are going to do more of that going forward.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/charts/embed/apr/2023-04-14-05:13:52/embed.html\" data-alt=\"Bar chart: how people paid for private healthcare\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/charts/embed/apr/2023-04-14-05:13:52/embed.html\">Interactive</a> </figure>  <p>Tom Powell, YouGov\u2019s research director, said: \u201cLooking at the 13% who used private healthcare in the last year for either themselves or another member of their household, 33% of this group said it was the first time they used private healthcare rather than using the NHS. A further 48% said it wasn\u2019t the first time they used private but typically they would use the NHS.</p> <p>\u201cThis means that around eight in 10 of those who used private healthcare last year were people who previously would have always or typically used the NHS.\u201d</p> <p>Among those who paid, the average spend was \u00a3500. However, 23% had spent between \u00a31,001 and \u00a35,000 while another 4% had spent between \u00a35,001 and \u00a310,000.</p> <p>A Department of Health and Social Care spokesperson said: \u201cThe NHS is working hard to cut waiting lists and we are making progress on our elective recovery plan, despite winter pressures on the NHS and industrial action.</p> <p>\u201cThe longest waits for treatment have fallen for the third month in a row and there were a record 2.1m diagnostic tests carried out in January thanks to our 100 community diagnostic centres, which have delivered over 3.4m tests, checks and scans in total.\u201d</p> <p>The NHS is spending at least \u00a361m a year on private ambulance services to attend emergencies such as car crashes and heart attacks in England because it cannot answer all 999 calls itself, new research by the union Unison found.</p> <p>The South Central ambulance service is spending the most \u2013 \u00a319m a year \u2013 freedom of information requests show. But the North West ambulance service is spending \u00a315m and the East Midlands ambulance service \u00a39.5m, Unison found.</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "One in eight Britons have paid for private health services in the last year, amid frustration with delays in getting NHS treatment and a growing willingness to buy care using salary or savings. New research by YouGov found that another 27% of people had considered going private, for themselves or a loved one, but decided against it, often because they couldn\u2019t afford it. Added to the 13% who did pay for care for themselves or someone they live with, that means that two in five people have either resorted to using medical care at private clinics and hospitals or thought about doing so. NHS campaigners said they feared that the findings show that it is becoming a \u201ctwo-tier\u201d health service and blamed underfunding and staff shortages for leaving it unable to provide timely care. \u201cWorsening NHS services related directly to a lack of planning, workforce shortages and underinvestment inevitably force some patients to seek care faster from the private sector,\u201d said Dr John Puntis, a retired consultant paediatrician who is the co-chair of the campaign group Keep Our NHS Public. \u201cThis option is available to those who can afford to pay, but excludes the vast majority of the population as over a third of people in the UK have less than \u00a31,000 in cash to cover unexpected expenses, thereby increasing health inequalities,\u201d he added.\nYouGov\u2019s survey of a representative sample of 1,164 Britons found that: 33% of those who had used private healthcare instead of the NHS had done so for the first time. 53% went private \u201cso I could be seen more quickly\u201d. most (48%) paid for non-urgent care, such as a diagnostic test or operation. Among the 13% who had paid for private care, 29% had used disposable income but others had used a work-based private health scheme (25%), savings (24%), private medical insurance (14%) or money they had borrowed from friends of family (6%). The body that represents private health firms said that YouGov\u2019s findings may show that, with NHS delays so common, use of services run by such providers is becoming normalised. \u201cPeople feel the independent sector can help them, and we could be seeing the beginning of a significant behavioural shift with people feeling it\u2019s perfectly normal and sensible to use private healthcare when they need it, in addition to, or separate from, their NHS care\u201d, said David Hare, the chief executive of the Independent Healthcare Provider Network. The \u201crelatively modest\u201d average \u00a3500 spend \u201cdemonstrates that private healthcare is an option for smaller procedures, consultations, scans or diagnostics, so it\u2019s not just about significant surgical operations \u2013 and may be more affordable than people assume\u201d, Hare added. The findings come as the \u201celective recovery taskforce\u201d that Rishi Sunak set up to tackle the 7.2m-strong backlog of people in England awaiting hospital care is reportedly finalising plans to give patients greater choice in where they have their care, paid for by the NHS. The move is likely to lead to the private sector treating more NHS-funded patients. In a hint of its recommendations, the prime minister said recently that: \u201cWe should be using the independent sector to provide choice, to provide competition, drive up quality. It\u2019s worked in the past and we are going to do more of that going forward.\u201d\nTom Powell, YouGov\u2019s research director, said: \u201cLooking at the 13% who used private healthcare in the last year for either themselves or another member of their household, 33% of this group said it was the first time they used private healthcare rather than using the NHS. A further 48% said it wasn\u2019t the first time they used private but typically they would use the NHS. \u201cThis means that around eight in 10 of those who used private healthcare last year were people who previously would have always or typically used the NHS.\u201d Among those who paid, the average spend was \u00a3500. However, 23% had spent between \u00a31,001 and \u00a35,000 while another 4% had spent between \u00a35,001 and \u00a310,000. A Department of Health and Social Care spokesperson said: \u201cThe NHS is working hard to cut waiting lists and we are making progress on our elective recovery plan, despite winter pressures on the NHS and industrial action. \u201cThe longest waits for treatment have fallen for the third month in a row and there were a record 2.1m diagnostic tests carried out in January thanks to our 100 community diagnostic centres, which have delivered over 3.4m tests, checks and scans in total.\u201d The NHS is spending at least \u00a361m a year on private ambulance services to attend emergencies such as car crashes and heart attacks in England because it cannot answer all 999 calls itself, new research by the union Unison found. The South Central ambulance service is spending the most \u2013 \u00a319m a year \u2013 freedom of information requests show.
