She explains what it takes to be the world\u2019s best javelin thrower, survive a breakdown and bounce back from financial ruin</p>", "trailText": "Left for dead as an infant, raised in care and abused as a child, Whitbread became an exceptional athlete. She explains what it takes to be the world\u2019s best javelin thrower, survive a breakdown and bounce back from financial ruin", "byline": "Emine Saner", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"a27b15c8686cddb6471d3accdbcab8d3faa0b24d\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/a27b15c8686cddb6471d3accdbcab8d3faa0b24d/0_130_6697_4019/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Fatima Whitbread at home in Essex\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">\u2018I had a sense of determination to succeed because of my childhood\u2019 \u2026 Fatima Whitbread at home in Essex.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Teri Pengilley/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>In the latest of the many lives of Fatima Whitbread, the former champion javelin thrower has become a formidable reality TV star \u2013 and it suits her. She is surely one good show away from \u201cbeloved\u201d status, which might prove to be the I\u2019m a Celebrity \u2026 Get Me Out of Here! spin-off in which she is soon to star, alongside a select group of other former participants in the ITV show.</p> <p>She was on I\u2019m a Celeb in 2011, when her nasal cavity became home to a cockroach during one of the challenges \u2013 \u201cThere\u2019s definitely something wriggling about in there!\u201d \u2013 and it took an hour for the camp doctor to flush it out. But I liked her best in last year\u2019s Celebrity SAS: Who Dares Wins, the Channel 4 series in which celebs do Special Forces training; Whitbread cracked three ribs jumping out of a helicopter, but kept it a secret because she didn\u2019t want to leave the show. She was charming, warm, capable and \u2013 having filmed it at 60 \u2013 ripped.</p> <p>This morning, she has been out exercising for two hours. She does an hour of cardio or weights every day. Even her jack russell terrier, Bertie, is ageing well; the vet remarked recently on his good health. \u201cThey said he\u2019s got a heartbeat like an athlete,\u201d says Whitbread, smiling. That is what you get when you are owned by an Olympic medallist and former world champion who once broke the women\u2019s javelin world record. Bertie sits between us on a large sofa in Whitbread\u2019s spotless, clutter-free home in Essex. The only hint at the greatness of her sporting career is a bronze cast of her hand, strong fingers wrapped around a javelin\u2019s grip, given to her by Madame Tussauds.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"6a48fa868da9b7bdefd00c4ecb844afb410c0253\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/6a48fa868da9b7bdefd00c4ecb844afb410c0253/0_0_6558_4372/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Fatima Whitbread with her dog, Bertie\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">With her dog, Bertie.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Teri Pengilley/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Whitbread, 62, has led an extraordinary life. This decade has been defined so far by physical and psychological challenges. Last year, as well as the SAS show, she climbed Mont Blanc. About a year ago, for the first time, she started having therapy (even when she had a breakdown in her 20s, she powered through without professional help). \u201cI\u2019ve realised I\u2019ve done bloody marvellous without it, but sometimes things trigger and all those childhood years can come back to haunt you,\u201d she says.</p> <p>As a baby, Whitbread was abandoned in a flat in London and essentially left to die. After hearing her cries, neighbours called the police. Whitbread recovered in hospital from malnutrition, dehydration and her terrible physical condition, then spent her childhood in children\u2019s homes. \u201cI felt this deep sense of loss within me,\u201d she says. When she was five, she was introduced to her biological mother \u2013 having had no idea of her history \u2013 and moved to a children\u2019s home in Essex, where she had two half-siblings. \u201cThat was the first time I started questioning what was going on in my life and what was to become of me.\u201d</p> <p>It was a life of deprivation, physical and emotional. There wasn\u2019t enough food and they had few clothes. The children played in a cold garage with a concrete floor. Love and affection were scant. She was abandoned again and again. Occasionally, her biological mother would arrive to take her half-siblings home for a visit, but not Whitbread. Once, the woman she calls \u201cthe biological mother\u201d, never \u201cmy biological mother\u201d \u2013 a Turkish Cypriot woman who spoke almost no English \u2013 did take her, but changed her mind and sent her back to the home.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"390a076b008f699e8a019067d827428272c5a82b\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/390a076b008f699e8a019067d827428272c5a82b/0_0_3500_2334/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Fatima Whitbread with Ferne McCann on Celebrity SAS: Who Dares Wins in 2022\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Whitbread with Ferne McCann on Celebrity SAS: Who Dares Wins in 2022.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Pete Dadds/Channel 4/PA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Whitbread\u2019s biological father, a Greek Cypriot, also surfaced. She spent a week with him, with the promise that he would be back to collect her again the weekend after, but he didn\u2019t appear. \u201cI sat on the front wall for a whole weekend,\u201d she says. \u201cThe second weekend, I did the same thing. I think that cracked me, emotionally. I put these walls up around myself to secure me.\u201d</p> <p>The only person who showed Whitbread any love was a woman who worked in the home, known as Auntie Rae. It was Rae who stopped Whitbread\u2019s biological mother, who arrived one day with three men, from taking her out of the home. Rae\u2019s suspicions proved horrifyingly true: at a later date, when her biological mother was able to take her to London for a while, 11-year-old Whitbread was raped by a man who was staying at the flat.</p> <p>Back at the children\u2019s home and traumatised, Whitbread refused to go to school. \u201cI just became withdrawn. Having not spoken to anyone about it, I felt ashamed, dirty.\u201d Eventually, she told Rae what had happened. Whitbread says it was reported, but nothing was done (she was referred to a child psychologist for a couple of weeks). \u201cUnbelievable what went on back then. You were never taken seriously. We had a social worker and I would talk to him about it. Nothing ever happened. Nobody took notice of the kids.\u201d</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>Sport gave me a sense of freedom, forgetting all the problems that were going on in the home</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>Is she angry at the system that failed her so spectacularly? \u201cWell, it does make me \u2026\u201d She pauses. \u201cEven today, some of the crazy policies \u2013 ousting kids [from care] at 16 is appalling. My son still lives at home; he\u2019s 25. At 16, these are vulnerable kids.\u201d At present, councils are allowed to put 16- and 17-year-old children in unregulated accommodation, although <a href=\"https://www.gov.uk/government/news/government-bans-unregulated-accommodation-for-young-people-in-care\" title=\"\">a ban on the practice</a> will come into force in October. \u201cFor a lot of young kids, history starts repeating itself: they start getting in trouble, or offending, and it costs the state a whole lot more. These young kids need that support, because once they get out there they\u2019re easily preyed upon. They\u2019re still kids.\u201d</p> <p>She worries about the cost of living crisis, inequality and poverty: \u201cThe kids are the ones that are getting the damage done.\u201d</p> <p>Sport saved her, she says. \u201cIt gave me a sense of freedom, forgetting all the problems that were going on in the home and the life we were living. It gave me a sense of achievement, that here was something I was good at. I got validation from my PE teachers and my school friends and started to realise life was a bit more positive. I realised that this could be my way out.\u201d</p> <p>Whitbread became the school netball captain and started going to a local athletics club. The javelin coach, Margaret Whitbread, recognised her talent. When she found out Whitbread lived in a children\u2019s home, she gave her some secondhand boots and a javelin. When Whitbread was grounded for a month, she managed to get a note to Margaret, fearing the coach would think she had left. She wrote that she hoped Margaret would take her back and that she intended to become the best javelin thrower in the world. \u201cIt was the start of a dream,\u201d says Whitbread.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"1ce9cea740e69338cabf403dfe3f36a0c4d714a3\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/1ce9cea740e69338cabf403dfe3f36a0c4d714a3/0_0_5244_3592/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Fatima Whitbread the Commonwealth Games in Edmonton, Canada, in 1978\" width=\"1000\" height=\"685\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">At the Commonwealth Games in Edmonton, Canada, in 1978.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Tony Duffy/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Margaret and her husband eventually fostered Whitbread, who changed her surname, Vedad, by deed poll. At 14, she finally had a family, which included the Whitbreads\u2019 two young sons. \u201cThat was amazing, the best thing that happened, to be a part of a family, which I\u2019d always wanted,\u201d she says. \u201cIt wasn\u2019t straightforward, because all families have their problems. Both as mum and daughter and athlete and coach, we worked it out somehow \u2013 and we conquered the world.\u201d</p> <p>Whitbread began training hard. \u201cI started taking more responsibility for myself,\u201d she says. \u201cYou have a whole lot of people that help you, but I\u2019ve got to get myself out at 5am, down the gym, three times a day training, seven days a week.\u201d She trained in a wooden shed at the bottom of the garden of a family friend. She smiles when she talks about how different facilities are now: \u201cI wouldn\u2019t have had it any other way. I loved every minute of it.\u201d</p> <p>Just two years later, in 1979, Whitbread was crowned European junior champion \u2013 becoming the first British woman to hold the title. At less than 1.65 metres (5ft 5in) tall, she wasn\u2019t built like a champion javelin thrower, but what she lacked in reach she made up for in determination: \u201cI had little room to manoeuvre where making mistakes was concerned, so I had to work exceptionally hard at analysing everybody\u2019s techniques and working out the best for me.\u201d</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>After retiring, the sense of loss, of identity and purpose, is very hard</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>What made her a good \u2013 at one stage, the best \u2013 thrower? \u201cI think the inner strength that I created as a child. If you asked me: \u2018Would I change anything about my life?\u2019 I\u2019d say no, because that created who I am. I had steely inner strength and a sense of determination to succeed because of my childhood. I possibly wouldn\u2019t have had that otherwise.\u201d She pauses. \u201cThere are some things you would have wanted to change.\u201d</p> <p>Whitbread had an incredible career \u2013 she was European and world champion and won bronze and silver at the 1984 and 1988 Olympics respectively. In 1986, she broke the world record with a throw of 77.44m. \u201cThat was a monumental experience,\u201d says Whitbread. As she let go of the javelin, she knew it was a good throw. \u201cThe hours and hours and hours of work that you put in, in order to get everything to click at the right time on the right day \u2026\u201d</p> <p>People told her it was the wrong day \u2013 it was the qualifying round for the European championships, so she had to go back and do it again. \u201cI just thought: I\u2019ll give it 100% and see what happens. I never allowed all that talk to get into there,\u201d she says, pointing at her head. \u201cI kept my mindset focused.\u201d She didn\u2019t manage to break her own record, but threw well enough to take gold.</p> <p>Much was made of her rivalry with the other British champion javelin thrower, Tessa Sanderson, who won the gold medal at the 1984 Olympics (Whitbread took bronze). \u201cBetween us, we achieved everything you could in an event. That\u2019s quite an astounding achievement for a country that wasn\u2019t known for its power events, so Tessa and I really flew that flag.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"8f3af0c2d2f986ebff22f6ff578307220a5e3cb6\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/8f3af0c2d2f986ebff22f6ff578307220a5e3cb6/0_0_3432_4345/790.jpg\" alt=\"Fatima Whitbread with her bronze medal at the 1984 Olympics\" width=\"790\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">With her bronze medal at the 1984 Olympics.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Tony Duffy/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The rivalry was real \u2013 although Whitbread says her main rival was East Germany\u2019s Petra Felke \u2013 but the media amped it up. Sanderson, who is a few years older, had been Whitbread\u2019s idol. Whitbread says she would have liked to have been friends. \u201cI thought there\u2019s nothing better than to be able to have a good friendship in an event where you can pull together. But everyone\u2019s different, aren\u2019t they? The media, what they instigated, it didn\u2019t lend itself very well [to friendship].\u201d</p> <p>Whitbread was aware of the comments in the media about her muscular physique. Did she care about that? \u201cIt\u2019s tools for the job,\u201d she says of her body. Had she been taller, maybe her muscles wouldn\u2019t have been so noticeable, but she was \u201cstubby\u201d, she says, laughing. \u201cBut I didn\u2019t care, because I loved what I did and that\u2019s what it took for me to succeed. I didn\u2019t take notice; I was just proud of my work ethos. But sometimes they could be unkind.\u201d</p> <p>As a child in the 80s, I say, I loved watching Whitbread and Sanderson \u2013 so strong and powerful, like warrior goddesses. She smiles: \u201cI think there were a lot of people who felt like that.\u201d</p> <p>Her success brought fame \u2013 and intrusion. The tabloids found her biological mother. The trauma resurfaced. \u201cIt forced me to have to tell my story. That was really the start of the demise in my athletic career, because it brought me to a physical and mental breakdown.\u201d While training for the 1988 Olympics, she was also writing a book about her childhood, to try to get control of her story. \u201cIt was awful. I shouldn\u2019t have gone to that Olympics, but I managed to pull on all my reserves and I came away with the silver medal.\u201d</p> <p>In the run-up, when she should have been training hard, she lost \u201call sense of time. My procrastination was terrible. When I was throwing, it was all over the place \u2013 30 metres, 40 metres, 70 metres.\u201d</p> <p>A shoulder injury, made worse by Whitbread\u2019s inability to train properly, ended her career officially in 1992. \u201cIt was eight years short, really,\u201d she says. \u201cIt was a big loss. For three or four years after that, when I went to championships, I would be watching with sadness, because I probably would still have been out there, winning.\u201d</p> <p>She had wanted more gold medals, including an Olympic one, and was aiming to throw more than 80m: \u201cI think I could have done.\u201d But it wasn\u2019t about the medals, she says. \u201cThe sense of loss, of identity and purpose, and then having to reinvent yourself in something that fills that void and the passion you had, is very hard.\u201d She went into sports marketing and did coaching and development.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"beae0badda6c05282cbc487a3466bae9ab1e95dd\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/beae0badda6c05282cbc487a3466bae9ab1e95dd/0_0_3746_2483/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Fatima Whitbread with Andy Norman in 1990\" width=\"1000\" height=\"663\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">With Andy Norman in 1990.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: John Gichigi/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>In 1997, she married Andy Norman, the controversial athletics promoter, with whom she had a son, Ryan, a year later. (Norman had been <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2007/sep/25/athletics.sport1\" title=\"\">implicated by the coroner</a> in the 1994 suicide of Cliff Temple, a Sunday Times journalist who had been investigating Norman\u2019s conduct as promotions officer of the British Athletics Federation.) After her traumatic childhood, she was determined that her son\u2019s would be different. \u201cI felt I would be a good mum,\u201d she says. \u201cI believed in myself. It was important for me to be able to prove that I could be a good mum and break the mould of what I\u2019d been through.\u201d</p> <p>She and Norman had experienced years of infertility, followed by a miscarriage, before their son was born via a third round of IVF. Norman left her for another athlete when Ryan was small, although he and Whitbread managed to remain close. Then, in 2007, he died suddenly, leaving Whitbread to raise Ryan alone. On top of that, it emerged that Norman had taken out loans, partly in Whitbread\u2019s name, which put her tens of thousands of pounds in debt. She had to sell the family home. The fees from reality TV kept her afloat and helped her rebuild her profile.</p> <p>She seems content, although a long friendship ended recently, which has saddened her: \u201cIt\u2019s not until something goes wrong in your life that everything else starts to come back and chase you.\u201d This is why she will stick at the therapy \u2013 she has found some kind of acceptance. The older she has got, she says, the more she has realised that \u201clife is about absorbing the good and the bad, learning from both and still moving forward\u201d. She made a choice, she says, not to feel angry or bitter. \u201cThat\u2019s only damaging to yourself. It blurs your vision, it doesn\u2019t allow you to progress. When I go back and talk to the five-year-old or the 11-year-old Fatima, I take her by the hand and say: don\u2019t worry, I\u2019ve got you now.\u201d</p>", "newspaperPageNumber": "6", "wordcount": "2469", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:33Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T12:53:11Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-17T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nmgtt", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/a27b15c8686cddb6471d3accdbcab8d3faa0b24d/0_130_6697_4019/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "sensitive": "true", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "In the latest of the many lives of Fatima Whitbread, the former champion javelin thrower has become a formidable reality TV star \u2013 and it suits her. She is surely one good show away from \u201cbeloved\u201d status, which might prove to be the I\u2019m a Celebrity \u2026 Get Me Out of Here! spin-off in which she is soon to star, alongside a select group of other former participants in the ITV show. She was on I\u2019m a Celeb in 2011, when her nasal cavity became home to a cockroach during one of the challenges \u2013 \u201cThere\u2019s definitely something wriggling about in there!\u201d \u2013 and it took an hour for the camp doctor to flush it out. But I liked her best in last year\u2019s Celebrity SAS: Who Dares Wins, the Channel 4 series in which celebs do Special Forces training; Whitbread cracked three ribs jumping out of a helicopter, but kept it a secret because she didn\u2019t want to leave the show. She was charming, warm, capable and \u2013 having filmed it at 60 \u2013 ripped. This morning, she has been out exercising for two hours. She does an hour of cardio or weights every day. Even her jack russell terrier, Bertie, is ageing well; the vet remarked recently on his good health. \u201cThey said he\u2019s got a heartbeat like an athlete,\u201d says Whitbread, smiling. That is what you get when you are owned by an Olympic medallist and former world champion who once broke the women\u2019s javelin world record. Bertie sits between us on a large sofa in Whitbread\u2019s spotless, clutter-free home in Essex. The only hint at the greatness of her sporting career is a bronze cast of her hand, strong fingers wrapped around a javelin\u2019s grip, given to her by Madame Tussauds. Whitbread, 62, has led an extraordinary life. This decade has been defined so far by physical and psychological challenges. Last year, as well as the SAS show, she climbed Mont Blanc. About a year ago, for the first time, she started having therapy (even when she had a breakdown in her 20s, she powered through without professional help). \u201cI\u2019ve realised I\u2019ve done bloody marvellous without it, but sometimes things trigger and all those childhood years can come back to haunt you,\u201d she says. As a baby, Whitbread was abandoned in a flat in London and essentially left to die. After hearing her cries, neighbours called the police. Whitbread recovered in hospital from malnutrition, dehydration and her terrible physical condition, then spent her childhood in children\u2019s homes. \u201cI felt this deep sense of loss within me,\u201d she says. When she was five, she was introduced to her biological mother \u2013 having had no idea of her history \u2013 and moved to a children\u2019s home in Essex, where she had two half-siblings. \u201cThat was the first time I started questioning what was going on in my life and what was to become of me.\u201d It was a life of deprivation, physical and emotional. There wasn\u2019t enough food and they had few clothes. The children played in a cold garage with a concrete floor. Love and affection were scant. She was abandoned again and again. Occasionally, her biological mother would arrive to take her half-siblings home for a visit, but not Whitbread. Once, the woman she calls \u201cthe biological mother\u201d, never \u201cmy biological mother\u201d \u2013 a Turkish Cypriot woman who spoke almost no English \u2013 did take her, but changed her mind and sent her back to the home. Whitbread\u2019s biological father, a Greek Cypriot, also surfaced. She spent a week with him, with the promise that he would be back to collect her again the weekend after, but he didn\u2019t appear. \u201cI sat on the front wall for a whole weekend,\u201d she says. \u201cThe second weekend, I did the same thing. I think that cracked me, emotionally. I put these walls up around myself to secure me.\u201d The only person who showed Whitbread any love was a woman who worked in the home, known as Auntie Rae. It was Rae who stopped Whitbread\u2019s biological mother, who arrived one day with three men, from taking her out of the home. Rae\u2019s suspicions proved horrifyingly true: at a later date, when her biological mother was able to take her to London for a while, 11-year-old Whitbread was raped by a man who was staying at the flat. Back at the children\u2019s home and traumatised, Whitbread refused to go to school. \u201cI just became withdrawn. Having not spoken to anyone about it, I felt ashamed, dirty.\u201d Eventually, she told Rae what had happened. Whitbread says it was reported, but nothing was done (she was referred to a child psychologist for a couple of weeks). \u201cUnbelievable what went on back then. You were never taken seriously. We had a social worker and I would talk to him about it. Nothing ever happened. Nobody took notice of the kids.\u201d Is she angry at the system that failed her so spectacularly? \u201cWell, it does make me \u2026\u201d She pauses. \u201cEven today, some of the crazy policies \u2013 ousting kids [from care] at 16 is appalling. My son still lives at home; he\u2019s 25. At 16, these are vulnerable kids.\u201d At present, councils are allowed to put 16- and 17-year-old children in unregulated accommodation, although a ban on the practice will come into force in October. \u201cFor a lot of young kids, history starts repeating itself: they start getting in trouble, or offending, and it costs the state a whole lot more. These young kids need that support, because once they get out there they\u2019re easily preyed upon. They\u2019re still kids.\u201d She worries about the cost of living crisis, inequality and poverty: \u201cThe kids are the ones that are getting the damage done.\u201d Sport saved her, she says. \u201cIt gave me a sense of freedom, forgetting all the problems that were going on in the home and the life we were living. It gave me a sense of achievement, that here was something I was good at. I got validation from my PE teachers and my school friends and started to realise life was a bit more positive. I realised that this could be my way out.\u201d Whitbread became the school netball captain and started going to a local athletics club. The javelin coach, Margaret Whitbread, recognised her talent. When she found out Whitbread lived in a children\u2019s home, she gave her some secondhand boots and a javelin. When Whitbread was grounded for a month, she managed to get a note to Margaret, fearing the coach would think she had left. She wrote that she hoped Margaret would take her back and that she intended to become the best javelin thrower in the world. \u201cIt was the start of a dream,\u201d says Whitbread. Margaret and her husband eventually fostered Whitbread, who changed her surname, Vedad, by deed poll. At 14, she finally had a family, which included the Whitbreads\u2019 two young sons. \u201cThat was amazing, the best thing that happened, to be a part of a family, which I\u2019d always wanted,\u201d she says. \u201cIt wasn\u2019t straightforward, because all families have their problems. Both as mum and daughter and athlete and coach, we worked it out somehow \u2013 and we conquered the world.\u201d Whitbread began training hard. \u201cI started taking more responsibility for myself,\u201d she says. \u201cYou have a whole lot of people that help you, but I\u2019ve got to get myself out at 5am, down the gym, three times a day training, seven days a week.\u201d She trained in a wooden shed at the bottom of the garden of a family friend. She smiles when she talks about how different facilities are now: \u201cI wouldn\u2019t have had it any other way. I loved every minute of it.\u201d Just two years later, in 1979, Whitbread was crowned European junior champion \u2013 becoming the first British woman to hold the title. At less than 1.65 metres (5ft 5in) tall, she wasn\u2019t built like a champion javelin thrower, but what she lacked in reach she made up for in determination: \u201cI had little room to manoeuvre where making mistakes was concerned, so I had to work exceptionally hard at analysing everybody\u2019s techniques and working out the best for me.\u201d What made her a good \u2013 at one stage, the best \u2013 thrower? \u201cI think the inner strength that I created as a child. If you asked me: \u2018Would I change anything about my life?\u2019 I\u2019d say no, because that created who I am. I had steely inner strength and a sense of determination to succeed because of my childhood. I possibly wouldn\u2019t have had that otherwise.\u201d She pauses. \u201cThere are some things you would have wanted to change.\u201d Whitbread had an incredible career \u2013 she was European and world champion and won bronze and silver at the 1984 and 1988 Olympics respectively. In 1986, she broke the world record with a throw of 77.44m. \u201cThat was a monumental experience,\u201d says Whitbread. As she let go of the javelin, she knew it was a good throw. \u201cThe hours and hours and hours of work that you put in, in order to get everything to click at the right time on the right day \u2026\u201d People told her it was the wrong day \u2013 it was the qualifying round for the European championships, so she had to go back and do it again. \u201cI just thought: I\u2019ll give it 100% and see what happens. I never allowed all that talk to get into there,\u201d she says, pointing at her head. \u201cI kept my mindset focused.\u201d She didn\u2019t manage to break her own record, but threw well enough to take gold. Much was made of her rivalry with the other British champion javelin thrower, Tessa Sanderson, who won the gold medal at the 1984 Olympics (Whitbread took bronze). \u201cBetween us, we achieved everything you could in an event. That\u2019s quite an astounding achievement for a country that wasn\u2019t known for its power events, so Tessa and I really flew that flag.\u201d The rivalry was real \u2013 although Whitbread says her main rival was East Germany\u2019s Petra Felke \u2013 but the media amped it up. Sanderson, who is a few years older, had been Whitbread\u2019s idol. Whitbread says she would have liked to have been friends. \u201cI thought there\u2019s nothing better than to be able to have a good friendship in an event where you can pull together. But everyone\u2019s different, aren\u2019t they? The media, what they instigated, it didn\u2019t lend itself very well [to friendship].\u201d Whitbread was aware of the comments in the media about her muscular physique. Did she care about that? \u201cIt\u2019s tools for the job,\u201d she says of her body. Had she been taller, maybe her muscles wouldn\u2019t have been so noticeable, but she was \u201cstubby\u201d, she says, laughing. \u201cBut I didn\u2019t care, because I loved what I did and that\u2019s what it took for me to succeed. I didn\u2019t take notice; I was just proud of my work ethos. But sometimes they could be unkind.\u201d As a child in the 80s, I say, I loved watching Whitbread and Sanderson \u2013 so strong and powerful, like warrior goddesses. She smiles: \u201cI think there were a lot of people who felt like that.\u201d Her success brought fame \u2013 and intrusion. The tabloids found her biological mother. The trauma resurfaced. \u201cIt forced me to have to tell my story. That was really the start of the demise in my athletic career, because it brought me to a physical and mental breakdown.\u201d While training for the 1988 Olympics, she was also writing a book about her childhood, to try to get control of her story. \u201cIt was awful. I shouldn\u2019t have gone to that Olympics, but I managed to pull on all my reserves and I came away with the silver medal.\u201d In the run-up, when she should have been training hard, she lost \u201call sense of time. My procrastination was terrible. When I was throwing, it was all over the place \u2013 30 metres, 40 metres, 70 metres.\u201d A shoulder injury, made worse by Whitbread\u2019s inability to train properly, ended her career officially in 1992. \u201cIt was eight years short, really,\u201d she says. \u201cIt was a big loss. For three or four years after that, when I went to championships, I would be watching with sadness, because I probably would still have been out there, winning.\u201d She had wanted more gold medals, including an Olympic one, and was aiming to throw more than 80m: \u201cI think I could have done.\u201d But it wasn\u2019t about the medals, she says. \u201cThe sense of loss, of identity and purpose, and then having to reinvent yourself in something that fills that void and the passion you had, is very hard.\u201d She went into sports marketing and did coaching and development. In 1997, she married Andy Norman, the controversial athletics promoter, with whom she had a son, Ryan, a year later. (Norman had been implicated by the coroner in the 1994 suicide of Cliff Temple, a Sunday Times journalist who had been investigating Norman\u2019s conduct as promotions officer of the British Athletics Federation.) After her traumatic childhood, she was determined that her son\u2019s would be different. \u201cI felt I would be a good mum,\u201d she says. \u201cI believed in myself. It was important for me to be able to prove that I could be a good mum and break the mould of what I\u2019d been through.\u201d She and Norman had experienced years of infertility, followed by a miscarriage, before their son was born via a third round of IVF. [{"id": "643693ec8f0885230b2d93c4", "bodyHtml": "<p>In the latest of the many lives of Fatima Whitbread, the former champion javelin thrower has become a formidable reality TV star \u2013 and it suits her. She is surely one good show away from \u201cbeloved\u201d status, which might prove to be the I\u2019m a Celebrity \u2026 Get Me Out of Here! spin-off in which she is soon to star, alongside a select group of other former participants in the ITV show.</p> <p>She was on I\u2019m a Celeb in 2011, when her nasal cavity became home to a cockroach during one of the challenges \u2013 \u201cThere\u2019s definitely something wriggling about in there!\u201d \u2013 and it took an hour for the camp doctor to flush it out. But I liked her best in last year\u2019s Celebrity SAS: Who Dares Wins, the Channel 4 series in which celebs do Special Forces training; Whitbread cracked three ribs jumping out of a helicopter, but kept it a secret because she didn\u2019t want to leave the show. She was charming, warm, capable and \u2013 having filmed it at 60 \u2013 ripped.</p> <p>This morning, she has been out exercising for two hours. She does an hour of cardio or weights every day. Even her jack russell terrier, Bertie, is ageing well; the vet remarked recently on his good health. \u201cThey said he\u2019s got a heartbeat like an athlete,\u201d says Whitbread, smiling. That is what you get when you are owned by an Olympic medallist and former world champion who once broke the women\u2019s javelin world record. Bertie sits between us on a large sofa in Whitbread\u2019s spotless, clutter-free home in Essex. The only hint at the greatness of her sporting career is a bronze cast of her hand, strong fingers wrapped around a javelin\u2019s grip, given to her by Madame Tussauds.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"6a48fa868da9b7bdefd00c4ecb844afb410c0253\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/6a48fa868da9b7bdefd00c4ecb844afb410c0253/0_0_6558_4372/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Fatima Whitbread with her dog, Bertie\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">With her dog, Bertie.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Teri Pengilley/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Whitbread, 62, has led an extraordinary life. This decade has been defined so far by physical and psychological challenges. Last year, as well as the SAS show, she climbed Mont Blanc. About a year ago, for the first time, she started having therapy (even when she had a breakdown in her 20s, she powered through without professional help). \u201cI\u2019ve realised I\u2019ve done bloody marvellous without it, but sometimes things trigger and all those childhood years can come back to haunt you,\u201d she says.</p> <p>As a baby, Whitbread was abandoned in a flat in London and essentially left to die. After hearing her cries, neighbours called the police. Whitbread recovered in hospital from malnutrition, dehydration and her terrible physical condition, then spent her childhood in children\u2019s homes. \u201cI felt this deep sense of loss within me,\u201d she says. When she was five, she was introduced to her biological mother \u2013 having had no idea of her history \u2013 and moved to a children\u2019s home in Essex, where she had two half-siblings. \u201cThat was the first time I started questioning what was going on in my life and what was to become of me.\u201d</p> <p>It was a life of deprivation, physical and emotional. There wasn\u2019t enough food and they had few clothes. The children played in a cold garage with a concrete floor. Love and affection were scant. She was abandoned again and again. Occasionally, her biological mother would arrive to take her half-siblings home for a visit, but not Whitbread. Once, the woman she calls \u201cthe biological mother\u201d, never \u201cmy biological mother\u201d \u2013 a Turkish Cypriot woman who spoke almost no English \u2013 did take her, but changed her mind and sent her back to the home.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"390a076b008f699e8a019067d827428272c5a82b\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/390a076b008f699e8a019067d827428272c5a82b/0_0_3500_2334/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Fatima Whitbread with Ferne McCann on Celebrity SAS: Who Dares Wins in 2022\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Whitbread with Ferne McCann on Celebrity SAS: Who Dares Wins in 2022.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Pete Dadds/Channel 4/PA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Whitbread\u2019s biological father, a Greek Cypriot, also surfaced. She spent a week with him, with the promise that he would be back to collect her again the weekend after, but he didn\u2019t appear. \u201cI sat on the front wall for a whole weekend,\u201d she says. \u201cThe second weekend, I did the same thing. I think that cracked me, emotionally. I put these walls up around myself to secure me.\u201d</p> <p>The only person who showed Whitbread any love was a woman who worked in the home, known as Auntie Rae. It was Rae who stopped Whitbread\u2019s biological mother, who arrived one day with three men, from taking her out of the home. Rae\u2019s suspicions proved horrifyingly true: at a later date, when her biological mother was able to take her to London for a while, 11-year-old Whitbread was raped by a man who was staying at the flat.</p> <p>Back at the children\u2019s home and traumatised, Whitbread refused to go to school. \u201cI just became withdrawn. Having not spoken to anyone about it, I felt ashamed, dirty.\u201d Eventually, she told Rae what had happened. Whitbread says it was reported, but nothing was done (she was referred to a child psychologist for a couple of weeks). \u201cUnbelievable what went on back then. You were never taken seriously. We had a social worker and I would talk to him about it. Nothing ever happened. Nobody took notice of the kids.\u201d</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>Sport gave me a sense of freedom, forgetting all the problems that were going on in the home</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>Is she angry at the system that failed her so spectacularly? \u201cWell, it does make me \u2026\u201d She pauses. \u201cEven today, some of the crazy policies \u2013 ousting kids [from care] at 16 is appalling. My son still lives at home; he\u2019s 25. At 16, these are vulnerable kids.\u201d At present, councils are allowed to put 16- and 17-year-old children in unregulated accommodation, although <a href=\"https://www.gov.uk/government/news/government-bans-unregulated-accommodation-for-young-people-in-care\" title=\"\">a ban on the practice</a> will come into force in October. \u201cFor a lot of young kids, history starts repeating itself: they start getting in trouble, or offending, and it costs the state a whole lot more. These young kids need that support, because once they get out there they\u2019re easily preyed upon. They\u2019re still kids.\u201d</p> <p>She worries about the cost of living crisis, inequality and poverty: \u201cThe kids are the ones that are getting the damage done.\u201d</p> <p>Sport saved her, she says. \u201cIt gave me a sense of freedom, forgetting all the problems that were going on in the home and the life we were living. It gave me a sense of achievement, that here was something I was good at. I got validation from my PE teachers and my school friends and started to realise life was a bit more positive. I realised that this could be my way out.\u201d</p> <p>Whitbread became the school netball captain and started going to a local athletics club. The javelin coach, Margaret Whitbread, recognised her talent. When she found out Whitbread lived in a children\u2019s home, she gave her some secondhand boots and a javelin. When Whitbread was grounded for a month, she managed to get a note to Margaret, fearing the coach would think she had left. She wrote that she hoped Margaret would take her back and that she intended to become the best javelin thrower in the world. \u201cIt was the start of a dream,\u201d says Whitbread.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"1ce9cea740e69338cabf403dfe3f36a0c4d714a3\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/1ce9cea740e69338cabf403dfe3f36a0c4d714a3/0_0_5244_3592/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Fatima Whitbread the Commonwealth Games in Edmonton, Canada, in 1978\" width=\"1000\" height=\"685\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">At the Commonwealth Games in Edmonton, Canada, in 1978.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Tony Duffy/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Margaret and her husband eventually fostered Whitbread, who changed her surname, Vedad, by deed poll. At 14, she finally had a family, which included the Whitbreads\u2019 two young sons. \u201cThat was amazing, the best thing that happened, to be a part of a family, which I\u2019d always wanted,\u201d she says. \u201cIt wasn\u2019t straightforward, because all families have their problems. Both as mum and daughter and athlete and coach, we worked it out somehow \u2013 and we conquered the world.\u201d</p> <p>Whitbread began training hard. \u201cI started taking more responsibility for myself,\u201d she says. \u201cYou have a whole lot of people that help you, but I\u2019ve got to get myself out at 5am, down the gym, three times a day training, seven days a week.\u201d She trained in a wooden shed at the bottom of the garden of a family friend. She smiles when she talks about how different facilities are now: \u201cI wouldn\u2019t have had it any other way. I loved every minute of it.\u201d</p> <p>Just two years later, in 1979, Whitbread was crowned European junior champion \u2013 becoming the first British woman to hold the title. At less than 1.65 metres (5ft 5in) tall, she wasn\u2019t built like a champion javelin thrower, but what she lacked in reach she made up for in determination: \u201cI had little room to manoeuvre where making mistakes was concerned, so I had to work exceptionally hard at analysing everybody\u2019s techniques and working out the best for me.\u201d</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>After retiring, the sense of loss, of identity and purpose, is very hard</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>What made her a good \u2013 at one stage, the best \u2013 thrower? \u201cI think the inner strength that I created as a child. If you asked me: \u2018Would I change anything about my life?\u2019 I\u2019d say no, because that created who I am. I had steely inner strength and a sense of determination to succeed because of my childhood. I possibly wouldn\u2019t have had that otherwise.\u201d She pauses. \u201cThere are some things you would have wanted to change.\u201d</p> <p>Whitbread had an incredible career \u2013 she was European and world champion and won bronze and silver at the 1984 and 1988 Olympics respectively. In 1986, she broke the world record with a throw of 77.44m. \u201cThat was a monumental experience,\u201d says Whitbread. As she let go of the javelin, she knew it was a good throw. \u201cThe hours and hours and hours of work that you put in, in order to get everything to click at the right time on the right day \u2026\u201d</p> <p>People told her it was the wrong day \u2013 it was the qualifying round for the European championships, so she had to go back and do it again. \u201cI just thought: I\u2019ll give it 100% and see what happens. I never allowed all that talk to get into there,\u201d she says, pointing at her head. \u201cI kept my mindset focused.\u201d She didn\u2019t manage to break her own record, but threw well enough to take gold.</p> <p>Much was made of her rivalry with the other British champion javelin thrower, Tessa Sanderson, who won the gold medal at the 1984 Olympics (Whitbread took bronze). \u201cBetween us, we achieved everything you could in an event. That\u2019s quite an astounding achievement for a country that wasn\u2019t known for its power events, so Tessa and I really flew that flag.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"8f3af0c2d2f986ebff22f6ff578307220a5e3cb6\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/8f3af0c2d2f986ebff22f6ff578307220a5e3cb6/0_0_3432_4345/790.jpg\" alt=\"Fatima Whitbread with her bronze medal at the 1984 Olympics\" width=\"790\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">With her bronze medal at the 1984 Olympics.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Tony Duffy/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The rivalry was real \u2013 although Whitbread says her main rival was East Germany\u2019s Petra Felke \u2013 but the media amped it up. Sanderson, who is a few years older, had been Whitbread\u2019s idol. Whitbread says she would have liked to have been friends. \u201cI thought there\u2019s nothing better than to be able to have a good friendship in an event where you can pull together. But everyone\u2019s different, aren\u2019t they? The media, what they instigated, it didn\u2019t lend itself very well [to friendship].\u201d</p> <p>Whitbread was aware of the comments in the media about her muscular physique. Did she care about that? \u201cIt\u2019s tools for the job,\u201d she says of her body. Had she been taller, maybe her muscles wouldn\u2019t have been so noticeable, but she was \u201cstubby\u201d, she says, laughing. \u201cBut I didn\u2019t care, because I loved what I did and that\u2019s what it took for me to succeed. I didn\u2019t take notice; I was just proud of my work ethos. But sometimes they could be unkind.\u201d</p> <p>As a child in the 80s, I say, I loved watching Whitbread and Sanderson \u2013 so strong and powerful, like warrior goddesses. She smiles: \u201cI think there were a lot of people who felt like that.\u201d</p> <p>Her success brought fame \u2013 and intrusion. The tabloids found her biological mother. The trauma resurfaced. \u201cIt forced me to have to tell my story. That was really the start of the demise in my athletic career, because it brought me to a physical and mental breakdown.\u201d While training for the 1988 Olympics, she was also writing a book about her childhood, to try to get control of her story. \u201cIt was awful. I shouldn\u2019t have gone to that Olympics, but I managed to pull on all my reserves and I came away with the silver medal.\u201d</p> <p>In the run-up, when she should have been training hard, she lost \u201call sense of time. My procrastination was terrible. When I was throwing, it was all over the place \u2013 30 metres, 40 metres, 70 metres.\u201d</p> <p>A shoulder injury, made worse by Whitbread\u2019s inability to train properly, ended her career officially in 1992. \u201cIt was eight years short, really,\u201d she says. \u201cIt was a big loss. For three or four years after that, when I went to championships, I would be watching with sadness, because I probably would still have been out there, winning.\u201d</p> <p>She had wanted more gold medals, including an Olympic one, and was aiming to throw more than 80m: \u201cI think I could have done.\u201d But it wasn\u2019t about the medals, she says. \u201cThe sense of loss, of identity and purpose, and then having to reinvent yourself in something that fills that void and the passion you had, is very hard.\u201d She went into sports marketing and did coaching and development.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"beae0badda6c05282cbc487a3466bae9ab1e95dd\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/beae0badda6c05282cbc487a3466bae9ab1e95dd/0_0_3746_2483/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Fatima Whitbread with Andy Norman in 1990\" width=\"1000\" height=\"663\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">With Andy Norman in 1990.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: John Gichigi/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>In 1997, she married Andy Norman, the controversial athletics promoter, with whom she had a son, Ryan, a year later. (Norman had been <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2007/sep/25/athletics.sport1\" title=\"\">implicated by the coroner</a> in the 1994 suicide of Cliff Temple, a Sunday Times journalist who had been investigating Norman\u2019s conduct as promotions officer of the British Athletics Federation.) After her traumatic childhood, she was determined that her son\u2019s would be different. \u201cI felt I would be a good mum,\u201d she says. \u201cI believed in myself. It was important for me to be able to prove that I could be a good mum and break the mould of what I\u2019d been through.\u201d</p> <p>She and Norman had experienced years of infertility, followed by a miscarriage, before their son was born via a third round of IVF. Norman left her for another athlete when Ryan was small, although he and Whitbread managed to remain close. Then, in 2007, he died suddenly, leaving Whitbread to raise Ryan alone. On top of that, it emerged that Norman had taken out loans, partly in Whitbread\u2019s name, which put her tens of thousands of pounds in debt. She had to sell the family home. The fees from reality TV kept her afloat and helped her rebuild her profile.</p> <p>She seems content, although a long friendship ended recently, which has saddened her: \u201cIt\u2019s not until something goes wrong in your life that everything else starts to come back and chase you.\u201d This is why she will stick at the therapy \u2013 she has found some kind of acceptance. The older she has got, she says, the more she has realised that \u201clife is about absorbing the good and the bad, learning from both and still moving forward\u201d. She made a choice, she says, not to feel angry or bitter. \u201cThat\u2019s only damaging to yourself. It blurs your vision, it doesn\u2019t allow you to progress. When I go back and talk to the five-year-old or the 11-year-old Fatima, I take her by the hand and say: don\u2019t worry, I\u2019ve got you now.\u201d</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "In the latest of the many lives of Fatima Whitbread, the former champion javelin thrower has become a formidable reality TV star \u2013 and it suits her. She is surely one good show away from \u201cbeloved\u201d status, which might prove to be the I\u2019m a Celebrity \u2026 Get Me Out of Here! spin-off in which she is soon to star, alongside a select group of other former participants in the ITV show. But I liked her best in last year\u2019s Celebrity SAS: Who Dares Wins, the Channel 4 series in which celebs do Special Forces training; Whitbread cracked three ribs jumping out of a helicopter, but kept it a secret because she didn\u2019t want to leave the show. She was charming, warm, capable and \u2013 having filmed it at 60 \u2013 ripped. This morning, she has been out exercising for two hours. She does an hour of cardio or weights every day. At 14, she finally had a family, which included the Whitbreads\u2019 two young sons. \u201cThat was amazing, the best thing that happened, to be a part of a family, which I\u2019d always wanted,\u201d she says. \u201cIt wasn\u2019t straightforward, because all families have their problems. Both as mum and daughter and athlete and coach, we worked it out somehow \u2013 and we conquered the world.\u201d Whitbread began training hard. \u201cI started taking more responsibility for myself,\u201d she says. \u201cYou have a whole lot of people that help you, but I\u2019ve got to get myself out at 5am, down the gym, three times a day training, seven days a week.\u201d She trained in a wooden shed at the bottom of the garden of a family friend. She smiles when she talks about how different facilities are now: \u201cI wouldn\u2019t have had it any other way. I loved every minute of it.\u201d Just two years later, in 1979, Whitbread was crowned European junior champion \u2013 becoming the first British woman to hold the title. At less than 1.65 metres (5ft 5in) tall, she wasn\u2019t built like a champion javelin thrower, but what she lacked in reach she made up for in determination: \u201cI had little room to manoeuvre where making mistakes was concerned, so I had to work exceptionally hard at analysing everybody\u2019s techniques and working out the best for me.\u201d\nWhat made her a good \u2013 at one stage, the best \u2013 thrower? \u201cI think the inner strength that I created as a child. If you asked me: \u2018Would I change anything about my life?\u2019 I\u2019d say no, because that created who I am. I had steely inner strength and a sense of determination to succeed because of my childhood. I possibly wouldn\u2019t have had that otherwise.\u201d She pauses. \u201cThere are some things you would have wanted to change.\u201d Whitbread had an incredible career \u2013 she was European and world champion and won bronze and silver at the 1984 and 1988 Olympics respectively. In 1986, she broke the world record with a throw of 77.44m. \u201cThat was a monumental experience,\u201d says Whitbread. As she let go of the javelin, she knew it was a good throw. \u201cThe hours and hours and hours of work that you put in, in order to get everything to click at the right time on the right day \u2026\u201d People told her it was the wrong day \u2013 it was the qualifying round for the European championships, so she had to go back and do it again. \u201cI just thought: I\u2019ll give it 100% and see what happens. I never allowed all that talk to get into there,\u201d she says, pointing at her head. \u201cI kept my mindset focused.\u201d She didn\u2019t manage to break her own record, but threw well enough to take gold. Much was made of her rivalry with the other British champion javelin thrower, Tessa Sanderson, who won the gold medal at the 1984 Olympics (Whitbread took bronze). \u201cBetween us, we achieved everything you could in an event. That\u2019s quite an astounding achievement for a country that wasn\u2019t known for its power events, so Tessa and I really flew that flag.\u201d\nThe rivalry was real \u2013 although Whitbread says her main rival was East Germany\u2019s Petra Felke \u2013 but the media amped it up. Sanderson, who is a few years older, had been Whitbread\u2019s idol. Whitbread says she would have liked to have been friends. \u201cI thought there\u2019s nothing better than to be able to have a good friendship in an event where you can pull together. But everyone\u2019s different, aren\u2019t they? The media, what they instigated, it didn\u2019t lend itself very well [to friendship].\u201d Whitbread was aware of the comments in the media about her muscular physique. Did she care about that? \u201cIt\u2019s tools for the job,\u201d she says of her body. Had she been taller, maybe her muscles wouldn\u2019t have been so noticeable, but she was \u201cstubby\u201d, she says, laughing. \u201cBut I didn\u2019t care, because I loved what I did and that\u2019s what it took for me to succeed. I didn\u2019t take notice; I was just proud of my work ethos. But sometimes they could be unkind.\u201d As a child in the 80s, I say, I loved watching Whitbread and Sanderson \u2013 so strong and powerful, like warrior goddesses. She smiles: \u201cI think there were a lot of people who felt like that.\u201d Her success brought fame \u2013 and intrusion. The tabloids found her biological mother. The trauma resurfaced. \u201cIt forced me to have to tell my story. That was really the start of the demise in my athletic career, because it brought me to a physical and mental breakdown.\u201d While training for the 1988 Olympics, she was also writing a book about her childhood, to try to get control of her story. \u201cIt was awful. I shouldn\u2019t have gone to that Olympics, but I managed to pull on all my reserves and I came away with the silver medal.\u201d In the run-up, when she should have been training hard, she lost \u201call sense of time. My procrastination was terrible. When I was throwing, it was all over the place \u2013 30 metres, 40 metres, 70 metres.\u201d A shoulder injury, made worse by Whitbread\u2019s inability to train properly, ended her career officially in 1992. \u201cIt was eight years short, really,\u201d she says. \u201cIt was a big loss. For three or four years after that, when I went to championships, I would be watching with sadness, because I probably would still have been out there, winning.\u201d She had wanted more gold medals, including an Olympic one, and was aiming to throw more than 80m: \u201cI think I could have done.\u201d But it wasn\u2019t about the medals, she says. \u201cThe sense of loss, of identity and purpose, and then having to reinvent yourself in something that fills that void and the passion you had, is very hard.\u201d She went into sports marketing and did coaching and development.\nIn 1997, she married Andy Norman, the controversial athletics promoter, with whom she had a son, Ryan, a year later. (Norman had been implicated by the coroner in the 1994 suicide of Cliff Temple, a Sunday Times journalist who had been investigating Norman\u2019s conduct as promotions officer of the British Athletics Federation.) After her traumatic childhood, she was determined that her son\u2019s would be different. \u201cI felt I would be a good mum,\u201d she says. \u201cI believed in myself. It was important for me to be able to prove that I could be a good mum and break the mould of what I\u2019d been through.\u201d She and Norman had experienced years of infertility, followed by a miscarriage, before their son was born via a third round of IVF. Norman left her for another athlete when Ryan was small, although he and Whitbread managed to remain close. Then, in 2007, he died suddenly, leaving Whitbread to raise Ryan alone. On top of that, it emerged that Norman had taken out loans, partly in Whitbread\u2019s name, which put her tens of thousands of pounds in debt. She had to sell the family home. The fees from reality TV kept her afloat and helped her rebuild her profile. She seems content, although a long friendship ended recently, which has saddened her: \u201cIt\u2019s not until something goes wrong in your life that everything else starts to come back and chase you.\u201d This is why she will stick at the therapy \u2013 she has found some kind of acceptance. The older she has got, she says, the more she has realised that \u201clife is about absorbing the good and the bad, learning from both and still moving forward\u201d. She made a choice, she says, not to feel angry or bitter. \u201cThat\u2019s only damaging to yourself. It blurs your vision, it doesn\u2019t allow you to progress. Had she been taller, maybe her muscles wouldn\u2019t have been so noticeable, but she was \u201cstubby\u201d, she says, laughing. \u201cBut I didn\u2019t care, because I loved what I did and that\u2019s what it took for me to succeed. I didn\u2019t take notice; I was just proud of my work ethos. But sometimes they could be unkind.\u201d</p> \n<p>As a child in the 80s, I say, I loved watching Whitbread and Sanderson \u2013 so strong and powerful, like warrior goddesses. She smiles: \u201cI think there were a lot of people who felt like that.\u201d</p> \n<p>Her success brought fame \u2013 and intrusion. The tabloids found her biological mother. The trauma resurfaced. \u201cIt forced me to have to tell my story. That was really the start of the demise in my athletic career, because it brought me to a physical and mental breakdown.\u201d While training for the 1988 Olympics, she was also writing a book about her childhood, to try to get control of her story. \u201cIt was awful. I shouldn\u2019t have gone to that Olympics, but I managed to pull on all my reserves and I came away with the silver medal.\u201d</p> \n<p>In the run-up, when she should have been training hard, she lost \u201call sense of time. My procrastination was terrible. When I was throwing, it was all over the place \u2013 30 metres, 40 metres, 70 metres.\u201d</p> \n<p>A shoulder injury, made worse by Whitbread\u2019s inability to train properly, ended her career officially in 1992. \u201cIt was eight years short, really,\u201d she says. \u201cIt was a big loss. For three or four years after that, when I went to championships, I would be watching with sadness, because I probably would still have been out there, winning.\u201d</p> \n<p>She had wanted more gold medals, including an Olympic one, and was aiming to throw more than 80m: \u201cI think I could have done.\u201d But it wasn\u2019t about the medals, she says. \u201cThe sense of loss, of identity and purpose, and then having to reinvent yourself in something that fills that void and the passion you had, is very hard.\u201d She went into sports marketing and did coaching and development.</p>"}}, {"html": "<p>In 1997, she married Andy Norman, the controversial athletics promoter, with whom she had a son, Ryan, a year later. (Norman had been <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2007/sep/25/athletics.sport1\" title=\"\">implicated by the coroner</a> in the 1994 suicide of Cliff Temple, a Sunday Times journalist who had been investigating Norman\u2019s conduct as promotions officer of the British Athletics Federation.) After her traumatic childhood, she was determined that her son\u2019s would be different. \u201cI felt I would be a good mum,\u201d she says. \u201cI believed in myself. It was important for me to be able to prove that I could be a good mum and break the mould of what I\u2019d been through.\u201d</p> \n<p>She and Norman had experienced years of infertility, followed by a miscarriage, before their son was born via a third round of IVF. Norman left her for another athlete when Ryan was small, although he and Whitbread managed to remain close. Then, in 2007, he died suddenly, leaving Whitbread to raise Ryan alone. On top of that, it emerged that Norman had taken out loans, partly in Whitbread\u2019s name, which put her tens of thousands of pounds in debt. She had to sell the family home. The fees from reality TV kept her afloat and helped her rebuild her profile.</p> \n<p>She seems content, although a long friendship ended recently, which has saddened her: \u201cIt\u2019s not until something goes wrong in your life that everything else starts to come back and chase you.\u201d This is why she will stick at the therapy \u2013 she has found some kind of acceptance. The older she has got, she says, the more she has realised that \u201clife is about absorbing the good and the bad, learning from both and still moving forward\u201d. She made a choice, she says, not to feel angry or bitter. \u201cThat\u2019s only damaging to yourself. It blurs your vision, it doesn\u2019t allow you to progress. When I go back and talk to the five-year-old or the 11-year-old Fatima, I take her by the hand and say: don\u2019t worry, I\u2019ve got you now.\u201d</p>"}}]}], "totalBodyBlocks": 1}, "rights": {"syndicatable": "true", "subscriptionDatabases": "true", "developerCommunity": "true"}, "section": {"id": "lifeandstyle", "webTitle": "Life and style", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/lifeandstyle", "editions": [{"id": "lifeandstyle", "webTitle": "Life and style", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/lifeandstyle", "code": "default"}, {"id": "au/lifeandstyle", "webTitle": "Life and style", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/au/lifeandstyle", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/au/lifeandstyle", "code": "au"}, {"id": "uk/lifeandstyle", "webTitle": "Life and style", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/uk/lifeandstyle", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/uk/lifeandstyle", "code": "uk"}, {"id": "us/lifeandstyle", "webTitle": "Life and style", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/us/lifeandstyle", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/us/lifeandstyle", "code": "us"}]}, "isHosted": false, "pillarId": "pillar/lifestyle", "pillarName": "Lifestyle"}, {"id": "commentisfree/2023/apr/17/british-pub-right-golliwogs-rightwing-politicians-press-racism-people-colour", "type": "article", "sectionId": "commentisfree", "sectionName": "Opinion", "webPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:33Z", "webTitle": "Is a British pub racist for displaying golliwogs? Think how that question makes people of colour like me feel | Nesrine Malik", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2023/apr/17/british-pub-right-golliwogs-rightwing-politicians-press-racism-people-colour", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/commentisfree/2023/apr/17/british-pub-right-golliwogs-rightwing-politicians-press-racism-people-colour", "fields": {"headline": "Is a British pub racist for displaying golliwogs? Think how that question makes people of colour like me feel", "standfirst": "<p>We cope with the micro slights and othering. But what are we to do when openly racist attitudes are exploited for political gain?</p>", "trailText": "We cope with the micro slights and othering. But openly racist attitudes are being exploited for political gain, says the Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik", "byline": "Nesrine Malik", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"836fd6e88c5352358484e5363fdc38a9b615787a\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/836fd6e88c5352358484e5363fdc38a9b615787a/0_429_7373_4426/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Behind the bar at the White Hart Inn in Grays, Essex, from where police removed a display of golliwog dolls.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Behind the bar at the White Hart Inn in Grays, Essex, from where police removed a display of golliwog dolls.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: David Levene/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>There is something particularly grotesque about a golliwog. It\u2019s the smile, I think, its teeth frozen in a rictus grin behind the exaggerated redness of the lips. The golliwog seems to say that not only is it OK to \u201cminstrelise\u201d black people and display them as dolls, but that they should enjoy it.</p> <p>That smile is the price of entry into white British society, of acceptance and integration into workplaces, social groups and our wider politics and culture. The golliwog, despite it being a relic of the past, is in fact a symbol of the present. You are only allowed visibility as a black figure if you\u2019re grateful, permanently smiling in all circumstances. Your status, as someone who is part of Britain and therefore gets a say in how they experience it, is conditional on the fact that you must never suggest that the country is not quite so hospitable to you sometimes. Ideally, if you want social and professional mobility as a person of colour, if you want to be moved from the bottom shelf to a position of higher prominence, you must go further. You must grin harder and always maintain that Britain is, in fact, a race-relations utopia, even as things regularly happen that prove that we are far from that.</p> <p>Let\u2019s take just last week. A pub in Essex had its <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/13/essex-police-investigating-golliwog-pub-display-examine-landlord-lynching-post\">collection of golliwogs confiscated</a>, after which they were promptly <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/11/essex-pub-landlady-benice-ryley-replaces-golliwog-doll-collection-that-was-seized-by-police\">replaced with a new collection</a> by the landlady, who refuses to accept that they are racist. Some of the new golliwogs she says were sent in by sympathetic supporters. In the same week, a <a href=\"https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/tory-councillor-white-men-black-slave-andrew-edwards-b2319335.html\">Tory councillor was suspended</a> after he was reportedly recorded saying \u201call white men should have a Black slave\u201d and that black people \u201care a lower class than us white people\u201d. Neither of these incidents suggest that Britain is a uniformly racist place, but clearly, I think it\u2019s safe to say, something is going on.</p> <p>And that something is that it is possible for a society to make large strides towards racial equality, and still be meaningfully prejudiced in ways that make life difficult and uncomfortable for a significant number of people of colour. This is not a complicated fact. Racism isn\u2019t a disease that is cured by a single shot of medicine, it\u2019s a combination of attitudes and social values around which there are varying levels of agreement. We have agreed, for example, that you can\u2019t say the N-word. But, it seems, not against the hanging of golliwogs in public places, as the pub landlord <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/13/essex-police-investigating-golliwog-pub-display-examine-landlord-lynching-post\">commented on a Facebook post</a>, the way \u201cthey used to hang them in Mississippi years ago\u201d. You might think we also agreed that we couldn\u2019t say white people should own black slaves, but it seems that even that is not a certainty.</p> <p>Constantly realising all the questions you thought were settled are in fact not, is my abiding experience of being a non-white Briton. Along with those realisations comes a queasy sense of foreboding, because I know that suggesting that all might not be well in Britain on the race front isn\u2019t going to be pretty. In choosing not to smile, there is a price to pay. You\u2019ll have to be subjected to the usual: that you are oversensitive, woke, and in fact, actually the one making it about race when it\u2019s just some dolls hanging like they used to hang black folk in Mississippi. Despite all recent fictions about Black Lives Matter (BLM) ushering in an age of deference to black people, one only has to look at how race incidents are discussed in our politics, and our media, to see that our group response to expressing discomfort about race isn\u2019t exactly \u201clet me kneel in solidarity this very moment\u201d.</p> <p>Any questions asked of the appropriateness of our symbols or historical legacies is not merely met with a lack of deference, but with punishment. Students who suggest modifying curriculums are <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/oct/25/decolonise-cambridge-university-row-attack-students-colour-lola-olufemi-curriculums\">mauled in the press</a>; others who campaign against systemic racism, such as BLMUK, are <a href=\"https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2021/02/07/exclusive-far-left-influence-black-lives-matter-extinctionrebellion/\">investigated</a> for something called \u201cprogressive extremism\u201d and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2021/feb/22/culture-war-chilling-effect-equality-government-rightwing-press\">struggle to open bank accounts</a> to disburse funds raised to support precariously employed and housed people. People such as Ngozi Fulani, who had the misfortune of expecting enlightened views of the royal household, are <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/mar/08/ngozi-fulani-sistah-space-charity-boss-at-centre-of-royal-race-row-steps-down-over-abuse\">savaged</a> by the press and, in turn, members of the public, for pointing out that it\u2019s not very nice to be aggressively asked where you are from.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/13/essex-police-investigating-golliwog-pub-display-examine-landlord-lynching-post\">Essex police examine golly doll pub landlord\u2019s \u2018racist\u2019 Facebook posts</a> </p> </aside>  <p>It\u2019s a sort of law of racial gravity \u2013 for every claim of a racist action there is a wildly unequal and disproportionate reaction. Most of the time I don\u2019t particularly care about who asked whom where they were from, or if there\u2019s a pub that wants to display golliwogs. Sometimes I actively will myself not to care, because really, in the grand scheme of things these are relatively small incidents that do not make up the sum total of the experience of being a person of colour in the UK. But one is forced into a state of outrage by a government and media that then throw their weight behind the aggressors. If we can be convinced that there is a powerful onslaught against the good British people and their history and traditions by radical leftwing identity politics, then maybe there\u2019s a chance we can be distracted from the colossal failures of the last 13 years.</p> <p>The home secretary, Suella Braverman, apparently found time to let it be known that she had <a href=\"https://news.sky.com/story/suella-braverman-makes-views-very-plain-to-police-over-golliwog-doll-seizure-from-essex-pub-12854721\">rebuked</a> the police for getting involved in the golliwog matter. In truth, according to weekend reports, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/10/essex-police-deny-braverman-rebuked-them-over-pub-seizure-of-golliwog-dolls\">no real attempt</a> was made by Braverman to contact Essex police. But no matter, for that starts a process. A columnist in the Telegraph laments the demonisation of the innocent golliwog and <a href=\"https://www.telegraph.co.uk/columnists/2023/04/11/police-arrest-golly-doll-essex-toys-suella-braverman/\">says your teddy bears could be next</a>. The matter then becomes not one of outliers and hold-outs, but rightwing state and media sanction of their positions. The result is an encouragement and entrenchment of racist views, that is a constant drag on a Britain that is <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/society/2022/sep/22/majority-of-uk-public-agree-with-liberal-views-on-race-and-sexual-identity-annual-poll\">becoming increasingly enlightened</a> on race.</p> <p>Racism as individuals acting out is ultimately a diversion from racism as threat to life and liberty. In the same week that golliwogs dominated, it was revealed that black girls are <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/06/black-girls-three-times-more-likely-to-undergo-invasive-strip-search-by-met-police\">three times more likely</a> to undergo an invasive strip-search by Met police than white girls, and that <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/09/britain-not-close-to-being-a-racially-just-society-finds-two-year-research-project\">more than a third</a> of people from ethnic and religious minorities have experienced racially motivated physical or verbal abuse. But when the Home Office gets involved to protect the right to insult you, then you have to care about golliwogs too. Because now they are now a matter of national debate, of dinner party conversations and school playground taunting, and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/YouGov/status/1646151432780009472\">actual YouGov polling</a> that asks if golliwogs are racist \u2013 a swirling national discourse in which the final arbiter of what is racist is never you.</p> <p>It\u2019s dizzying, trying to calibrate the appropriate response to these travesties, because, yes, of course things are getting better. But they are also getting worse, because the frontier for what constitutes racial equality is always shifting. The questions are new: not ones of civil rights, but of all the cultural adjustments that are required to make people of colour feel at home and equal, not erased from history, not subject to the glorification of imperial overlords, not having to drink a pint as a golliwog hangs over them or as a nation debates whether they should be forced to. It\u2019s an awful lot of contempt to carry around with you, while simultaneously disciplining and reminding yourself that it\u2019s not all this nation has to offer. So forgive me, for not smiling.</p> <ul> <li><p>Nesrine Malik is a Guardian columnist</p></li> </ul>", "newspaperPageNumber": "3", "wordcount": "1279", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:33Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T05:00:33Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-17T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnvmm", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/836fd6e88c5352358484e5363fdc38a9b615787a/0_429_7373_4426/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "There is something particularly grotesque about a golliwog.
