"bodyHtml": "<p>There is something particularly grotesque about a golliwog. It\u2019s the smile, I think, its teeth frozen in a rictus grin behind the exaggerated redness of the lips. The golliwog seems to say that not only is it OK to \u201cminstrelise\u201d black people and display them as dolls, but that they should enjoy it.</p> <p>That smile is the price of entry into white British society, of acceptance and integration into workplaces, social groups and our wider politics and culture. The golliwog, despite it being a relic of the past, is in fact a symbol of the present. You are only allowed visibility as a black figure if you\u2019re grateful, permanently smiling in all circumstances. Your status, as someone who is part of Britain and therefore gets a say in how they experience it, is conditional on the fact that you must never suggest that the country is not quite so hospitable to you sometimes. Ideally, if you want social and professional mobility as a person of colour, if you want to be moved from the bottom shelf to a position of higher prominence, you must go further. You must grin harder and always maintain that Britain is, in fact, a race-relations utopia, even as things regularly happen that prove that we are far from that.</p> <p>Let\u2019s take just last week. A pub in Essex had its <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/13/essex-police-investigating-golliwog-pub-display-examine-landlord-lynching-post\">collection of golliwogs confiscated</a>, after which they were promptly <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/11/essex-pub-landlady-benice-ryley-replaces-golliwog-doll-collection-that-was-seized-by-police\">replaced with a new collection</a> by the landlady, who refuses to accept that they are racist. Some of the new golliwogs she says were sent in by sympathetic supporters. In the same week, a <a href=\"https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/tory-councillor-white-men-black-slave-andrew-edwards-b2319335.html\">Tory councillor was suspended</a> after he was reportedly recorded saying \u201call white men should have a Black slave\u201d and that black people \u201care a lower class than us white people\u201d. Neither of these incidents suggest that Britain is a uniformly racist place, but clearly, I think it\u2019s safe to say, something is going on.</p> <p>And that something is that it is possible for a society to make large strides towards racial equality, and still be meaningfully prejudiced in ways that make life difficult and uncomfortable for a significant number of people of colour. This is not a complicated fact. Racism isn\u2019t a disease that is cured by a single shot of medicine, it\u2019s a combination of attitudes and social values around which there are varying levels of agreement. We have agreed, for example, that you can\u2019t say the N-word. But, it seems, not against the hanging of golliwogs in public places, as the pub landlord <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/13/essex-police-investigating-golliwog-pub-display-examine-landlord-lynching-post\">commented on a Facebook post</a>, the way \u201cthey used to hang them in Mississippi years ago\u201d. You might think we also agreed that we couldn\u2019t say white people should own black slaves, but it seems that even that is not a certainty.</p> <p>Constantly realising all the questions you thought were settled are in fact not, is my abiding experience of being a non-white Briton. Along with those realisations comes a queasy sense of foreboding, because I know that suggesting that all might not be well in Britain on the race front isn\u2019t going to be pretty. In choosing not to smile, there is a price to pay. You\u2019ll have to be subjected to the usual: that you are oversensitive, woke, and in fact, actually the one making it about race when it\u2019s just some dolls hanging like they used to hang black folk in Mississippi. Despite all recent fictions about Black Lives Matter (BLM) ushering in an age of deference to black people, one only has to look at how race incidents are discussed in our politics, and our media, to see that our group response to expressing discomfort about race isn\u2019t exactly \u201clet me kneel in solidarity this very moment\u201d.</p> <p>Any questions asked of the appropriateness of our symbols or historical legacies is not merely met with a lack of deference, but with punishment. Students who suggest modifying curriculums are <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/oct/25/decolonise-cambridge-university-row-attack-students-colour-lola-olufemi-curriculums\">mauled in the press</a>; others who campaign against systemic racism, such as BLMUK, are <a href=\"https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2021/02/07/exclusive-far-left-influence-black-lives-matter-extinctionrebellion/\">investigated</a> for something called \u201cprogressive extremism\u201d and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2021/feb/22/culture-war-chilling-effect-equality-government-rightwing-press\">struggle to open bank accounts</a> to disburse funds raised to support precariously employed and housed people. People such as Ngozi Fulani, who had the misfortune of expecting enlightened views of the royal household, are <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/mar/08/ngozi-fulani-sistah-space-charity-boss-at-centre-of-royal-race-row-steps-down-over-abuse\">savaged</a> by the press and, in turn, members of the public, for pointing out that it\u2019s not very nice to be aggressively asked where you are from.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/13/essex-police-investigating-golliwog-pub-display-examine-landlord-lynching-post\">Essex police examine golly doll pub landlord\u2019s \u2018racist\u2019 Facebook posts</a> </p> </aside>  <p>It\u2019s a sort of law of racial gravity \u2013 for every claim of a racist action there is a wildly unequal and disproportionate reaction. Most of the time I don\u2019t particularly care about who asked whom where they were from, or if there\u2019s a pub that wants to display golliwogs. Sometimes I actively will myself not to care, because really, in the grand scheme of things these are relatively small incidents that do not make up the sum total of the experience of being a person of colour in the UK. But one is forced into a state of outrage by a government and media that then throw their weight behind the aggressors. If we can be convinced that there is a powerful onslaught against the good British people and their history and traditions by radical leftwing identity politics, then maybe there\u2019s a chance we can be distracted from the colossal failures of the last 13 years.</p> <p>The home secretary, Suella Braverman, apparently found time to let it be known that she had <a href=\"https://news.sky.com/story/suella-braverman-makes-views-very-plain-to-police-over-golliwog-doll-seizure-from-essex-pub-12854721\">rebuked</a> the police for getting involved in the golliwog matter. In truth, according to weekend reports, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/10/essex-police-deny-braverman-rebuked-them-over-pub-seizure-of-golliwog-dolls\">no real attempt</a> was made by Braverman to contact Essex police. But no matter, for that starts a process. A columnist in the Telegraph laments the demonisation of the innocent golliwog and <a href=\"https://www.telegraph.co.uk/columnists/2023/04/11/police-arrest-golly-doll-essex-toys-suella-braverman/\">says your teddy bears could be next</a>. The matter then becomes not one of outliers and hold-outs, but rightwing state and media sanction of their positions. The result is an encouragement and entrenchment of racist views, that is a constant drag on a Britain that is <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/society/2022/sep/22/majority-of-uk-public-agree-with-liberal-views-on-race-and-sexual-identity-annual-poll\">becoming increasingly enlightened</a> on race.</p> <p>Racism as individuals acting out is ultimately a diversion from racism as threat to life and liberty. In the same week that golliwogs dominated, it was revealed that black girls are <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/06/black-girls-three-times-more-likely-to-undergo-invasive-strip-search-by-met-police\">three times more likely</a> to undergo an invasive strip-search by Met police than white girls, and that <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/09/britain-not-close-to-being-a-racially-just-society-finds-two-year-research-project\">more than a third</a> of people from ethnic and religious minorities have experienced racially motivated physical or verbal abuse. But when the Home Office gets involved to protect the right to insult you, then you have to care about golliwogs too. Because now they are now a matter of national debate, of dinner party conversations and school playground taunting, and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/YouGov/status/1646151432780009472\">actual YouGov polling</a> that asks if golliwogs are racist \u2013 a swirling national discourse in which the final arbiter of what is racist is never you.</p> <p>It\u2019s dizzying, trying to calibrate the appropriate response to these travesties, because, yes, of course things are getting better. But they are also getting worse, because the frontier for what constitutes racial equality is always shifting. The questions are new: not ones of civil rights, but of all the cultural adjustments that are required to make people of colour feel at home and equal, not erased from history, not subject to the glorification of imperial overlords, not having to drink a pint as a golliwog hangs over them or as a nation debates whether they should be forced to. It\u2019s an awful lot of contempt to carry around with you, while simultaneously disciplining and reminding yourself that it\u2019s not all this nation has to offer. So forgive me, for not smiling.</p> <ul> <li><p>Nesrine Malik is a Guardian columnist</p></li> </ul>", "bodyTextSummary": "There is something particularly grotesque about a golliwog. It\u2019s the smile, I think, its teeth frozen in a rictus grin behind the exaggerated redness of the lips. The golliwog seems to say that not only is it OK to \u201cminstrelise\u201d black people and display them as dolls, but that they should enjoy it. That smile is the price of entry into white British society, of acceptance and integration into workplaces, social groups and our wider politics and culture. The golliwog, despite it being a relic of the past, is in fact a symbol of the present. Your status, as someone who is part of Britain and therefore gets a say in how they experience it, is conditional on the fact that you must never suggest that the country is not quite so hospitable to you sometimes. Ideally, if you want social and professional mobility as a person of colour, if you want to be moved from the bottom shelf to a position of higher prominence, you must go further. You must grin harder and always maintain that Britain is, in fact, a race-relations utopia, even as things regularly happen that prove that we are far from that. Let\u2019s take just last week. A pub in Essex had its collection of golliwogs confiscated, after which they were promptly replaced with a new collection by the landlady, who refuses to accept that they are racist. Some of the new golliwogs she says were sent in by sympathetic supporters. In the same week, a Tory councillor was suspended after he was reportedly recorded saying \u201call white men should have a Black slave\u201d and that black people \u201care a lower class than us white people\u201d. Neither of these incidents suggest that Britain is a uniformly racist place, but clearly, I think it\u2019s safe to say, something is going on. And that something is that it is possible for a society to make large strides towards racial equality, and still be meaningfully prejudiced in ways that make life difficult and uncomfortable for a significant number of people of colour. This is not a complicated fact. Racism isn\u2019t a disease that is cured by a single shot of medicine, it\u2019s a combination of attitudes and social values around which there are varying levels of agreement. We have agreed, for example, that you can\u2019t say the N-word. But, it seems, not against the hanging of golliwogs in public places, as the pub landlord commented on a Facebook post, the way \u201cthey used to hang them in Mississippi years ago\u201d. You might think we also agreed that we couldn\u2019t say white people should own black slaves, but it seems that even that is not a certainty. Constantly realising all the questions you thought were settled are in fact not, is my abiding experience of being a non-white Briton. Along with those realisations comes a queasy sense of foreboding, because I know that suggesting that all might not be well in Britain on the race front isn\u2019t going to be pretty. In choosing not to smile, there is a price to pay. You\u2019ll have to be subjected to the usual: that you are oversensitive, woke, and in fact, actually the one making it about race when it\u2019s just some dolls hanging like they used to hang black folk in Mississippi. Despite all recent fictions about Black Lives Matter (BLM) ushering in an age of deference to black people, one only has to look at how race incidents are discussed in our politics, and our media, to see that our group response to expressing discomfort about race isn\u2019t exactly \u201clet me kneel in solidarity this very moment\u201d. Any questions asked of the appropriateness of our symbols or historical legacies is not merely met with a lack of deference, but with punishment. Students who suggest modifying curriculums are mauled in the press; others who campaign against systemic racism, such as BLMUK, are investigated for something called \u201cprogressive extremism\u201d and struggle to open bank accounts to disburse funds raised to support precariously employed and housed people. People such as Ngozi Fulani, who had the misfortune of expecting enlightened views of the royal household, are savaged by the press and, in turn, members of the public, for pointing out that it\u2019s not very nice to be aggressively asked where you are from.\nIt\u2019s a sort of law of racial gravity \u2013 for every claim of a racist action there is a wildly unequal and disproportionate reaction. Most of the time I don\u2019t particularly care about who asked whom where they were from, or if there\u2019s a pub that wants to display golliwogs. Sometimes I actively will myself not to care, because really, in the grand scheme of things these are relatively small incidents that do not make up the sum total of the experience of being a person of colour in the UK. But one is forced into a state of outrage by a government and media that then throw their weight behind the aggressors. If we can be convinced that there is a powerful onslaught against the good British people and their history and traditions by radical leftwing identity politics, then maybe there\u2019s a chance we can be distracted from the colossal failures of the last 13 years. The home secretary, Suella Braverman, apparently found time to let it be known that she had rebuked the police for getting involved in the golliwog matter. In truth, according to weekend reports, no real attempt was made by Braverman to contact Essex police. But no matter, for that starts a process. A columnist in the Telegraph laments the demonisation of the innocent golliwog and says your teddy bears could be next. The matter then becomes not one of outliers and hold-outs, but rightwing state and media sanction of their positions. The result is an encouragement and entrenchment of racist views, that is a constant drag on a Britain that is becoming increasingly enlightened on race. Racism as individuals acting out is ultimately a diversion from racism as threat to life and liberty. In the same week that golliwogs dominated, it was revealed that black girls are three times more likely to undergo an invasive strip-search by Met police than white girls, and that more than a third of people from ethnic and religious minorities have experienced racially motivated physical or verbal abuse. But when the Home Office gets involved to protect the right to insult you, then you have to care about golliwogs too. Because now they are now a matter of national debate, of dinner party conversations and school playground taunting, and actual YouGov polling that asks if golliwogs are racist \u2013 a swirling national discourse in which the final arbiter of what is racist is never you. It\u2019s dizzying, trying to calibrate the appropriate response to these travesties, because, yes, of course things are getting better. But they are also getting worse, because the frontier for what constitutes racial equality is always shifting. The questions are new: not ones of civil rights, but of all the cultural adjustments that are required to make people of colour feel at home and equal, not erased from history, not subject to the glorification of imperial overlords, not having to drink a pint as a golliwog hangs over them or as a nation debates whether they should be forced to. Racism isn\u2019t a disease that is cured by a single shot of medicine, it\u2019s a combination of attitudes and social values around which there are varying levels of agreement. We have agreed, for example, that you can\u2019t say the N-word. But, it seems, not against the hanging of golliwogs in public places, as the pub landlord <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/13/essex-police-investigating-golliwog-pub-display-examine-landlord-lynching-post\">commented on a Facebook post</a>, the way \u201cthey used to hang them in Mississippi years ago\u201d. You might think we also agreed that we couldn\u2019t say white people should own black slaves, but it seems that even that is not a certainty.</p> \n<p>Constantly realising all the questions you thought were settled are in fact not, is my abiding experience of being a non-white Briton. Along with those realisations comes a queasy sense of foreboding, because I know that suggesting that all might not be well in Britain on the race front isn\u2019t going to be pretty. In choosing not to smile, there is a price to pay. You\u2019ll have to be subjected to the usual: that you are oversensitive, woke, and in fact, actually the one making it about race when it\u2019s just some dolls hanging like they used to hang black folk in Mississippi. Despite all recent fictions about Black Lives Matter (BLM) ushering in an age of deference to black people, one only has to look at how race incidents are discussed in our politics, and our media, to see that our group response to expressing discomfort about race isn\u2019t exactly \u201clet me kneel in solidarity this very moment\u201d.</p> \n<p>Any questions asked of the appropriateness of our symbols or historical legacies is not merely met with a lack of deference, but with punishment. Students who suggest modifying curriculums are <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/oct/25/decolonise-cambridge-university-row-attack-students-colour-lola-olufemi-curriculums\">mauled in the press</a>; others who campaign against systemic racism, such as BLMUK, are <a href=\"https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2021/02/07/exclusive-far-left-influence-black-lives-matter-extinctionrebellion/\">investigated</a> for something called \u201cprogressive extremism\u201d and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2021/feb/22/culture-war-chilling-effect-equality-government-rightwing-press\">struggle to open bank accounts</a> to disburse funds raised to support precariously employed and housed people. People such as Ngozi Fulani, who had the misfortune of expecting enlightened views of the royal household, are <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/mar/08/ngozi-fulani-sistah-space-charity-boss-at-centre-of-royal-race-row-steps-down-over-abuse\">savaged</a> by the press and, in turn, members of the public, for pointing out that it\u2019s not very nice to be aggressively asked where you are from.</p>"}}, {"type": "rich-link", "assets": [], "richLinkTypeData": {"url": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/13/essex-police-investigating-golliwog-pub-display-examine-landlord-lynching-post", "originalUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/13/essex-police-investigating-golliwog-pub-display-examine-landlord-lynching-post", "linkText": "Essex police examine golly doll pub landlord\u2019s \u2018racist\u2019 Facebook posts", "linkPrefix": "Related: ", "role": "thumbnail"}}, {"type": "text", "assets": [], "textTypeData": {"html": "<p>It\u2019s a sort of law of racial gravity \u2013 for every claim of a racist action there is a wildly unequal and disproportionate reaction. Most of the time I don\u2019t particularly care about who asked whom where they were from, or if there\u2019s a pub that wants to display golliwogs. Sometimes I actively will myself not to care, because really, in the grand scheme of things these are relatively small incidents that do not make up the sum total of the experience of being a person of colour in the UK. But one is forced into a state of outrage by a government and media that then throw their weight behind the aggressors. If we can be convinced that there is a powerful onslaught against the good British people and their history and traditions by radical leftwing identity politics, then maybe there\u2019s a chance we can be distracted from the colossal failures of the last 13 years.</p> \n<p>The home secretary, Suella Braverman, apparently found time to let it be known that she had <a href=\"https://news.sky.com/story/suella-braverman-makes-views-very-plain-to-police-over-golliwog-doll-seizure-from-essex-pub-12854721\">rebuked</a> the police for getting involved in the golliwog matter. In truth, according to weekend reports, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/10/essex-police-deny-braverman-rebuked-them-over-pub-seizure-of-golliwog-dolls\">no real attempt</a> was made by Braverman to contact Essex police. But no matter, for that starts a process. A columnist in the Telegraph laments the demonisation of the innocent golliwog and <a href=\"https://www.telegraph.co.uk/columnists/2023/04/11/police-arrest-golly-doll-essex-toys-suella-braverman/\">says your teddy bears could be next</a>. The matter then becomes not one of outliers and hold-outs, but rightwing state and media sanction of their positions. The result is an encouragement and entrenchment of racist views, that is a constant drag on a Britain that is <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/society/2022/sep/22/majority-of-uk-public-agree-with-liberal-views-on-race-and-sexual-identity-annual-poll\">becoming increasingly enlightened</a> on race.</p> \n<p>Racism as individuals acting out is ultimately a diversion from racism as threat to life and liberty. In the same week that golliwogs dominated, it was revealed that black girls are <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/06/black-girls-three-times-more-likely-to-undergo-invasive-strip-search-by-met-police\">three times more likely</a> to undergo an invasive strip-search by Met police than white girls, and that <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/09/britain-not-close-to-being-a-racially-just-society-finds-two-year-research-project\">more than a third</a> of people from ethnic and religious minorities have experienced racially motivated physical or verbal abuse. But when the Home Office gets involved to protect the right to insult you, then you have to care about golliwogs too. Because now they are now a matter of national debate, of dinner party conversations and school playground taunting, and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/YouGov/status/1646151432780009472\">actual YouGov polling</a> that asks if golliwogs are racist \u2013 a swirling national discourse in which the final arbiter of what is racist is never you.</p> \n<p>It\u2019s dizzying, trying to calibrate the appropriate response to these travesties, because, yes, of course things are getting better. But they are also getting worse, because the frontier for what constitutes racial equality is always shifting. The questions are new: not ones of civil rights, but of all the cultural adjustments that are required to make people of colour feel at home and equal, not erased from history, not subject to the glorification of imperial overlords, not having to drink a pint as a golliwog hangs over them or as a nation debates whether they should be forced to. It\u2019s an awful lot of contempt to carry around with you, while simultaneously disciplining and reminding yourself that it\u2019s not all this nation has to offer. So forgive me, for not smiling.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><p>Nesrine Malik is a Guardian columnist</p></li> \n</ul>"}}]}], "totalBodyBlocks": 1}, "rights": {"syndicatable": "true", "subscriptionDatabases": "us-news/2023/apr/17/new-york-clubs-violence-drugs-deaths", "type": "article", "sectionId": "us-news", "sectionName": "US news", "webPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:32Z", "webTitle": "Forty-three druggings, seven deaths: New York clubgoers face wave of violent robberies", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/apr/17/new-york-clubs-violence-drugs-deaths", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/us-news/2023/apr/17/new-york-clubs-violence-drugs-deaths", "fields": {"headline": "Forty-three druggings, seven deaths: New York clubgoers face wave of violent robberies", "standfirst": "<p><strong>Seven have died in the incidents since 2021, with much of the violence taking place around LGBTQ+ spaces</strong></p>", "trailText": "Seven people have died in the incidents since 2021, with much of the violence taking place around LGBTQ+ spaces", "byline": "Wilfred Chan in New York", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"23e1a7bfce2998d9595830fe5d538e36789d3940\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/23e1a7bfce2998d9595830fe5d538e36789d3940/0_0_3000_1996/1000.jpg\" alt=\"view of street with rainbow streamers on building\" width=\"1000\" height=\"665\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Outside the Ritz Bar and Lounge in Hell's Kitchen, New York, in 2020.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Dia Dipasupil/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>Last April, Julio Ramirez, a 25-year-old social worker, met a group of men at the Ritz Bar &amp; Lounge, a nautical-themed gay dance club in Hell\u2019s Kitchen, two blocks from Times Square. Less than two hours after leaving with them, Ramirez was dead from a drug overdose after his new acquaintances abandoned him in the backseat of a cab. Investigators believe they used payment apps like Zelle to steal about $20,000 from his bank accounts before leaving him.</p> <p>A month later, John Umberger, a 33-year-old political consultant, was found dead in a Manhattan townhouse after meeting the same group of men at the Q, a multi-story queer nightclub around the corner from the Ritz. According to his mother, Linda Clary, Umberger had been with a group of friends until he decided to head to the Q alone to catch a late-night DJ show.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"ef4e9e1bdf7ec69b09ce14fdd247407e2526177f\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/ef4e9e1bdf7ec69b09ce14fdd247407e2526177f/19_93_1885_1885/1000.jpg\" alt=\"man poses, smiling\" width=\"1000\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">John Umberger, who died after leaving the Q nightclub.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Courtesy of Linda Clary</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Umberger never got into the final cab that he ordered and was instead hustled into the backseat of another car by the suspects. The accused killers allegedly stole about $20,000 from Umberger\u2019s bank accounts, and filmed on their phones as he overdosed.</p> <p>\u201cIt speaks to their depravity,\u201d Clary tells the Guardian. \u201cAnd it is concerning how many other groups may be still doing it.\u201d</p> <p>These attacks are part of a wave of drug-assisted thefts that has left at least seven clubgoers dead in New York City, with at least 43 known druggings since September 2021, in at least <a href=\"https://abc7ny.com/drugging-robbery-crime-manhattan/13049315/\">two separate patterns</a>.</p> <p>Police were initially dismissive of the incidents and blamed the victims. \u201cNYPD presented to me that John went to a club, got robbed, and was so depressed that he came home and did drugs,\u201d says Clary, who immediately doubted the story. \u201cIf that had happened to John, that would not have been his response on any level.\u201d</p> <p>Now police acknowledge those killings were not isolated incidents. This month they announced the arrests of four suspects who, according to prosecutor filings at the Manhattan district attorney\u2019s office, conspired to \u201capproach intoxicated individuals upon exiting a bar or nightclub, engage them in conversation, and offer and administer dangerous and illicit substances to them for the purpose of causing their incapacitation\u201d. A fifth person charged in the deaths remains at large.</p> <p>That indictment comes months after the <a href=\"https://pix11.com/news/local-news/manhattan/man-accused-of-robbing-drugging-manhattan-clubgoers-arrested-on-murder-charges-nypd/\">arrest</a> of an unconnected suspect in December 2022, charged with drug-assisted thefts that killed two clubgoers on Manhattan\u2019s Lower East Side. In March 2023, police also determined that the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/mar/25/new-york-fashion-designer-death-homicide-katie-gallagher\">mysterious death</a> of a rising New York fashion designer, Katie Gallagher, in July had been due to drug-assisted theft, though no suspects have been arrested. And in January, a New York City law student, Jordan Taylor, went <a href=\"https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/wheres-jordan-taylor-nyc-law-student-missing-after-going-to-hells-kitchen-lgbtq-bar/4058071/\">missing</a> after visiting the Q, in a case that remains unsolved.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"8e84cd6fbc92fc9976bba4d482a91fd4f403f6a6\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/8e84cd6fbc92fc9976bba4d482a91fd4f403f6a6/3_0_2993_1796/1000.jpg\" alt=\"portrait\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The fashion designer Katie Gallagher.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Andrew Toth/FilmMagic</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Clary worries that there are even more drugging attacks that aren\u2019t getting attention. \u201cI\u2019m convinced that there are significantly more cases because I think out of embarrassment, shame or fear, victims have not come forward,\u201d she says.</p> <h2><strong>\u2018Shady outsiders in gay spaces\u2019</strong></h2> <p>The NYPD chief of detectives, James Essig, has stressed that these drugging attacks aren\u2019t just aimed at queer people: \u201cThis is based solely on monetary gain,\u201d he said last year. But some members of the LGBTQ+ community say they feel particularly vulnerable, especially when hate crimes are on the rise.</p> <p>That includes Arthur Bramhandtam, a Hell\u2019s Kitchen resident and swimwear designer who frequents New York\u2019s queer venues. He can name at least four different friends who had been robbed of their phones or wallets, with three of the incidents in the last two months alone. \u201cIt\u2019s scary,\u201d he says. He doesn\u2019t believe the perpetrators belong to the community: \u201cIt\u2019s shady outsiders that come into these gay spaces.\u201d</p> <p>Miguel Tavares, a New Yorker who has joined Hell\u2019s Kitchen parties for more than a decade, thinks the thieves could be exploiting the things that make gay nightlife so appealing: \u201cThe truth is, I do let my guard down when I come out to these places, because you\u2019re yearning for connection. And I think for homosexuals especially, we want to commingle, want to let others into our friend groups.\u201d</p> <p>For queer people, the attacks pose a dilemma: how do you stay vigilant in intimate venues that are meant to allow you to drop your defenses?</p> <p>Marybec Griffin, a Rutgers University assistant professor who researches LGBTQ+ health, says the drugging attacks are just the \u201cnewest twist\u201d in the legacy of violence targeting queer people \u2013 \u201dsomething that has been happening since the beginning of time\u201d. But these attacks are particularly insidious \u201cbecause the perpetrators are preying on people in places where they\u2019re supposed to be safe\u201d.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"f35f2a8ac4d25bec8d624561a16d17511af37a2b\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/f35f2a8ac4d25bec8d624561a16d17511af37a2b/0_0_4000_2666/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Pride flags hang outside of storefronts in the Hell\u2019s Kitchen neighborhood in June 2022.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Pride flags hang outside of storefronts in the Hell\u2019s Kitchen neighborhood in June 2022.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Bloomberg/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Carl Smith-Hudson, a Brooklyn resident who has been going out to Hell\u2019s Kitchen with his friends for years, says he often sees strangers approach queer people in the area with offers of drugs. \u201cThey target these areas, like, \u2018Oh, I\u2019m not gay, but listen, I have this for you, I have that.\u2019\u201d</p> <p>Bramhandtam says an atmosphere where drugs are commonplace allows perpetrators to blend in: \u201cMaybe someone\u2019s hitting on you, or you\u2019re hitting on them \u2013 it\u2019s not unusual for someone to just offer you a bump.\u201d He thinks thieves might also target people using more dissociative drugs, like GHB, ketamine and molly. \u201cEveryone\u2019s in a pretty good mood. They\u2019re not taking things that make you aggressive,\u201d he says.</p> <p>In this environment, it\u2019s easier for attackers to slip substances into people\u2019s drinks, or give someone a substance that\u2019s been combined with unknown drugs, says William Eggleston, an assistant professor and toxicologist at the State University of New York, Binghamton. \u201cThese drugs are often mixed, and most of the time, what you think you\u2019re buying is not necessarily what you\u2019re getting.\u201d</p> <p>Medical examiners found drugs in the victims\u2019 bodies that included fentanyl, cocaine, ethanol and p-fluorofentanyl. The latter is a synthetic opioid that\u2019s often mixed with fentanyl, and just about as deadly, according to Eggleston. It doesn\u2019t take much of either drug to slow someone\u2019s breathing or make them unresponsive, and \u201cit\u2019s important to note that the effects of drugs like fentanyl are increased with the presence of alcohol\u201d, he says.</p> <h2><strong>Skeptical cops</strong></h2> <p>Local government is aware of the problem. In response to the drugging attacks, New York City\u2019s office for the prevention of hate crimes has partnered with a non-profit called the <a href=\"https://avp.org/\">Anti-Violence Project</a> to monitor incidents in LGBTQ+ nightlife areas, promote safety practices and hand out fentanyl testing strips.</p> <p>Audacia Ray, AVP\u2019s director of community organizing and public advocacy, says venues can improve safety by training more eyes on their space. Even better if the staff are part of the queer community: \u201cOne of the bartenders we met during our canvassing was an elder gay man working for a private security company. He knew what he was looking for. That was really helpful to have someone who had knowledge of queer culture to be in that space.\u201d</p> <p>Clubgoers who spoke to the Guardian said that some of the smaller, queer-owned venues removed from tourist areas felt safer than some of the larger bars and clubs in Manhattan. Many also agreed that the two venues that Martinez and Umberger visited before they died \u2013 the Ritz and the Q \u2013 felt like places where there was a higher risk of being harassed or robbed.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"c0bdc108b6609e5623dc000dcd9455f4e27fe6a9\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/c0bdc108b6609e5623dc000dcd9455f4e27fe6a9/0_328_4842_2904/1000.jpg\" alt=\"people smile and cheer under pride flags\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">People gather at the Stonewall Inn in New York\u2019s West Village.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Yana Paskova/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>At a <a href=\"https://w42st.com/post/ritz-tommy-greco-julio-ramirez-death-hells-kitchen/\">press conference</a> after last year\u2019s deaths, the Ritz\u2019s owner, Tom Greco, who is straight, said he would implement \u201cheightened bag checks\u201d and advised patrons to \u201cbe aware of who\u2019s with you and who\u2019s coming and going\u201d. But last week, a bouncer outside the Ritz told the Guardian he had \u201cnever heard of\u201d the deadly drugging attacks in the area, and he said that the Ritz\u2019s security manager wasn\u2019t on the premises. Greco didn\u2019t respond to messages requesting comment.</p> <p>The Q\u2019s owners also couldn\u2019t be reached for comment. Last month, the club <a href=\"https://w42st.com/post/q-club-shutters-amid-ongoing-litigation-and-umberger-homicide/\">abruptly shut down</a> following a <a href=\"https://instinctmagazine.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/FILE_8646.pdf\">lawsuit</a> filed last June by co-founder Frank Sharp against his partners Bob Fluet and Allan Pikus. While Sharp\u2019s complaint didn\u2019t mention Umberger\u2019s death or drug-assisted thefts, Sharp accused his partners of turning the club into a toxic and racist work environment, and ordering security to turn a blind eye to drugs like GHB.</p> <p>The only person associated with the club who spoke to the Guardian was Nikki, a former security manager at the Q who declined to give her last name. She told the Guardian she never allowed illegal substances to be brought inside: \u201cSomething like that happens, you\u2019re getting the fuck out of my club.\u201d As for the deadly drug-assisted thefts: \u201cIt\u2019s fucked up. But it just happened. There was a lot going on, so it happened.\u201d</p> <p>Even when venues try to stop attacks, they aren\u2019t always taken seriously by police. The New York state senator Brad Hoylman-Sigal, whose district includes Hell\u2019s Kitchen and Chelsea \u2013 another queer nightlife district \u2013 says he heard from a Chelsea gay bar owner who \u201cliterally pulled out a potential victim from a van\u201d after someone tried to kidnap one of his patrons. But law enforcement was skeptical when the owner reported it, the lawmaker says. \u201cI think there\u2019s immediately a sense of suspicion around men who frequent gay bars and nightclubs.\u201d</p> <p>Clary says she\u2019s also heard from other drug attack victims who tried reporting their attacks to police. But the victims, who were also gay, \u201cdid not get the care and concern from NYPD that everyone should get. They were like, \u2018You did this, that\u2019s on you. Sorry, buddy.\u2019\u201d</p> <p>In an emailed statement, an NYPD spokesperson said it \u201cworks to establish patterns and motives in all robberies\u201d and \u201cthere are no robberies or kidnappings on file\u201d for the Chelsea bar last year. \u201cThe NYPD encourages all crime victims to come forward to police and report any incidents so that we can investigate and hold any perpetrators responsible,\u201d the spokesperson added.</p> <h2><strong>\u2018Stick with your friends\u2019</strong></h2> <p>To make going out safer, it\u2019s crucial not to blame victims for what happened, says Griffin, of Rutgers University. \u201cShame is the enemy of open and honest communication.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"17bf27d5e351832ed6cfb532093d18e04a2474f9\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/17bf27d5e351832ed6cfb532093d18e04a2474f9/0_220_5616_3373/1000.jpg\" alt=\"manhattan skyline\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">For now the best protection for many queer nightlifers remains each other.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Gary Hershorn/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>A better approach is a harm reduction model, which prioritizes giving people the tools and information to make informed choices about substances. \u201cThere is no reason why you shouldn\u2019t be able to test your substances to make sure you know what you\u2019re consuming,\u201d she says.</p> <p>Eggleston, the toxicologist, advises keeping your drink in your hand, and not accepting drinks from strangers. He recommends going to the emergency room if you think you\u2019ve been drugged \u2013 \u201cthey can do tests and keep a close eye on you.\u201d If you suspect someone you\u2019re with is overdosing, call 911 and give them naloxone, also known as Narcan, a medication that can stop overdoses. \u201cIf you\u2019re right, it\u2019ll help them start breathing again. If you\u2019re wrong, it\u2019s not going to hurt them.\u201d</p> <p>Bargoers should develop a safety plan with people they trust. \u201cHave a plan with a check-in person about when you plan to go home, and turn on location sharing on your phone,\u201d Ray, the community organizer, says.</p> <p>Ray also advises turning off face-unlocking on your phone. \u201cIt\u2019s something that folks have used when someone was incapacitated, to be able to get into their phone, turn off location sharing, and pull money out of their bank accounts.\u201d</p> <p>Hoylman-Sigal says he\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.nysenate.gov/sites/default/files/press-release/attachment/zelle_letter_-_banks.pdf\">contacted</a> Zelle to ask for stronger fraud protection measures. \u201cI think the ease of defrauding customers who use their platform may have contributed to these horrific attacks,\u201d the state senator says. (A spokesperson for Zelle said it \u201ccontinues to have conversations\u201d with officials and financial institutions \u201cin how we can all partner to protect consumers\u201d.)</p> <p>But for now the best protection for many queer nightlifers remains each other. \u201cDon\u2019t take drugs from strangers that you don\u2019t know, and stick with your friends, right?\u201d says Bramhandtam, who also carries fentanyl test strips on nights out. \u201cThat\u2019s all you really got in these types of situations.\u201d</p> <p>Later this month, Bramhandtam plans to attend a Brooklyn queer party that was hit by a mass theft incident in February \u2013 so he expects he\u2019ll be looking out for suspicious outsiders. \u201cWe\u2019ve already created so many enclaves pretty far away from main parts of society,\u201d he says. \u201cBut they just keep finding us.\u201d</p>", "wordcount": "2028", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:32Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T05:17:23Z", "productionOffice": "US", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nmta7", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/23e1a7bfce2998d9595830fe5d538e36789d3940/0_197_3000_1799/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Last April, Julio Ramirez, a 25-year-old social worker, met a group of men at the Ritz Bar &amp; Lounge, a nautical-themed gay dance club in Hell\u2019s Kitchen, two blocks from Times Square. Less than two hours after leaving with them, Ramirez was dead from a drug overdose after his new acquaintances abandoned him in the backseat of a cab. Investigators believe they used payment apps like Zelle to steal about $20,000 from his bank accounts before leaving him. A month later, John Umberger, a 33-year-old political consultant, was found dead in a Manhattan townhouse after meeting the same group of men at the Q, a multi-story queer nightclub around the corner from the Ritz. According to his mother, Linda Clary, Umberger had been with a group of friends until he decided to head to the Q alone to catch a late-night DJ show. Umberger never got into the final cab that he ordered and was instead hustled into the backseat of another car by the suspects. The accused killers allegedly stole about $20,000 from Umberger\u2019s bank accounts, and filmed on their phones as he overdosed. \u201cIt speaks to their depravity,\u201d Clary tells the Guardian. \u201cAnd it is concerning how many other groups may be still doing it.\u201d These attacks are part of a wave of drug-assisted thefts that has left at least seven clubgoers dead in New York City, with at least 43 known druggings since September 2021, in at least two separate patterns. Police were initially dismissive of the incidents and blamed the victims. \u201cNYPD presented to me that John went to a club, got robbed, and was so depressed that he came home and did drugs,\u201d says Clary, who immediately doubted the story. \u201cIf that had happened to John, that would not have been his response on any level.\u201d Now police acknowledge those killings were not isolated incidents. This month they announced the arrests of four suspects who, according to prosecutor filings at the Manhattan district attorney\u2019s office, conspired to \u201capproach intoxicated individuals upon exiting a bar or nightclub, engage them in conversation, and offer and administer dangerous and illicit substances to them for the purpose of causing their incapacitation\u201d. A fifth person charged in the deaths remains at large. That indictment comes months after the arrest of an unconnected suspect in December 2022, charged with drug-assisted thefts that killed two clubgoers on Manhattan\u2019s Lower East Side. In March 2023, police also determined that the mysterious death of a rising New York fashion designer, Katie Gallagher, in July had been due to drug-assisted theft, though no suspects have been arrested. And in January, a New York City law student, Jordan Taylor, went missing after visiting the Q, in a case that remains unsolved. Clary worries that there are even more drugging attacks that aren\u2019t getting attention. \u201cI\u2019m convinced that there are significantly more cases because I think out of embarrassment, shame or fear, victims have not come forward,\u201d she says. \u2018Shady outsiders in gay spaces\u2019 The NYPD chief of detectives, James Essig, has stressed that these drugging attacks aren\u2019t just aimed at queer people: \u201cThis is based solely on monetary gain,\u201d he said last year. But some members of the LGBTQ+ community say they feel particularly vulnerable, especially when hate crimes are on the rise. That includes Arthur Bramhandtam, a Hell\u2019s Kitchen resident and swimwear designer who frequents New York\u2019s queer venues. He can name at least four different friends who had been robbed of their phones or wallets, with three of the incidents in the last two months alone. \u201cIt\u2019s scary,\u201d he says. He doesn\u2019t believe the perpetrators belong to the community: \u201cIt\u2019s shady outsiders that come into these gay spaces.\u201d Miguel Tavares, a New Yorker who has joined Hell\u2019s Kitchen parties for more than a decade, thinks the thieves could be exploiting the things that make gay nightlife so appealing: \u201cThe truth is, I do let my guard down when I come out to these places, because you\u2019re yearning for connection. And I think for homosexuals especially, we want to commingle, want to let others into our friend groups.\u201d For queer people, the attacks pose a dilemma: how do you stay vigilant in intimate venues that are meant to allow you to drop your defenses? Marybec Griffin, a Rutgers University assistant professor who researches LGBTQ+ health, says the drugging attacks are just the \u201cnewest twist\u201d in the legacy of violence targeting queer people \u2013 \u201dsomething that has been happening since the beginning of time\u201d. But these attacks are particularly insidious \u201cbecause the perpetrators are preying on people in places where they\u2019re supposed to be safe\u201d. Carl Smith-Hudson, a Brooklyn resident who has been going out to Hell\u2019s Kitchen with his friends for years, says he often sees strangers approach queer people in the area with offers of drugs. \u201cThey target these areas, like, \u2018Oh, I\u2019m not gay, but listen, I have this for you, I have that.\u2019\u201d Bramhandtam says an atmosphere where drugs are commonplace allows perpetrators to blend in: \u201cMaybe someone\u2019s hitting on you, or you\u2019re hitting on them \u2013 it\u2019s not unusual for someone to just offer you a bump.\u201d He thinks thieves might also target people using more dissociative drugs, like GHB, ketamine and molly. \u201cEveryone\u2019s in a pretty good mood. They\u2019re not taking things that make you aggressive,\u201d he says. In this environment, it\u2019s easier for attackers to slip substances into people\u2019s drinks, or give someone a substance that\u2019s been combined with unknown drugs, says William Eggleston, an assistant professor and toxicologist at the State University of New York, Binghamton. \u201cThese drugs are often mixed, and most of the time, what you think you\u2019re buying is not necessarily what you\u2019re getting.\u201d Medical examiners found drugs in the victims\u2019 bodies that included fentanyl, cocaine, ethanol and p-fluorofentanyl. The latter is a synthetic opioid that\u2019s often mixed with fentanyl, and just about as deadly, according to Eggleston. It doesn\u2019t take much of either drug to slow someone\u2019s breathing or make them unresponsive, and \u201cit\u2019s important to note that the effects of drugs like fentanyl are increased with the presence of alcohol\u201d, he says. Skeptical cops Local government is aware of the problem. In response to the drugging attacks, New York City\u2019s office for the prevention of hate crimes has partnered with a non-profit called the Anti-Violence Project to monitor incidents in LGBTQ+ nightlife areas, promote safety practices and hand out fentanyl testing strips. Audacia Ray, AVP\u2019s director of community organizing and public advocacy, says venues can improve safety by training more eyes on their space. Even better if the staff are part of the queer community: \u201cOne of the bartenders we met during our canvassing was an elder gay man working for a private security company. He knew what he was looking for. That was really helpful to have someone who had knowledge of queer culture to be in that space.\u201d Clubgoers who spoke to the Guardian said that some of the smaller, queer-owned venues removed from tourist areas felt safer than some of the larger bars and clubs in Manhattan. Many also agreed that the two venues that Martinez and Umberger visited before they died \u2013 the Ritz and the Q \u2013 felt like places where there was a higher risk of being harassed or robbed. At a press conference after last year\u2019s deaths, the Ritz\u2019s owner, Tom Greco, who is straight, said he would implement \u201cheightened bag checks\u201d and advised patrons to \u201cbe aware of who\u2019s with you and who\u2019s coming and going\u201d. But last week, a bouncer outside the Ritz told the Guardian he had \u201cnever heard of\u201d the deadly drugging attacks in the area, and he said that the Ritz\u2019s security manager wasn\u2019t on the premises. Greco didn\u2019t respond to messages requesting comment. The Q\u2019s owners also couldn\u2019t be reached for comment. Last month, the club abruptly shut down following a lawsuit filed last June by co-founder Frank Sharp against his partners Bob Fluet and Allan Pikus. While Sharp\u2019s complaint didn\u2019t mention Umberger\u2019s death or drug-assisted thefts, Sharp accused his partners of turning the club into a toxic and racist work environment, and ordering security to turn a blind eye to drugs like GHB. The only person associated with the club who spoke to the Guardian was Nikki, a former security manager at the Q who declined to give her last name. She told the Guardian she never allowed illegal substances to be brought inside: \u201cSomething like that happens, you\u2019re getting the fuck out of my club.\u201d As for the deadly drug-assisted thefts: \u201cIt\u2019s fucked up. But it just happened. There was a lot going on, so it happened.\u201d Even when venues try to stop attacks, they aren\u2019t always taken seriously by police. The New York state senator Brad Hoylman-Sigal, whose district includes Hell\u2019s Kitchen and Chelsea \u2013 another queer nightlife district \u2013 says he heard from a Chelsea gay bar owner who \u201cliterally pulled out a potential victim from a van\u201d after someone tried to kidnap one of his patrons. But law enforcement was skeptical when the owner reported it, the lawmaker says. \u201cI think there\u2019s immediately a sense of suspicion around men who frequent gay bars and nightclubs.\u201d Clary says she\u2019s also heard from other drug attack victims who tried reporting their attacks to police. But the victims, who were also gay, \u201cdid not get the care and concern from NYPD that everyone should get. They were like, \u2018You did this, that\u2019s on you. Sorry, buddy.\u2019\u201d In an emailed statement, an NYPD spokesperson said it \u201cworks to establish patterns and motives in all robberies\u201d and \u201cthere are no robberies or kidnappings on file\u201d for the Chelsea bar last year. \u201cThe NYPD encourages all crime victims to come forward to police and report any incidents so that we can investigate and hold any perpetrators responsible,\u201d the spokesperson added. \u2018Stick with your friends\u2019 To make going out safer, it\u2019s crucial not to blame victims for what happened, says Griffin, of Rutgers University. \u201cShame is the enemy of open and honest communication.\u201d A better approach is a harm reduction model, which prioritizes giving people the tools and information to make informed choices about substances. \u201cThere is no reason why you shouldn\u2019t be able to test your substances to make sure you know what you\u2019re consuming,\u201d she says. Eggleston, the toxicologist, advises keeping your drink in your hand, and not accepting drinks from strangers. He recommends going to the emergency room if you think you\u2019ve been drugged \u2013 \u201cthey can do tests and keep a close eye on you.\u201d If you suspect someone you\u2019re with is overdosing, call 911 and give them naloxone, also known as Narcan, a medication that can stop overdoses. \u201cIf you\u2019re right, it\u2019ll help them start breathing again. If you\u2019re wrong, it\u2019s not going to hurt them.\u201d Bargoers should develop a safety plan with people they trust. \u201cHave a plan with a check-in person about when you plan to go home, and turn on location sharing on your phone,\u201d Ray, the community organizer, says. Ray also advises turning off face-unlocking on your phone. \u201cIt\u2019s something that folks have used when someone was incapacitated, to be able to get into their phone, turn off location sharing, and pull money out of their bank accounts.\u201d Hoylman-Sigal says he\u2019s contacted Zelle to ask for stronger fraud protection measures. \u201cI think the ease of defrauding customers who use their platform may have contributed to these horrific attacks,\u201d the state senator says. (A spokesperson for Zelle said it \u201ccontinues to have conversations\u201d with officials and financial institutions \u201cin how we can all partner to protect consumers\u201d.) But for now the best protection for many queer nightlifers remains each other. \u201cDon\u2019t take drugs from strangers that you don\u2019t know, and stick with your friends, right?\u201d says And I think for homosexuals especially, we want to commingle, want to let others into our friend groups.\u201d</p> <p>For queer people, the attacks pose a dilemma: how do you stay vigilant in intimate venues that are meant to allow you to drop your defenses?</p> <p>Marybec Griffin, a Rutgers University assistant professor who researches LGBTQ+ health, says the drugging attacks are just the \u201cnewest twist\u201d in the legacy of violence targeting queer people \u2013 \u201dsomething that has been happening since the beginning of time\u201d. But these attacks are particularly insidious \u201cbecause the perpetrators are preying on people in places where they\u2019re supposed to be safe\u201d.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"f35f2a8ac4d25bec8d624561a16d17511af37a2b\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/f35f2a8ac4d25bec8d624561a16d17511af37a2b/0_0_4000_2666/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Pride flags hang outside of storefronts in the Hell\u2019s Kitchen neighborhood in June 2022.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Pride flags hang outside of storefronts in the Hell\u2019s Kitchen neighborhood in June 2022.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Bloomberg/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Carl Smith-Hudson, a Brooklyn resident who has been going out to Hell\u2019s Kitchen with his friends for years, says he often sees strangers approach queer people in the area with offers of drugs. \u201cThey target these areas, like, \u2018Oh, I\u2019m not gay, but listen, I have this for you, I have that.\u2019\u201d</p> <p>Bramhandtam says an atmosphere where drugs are commonplace allows perpetrators to blend in: \u201cMaybe someone\u2019s hitting on you, or you\u2019re hitting on them \u2013 it\u2019s not unusual for someone to just offer you a bump.\u201d He thinks thieves might also target people using more dissociative drugs, like GHB, ketamine and molly. \u201cEveryone\u2019s in a pretty good mood. They\u2019re not taking things that make you aggressive,\u201d he says.</p> <p>In this environment, it\u2019s easier for attackers to slip substances into people\u2019s drinks, or give someone a substance that\u2019s been combined with unknown drugs, says William Eggleston, an assistant professor and toxicologist at the State University of New York, Binghamton. \u201cThese drugs are often mixed, and most of the time, what you think you\u2019re buying is not necessarily what you\u2019re getting.\u201d</p> <p>Medical examiners found drugs in the victims\u2019 bodies that included fentanyl, cocaine, ethanol and p-fluorofentanyl. The latter is a synthetic opioid that\u2019s often mixed with fentanyl, and just about as deadly, according to Eggleston. It doesn\u2019t take much of either drug to slow someone\u2019s breathing or make them unresponsive, and \u201cit\u2019s important to note that the effects of drugs like fentanyl are increased with the presence of alcohol\u201d, he says.</p> <h2><strong>Skeptical cops</strong></h2> <p>Local government is aware of the problem. In response to the drugging attacks, New York City\u2019s office for the prevention of hate crimes has partnered with a non-profit called the <a href=\"https://avp.org/\">Anti-Violence Project</a> to monitor incidents in LGBTQ+ nightlife areas, promote safety practices and hand out fentanyl testing strips.</p> <p>Audacia Ray, AVP\u2019s director of community organizing and public advocacy, says venues can improve safety by training more eyes on their space. Even better if the staff are part of the queer community: \u201cOne of the bartenders we met during our canvassing was an elder gay man working for a private security company. He knew what he was looking for. That was really helpful to have someone who had knowledge of queer culture to be in that space.\u201d</p> <p>Clubgoers who spoke to the Guardian said that some of the smaller, queer-owned venues removed from tourist areas felt safer than some of the larger bars and clubs in Manhattan. Many also agreed that the two venues that Martinez and Umberger visited before they died \u2013 the Ritz and the Q \u2013 felt like places where there was a higher risk of being harassed or robbed.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"c0bdc108b6609e5623dc000dcd9455f4e27fe6a9\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/c0bdc108b6609e5623dc000dcd9455f4e27fe6a9/0_328_4842_2904/1000.jpg\" alt=\"people smile and cheer under pride flags\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">People gather at the Stonewall Inn in New York\u2019s West Village.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Yana Paskova/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>At a <a href=\"https://w42st.com/post/ritz-tommy-greco-julio-ramirez-death-hells-kitchen/\">press conference</a> after last year\u2019s deaths, the Ritz\u2019s owner, Tom Greco, who is straight, said he would implement \u201cheightened bag checks\u201d and advised patrons to \u201cbe aware of who\u2019s with you and who\u2019s coming and going\u201d. But last week, a bouncer outside the Ritz told the Guardian he had \u201cnever heard of\u201d the deadly drugging attacks in the area, and he said that the Ritz\u2019s security manager wasn\u2019t on the premises. Greco didn\u2019t respond to messages requesting comment.</p> <p>The Q\u2019s owners also couldn\u2019t be reached for comment. Last month, the club <a href=\"https://w42st.com/post/q-club-shutters-amid-ongoing-litigation-and-umberger-homicide/\">abruptly shut down</a> following a <a href=\"https://instinctmagazine.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/FILE_8646.pdf\">lawsuit</a> filed last June by co-founder Frank Sharp against his partners Bob Fluet and Allan Pikus. While Sharp\u2019s complaint didn\u2019t mention Umberger\u2019s death or drug-assisted thefts, Sharp accused his partners of turning the club into a toxic and racist work environment, and ordering security to turn a blind eye to drugs like GHB.</p> <p>The only person associated with the club who spoke to the Guardian was Nikki, a former security manager at the Q who declined to give her last name. She told the Guardian she never allowed illegal substances to be brought inside: \u201cSomething like that happens, you\u2019re getting the fuck out of my club.\u201d As for the deadly drug-assisted thefts: \u201cIt\u2019s fucked up. But it just happened. There was a lot going on, so it happened.\u201d</p> <p>Even when venues try to stop attacks, they aren\u2019t always taken seriously by police. The New York state senator Brad Hoylman-Sigal, whose district includes Hell\u2019s Kitchen and Chelsea \u2013 another queer nightlife district \u2013 says he heard from a Chelsea gay bar owner who \u201cliterally pulled out a potential victim from a van\u201d after someone tried to kidnap one of his patrons. But law enforcement was skeptical when the owner reported it, the lawmaker says. \u201cI think there\u2019s immediately a sense of suspicion around men who frequent gay bars and nightclubs.\u201d</p> <p>Clary says she\u2019s also heard from other drug attack victims who tried reporting their attacks to police. But the victims, who were also gay, \u201cdid not get the care and concern from NYPD that everyone should get. They were like, \u2018You did this, that\u2019s on you. Sorry, buddy.\u2019\u201d</p> <p>In an emailed statement, an NYPD spokesperson said it \u201cworks to establish patterns and motives in all robberies\u201d and \u201cthere are no robberies or kidnappings on file\u201d for the Chelsea bar last year. \u201cThe NYPD encourages all crime victims to come forward to police and report any incidents so that we can investigate and hold any perpetrators responsible,\u201d the spokesperson added.</p> <h2><strong>\u2018Stick with your friends\u2019</strong></h2> <p>To make going out safer, it\u2019s crucial not to blame victims for what happened, says Griffin, of Rutgers University. \u201cShame is the enemy of open and honest communication.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"17bf27d5e351832ed6cfb532093d18e04a2474f9\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/17bf27d5e351832ed6cfb532093d18e04a2474f9/0_220_5616_3373/1000.jpg\" alt=\"manhattan skyline\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">For now the best protection for many queer nightlifers remains each other.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Gary Hershorn/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>A better approach is a harm reduction model, which prioritizes giving people the tools and information to make informed choices about substances. \u201cThere is no reason why you shouldn\u2019t be able to test your substances to make sure you know what you\u2019re consuming,\u201d she says.</p> <p>Eggleston, the toxicologist, advises keeping your drink in your hand, and not accepting drinks from strangers. He recommends going to the emergency room if you think you\u2019ve been drugged \u2013 \u201cthey can do tests and keep a close eye on you.\u201d If you suspect someone you\u2019re with is overdosing, call 911 and give them naloxone, also known as Narcan, a medication that can stop overdoses. \u201cIf you\u2019re right, it\u2019ll help them start breathing again. If you\u2019re wrong, it\u2019s not going to hurt them.\u201d</p> <p>Bargoers should develop a safety plan with people they trust. \u201cHave a plan with a check-in person about when you plan to go home, and turn on location sharing on your phone,\u201d Ray, the community organizer, says.</p> <p>Ray also advises turning off face-unlocking on your phone. \u201cIt\u2019s something that folks have used when someone was incapacitated, to be able to get into their phone, turn off location sharing, and pull money out of their bank accounts.\u201d</p> <p>Hoylman-Sigal says he\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.nysenate.gov/sites/default/files/press-release/attachment/zelle_letter_-_banks.pdf\">contacted</a> Zelle to ask for stronger fraud protection measures. \u201cI think the ease of defrauding customers who use their platform may have contributed to these horrific attacks,\u201d the state senator says. (A spokesperson for Zelle said it \u201ccontinues to have conversations\u201d with officials and financial institutions \u201cin how we can all partner to protect consumers\u201d.)</p> <p>But for now the best protection for many queer nightlifers remains each other. \u201cDon\u2019t take drugs from strangers that you don\u2019t know, and stick with your friends, right?\u201d says Bramhandtam, who also carries fentanyl test strips on nights out. \u201cThat\u2019s all you really got in these types of situations.\u201d</p> <p>Later this month, Bramhandtam plans to attend a Brooklyn queer party that was hit by a mass theft incident in February \u2013 so he expects he\u2019ll be looking out for suspicious outsiders. \u201cWe\u2019ve already created so many enclaves pretty far away from main parts of society,\u201d he says. \u201cBut they just keep finding us.\u201d</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "Last April, Julio Ramirez, a 25-year-old social worker, met a group of men at the Ritz Bar & Lounge, a nautical-themed gay dance club in Hell\u2019s Kitchen, two blocks from Times Square. Less than two hours after leaving with them, Ramirez was dead from a drug overdose after his new acquaintances abandoned him in the backseat of a cab. Investigators believe they used payment apps like Zelle to steal about $20,000 from his bank accounts before leaving him. A month later, John Umberger, a 33-year-old political consultant, was found dead in a Manhattan townhouse after meeting the same group of men at the Q, a multi-story queer nightclub around the corner from the Ritz. According to his mother, Linda Clary, Umberger had been with a group of friends until he decided to head to the Q alone to catch a late-night DJ show.\nUmberger never got into the final cab that he ordered and was instead hustled into the backseat of another car by the suspects. The accused killers allegedly stole about $20,000 from Umberger\u2019s bank accounts, and filmed on their phones as he overdosed. \u201cIt speaks to their depravity,\u201d Clary tells the Guardian. \u201cAnd it is concerning how many other groups may be still doing it.\u201d These attacks are part of a wave of drug-assisted thefts that has left at least seven clubgoers dead in New York City, with at least 43 known druggings since September 2021, in at least two separate patterns. Police were initially dismissive of the incidents and blamed the victims. \u201cNYPD presented to me that John went to a club, got robbed, and was so depressed that he came home and did drugs,\u201d says Clary, who immediately doubted the story. \u201cIf that had happened to John, that would not have been his response on any level.\u201d Now police acknowledge those killings were not isolated incidents. This month they announced the arrests of four suspects who, according to prosecutor filings at the Manhattan district attorney\u2019s office, conspired to \u201capproach intoxicated individuals upon exiting a bar or nightclub, engage them in conversation, and offer and administer dangerous and illicit substances to them for the purpose of causing their incapacitation\u201d. A fifth person charged in the deaths remains at large. That indictment comes months after the arrest of an unconnected suspect in December 2022, charged with drug-assisted thefts that killed two clubgoers on Manhattan\u2019s Lower East Side. In March 2023, police also determined that the mysterious death of a rising New York fashion designer, Katie Gallagher, in July had been due to drug-assisted theft, though no suspects have been arrested. And in January, a New York City law student, Jordan Taylor, went missing after visiting the Q, in a case that remains unsolved.\nClary worries that there are even more drugging attacks that aren\u2019t getting attention. \u201cI\u2019m convinced that there are significantly more cases because I think out of embarrassment, shame or fear, victims have not come forward,\u201d she says. \u2018Shady outsiders in gay spaces\u2019 The NYPD chief of detectives, James Essig, has stressed that these drugging attacks aren\u2019t just aimed at queer people: \u201cThis is based solely on monetary gain,\u201d he said last year. But some members of the LGBTQ+ community say they feel particularly vulnerable, especially when hate crimes are on the rise. That includes Arthur Bramhandtam, a Hell\u2019s Kitchen resident and swimwear designer who frequents New York\u2019s queer venues. He can name at least four different friends who had been robbed of their phones or wallets, with three of the incidents in the last two months alone. \u201cIt\u2019s scary,\u201d he says. He doesn\u2019t believe the perpetrators belong to the community: \u201cIt\u2019s shady outsiders that come into these gay spaces.\u201d Miguel Tavares, a New Yorker who has joined Hell\u2019s Kitchen parties for more than a decade, thinks the thieves could be exploiting the things that make gay nightlife so appealing: \u201cThe truth is, I do let my guard down when I come out to these places, because you\u2019re yearning for connection. And I think for homosexuals especially, we want to commingle, want to let others into our friend groups.\u201d For queer people, the attacks pose a dilemma: how do you stay vigilant in intimate venues that are meant to allow you to drop your defenses? Marybec Griffin, a Rutgers University assistant professor who researches LGBTQ+ health, says the drugging attacks are just the \u201cnewest twist\u201d in the legacy of violence targeting queer people \u2013 \u201dsomething that has been happening since the beginning of time\u201d. But these attacks are particularly insidious \u201cbecause the perpetrators are preying on people in places where they\u2019re supposed to be safe\u201d.\nCarl Smith-Hudson, a Brooklyn resident who has been going out to Hell\u2019s Kitchen with his friends for years, says he often sees strangers approach queer people in the area with offers of drugs. \u201cThey target these areas, like, \u2018Oh, I\u2019m not gay, but listen, I have this for you, I have that.\u2019\u201d Bramhandtam says an atmosphere where drugs are commonplace allows perpetrators to blend in: \u201cMaybe someone\u2019s hitting on you, or you\u2019re hitting on them \u2013 it\u2019s not unusual for someone to just offer you a bump.\u201d He thinks thieves might also target people using more dissociative drugs, like GHB, ketamine and molly. \u201cEveryone\u2019s in a pretty good mood. They\u2019re not taking things that make you aggressive,\u201d he says. In this environment, it\u2019s easier for attackers to slip substances into people\u2019s drinks, or give someone a substance that\u2019s been combined with unknown drugs, says William Eggleston, an assistant professor and toxicologist at the State University of New York, Binghamton. \u201cThese drugs are often mixed, and most of the time, what you think you\u2019re buying is not necessarily what you\u2019re getting.\u201d Medical examiners found drugs in the victims\u2019 bodies that included fentanyl, cocaine, ethanol and p-fluorofentanyl. The latter is a synthetic opioid that\u2019s often mixed with fentanyl, and just about as deadly, according to Eggleston. It doesn\u2019t take much of either drug to slow someone\u2019s breathing or make them unresponsive, and \u201cit\u2019s important to note that the effects of drugs like fentanyl are increased with the presence of alcohol\u201d, he says. Skeptical cops Local government is aware of the problem. In response to the drugging attacks, New York City\u2019s office for the prevention of hate crimes has partnered with a non-profit called the Anti-Violence Project to monitor incidents in LGBTQ+ nightlife areas, promote safety practices and hand out fentanyl testing strips. Audacia Ray, AVP\u2019s director of community organizing and public advocacy, says venues can improve safety by training more eyes on their space. Even better if the staff are part of the queer community: \u201cOne of the bartenders we met during our canvassing was an elder gay man working for a private security company. "https://content.guardianapis.com/environment/2023/apr/17/discovered-in-the-deep-the-squid-that-sees-both-ways-at-once", "fields": {"headline": "Discovered in the deep: the squid that sees both ways at once", "standfirst": "<p>Living in the twilight zone, cockeye squid float between two worlds and have adapted to keep an eye on both</p>", "trailText": "Living in the twilight zone, cockeye squid float between two worlds and have adapted to keep an eye on both", "byline": "Helen Scales", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"8d523973ff63d27fd6332819a65bd50404831e4e\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/8d523973ff63d27fd6332819a65bd50404831e4e/0_0_1406_844/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A cockeye squid (Histioteuthis
