prey or enemies above. </span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Courtesy of MBARI</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure>", "body": "<p>Cockeye squid face a conundrum. Living hundreds of metres underwater, they float in between two worlds. Above them is the surface ocean, where a dim blue fraction of sunlight filters down. Below them is the deep sea, sunless and black. Which way to look?</p> \n<p>Their mismatched eyes solve the problem \u2013 by letting them gaze into both worlds at once.</p> \n<p>The squid are born with two identical eyes, but the left eyeball grows much faster, eventually forming a long tube, often with a bright yellow lens. This huge, highly sensitive eye gazes upwards and looks for the dark silhouettes of food or enemies passing overhead. The yellow colour filters out background light and breaks the camouflage of glowing animals that try to blend with the blue around them.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-atom\"> <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"a8dde4b0-2e5b-4715-a3ee-2342e836b037\" data-atom-type=\"qanda\"> \n  <div>\n   <div class=\"atom-Qanda\">\n    <p></p>\n    <p>The ocean is one of the world\u2019s last truly wild spaces. It teems with fascinating species that sometimes seems to border on the absurd, from fish that look up through transparent heads to golden snails with iron armour. We know more about deep space than deep oceans, and science is only beginning to scratch the surface of the rich variety of life in the depths.</p>\n    <p>As mining companies push to <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2021/sep/27/race-to-the-bottom-the-disastrous-blindfolded-rush-to-mine-the-deep-sea\">industrialise the sea floor</a> and global leaders continue to <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/mar/21/un-ocean-treaty-summit-collapses-as-states-accused-of-dragging-out-talks\">squabble over how to protect the high seas</a>, a new Guardian Seascape series will profile some of the most recently discovered weird, wonderful, majestic, ridiculous, hardcore and mind-blowing creatures. They reveal how much there is still to learn about the least known environment on Earth \u2013 and how much there is to protect.&nbsp;<br></p>\n    <p></p>\n   </div>\n  </div>\n </gu-atom> \n</figure> \n<p>The right eyeball, meanwhile, ends up less than half the diameter of its partner. The squid aims it downwards, scanning for flashes of glowing animals against the dark waters below.</p> \n<p>\u201cIt\u2019s a lovely example of how they exploit and inhabit those two very different environments,\u201d says Jon Ablett, senior curator of molluscs at the Natural History Museum in London.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-video\" data-canonical-url=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pHIUxEiprsk\"> <iframe height=\"480\" width=\"854\" src=\"https://www.youtube-nocookie.com/embed/pHIUxEiprsk?wmode=opaque&amp;feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe> \n</figure> \n<p>Although cockeye squid (<em>Histioteuthis heteropsis) </em>have been known to science for decades, scientists recently caught one on an expedition around the remote Atlantic islands of Ascension and Saint Helena which brilliantly lived up to another name for the creature \u2013 the jewel squid. With an ultraviolet torch shining on it, the squid\u2019s finger-length body twinkled all over in ruby red spots.</p> \n<p>\u201cWhen you get within about 15cm suddenly everything glows red, and the closer you go, the stronger the colour is,\u201d says James Maclaine, senior curator of fish at the Natural History Museum, who brought a UV torch on the expedition to see which animals perform this trick. \u201cIt\u2019s really dramatic,\u201d he says.</p> \n<aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> \n <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/gallery/2023/feb/23/oddities-of-the-not-so-deep-in-pictures\">Discovered in the deep: a \u2018night-time migration\u2019 of marine life \u2013 in pictures </a> </p> \n</aside> \n<p>As far as he knows, no other scientists have tried shining UV light on deep-sea animals. Maclaine found that some have red-glowing spots, including jewel squid and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/dec/14/discovered-in-the-deep-the-fish-with-razor-sharp-fangs-too-big-for-its-mouth\">viperfish</a>, and some, such as <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/sep/29/into-the-twilight-zone-lanternfish-the-fish-that-could-feed-the-world-or-destroy-it\">lanternfish</a>, don\u2019t.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"c6512f58efaef07cd6487dfee3b75cf8a83cc736\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/c6512f58efaef07cd6487dfee3b75cf8a83cc736/0_51_4196_2517/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A cockeye squid against black water\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The squid\u2019s red dots are light-emitting organs, known as photophores.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Kate Thomas/Duke University/NSF</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>The red dots are light-emitting organs, known as photophores, which actually glow blue when the squid are swimming hundreds of metres underwater. There is no UV light in the deep sea so the photophores don\u2019t glow red in their natural environment.</p> \n<p>Like the animals they\u2019re trying to spot with their big yellow eye, cockeye squid may use their glowing photophores to disguise their silhouette. Flashing bioluminescent lights could also be a form of squid communication and a way to attract mates. Or they could lure in prey that mistake them for something to eat. \u201cIt\u2019s possibly all of these reasons,\u201d says Ablett, \u201ca little bit of camouflage, a little bit of sexual selection, a little bit of attracting prey.\u201d</p>", "wordcount": "453", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:32Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T05:17:23Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nmn83", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/8d523973ff63d27fd6332819a65bd50404831e4e/0_0_1406_844/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Cockeye squid face a conundrum. Living hundreds of metres underwater, they float in between two worlds. Above them is the surface ocean, where a dim blue fraction of sunlight filters down. Below them is the deep sea, sunless and black. Which way to look? Their mismatched eyes solve the problem \u2013 by letting them gaze into both worlds at once. The squid are born with two identical eyes, but the left eyeball grows much faster, eventually forming a long tube, often with a bright yellow lens. This huge, highly sensitive eye gazes upwards and looks for the dark silhouettes of food or enemies passing overhead. The yellow colour filters out background light and breaks the camouflage of glowing animals that try to blend with the blue around them. The right eyeball, meanwhile, ends up less than half the diameter of its partner. The squid aims it downwards, scanning for flashes of glowing animals against the dark waters below. \u201cIt\u2019s a lovely example of how they exploit and inhabit those two very different environments,\u201d says Jon Ablett, senior curator of molluscs at the Natural History Museum in London. Although cockeye squid (Histioteuthis heteropsis) have been known to science for decades, scientists recently caught one on an expedition around the remote Atlantic islands of Ascension and Saint Helena which brilliantly lived up to another name for the creature \u2013 the jewel squid. With an ultraviolet torch shining on it, the squid\u2019s finger-length body twinkled all over in ruby red spots. \u201cWhen you get within about 15cm suddenly everything glows red, and the closer you go, the stronger the colour is,\u201d says James Maclaine, senior curator of fish at the Natural History Museum, who brought a UV torch on the expedition to see which animals perform this trick. \u201cIt\u2019s really dramatic,\u201d he says. As far as he knows, no other scientists have tried shining UV light on deep-sea animals. Maclaine found that some have red-glowing spots, including jewel squid and viperfish, and some, such as lanternfish, don\u2019t. The red dots are light-emitting organs, known as photophores, which actually glow blue when the squid are swimming hundreds of metres underwater. There is no UV light in the deep sea so the photophores don\u2019t glow red in their natural environment. Like the animals they\u2019re trying to spot with their big yellow eye, cockeye squid may use their glowing photophores to disguise their silhouette. Flashing bioluminescent lights could also be a form of squid communication and a way to attract mates. Or they could lure in prey that mistake them for something to eat. \u201cIt\u2019s possibly all of these reasons,\u201d says Ablett, \u201ca little bit of camouflage, a little bit of sexual selection, data-media-id=\"0b1e67bc1e4978345cf8c142f8cc32bf211d91e3\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/0b1e67bc1e4978345cf8c142f8cc32bf211d91e3/2073_352_3443_2066/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Three forces had, by </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>Sexual misconduct and racism claims against officers are proportionally higher in some English forces than at the Metropolitan police, a Guardian investigation has found, as new figures also revealed starkly different approaches to recording.</p> <p>Three forces \u2013 Essex, Suffolk and Staffordshire \u2013 had, by proportion, more officers under investigation due to allegations of racism than the Met, according to the snapshot of investigations covering the period of late January and early February.</p> <p>While 30 officers were under investigation in Suffolk \u2013 a force of 1,298 \u2013 over allegations of racism and 37 at Staffordshire, the figure was as high as 157 at Essex police, according to data released under the Freedom of Information (FoI) Act.</p> <p>Essex police said this was because the force comprehensively followed Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC) guidance that all public complaints around racial discrimination are recorded as an investigation at the point they are lodged. This differs to processes followed by other forces, some of which do not formally record discrimination allegations.</p> <p>A spokesperson for the force, which has more than 3,400 officers, said: \u201cOur approach ensures a better service to the complainant, as they receive a comprehensive report in response to their concerns and any issues arising about officer behaviour are identified. This does also mean that we would expect our figures to be higher than those of some other forces.\u201d</p> <p>Of the 157 Essex police officers under investigation as of 13 January, 70 have been told they have no case to answer. Eighty-six investigations are continuing.</p> <p>Meanwhile, two forces \u2013 Staffordshire and Bedfordshire \u2013 had by proportion more officers officially under investigation for alleged sexual misconduct than the Met.</p> <p>Nineteen officers were being investigated at Staffordshire and 14 at Bedfordshire, according to the snapshot of investigations.</p> <p>Another force with a relatively high proportion of investigations into allegations of racism against its officers was the Civil Nuclear Constabulary, whose ranks had included Sarah Everard\u2019s killer, Wayne Couzens. Twelve officers were under investigation over alleged racism, including seven suspended ones.</p> <p>The figures were obtained by the Guardian through multiple FoI requests, although some forces refused to provide any figures, claiming that doing so could lead to the identification of individuals. This included the British Transport Police.</p> <p>However, the challenges of trying to understand the scale of the problem and comparing the approaches of different police forces was also illustrated by marked variations in the way different forces record complaints.</p> <p>Staffordshire\u2019s figures included some cases where an investigation was no longer active, due to limitations in the force\u2019s recording system, which it is working to resolve.</p> <p>Nevertheless, a spokesperson for the force said there had been an increase in officers under investigation and it believed this was \u201cdue to an increase in confidence in reporting and our robust stance\u201d.</p> <p>Reclaim These Streets, a movement that has campaigned to increase women\u2019s safety, said the figures were still a stark reminder of how policing was in need of reform.</p> <p>\u201cThese numbers demonstrate exactly why it is not appropriate for an all-white leadership team led by Metropolitan police commissioner Mark Rowley to only focus on sexual misconduct,\u201d it said.</p> <p>\u201cThere cannot and should not be a hierarchy of evils so that the squeakiest and loudest wheel gets attention but the others go unchecked. And this is not just a London problem.\u201d</p> <p>Andy George, the president of the National Black Police Association (NBPA), said the data was the type that was needed in order to understand the scale of the problem of racism in police ranks.</p> <p>\u201cSome of the lower figures are, in part, an indication of the lack of trust and confidence some people have about coming forward to make complaints. If you are really isolated in a workforce then it\u2019s particularly hard to come forward,\u201d he added.</p> <p>But the figures alone did not explain why there was such variation among forces, said George, who added that there was a pressing need for a more consistent approach to best practice and recording.</p> <p>\u201cWhen there are more than 40 different models of policing across England and Wales there is no consistency, which is a major challenge in itself,\u201d he said.</p> <p>While the figures showed that just three investigations were under way during the period concerned into allegations of racism in the Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI), George said his own experience of that force was that one-third of all minority ethnic officers had reported experiencing or witnessing racism. The PSNI listed 62 investigations under way for alleged sexual misconduct.</p> <p>Among other larger forces, 33 officers were under investigation for alleged sexual misconduct at West Yorkshire, which has about 5,500 officers. Sixteen were under investigation over alleged racism, eight of which were part of the same case.</p> <p>Police Scotland, which has about 16,644 officers, had 29 investigations under way over allegations of racism and 54 for alleged sexual misconduct.</p> <p>Bedfordshire police\u2019s chief constable, Trevor Rodenhurst, said the force was working relentlessly to identify and root out anyone who did not uphold standards. He added that its efforts would no doubt result in an increase in reports and investigations in the short term \u201cas those who betray our values are removed from the force\u201d.</p> <p>Suffolk constabulary said it was committed to tackling hate crime and racism and this included within the force, adding that employees and volunteers should feel confident that any allegations would be taken seriously and investigated thoroughly.</p> <p>A spokesperson for the National Police Chiefs\u2019 Council said: \u201cThe public rightly expect the highest standards from police officers, and we are working hard to rid policing of abusers and corrupt individuals.</p> <p>\u201cWhen allegations are made and where criminal thresholds are met, we will take robust action against those involved, and we will continue to root out those whose actions do not meet that threshold but who betray our professional standards.\u201d</p>", "newspaperPageNumber": "11", "wordcount": "967", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:32Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T10:39:33Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-17T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nmgjc", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/0b1e67bc1e4978345cf8c142f8cc32bf211d91e3/2073_352_3443_2066/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Sexual misconduct and racism claims against officers are proportionally higher in some English forces than at the Metropolitan police, a Guardian investigation has found, as new figures also revealed starkly different approaches to recording. Three forces \u2013 Essex, Suffolk and Staffordshire \u2013 had, by proportion, more officers under investigation due to allegations of racism than the Met, according to the snapshot of investigations covering the period of late January and early February. While 30 officers were under investigation in Suffolk \u2013 a force of 1,298 \u2013 over allegations of racism and 37 at Staffordshire, the figure was as high as 157 at Essex police, according to data released under the Freedom of Information (FoI) Act. Essex police said this was because the force comprehensively followed Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC) guidance that all public complaints around racial discrimination are recorded as an investigation at the point they are lodged. This differs to processes followed by other forces, some of which do not formally record discrimination allegations. A spokesperson for the force, which has more than 3,400 officers, said: \u201cOur approach ensures a better service to the complainant, as they receive a comprehensive report in response to their concerns and any issues arising about officer behaviour are identified. This does also mean that we would expect our figures to be higher than those of some other forces.\u201d Of the 157 Essex police officers under investigation as of 13 January, 70 have been told they have no case to answer. Eighty-six investigations are continuing. Meanwhile, two forces \u2013 Staffordshire and Bedfordshire \u2013 had by proportion more officers officially under investigation for alleged sexual misconduct than the Met. Nineteen officers were being investigated at Staffordshire and 14 at Bedfordshire, according to the snapshot of investigations. Another force with a relatively high proportion of investigations into allegations of racism against its officers was the Civil Nuclear Constabulary, whose ranks had included Sarah Everard\u2019s killer, Wayne Couzens. Twelve officers were under investigation over alleged racism, including seven suspended ones. The figures were obtained by the Guardian through multiple FoI requests, although some forces refused to provide any figures, claiming that doing so could lead to the identification of individuals. This included the British Transport Police. However, the challenges of trying to understand the scale of the problem and comparing the approaches of different police forces was also illustrated by marked variations in the way different forces record complaints. Staffordshire\u2019s figures included some cases where an investigation was no longer active, due to limitations in the force\u2019s recording system, which it is working to resolve. Nevertheless, a spokesperson for the force said there had been an increase in officers under investigation and it believed this was \u201cdue to an increase in confidence in reporting and our robust stance\u201d. Reclaim These Streets, a movement that has campaigned to increase women\u2019s safety, said the figures were still a stark reminder of how policing was in need of reform. \u201cThese numbers demonstrate exactly why it is not appropriate for an all-white leadership team led by Metropolitan police commissioner Mark Rowley to only focus on sexual misconduct,\u201d it said. \u201cThere cannot and should not be a hierarchy of evils so that the squeakiest and loudest wheel gets attention but the others go unchecked. And this is not just a London problem.\u201d Andy George, the president of the National Black Police Association (NBPA), said the data was the type that was needed in order to understand the scale of the problem of racism in police ranks. \u201cSome of the lower figures are, in part, an indication of the lack of trust and confidence some people have about coming forward to make complaints. If you are really isolated in a workforce then it\u2019s particularly hard to come forward,\u201d he added. The PSNI listed 62 investigations under way for alleged sexual misconduct. Among other larger forces, 33 officers were under investigation for alleged sexual misconduct at West Yorkshire, which has about 5,500 officers. Sixteen were under investigation over alleged racism, eight of which were part of the same case. Police Scotland, which has about 16,644 officers, had 29 investigations under way over allegations of racism and 54 for alleged sexual misconduct. Bedfordshire police\u2019s chief constable, Trevor Rodenhurst, said the force was working relentlessly to identify and root out anyone who did not uphold standards. He added that its efforts would no doubt result in an increase in reports and investigations in the short term \u201cas those who betray our values are removed from the force\u201d. Suffolk constabulary said it was committed to tackling hate crime and racism and this included within the force, adding that employees and volunteers should feel confident that any allegations would be taken seriously and investigated thoroughly. revealed starkly different approaches to recording.</p> <p>Three forces \u2013 Essex, Suffolk and Staffordshire \u2013 had, by proportion, more officers under investigation due to allegations of police said this was because the force comprehensively followed Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC) guidance that all public complaints around racial discrimination are recorded as an investigation at the point they are lodged. This differs to processes followed by other forces, some of which do not formally record discrimination allegations.</p> <p>A spokesperson for the force, which has more than 3,400 officers, said: \u201cOur approach ensures a better service to the complainant, as they receive a comprehensive report in response to their concerns and any issues arising about officer behaviour are identified. This does also mean that we would expect our figures to be higher than those of some other forces.\u201d</p> <p>Of the 157 Essex police officers under investigation as of 13 January, 70 have been told they have no case to answer. Eighty-six investigations are continuing.</p> <p>Meanwhile, two forces \u2013 Staffordshire and Bedfordshire \u2013 had by proportion more officers officially under investigation for alleged sexual misconduct than the Met.</p> <p>Nineteen officers were being investigated at Staffordshire and 14 at Bedfordshire, according to the snapshot of investigations.</p> <p>Another force with a relatively high proportion of investigations into allegations of racism against its officers was the Civil Nuclear Constabulary, whose ranks had included Sarah Everard\u2019s killer, Wayne Couzens. Twelve officers were under investigation over alleged racism, including seven suspended ones.</p> <p>The figures were obtained by the Guardian through multiple FoI requests, although some forces refused to provide any figures, claiming that doing so could lead to the identification of individuals. This included the British Transport Police.</p> <p>However, the challenges of trying to understand the scale of the problem and comparing the approaches of different police forces was also illustrated by marked variations in the way different forces record complaints.</p> <p>Staffordshire\u2019s figures included some cases where an investigation was no longer active, due to limitations in the force\u2019s recording system, which it is working to resolve.</p> <p>Nevertheless, a spokesperson for the force said there had been an increase in officers under investigation and it believed this was \u201cdue to an increase in confidence in reporting and our robust stance\u201d.</p> <p>Reclaim These Streets, a movement that has campaigned to increase women\u2019s safety, said the figures were still a stark reminder of how policing was in need of reform.</p> <p>\u201cThese numbers demonstrate exactly why it is not appropriate for an all-white leadership team led by Metropolitan police commissioner Mark Rowley to only focus on sexual misconduct,\u201d it said.</p> <p>\u201cThere cannot and should not be a hierarchy of evils so that the squeakiest and loudest wheel gets attention but the others go unchecked. And this is not just a London problem.\u201d</p> <p>Andy George, the president of the National Black Police Association (NBPA), said the data was the type that was needed in order to understand the scale of the problem of racism in police ranks.</p> <p>\u201cSome of the lower figures are, in part, an indication of the lack of trust and confidence some people have about coming forward to make complaints. If you are really isolated in a workforce then it\u2019s particularly hard to come forward,\u201d he added.</p> <p>But the figures alone did not explain why there was such variation among forces, said George, who added that there was a pressing need for a more consistent approach to best practice and recording.</p> <p>\u201cWhen there are more than 40 different models of policing across England and Wales there is no consistency, which is a major challenge in itself,\u201d he said.</p> <p>While the figures showed that just three investigations were under way during the period concerned into allegations of racism in the Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI), George said his own experience of that force was that one-third of all minority ethnic officers had reported experiencing or witnessing racism. The PSNI listed 62 investigations under way for alleged sexual misconduct.</p> <p>Among other larger forces, 33 officers were under investigation for alleged sexual misconduct at West Yorkshire, which has about 5,500 officers. He added that its efforts would no doubt result in an increase in reports and investigations in the short term \u201cas those who betray our values are removed from the force\u201d.</p> <p>Suffolk constabulary said it was committed to tackling hate crime and racism and this included within the force, adding that employees and volunteers should feel confident that any allegations would be taken seriously and investigated thoroughly.</p> <p>A spokesperson for the National Police Chiefs\u2019 Council said: \u201cThe public rightly expect the highest standards from police officers, and we are working hard to rid policing of abusers and corrupt individuals.</p> <p>\u201cWhen allegations are made and where criminal thresholds are met, we will take robust action against those involved, and we will continue to root out those whose actions do not meet that threshold but who betray our professional standards.\u201d</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "Sexual misconduct and racism claims against officers are proportionally higher in some English forces than at the Metropolitan police, a Guardian investigation has found, as new figures also revealed starkly different approaches to recording. Three forces \u2013 Essex, Suffolk and Staffordshire \u2013 had, by proportion, more officers under investigation due to allegations of racism than the Met, according to the snapshot of investigations covering the period of late January and early February. While 30 officers were under investigation in Suffolk \u2013 a force of 1,298 \u2013 over allegations of racism and 37 at Staffordshire, the figure was as high as 157 at Essex police, according to data released under the Freedom of Information (FoI) Act. Essex police said this was because the force comprehensively followed Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC) guidance that all public complaints around racial discrimination are recorded as an investigation at the point they are lodged. This differs to processes followed by other forces, some of which do not formally record discrimination allegations. A spokesperson for the force, which has more than 3,400 officers, said: \u201cOur approach ensures a better service to the complainant, as they receive a comprehensive report in response to their concerns and any issues arising about officer behaviour are identified. This does also mean that we would expect our figures to be higher than those of some other forces.\u201d Of the 157 Essex police officers under investigation as of 13 January, 70 have been told they have no case to answer. Eighty-six investigations are continuing. Meanwhile, two forces \u2013 Staffordshire and Bedfordshire \u2013 had by proportion more officers officially under investigation for alleged sexual misconduct than the Met. Nineteen officers were being investigated at Staffordshire and 14 at Bedfordshire, according to the snapshot of investigations. Another force with a relatively high proportion of investigations into allegations of racism against its officers was the Civil Nuclear Constabulary, whose ranks had included Sarah Everard\u2019s killer, Wayne Couzens. Twelve officers were under investigation over alleged racism, including seven suspended ones. The figures were obtained by the Guardian through multiple FoI requests, although some forces refused to provide any figures, claiming that doing so could lead to the identification of individuals. This included the British Transport Police. However, the challenges of trying to understand the scale of the problem and comparing the approaches of different police forces was also illustrated by marked variations in the way different forces record complaints. Staffordshire\u2019s figures included some cases where an investigation was no longer active, due to limitations in the force\u2019s recording system, which it is working to resolve. Nevertheless, a spokesperson for the force said there had been an increase in officers under investigation and it believed this was \u201cdue to an increase in confidence in reporting and our robust stance\u201d. Reclaim These Streets, a movement that has campaigned to increase women\u2019s safety, said the figures were still a stark reminder of how policing was in need of reform. \u201cThese numbers demonstrate exactly why it is not appropriate for an all-white leadership team led by Metropolitan police commissioner Mark Rowley to only focus on sexual misconduct,\u201d it said. \u201cThere cannot and should not be a hierarchy of evils so that the squeakiest and loudest wheel gets attention but the others go unchecked. And this is not just a London problem.\u201d Andy George, the president of the National Black Police Association (NBPA), said the data was the type that was needed in order to understand the scale of the problem of racism in police ranks. \u201cSome of the lower figures are, in part, an indication of the lack of trust and confidence some people have about coming forward to make complaints. If you are really isolated in a workforce then it\u2019s particularly hard to come forward,\u201d he added. But the figures alone did not explain why there was such variation among forces, said George, who added that there was a pressing need for a more consistent approach to best practice and recording. \u201cWhen there are more than 40 different models of policing across England and Wales there is no consistency, which is a major challenge in itself,\u201d he said. \n</figure>", "body": "<p>The name and logo are familiar to the hundreds of thousands of people who visit every year to climb the peaks, explore the fast-flowing streams and rivers and unwind in the towns and villages.</p> \n<p>But from Monday the Brecon Beacons national park is dropping its English language name and scrapping its logo of a fiery greenhouse gas-emitting beacon as it launches a plan designed to tackle issues in the park created by the climate and biodiversity emergencies.</p> \n<p>The park in southern Wales is to be known as Bannau Brycheiniog \u2013 pronounced Ban-eye Bruck-ein-iog \u2013 national park or informally The Bannau.</p> \n<p>Bannau is the plural of \u201cban\u201d, which means peak in Welsh, while Brycheiniog refers to the kingdom of the fifth-century king Brychan, so the name translates into English as the Peaks of Brychan\u2019s Kingdom.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image element--thumbnail\" data-media-id=\"f2e1750e77a1d19ef14faf1c1d5499b50d7e61dd\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/f2e1750e77a1d19ef14faf1c1d5499b50d7e61dd/0_0_1192_312/1000.jpg\" alt=\"New Bannau Brycheiniog national park logo\" width=\"1000\" height=\"262\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">New Bannau Brycheiniog national park logo</span> <span the park.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"4044ce45210e80334e61026261ed8de513f406a5\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/4044ce45210e80334e61026261ed8de513f406a5/0_223_6690_4014/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Hikers in Bannau Brycheiniog.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Hikers in Bannau Brycheiniog.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Tim Jones</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>The name change has caused political debate in Wales with the Tories suggesting the funds spent on it could have been better spent elsewhere.</p> \n<p>The Welsh Conservative shadow minister for Mid-Wales James Evans said: \u201cI am concerned that the whole rebranding exercise by the national park is not a priority for the people and the businesses who live in the park. Many of the residents in the area will also be wondering how much the rebranding exercise is going to cost.\u201d</p> \n<p>But the Welsh Liberal Democrat leader Jane Dodds said: \u201cOther countries like New Zealand see the use of their indigenous languages such as M\u0101ori as not only key to protecting their history and culture, but also as a key marketing tool. There is no reason we shouldn\u2019t be doing so in Wales.\u201d</p> \n<p>Plaid Cymru\u2019s spokesperson for the Welsh language, Heledd Fychan, said: \u201cThis decision by the national park is a positive step in normalising the use of Welsh.</p> \n<p>\u201cIn reclaiming our original Welsh names, we can reclaim our heritage, which is vital if we want our language to continue to play a role in Wales\u2019s future.\u201d</p> \n<p>The launch is being promoted with a stirring short film, written by the novelist, poet and playwright Owen Sheers, who was brought up <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/mar/24/owen-sheers-on-gwent-its-a-more-ancient-world-than-londons-\">in an old Welsh longhouse outside Abergavenny</a>, and featuring <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/2022/sep/13/wales-football-squad-michael-sheen-speech-a-league-of-their-own\">the actor and activist Michael Sheen,</a> who hails from south Wales.</p> \n<p>It is entitled Cynefin, a Welsh word that <a href=\"https://www.owensheers.co.uk/\">Sheers</a> defines as \u201ca landscape which, as you step into it, feels like arriving at your hearth\u201d and opens with Sheen striding across a beautiful hillside.</p> \n<p>The film, however, cuts to less picturesque aspects of the park including dumped rubbish, polluted water and wildfires. It depicts a depleted landscape where birds such as the curlew, swallow and rook are struggling and rivers \u2013 the \u201cveins\u201d of the landscape \u2013 are sluggish with nitrates and phosphates.</p> \n<p>According to the film, this is a place \u201chooked\u201d on carbon, diesel, petrol and oil, and with a human population that is growing older, younger people forced out because of the lack of well-paid jobs and affordable housing.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-atom\"> <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"815c4f66-5bb2-44ee-86cf-8e1ac6add599\" data-atom-type=\"media\"> \n  <div>\n   <iframe frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" src=\"https://www.youtube-nocookie.com/embed/1HJGKGoS9AY?showinfo=0&amp;rel=0\"></iframe>\n  </div>\n </gu-atom> \n</figure> \n<p>The film looks forward to a better future that it hopes the new plan will create \u2013 skies filled with birds, dark nights \u201cthick with stars\u201d, water running \u201cwith life, not pollution\u201d and young people nurtured by culture and educational opportunities.</p> \n<p>Explaining why he was keen to be involved in the launch, Sheen said the park was much more than a place of beauty and inspiration.</p> \n<p>\u201cNational parks have a vital role to play in providing for nature, for people, and for our shared future,\u201d he said. He welcomed the reclamation of the Welsh name as \u201can old name for a new way of being\u201d.</p> \n<p>The rationale for the name and logo change is that the 520 sq miles (1,350 sq km) of park covers a much greater area than the central Beacons range \u2013 and that it shows a commitment to the Welsh language.</p> \n<p>As well as the flaming beacon not fitting with the park\u2019s ethos, the management says there is no evidence of burning beacons ever existing on its summits.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image element--thumbnail\" data-media-id=\"7f60069be21daa7dd5c8d86718c99b71bc6dd0e9\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/7f60069be21daa7dd5c8d86718c99b71bc6dd0e9/0_0_1804_2527/714.jpg\" alt=\"Od Brecon Beacons national park logo\" width=\"714\" height=\"1000\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Od Brecon Beacons national park logo</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph:</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>The park authority CEO, Catherine Mealing-Jones, said: \u201cThe more we looked into it the more we realised the name Brecon Beacons doesn\u2019t make any sense. It\u2019s a very English description of something that probably never happened. A massive carbon-burning brazier is not a good look for an environmental organisation.\u201d</p> \n<p>Snowdonia national park authority <a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-63649930\">voted last year to use Yr Wyddfa and Eryri</a> rather than Snowdon and Snowdonia after 5,000 people signed a petition calling for the change.</p> \n<p>\u201cWelsh names are beautiful,\u201d Mealing-Jones said. \u201cThey are very descriptive. We\u2019re not demanding people use the Welsh name, but gradually it will catch on, hopefully.\u201d</p> \n<p>The management plan sets goals including reaching net zero greenhouse gas emissions across the park by 2035, ensuring water resources and water environments are clean, safe and resilient by 2030 and creating thriving and sustainable places for people as well as nature.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"93e1087b43f821ab4eb5d35abb70944dda862065\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/93e1087b43f821ab4eb5d35abb70944dda862065/0_192_5760_3456/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Frosty sunrise in Bannau Brycheiniog.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Frosty sunrise in Bannau Brycheiniog.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Anthony Pease</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>It flags up problems such as the second-home crisis that is hollowing out communities and the issue of some of the park\u2019s favourite spots such as <a href=\"https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/visit/wales/sugar-loaf-and-usk-valley\">Sugar Loaf mountain</a> suffering because they draw too many visitors. But it is also keen to make the point that everyone must feel welcomed in the park regardless of their background.</p> \n<p>The plan includes images of what it hopes the park can become within 25 years \u2013 still beautiful, with more biodiversity, a recovering natural world and lively communities.</p> \n<p>Mealing-Jones said: \u201cPeople are making a living in the park. There are still sheep on the hills, still cattle grazing. But there are more trees, peatland is being restored, species are coming back. There are small-scale market gardens, small wind turbines, vineyards, water being slowed down. It is a reinvention of what a national park is all about, a picture of hope for the future.\u201d</p>", "newspaperPageNumber": "13", "wordcount": "970", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:32Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T12:30:12Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-17T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnam8", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/0c2e5362e01bacb545c213696ae9352dec25f197/0_348_4592_2756/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "The name and logo are familiar to the hundreds of thousands of people who visit every year to climb the peaks, explore the fast-flowing streams and rivers and unwind in the towns and villages. But from Monday the Brecon Beacons national park is dropping its English language name and scrapping its logo of a fiery greenhouse gas-emitting beacon as it launches a plan designed to tackle issues in the park created by the climate and biodiversity emergencies. The park in southern Wales is to be known as Bannau Brycheiniog \u2013 pronounced Ban-eye Bruck-ein-iog \u2013 national park or informally The Bannau. Bannau is the plural of \u201cban\u201d, which means peak in Welsh, while Brycheiniog refers to the kingdom of the fifth-century king Brychan, so the name translates into English as the Peaks of Brychan\u2019s Kingdom. The new logo is more muted and features nods to a king\u2019s crown and the starry skies, hills and watercourses of the park. The name change has caused political debate in Wales with the Tories suggesting the funds spent on it could have been better spent elsewhere. The Welsh Conservative shadow minister for Mid-Wales James Evans said: \u201cI am concerned that the whole rebranding exercise by the national park is not a priority for the people and the businesses who live in the park. Many of the residents in the area will also be wondering how much the rebranding exercise is going to cost.\u201d But the Welsh Liberal Democrat leader Jane Dodds said: \u201cOther countries like New Zealand see the use of their indigenous languages such as M\u0101ori as not only key to protecting their history and culture, but also as a key marketing tool. There is no reason we shouldn\u2019t be doing so in Wales.\u201d Plaid Cymru\u2019s spokesperson for the Welsh language, Heledd Fychan, said: \u201cThis decision by the national park is a positive step in normalising the use of Welsh. \u201cIn reclaiming our original Welsh names, we can reclaim our heritage, which is vital if we want our language to continue to play a role in Wales\u2019s future.\u201d The launch is being promoted with a stirring short film, written by the novelist, poet and playwright Owen Sheers, who was brought up in an old Welsh longhouse outside Abergavenny, and featuring the actor and activist Michael Sheen, who hails from south Wales. It is entitled Cynefin, a Welsh word that Sheers defines as \u201ca landscape which, as you step into it, feels like arriving at your hearth\u201d and opens with Sheen striding across a beautiful hillside. The film, however, cuts to less picturesque aspects of the park including dumped rubbish, polluted water and wildfires. It depicts a depleted landscape where birds such as the curlew, swallow and rook are struggling and rivers \u2013 the \u201cveins\u201d of the landscape \u2013 are sluggish with nitrates and phosphates. According to the film, this is a place \u201chooked\u201d on carbon, diesel, petrol and oil, and with a human population that is growing older, younger people forced out because of the lack of well-paid jobs and affordable housing. The film looks forward to a better future that it hopes the new plan will create \u2013 skies filled with birds, dark nights \u201cthick with stars\u201d, water running \u201cwith life, not pollution\u201d and young people nurtured by culture and educational opportunities. Explaining why he was keen to be involved in the launch, Sheen said the park was much more than a place of beauty and inspiration. \u201cNational parks have a vital role to play in providing for nature, for people, and for our shared future,\u201d he said. He welcomed the reclamation of the Welsh name as \u201can old name for a new way of being\u201d. The rationale for the name and logo change is that the 520 sq miles (1,350 sq km) of park covers a much greater area than the central Beacons range \u2013 and that it shows a commitment to the Welsh language. As well as the flaming beacon not fitting with the park\u2019s ethos, the management says there is no evidence of burning beacons ever existing on its summits. The park authority CEO, Catherine Mealing-Jones, said: \u201cThe more we looked into it the more we realised the name Brecon Beacons doesn\u2019t make any sense. It\u2019s a very English description of something that probably never happened. A massive carbon-burning brazier is not a good look for an environmental organisation.\u201d Snowdonia national park authority voted last year to use Yr Wyddfa and Eryri rather than Snowdon and Snowdonia after 5,000 people signed a petition calling for the change. \u201cWelsh names are beautiful,\u201d Mealing-Jones said. \u201cThey are very descriptive. We\u2019re not demanding people use the Welsh name, but gradually it will catch on, hopefully.\u201d The management plan sets goals including reaching net zero greenhouse gas emissions across the park by 2035, ensuring water resources and water environments are clean, safe and resilient by 2030 and creating thriving and sustainable places for people as well as nature. It flags up problems such as the second-home crisis that is hollowing out communities and the issue of some of the park\u2019s favourite spots such as Sugar Loaf mountain suffering because they draw too many visitors. But it is also keen to make the point that everyone must feel welcomed in the park regardless of their background. The plan includes images of what it hopes the park can become within 25 years \u2013 still beautiful, with more biodiversity, a recovering natural world and lively communities. Mealing-Jones said: \u201cPeople are making a living in the park. There are still sheep on the hills, still cattle grazing. But there are more trees, peatland is being restored, species are coming back. There are small-scale market gardens, small wind turbines, vineyards, water being slowed down. It is a reinvention of what a national park is all about, a picture of hope for the future.\u201d", "charCount": "5733", "shouldHideReaderRevenue": "false", "showAffiliateLinks": "false", "<p>The name and logo are familiar to the hundreds of thousands of people who visit every year to climb the peaks, explore the fast-flowing streams and rivers and unwind in the towns and villages.</p> \n<p>But from Monday the Brecon Beacons national park is dropping its English language name and scrapping its logo of a fiery greenhouse gas-emitting beacon as it launches a plan designed to tackle issues in the park created by the climate and biodiversity emergencies.</p> \n<p>The park in southern Wales is to be known as Bannau Brycheiniog \u2013 pronounced Ban-eye Bruck-ein-iog \u2013 national park or informally The Bannau.</p> \n<p>Bannau is the plural of \u201cban\u201d, which means peak in Welsh, while Brycheiniog refers to the kingdom of the fifth-century king Brychan, so the name translates into English as the Peaks of Brychan\u2019s Kingdom.</p>"}}, {"type": "image", "assets": [{"type": "image", "mimeType": "image/jpeg", "file": "assets": [], "textTypeData": {"html": "<p>The name change has caused political debate in Wales with the Tories suggesting the funds spent on it could have been better spent elsewhere.</p> \n<p>The Welsh Conservative shadow minister for Mid-Wales James Evans said: \u201cI am concerned that the whole rebranding exercise by the national park is not a priority for the people and the businesses who live in the park. Many of the residents in the area will also be wondering how much the rebranding exercise is going to cost.\u201d</p> \n<p>But the Welsh Liberal Democrat leader Jane Dodds said: \u201cOther countries like New Zealand see the use of their indigenous languages such as M\u0101ori as not only key to protecting their history and culture, but also as a key marketing tool. There is no reason we shouldn\u2019t be doing so in Wales.\u201d</p> \n<p>Plaid Cymru\u2019s spokesperson for the Welsh language, Heledd Fychan, said: \u201cThis decision by the national park is a positive step in normalising the use of Welsh.</p> \n<p>\u201cIn reclaiming our original Welsh names, we can reclaim our heritage, which is vital if we want our language to continue to play a role in Wales\u2019s future.\u201d</p> \n<p>The launch is being promoted with a stirring short film, written by the novelist, poet and playwright Owen Sheers, who was brought up <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/mar/24/owen-sheers-on-gwent-its-a-more-ancient-world-than-londons-\">in an old Welsh longhouse outside Abergavenny</a>, and featuring <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/2022/sep/13/wales-football-squad-michael-sheen-speech-a-league-of-their-own\">the actor and activist Michael Sheen,</a> who hails from south Wales.</p> \n<p>It is entitled Cynefin, a Welsh word that <a href=\"https://www.owensheers.co.uk/\">Sheers</a> defines as \u201ca landscape which, as you step into it, feels like arriving at your hearth\u201d and opens with Sheen striding across a beautiful hillside.</p> \n<p>The film, however, cuts to less picturesque aspects of the park including dumped rubbish, polluted water and wildfires. It depicts a depleted landscape where birds such as the curlew, swallow and rook are struggling and rivers \u2013 the \u201cveins\u201d of the landscape \u2013 are sluggish with nitrates and phosphates.</p> \n<p>According to the film, this is a place \u201chooked\u201d on carbon, diesel, petrol and oil, and with a human population that is growing older, younger people forced out because of the lack of well-paid jobs and affordable housing.</p>"}}, {"type": "contentatom", "assets": [], "contentAtomTypeData": {"atomId": "815c4f66-5bb2-44ee-86cf-8e1ac6add599", "atomType": "media", "isMandatory": true}}, {"type": "text", "assets": [], "textTypeData": {"html": "<p>The film looks forward to a better future that it hopes the new plan will create \u2013 skies filled with birds, dark nights \u201cthick with stars\u201d, water running \u201cwith life, not pollution\u201d and young people nurtured by culture and educational opportunities.</p> \n<p>Explaining why he was keen to be involved in the launch, Sheen said the park was much more than a place of beauty and inspiration.</p> \n<p>\u201cNational parks have a vital role to play in providing for nature, for people, and for our shared future,\u201d he said. </figure>", "body": "<p>Some councils in England take far more than a month on average to repair potholes, with some individual potholes remaining in place for 18 months, research by the Liberal Democrats has shown.</p> <p>Based on freedom of information requests to councils in advance of next month\u2019s local elections, the data uncovered nine councils where the average pothole repair time is four weeks or longer.</p> <p>Newham council in east London took an average of 56 days per reported pothole, the responses found, with Lambeth, in south London, averaging 50 days.</p> <p>Data from 2017-18 showed that the average repair time in Lambeth then was 14 days, the Lib Dems said, arguing that the increase since is due to significant cuts to local authorities\u2019 highways maintenance grants.</p> <p>Overall, of the 81 English councils which provided data, nine had waiting times for fixing potholes of 28 days or more, also including Stoke-on-Trent, Norfolk, North East Lincolnshire, Westminster, Southampton, West Sussex, and Hammersmith and Fulham.</p> <p>On individual potholes, the longest recorded example was in Stoke-on-Trent, with a gap of 567 days between reporting and fixing, just beating the 556 days for one example in Westminster.</p> <p>The Lib Dems said a \u00a3500m cut to highways maintenance budgets since 2020-21, only partly made up for by a \u00a3200m \u201cpotholes fund\u201d in the budget in March, had caused a \u201cpothole postcode lottery\u201d.</p> <p>In total, the councils reported 556,658 potholes in the year 2021-22, up from 519,968 in 2017/18. Derbyshire county council had the most reported potholes at 90,596.</p> <p>Helen Morgan, the Lib Dems\u2019 local government spokesperson, said: \u201cPotholes have become a plague on our roads. Motorists should not have to spend their journeys choosing between hitting potholes or dangerously swerving around an obstacle course of tarmac craters.</p> <p>\u201cHard-working people are paying huge bills to repair damage from potholes, while this Conservative government takes away the money local councils need to repair our roads. It is not fair for local residents in some areas of the country to be waiting over a year for road repairs because their council cannot afford it.\u201d</p> <p>The Conservatives have also used potholes as part of their local election campaigning. At the end of last month, Rishi Sunak used a trip to Darlington to pledge more action on the subject, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/politics/live/2023/mar/31/rishi-sunak-kemi-badenoch-trade-deal-conservatives-tory-labour-keir-starmer-latest-politics-updates\">staring into one</a> in a much-used photograph from the visit.</p> <p>Sunak announced plans for a more rigorous enforcement regime over potholes, plus the \u00a3200m fund, neither of which are new policies.</p> <p>A Department for Transport spokesperson said: \u201cWe\u2019re investing more than \u00a35.5bn to maintain roads up and down the country, and cracking down on utility companies that leave potholes in their wake, so motorists and cyclists can enjoy smoother, safer journeys.\u201d</p>", "newspaperPageNumber": "9", "wordcount": "447", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:31Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T05:00:31Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-17T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnbpc", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/fcfab8efb93ca06ef092816b69e55a37a42c9ea5/0_92_3000_1801/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Some councils in England take far more than a month on average to repair potholes, with some individual potholes remaining in place for 18 months, research by the Liberal Democrats has shown. Based on freedom of information requests to councils in advance of next month\u2019s local elections, the data uncovered nine councils where the average pothole repair time is four weeks or longer. Newham council in east London took an average of 56 days per reported pothole, the responses found, with Lambeth, in south London, averaging 50 days. Data from 2017-18 showed that the average repair time in Lambeth then was 14 days, the Lib Dems said, arguing that the increase since is due to significant cuts to local authorities\u2019 highways maintenance grants. Overall, of the 81 English councils which provided data, nine had waiting times for fixing potholes of 28 days or more, also including Stoke-on-Trent, Norfolk, North East Lincolnshire, Westminster, Southampton, West Sussex, and Hammersmith and Fulham. The Lib Dems said a \u00a3500m cut to highways maintenance budgets since 2020-21, only partly made up for by a \u00a3200m \u201cpotholes fund\u201d in the budget in March, had caused a \u201cpothole postcode lottery\u201d. In total, the councils reported 556,658 potholes in the year 2021-22, up from 519,968 in 2017/18. Derbyshire county council had the most reported potholes at 90,596. Helen Morgan, the Lib Dems\u2019 local government spokesperson, said: \u201cPotholes have become a plague on our roads. Motorists should not have to spend their journeys choosing between hitting potholes or dangerously swerving around an obstacle course of tarmac craters. \u201cHard-working people are paying huge bills to repair damage from potholes, while this Conservative government takes away the money local councils need to repair our roads. with some individual potholes remaining in place for 18 months, research by the Liberal Democrats has shown.</p> <p>Based on freedom of information requests to councils in advance of next month\u2019s local elections, the data uncovered nine councils where the average pothole repair time is four weeks or longer.</p> <p>Newham council in east London took an average of 56 days per reported pothole, the responses found, with Lambeth, in south London, averaging 50 days.</p> <p>Data from 2017-18 showed that the average repair time in Lambeth then was 14 days, the Lib Dems said, arguing that the increase since is due to significant cuts to local authorities\u2019 highways maintenance grants.</p> <p>Overall, of the 81 English councils which provided data, nine had waiting times for fixing potholes of 28 days or more, also including Stoke-on-Trent, Norfolk, North East Lincolnshire, Westminster, Southampton, West Sussex, and Hammersmith and Fulham.</p> <p>On individual potholes, the longest recorded example was in Stoke-on-Trent, with a gap of 567 days between reporting and fixing, just beating the 556 days for one example in Westminster.</p> <p>The Lib Dems said a \u00a3500m cut to highways maintenance budgets since 2020-21, only partly made up for by a \u00a3200m \u201cpotholes fund\u201d in the budget in March, had caused a \u201cpothole postcode lottery\u201d.</p> <p>In total, the councils reported 556,658 potholes in the year 2021-22, up from 519,968 in 2017/18. Derbyshire county council had the most reported potholes at 90,596.</p> <p>Helen Morgan, the Lib Dems\u2019 local government spokesperson, said: \u201cPotholes have become a plague on our roads. Motorists should not have to spend their journeys choosing between hitting potholes or dangerously swerving around an obstacle course of tarmac craters.</p> <p>\u201cHard-working people are paying huge bills to repair damage from potholes, while this Conservative government takes away the money local councils need to repair our roads. It is not fair for local residents in some areas of the country to be waiting over a year for road repairs because their council cannot afford it.\u201d</p> <p>The Conservatives have also used potholes as part of their local election campaigning. At the end of last month, Rishi Sunak used a trip to Darlington to pledge more action on the subject, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/politics/live/2023/mar/31/rishi-sunak-kemi-badenoch-trade-deal-conservatives-tory-labour-keir-starmer-latest-politics-updates\">staring into one</a> in a much-used photograph from the visit.</p> <p>Sunak announced plans for a more rigorous enforcement regime over potholes, plus the \u00a3200m fund, neither of which are new policies.</p> <p>A Department for Transport spokesperson said: \u201cWe\u2019re investing more than \u00a35.5bn to maintain roads up and down the country, and cracking down on utility companies that leave potholes in their wake, so motorists and cyclists can enjoy smoother, safer journeys.\u201d</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "Some councils in England take far more than a month on average to repair potholes, with some individual potholes remaining in place for 18 months, research by the Liberal Democrats has shown. "2023-04-17T05:00:31Z", "webTitle": "Home Office\u2019s Windrush payout scheme needs urgent reform, study finds", "webUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/uk-news/2023/apr/17/home-offices-windrush-payout-scheme-needs-urgent-reform-study-finds", "fields": {"headline": "Home Office\u2019s Windrush payout scheme needs urgent reform, study finds", "standfirst": "<p>Human Rights Watch says claimants\u2019 rights are being violated, with high obstacles to making claims and low awards</p>", "trailText": "Human Rights data-media-id=\"86c80feb529b276cebd2d2b0617402b8d5e08402\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/86c80feb529b276cebd2d2b0617402b8d5e08402/0_276_5743_3446/1000.jpg\" alt=\"justice for Windrush placard\" light.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Thabo Jaiyesimi/Sopa Images/Shutterstock</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>The Windrush compensation scheme is failing claimants and violating their rights, the first international study into the government\u2019s handling of the immigration scandal has concluded.</p> <p>The Human Rights Watch <a href=\"https://www.hrw.org/news/2023/04/17/uk-hostile-compensation-scheme-fails-windrush-victims\">report</a> is critical of the Home Office\u2019s slow progress towards compensating those affected by the scandal in which thousands of UK residents were wrongly categorised as immigration offenders, and called on the government to launch \u201curgent reform to protect the rights of claimants\u201d.</p> <p>The rights organisation has questioned the wisdom of allowing the Home Office to be in charge of the compensation programme designed to deliver justice to those affected by the department\u2019s mistakes, and recommends handing the scheme to an independent, neutral organisation.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/07/windrush-victim-joseph-mowlah-baksh-dwp-documentation\">\u2018Like a blocked gate I can\u2019t climb over\u2019: a Windrush victim\u2019s DWP impasse </a> </p> </aside>  <p>The report highlighted the complexity of the 44-page compensation application form, and criticises the absence of legal aid to support applicants, who have found it challenging to provide evidence demonstrating that they lost work, housing, healthcare and benefits as a direct result of the Home Office\u2019s errors.</p> <p>Anna Steiner, a solicitor and senior lecturer at the University of Westminster who co-founded the pro bono <a href=\"https://windrushjc.org/\">Windrush Justice Clinic</a> that assists Windrush claimants, told researchers it took lawyers a minimum of 40 hours to prepare a claim for compensation, with much of that time dedicated to making a detailed statement about the impact the ordeal has had on those affected.</p> <p>The report noted that initial offers of compensation were often very low, but were regularly later increased on appeal. All 11 claimants interviewed for the research said they had appealed against their initial compensation offer, and this was confirmed as standard practice by lawyers who assisted claimants. Steiner said in some cases where applications were resubmitted without new evidence the Home Office had doubled its first compensation offer, suggesting that the officials did not pay close attention to the evidence the first time around.</p> <p>Two claimants interviewed for the study said they had been made homeless after being misclassified as immigration offenders, but had later been unable to prove to the satisfaction of compensation scheme caseworkers that their homelessness was the result of being unable to prove their lawful immigration status, because they had no paperwork stating clearly that this was the case.</p> <p>\u201cI can\u2019t put across how tiring and traumatic the scheme is. It\u2019s so draining,\u201d Charlotte Tobierre, who helped her father claim compensation after he lost his job when he was stripped of his legal status, told researchers.</p> <p>The Human Rights Watch study is published exactly five years after Theresa May apologised for the mistakes made by her Home Office, many of which were the direct result of the introduction of a series of hostile environment policies. \u201cFive years after the Windrush scandal came to light, the Home Office compensation scheme is compounding its injustice by denying claimants their right to redress for the life-altering losses and negative effects it has had on their lives for years,\u201d said <a href=\"https://www.hrw.org/about/people/almaz-teffera\">Almaz Teffera</a>, researcher on racism in Europe at Human Rights Watch.</p> <p>\u201cThe failure of the Windrush compensation scheme and the scandal itself are connected to unresolved institutional racism that dates back to the British Empire. To avoid more Windrush-style scandals, the UK government should urgently reform its immigration system in response to international and national concerns about the existence of deeply rooted racism.\u201d</p> <p>A Home Office spokesperson said a series of improvements had been made to the scheme, adding: \u201cWe remain absolutely committed to righting the wrongs of Windrush and have paid or offered more than \u00a368m in compensation to the people affected. The home secretary continues to co-host Windrush Working Group meetings to discuss how we can work together to drive further improvements.\u201d</p>", "newspaperPageNumber": "6", "wordcount": "606", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:31Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T05:00:31Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-17T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnc4y", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/86c80feb529b276cebd2d2b0617402b8d5e08402/0_276_5743_3446/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "The Windrush compensation scheme is failing claimants and violating their rights, the first international study into the government\u2019s handling of the immigration scandal has concluded. The Human Rights Watch report is critical of the Home Office\u2019s slow progress towards compensating those affected by the scandal in which thousands of UK residents were wrongly categorised as immigration offenders, and called on the government to launch \u201curgent reform to protect the rights of claimants\u201d. The rights organisation has questioned the wisdom of allowing the Home Office to be in charge of the compensation programme designed to deliver justice to those affected by the department\u2019s mistakes, and recommends handing the scheme to an independent, neutral organisation. The report highlighted the complexity of the 44-page compensation application form, and criticises the absence of legal aid to support applicants, who have found it challenging to provide evidence demonstrating that they lost work, housing, healthcare and benefits as a direct result of the Home Office\u2019s errors. Anna Steiner, a solicitor and senior lecturer at the University of Westminster who co-founded the pro bono Windrush Justice Clinic that assists Windrush claimants, told researchers it took lawyers a minimum of 40 hours to prepare a claim for compensation, with much of that time dedicated to making a detailed statement about the impact the ordeal has had on those affected. The report noted that initial offers of compensation were often very low, but were regularly later increased on appeal. All 11 claimants interviewed for the research said they had appealed against their initial compensation offer, and this was confirmed as standard practice by lawyers who assisted claimants. Steiner said in some cases where applications were resubmitted without new evidence the Home Office had doubled its first compensation offer, suggesting that the officials did not pay close attention to the evidence the first time around. Two claimants interviewed for the study said they had been made homeless after being misclassified as immigration offenders, but had later been unable to prove to the satisfaction of compensation scheme caseworkers that their homelessness was the result of being unable to prove their lawful immigration status, because they had no paperwork stating clearly that this was the case. \u201cI can\u2019t put across how tiring and traumatic the scheme is. It\u2019s so draining,\u201d Charlotte Tobierre, who helped her father claim compensation after he lost his job when he was stripped of his legal status, told researchers. The Human Rights Watch study is published exactly five years after Theresa May apologised for the mistakes made by her Home Office, many of which were the direct result of the introduction of a series of hostile environment policies. \u201cFive years after the Windrush scandal came to light, the Home Office compensation scheme is compounding its injustice by denying claimants their right to redress for the life-altering losses and negative effects it has had on their lives for years,\u201d said Almaz Teffera, researcher on racism in Europe at Human Rights Watch. \u201cThe failure of the Windrush compensation scheme and the scandal itself are connected to unresolved institutional racism that dates back to the British Empire. To avoid more Windrush-style scandals, the UK government should urgently reform its immigration system in response to international and national concerns about the existence of deeply rooted racism.\u201d A Home Office spokesperson said a series of improvements had been made to the scheme, adding: \u201cWe remain absolutely committed to righting the wrongs of Windrush and have paid or offered more than \u00a368m in compensation to the people affected. The home secretary continues to co-host Windrush Working Group meetings to discuss how we can work together to drive further improvements.\u201d", "charCount": "3905", "shouldHideReaderRevenue": "643c09258f08791e579d60dd", "bodyHtml": "<p>The Windrush compensation scheme is failing claimants and violating their rights, the first international study into the government\u2019s handling of the immigration scandal has concluded.</p> <p>The Human Rights Watch <a href=\"https://www.hrw.org/news/2023/04/17/uk-hostile-compensation-scheme-fails-windrush-victims\">report</a> is critical of the Home Office\u2019s slow progress towards compensating those affected by the scandal in which thousands of UK residents were wrongly categorised as immigration offenders, and called on the government to launch \u201curgent reform to protect the rights of claimants\u201d.</p> <p>The rights organisation has questioned the wisdom of allowing the Home Office to be in charge of the compensation programme designed to deliver justice to those affected by the department\u2019s mistakes, and recommends handing the scheme to an independent, neutral organisation.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/07/windrush-victim-joseph-mowlah-baksh-dwp-documentation\">\u2018Like a blocked gate I can\u2019t climb over\u2019: a Windrush victim\u2019s DWP impasse </a> </p> </aside>  <p>The report highlighted the complexity of the 44-page compensation application form, and criticises the absence of legal aid to support applicants, who have found it challenging to provide evidence demonstrating that they lost work, housing, healthcare and benefits as a direct result of the Home Office\u2019s errors.</p> <p>Anna Steiner, a solicitor and senior lecturer at the University of Westminster who co-founded the pro bono <a href=\"https://windrushjc.org/\">Windrush Justice Clinic</a> that assists Windrush claimants, told researchers it took lawyers a minimum of 40 hours to prepare a claim for compensation, with much of that time dedicated to making a detailed statement about the impact the ordeal has had on those affected.</p> <p>The report noted that initial offers of compensation were often very low, but were regularly later increased on appeal. All 11 claimants interviewed for the research said they had appealed against their initial compensation offer, and this was confirmed as standard practice by lawyers who assisted claimants. Steiner said in some cases where applications were resubmitted without new evidence the Home Office had doubled its first compensation offer, suggesting that the officials did not pay close attention to the evidence the first time around.</p> <p>Two claimants interviewed for the study said they had been made homeless after being misclassified as immigration offenders, but had later been unable to prove to the satisfaction of compensation scheme caseworkers that their homelessness was the result of being unable to prove their lawful immigration status, because they had no paperwork stating clearly that this was the case.</p> <p>\u201cI can\u2019t put across how tiring and traumatic the scheme is. It\u2019s so draining,\u201d Charlotte Tobierre, who helped her father claim compensation after he lost his job when he was stripped of his legal status, told researchers.</p> <p>The Human Rights Watch study is published exactly five years after Theresa May apologised for the mistakes made by her Home Office, many of which were the direct result of the introduction of a series of hostile environment policies. \u201cFive years after the Windrush scandal came to light, the Home Office compensation scheme is compounding its injustice by denying claimants their right to redress for the life-altering losses and negative effects it has had on their lives for years,\u201d said <a href=\"https://www.hrw.org/about/people/almaz-teffera\">Almaz Teffera</a>, researcher on racism in Europe at Human Rights Watch.</p> <p>\u201cThe failure of the Windrush compensation scheme and the scandal itself are connected to unresolved institutional racism that dates back to the British Empire. To avoid more Windrush-style scandals, the UK government should urgently reform its immigration system in response to international and national concerns about the existence of deeply rooted racism.\u201d</p> <p>A Home Office spokesperson said a series of improvements had been made to the scheme, adding: \u201cWe remain absolutely committed to righting the wrongs of Windrush and have paid or offered more than \u00a368m in compensation to the people affected. The home secretary continues to co-host Windrush Working Group meetings to discuss how we can work together to drive further improvements.\u201d</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "The Windrush compensation scheme is failing claimants and violating their rights, the first international study into the government\u2019s handling of the immigration scandal has concluded. The Human Rights Watch report is critical of the Home Office\u2019s slow progress towards compensating those affected by the scandal in which thousands of UK residents were wrongly categorised as immigration offenders, and called on the government to launch \u201curgent reform to protect the rights of claimants\u201d. The rights organisation has questioned the wisdom of allowing the Home Office to be in charge of the compensation programme designed to deliver justice to those affected by the department\u2019s mistakes, and recommends handing the scheme to an independent, neutral organisation.\nThe report highlighted the complexity of the 44-page compensation application form, and criticises the absence of legal aid to support applicants, who have found it challenging to provide evidence demonstrating that they lost work, housing, healthcare and benefits as a direct result of the Home Office\u2019s errors. Anna Steiner, a solicitor and senior lecturer at the University of Westminster who co-founded the pro bono Windrush Justice Clinic that assists Windrush claimants, told researchers it took lawyers a minimum of 40 hours to prepare a claim for compensation, with much of that time dedicated to making a detailed statement about the impact the ordeal has had on those affected. The report noted that initial offers of compensation were often very low, but were regularly later increased on appeal. All 11 claimants interviewed for the research said they had appealed against their initial compensation offer, and this was confirmed as standard practice by lawyers who assisted claimants. Steiner said in some cases where applications were resubmitted without new evidence the Home Office had doubled its first compensation offer, suggesting that the officials did not pay close attention to the evidence the first time around. Two claimants interviewed for the study said they had been made homeless after being misclassified as immigration offenders, but had later been unable to prove to the satisfaction of compensation scheme caseworkers that their homelessness was the result of being unable to prove their lawful immigration status, because they had no paperwork stating clearly that this was the case. \u201cI can\u2019t put across how tiring and traumatic the scheme is. It\u2019s so draining,\u201d Charlotte Tobierre, who helped her father claim compensation after he lost his job when he was stripped of his legal status, told researchers. The Human Rights Watch study is published exactly five years after Theresa May apologised for the mistakes made by her Home Office, many of which were the direct result of the introduction of a series of hostile environment policies. \u201cFive years after the Windrush scandal came to light, the Home Office compensation scheme is compounding its injustice by denying claimants their right to redress for the life-altering losses and negative effects it has had on their lives for years,\u201d said Almaz Teffera, researcher on racism in Europe at Human Rights Watch. \u201cThe failure of the Windrush compensation scheme and the scandal itself are connected to unresolved institutional racism that dates back to the British Empire. To avoid more Windrush-style scandals, the UK government should urgently reform its immigration system in response to international and national concerns about the existence of deeply rooted racism.\u201d A Home Office spokesperson said a series of improvements had been made to the scheme, adding: \u201cWe remain absolutely committed to righting the wrongs of Windrush and have paid or offered more than \u00a368m in compensation to the people affected. The home secretary continues to co-host Windrush Working Group meetings to discuss how we can work together to drive further improvements.\u201d", "attributes": {}, "published": true, "createdDate":
