23 April. Created by dust from the tail of comet C/1861 G1 (Thatcher), the Lyrids are not usually vast in number \u2013 only about 18 an hour are expected \u2013 but they are often very bright and fast moving. Some of the more spectacular ones are known to burn up so brightly that they cast shadows.</p> <p>This year, viewing conditions are expected to be good because the moon has just 9% of its surface illuminated, so even faint meteors will be visible. Occasionally, brief outbursts of 100 meteors an hour have been recorded for the Lyrids. The last report of such an outburst came from the US in 1982 and before that Japan in 1945, and Greece in 1922.</p> <p>The chart shows the view looking east from London at midnight as 22 April becomes 23 April. The meteors will appear to emanate from the radiate point, labelled Lyrids, and could travel in any direction away from it. Remember, meteor watching takes patience: expect to be under the stars for an hour or two at least. So, wrap up warm. The shower is also visible from the southern hemisphere. Occasionally, brief outbursts of 100 meteors an hour have been recorded for the Lyrids. The last report of such an outburst came from the US in 1982 and before that Japan in 1945, and Greece in 1922.</p> <p>The chart shows the view looking east from London at midnight as 22 April becomes 23 April. The meteors will appear to emanate from the radiate point, labelled Lyrids, and could travel in any direction away from it. Remember, meteor watching takes patience: expect to be under the stars for an hour or two at least. So, wrap up warm. The shower is also visible from the southern hemisphere. From Cape Town, South Africa, the radiant will have climbed high enough into the sky by about 02.00 SAST.</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "\nThe Lyrid meteor shower will reach its peak in the early hours of 23 April. Created by dust from the tail of comet C/1861 G1 (Thatcher), the Lyrids are not usually vast in number \u2013 only about 18 an hour are expected \u2013 but they are often very bright and fast moving. Some of the more spectacular ones are known to burn up so brightly that they cast shadows. This year, viewing conditions are expected to be good because the moon has just 9% of its surface illuminated, so even faint meteors will be visible. Occasionally, brief outbursts of 100 meteors an hour have been recorded for the Lyrids. The last report of such an outburst came from the US in 1982 and before that Japan in 1945, and Greece in 1922. The chart shows the view looking east from London at midnight as 22 April becomes 23 April. The meteors will appear to emanate from the radiate point, labelled Lyrids, and could travel in any direction away from it. Remember, meteor watching takes patience: expect to be under the stars for an hour or two at least. So, wrap up warm. The shower is also visible from the southern hemisphere. "https://content.guardianapis.com/music", "editions": [{"id": "music", "webTitle": "Music", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/music", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/music", "code": "uk-news/2023/apr/17/the-other-royal-collection-windsors-multimillion-pound-private-trove-of-art-may-include-official-gifts", "type": "article", "sectionId": "uk-news", "sectionName": "UK news", "webPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:30Z", "webTitle": "The other royal collection: Windsors\u2019 multimillion-pound private trove of art may include official gifts", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/17/the-other-royal-collection-windsors-multimillion-pound-private-trove-of-art-may-include-official-gifts", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/uk-news/2023/apr/17/the-other-royal-collection-windsors-multimillion-pound-private-trove-of-art-may-include-official-gifts", "fields": {"headline": "The other royal collection: Windsors\u2019 multimillion-pound private trove of art may include official gifts", "standfirst": "<p>Guardian identifies almost 400 artworks as being privately owned by family, including works by Dal\u00ed, Monet, Freud, Chagall and Lowry</p>", "trailText": "Guardian identifies almost 400 artworks as being privately owned by family, including works by Dal\u00ed, Monet, Freud, Chagall and Lowry", "byline": "Maeve McClenaghan Investigations correspondent", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"d6c3303152d2c092a00bc45462cc82ec4d276562\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/d6c3303152d2c092a00bc45462cc82ec4d276562/0_0_5000_3000/1000.jpg\" alt=\"King Charles and Queen Elizabeth II illustration\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">It is assumed that Charles has inherited almost all of the artwork previously owned by the queen, Prince Philip and the queen mother.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Composite: Guardian Design/Getty Images/Alamy</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure>", "body": "<p>Prince Philip was accompanying Queen Elizabeth II on an official visit to Denmark when the venerated modernist painter Marc Chagall pressed a gift into his hands. It was 1960 and the pair had just met at a ceremony where Chagall was presented with the prestigious Erasmus prize. Philip would later recall the artist\u2019s \u201cjocular attitude\u201d as he showed him around his exhibition.</p> \n<p>\u201cHe gave me this Bible he has illustrated, just out of the blue. He was a very strange man,\u201d Philip reportedly said. It was also something of a strange gift. Inside the Bible, Chagall had daubed colourful illustrations in watercolours, chalk and ink. Those two illustrations could now be worth as much as \u00a360,000.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"ffaabfc8f6de80dd694e32abe14f603e57f10b2d\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/ffaabfc8f6de80dd694e32abe14f603e57f10b2d/59_27_3973_2938/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Image from Chagall\u2019s Bible given to Prince Philip.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"739\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Image from Chagall\u2019s Bible given to Prince Philip.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: His Majesty King Charles III 2023</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>As contemporary artworks go, that is not a huge sum. However, the Chagall Bible is one of an extraordinary collection of almost 400 artworks, some worth much more, that have been exhibited by the Windsors in \u201cpersonal\u201d or \u201cprivate\u201d collections.</p> \n<p>They are, in total, likely to be worth tens of millions of pounds, possibly more, and include pieces by Salvador Dal\u00ed, LS Lowry, Claude Monet and Lucian Freud.</p> \n<p>Many of the items, however, raise questions for the Windsors about whether all of these artworks should really belong to them. </p> \n<p>Royal art can broadly be separated into two categories. Most of it is part of the royal collection, more than a million items that are held in trust by the sovereign for the benefit of the nation. Described as one of the greatest art collections in the world, it is the nearest the UK has to a public custodian of royal-linked art.</p> \n<p>The second, much more elusive category is that which the royals treat as their own: the Windsors\u2019 private collection. There is no public register of these works and Buckingham Palace refuses to comment in any detail on what it regards as private wealth. However, items such as the Chagall Bible raise questions about what falls under that definition.</p> \n<p>Not in the royal collection, the artwork casually given to Philip on a state visit appears to have been absorbed into his own collection. At a special exhibition in Holyrood Palace in 1994, the Chagall piece was on display as part of the prince\u2019s \u201cpersonal collection\u201d.</p> \n<p>Buckingham Palace\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/07/what-are-the-rules-on-gifts-for-the-royal-family\">gift policy</a>, introduced the following year, distinguishes between \u201cofficial gifts\u201d, which are generally those received in the course of formal duties and functions, and \u201cpersonal gifts\u201d, from people whom members of the royal family know personally. The policy adds: \u201cIn all cases, and particularly on official overseas trips, organisations and individuals should be discouraged from offering extravagant gifts, ie gifts of high monetary value.\u201d</p> \n<p>Contacted by the Guardian, the palace declined to comment on the ownership status of the Chagall or more than a dozen other artworks that would appear to have been official gifts but have been exhibited as part of the Windsors\u2019 personal or private collections. \u201cIt is incorrect to suggest that the artworks you list were all official gifts,\u201d a spokesperson said. \u201cWe would not comment on the value of works of art.\u201d</p> \n<h2><strong>A Monet worth millions</strong></h2> \n<p>A watercolour artist himself, King Charles III is an aficionado of fine art.<strong> </strong>The four floors of his London residence, Clarence House, are filled with artwork, much of which is unequivocally the private property of the Windsors.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"f1458aaefe7828e2fbfc71c9835725ce445e362c\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/f1458aaefe7828e2fbfc71c9835725ce445e362c/0_0_2795_1677/1000.jpg\" alt=\"TV presenter Claire Balding (L) talks to Camilla, the Queen Consort, during an event at Clarence House in April 2010.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">TV presenter Claire Balding (L) talks to Camilla, the Queen Consort, during an event at Clarence House in April 2010.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Leon Neal/AFP/Getty Images</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>Charles can largely thank his grandmother for the art adorning the walls of Clarence House. An avid private collector, Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother bought dozens of valuable artworks between the 1930s and 1950s, when prices were lower because of the war, and bargains could be found in the frequent country house sales of the time.</p> \n<p>Over the years, the queen mother filled Clarence House, then her London residence, with a collection worthy of any great gallery, although its presentation was more homely.</p> \n<p>In the corner of the Morning Room, behind a side table covered with family photographs and the shade of a table lamp, hangs what is probably the most valuable of all the art in the royals\u2019 private collection: Claude Monet\u2019s Study of Rocks; Creuse: Le Bloc. The painting was bought by the queen mother in 1945, at the Wildenstein gallery in Paris. The second world war had dampened art prices and she snapped it up for \u00a32,000, the equivalent of \u00a3110,000 today.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"eec13dd10300d7b5746927244fdf325b8e000650\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/eec13dd10300d7b5746927244fdf325b8e000650/0_0_4096_2458/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Camilla meeting the broadcaster Chris Evans at Clarence House in 2015 with Monet\u2019s Study of Rocks; Creuse: Le Bloc hanging on the wall behind her.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Camilla meeting the broadcaster Chris Evans at Clarence House in 2015 with Monet\u2019s Study of Rocks; Creuse: Le Bloc hanging on the wall behind her.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Heathcliff O\u2019Malley/Shutterstock</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>Susan Orringe, of Prestige Valuations, told the Guardian the painting could fetch up to \u00a320m if it were sold today. However, she clarified that the estimated price was highly speculative and the paucity of Monets on the market, coupled with the fact that it had hung for decades in the queen mother\u2019s front room, could raise its value much higher.</p> \n<p>Clarence House, which used to be open to the public, has been closed since 2019. The Monet and other artworks can be seen in a <a href=\"https://artsandculture.google.com/story/inside-clarence-house-clarence-house/dgXRGpeByJlLJg?hl=en-GB\">virtual tour</a> of the residence.</p> \n<p>The artworks also include Fylde Farm by LS Lowry, worth about \u00a3120,000, and a portrait of George Bernard Shaw by Augustus John, worth about \u00a370,000<strong>. </strong>Elsewhere in the house are multiple other works, including paintings by Paul Nash, Raffaellino del Garbo and Alfred Sisley. The Eve of St Agnes by John Everett Millais, which the queen mother bought at auction in 1942 for \u00a3630, could be worth about \u00a31.5m today.</p> \n<p>Charles moved into Clarence House in 2003, after the death of the queen mother the previous year. He has previously said that among his favourite works are a moody series of paintings of Windsor Castle by John Piper. They hang on the wall of his dining room. The queen mother paid \u00a310 each for them (equivalent to \u00a3646 in today\u2019s money). Today the set could be worth \u00a3150,000.</p> \n<p>It is assumed Charles has inherited almost all of the artwork previously owned by the queen mother, the queen and Prince Philip. As monarch, he is exempt from the inheritance tax that would be due on any high-value bequests to his siblings.</p> \n<p>However, it is impossible to know precisely who owns which pieces in the Windsors\u2019 private collection, and how much it may all be worth. </p> \n<p>The Guardian consulted experts on the value of 60 of the most significant works on a list of 392 identified as being privately owned by the Windsors. The total value of the 60 was estimated to be at least \u00a324m. But that valuation is based on only a fraction of a much larger collection.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-atom\"> <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"a58417ce-9d40-4395-ab38-0bf2ace661d9\" data-atom-type=\"guide\"> \n  <div>\n   <div class=\"atom-Guide\">\n    <p></p>\n    <p>The Guardian scoured press reports, exhibition guides and photographs and visited palaces to&nbsp;create a log of 392 artworks that appear to be owned by central members of the royal family. We focused on reports and exhibitions describing the personal or private collections of the Windsors.&nbsp;</p>\n    <p>This is likely to be just a fraction of the total. The queen mother, for example, owned 1,200 prints, paintings and drawings, according to the art historian Dr Susan Owens. Prince Philip was estimated by the art expert Robin Simon to have had more than 1,500 works. It is not known how many the late queen owned, but it was presumably hundreds.&nbsp;</p>\n    <p>The log was then checked against the Royal Collection Trust, both via the online catalogue and through direct inquiries to the trust, which confirmed that none were officially part of the collection.</p>\n    <p>All 392 items are therefore believed to have been owned privately by the queen mother, Prince Philip, Queen Elizabeth II or King Charles III.&nbsp;</p>\n    <p>Where possible, we logged details of how and when the artwork was acquired. We then asked the palace detailed questions about the ownership status of those we believed fell into the category of 'official gifts', according to the royal gift policy.</p>\n    <p>Experts estimated the potential sale value of 60 of the most significant pieces on the list based on comparable works by each artist, while working with limited information and without physical inspection.&nbsp;</p>\n    <p>The estimates did not take into account any \u2018royal premium\u2019 buyers might pay for artworks previously owned by the Windsors.&nbsp;</p>\n    <p>Susan Orringe, from Prestige Valuations, estimated works by Monet, Grant, Seago, Fantin-Latour, Topolski, Constable, Piper, Lowry, Chagall, Millais, Freud.</p>\n    <p>Robert James, from Coram James, estimated works by Augustus John, Nash, Del Garbo, Dali, Gainsborough.</p>\n    <p>Jane Raffan, from ArtiFacts, in Australia, estimated works by Namatjira, Pugh, Friend, Jack, Battarbee, Hill, Drysdale, Dobell, Landara, Inkamala, Pareroultja, Raberaba, Crooke, Charles Pro Hart, Swann, Dridan and Garner.</p>\n    <p></p>\n   </div>\n  </div>\n </gu-atom> \n</figure> \n<p>In 2020, the historian David McClure estimated that the queen mother\u2019s private collection, said to have comprised 1,200 prints, paintings and drawings, was worth \u00a330m. He concluded that Prince Philip\u2019s collection, said to include more than 1,500 items, was worth \u00a32m. In 2001, the art expert Robin Simon valued the queen\u2019s collection for the Mail on Sunday and concluded it was worth \u00a3150m (the equivalent of \u00a3261m today).</p> \n<p>That would suggest the Windsors\u2019 private collection could be worth more than \u00a3290m. However, the lack of any public register of these works means all of these estimates are speculative. It is impossible to say anything with certainty about the value of the private art collection, although there is no doubt it is worth many millions of pounds.</p> \n<h2><strong>Dal\u00ed and Freud</strong></h2> \n<p>The value of the private collection matters because while much of the Windsors\u2019 private art is unequivocally theirs, some of it might be better described as belonging to the nation. The royal policy on accepting gifts states that items presented on official duties, by people not considered close personal friends, \u201care not the private property of the member of the royal family who receives them\u201d.</p> \n<p>More than a third of the 392 pieces identified by the Guardian in private royal collections appear to have been gifts of one sort or another. Some were wedding presents, while others were official gifts on overseas trips, including from artists themselves. All were displayed in exhibitions of \u201cpersonal\u201d art collections. None are part of the public royal collection.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"415a0a6f9e9fcf05e6e4119899717453acd4ab11\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/415a0a6f9e9fcf05e6e4119899717453acd4ab11/0_0_4135_2481/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Charles presents the Prince of Wales medals for arts philanthropy at Clarence House in November 2011.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Charles presents the Prince of Wales medals for arts philanthropy at Clarence House in November 2011.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Anwar Hussein/Getty Images</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>One such instance was a gift from the Spanish surrealist Salvador Dal\u00ed, whom Philip met in 1972 while staying near Avignon on a state visit to the south of France. Not much is known about that meeting, but at some point Dal\u00ed presented Philip with an etching called Hommage, as well as a special edition of his book adorned with sketches in ballpoint pen.</p> \n<p>Those gifts could be worth in the region of \u00a310,000 today. Philip included them in an exhibition of work described as his personal collection in 1994.</p> \n<p>An infamous portrait of Queen Elizabeth II by Lucian Freud is another example of a direct gift from an artist. The 2001 work divided opinion, prompting the Sun\u2019s royal photographer Arthur Edwards to declare: \u201cFreud should be locked in the Tower [of London] for this.\u201d</p> \n<p>But it would appear that the queen liked it enough to adopt it as part of her personal collection. The small oil painting has now passed into the possession of the king, who loaned it to a Freud exhibition late last year.</p> \n<p>The painting joins another by Freud, Small Fern, which was given to Charles for his 50th birthday in 1998 and exhibited as one of his privately owned works in 2018. Oils by Freud are considered extremely valuable; Orringe estimated the botanical painting could fetch up to \u00a3600,000.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"17ce326c914790b3e78520d2e5ad0c44d6faab0d\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/17ce326c914790b3e78520d2e5ad0c44d6faab0d/0_215_3500_2101/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A curator dusts a portrait by Lucian Freud of Queen Elizabeth II as part of the exhibition The Queen: Portraits of a Monarch at Windsor Castle in 2012.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A curator dusts a portrait by Lucian Freud of Queen Elizabeth II as part of the exhibition The Queen: Portraits of a Monarch at Windsor Castle in 2012.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Steve Parsons/PA</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>Other artworks given to the royals on state visits include a watercolour of an Australian bird by Carol O\u2019Connor, presented to Philip on an official visit to Perth in 1990; an acrylic on masonite of pelicans by Robert Bateman, given to Philip in 1987 to mark 100 years of national parks in Canada; both were exhibited as part of Prince Philip\u2019s \u201cpersonal collection\u201d. A watercolour painting by Charles Decimus Barraud, given to the queen mother by the mayor of Auckland, New Zealand, in 1958 was included in a list of her collection, which passed to the queen on her death.</p> \n<p>In their statement, the palace spokesperson did not shed any light on whether specific artworks exhibited in private collections were regarded as official or personal gifts.</p> \n<p>\u201cOfficial gifts are not the personal property of the member of the royal family who receives them, but may be held by the sovereign in right of the crown or designated in due course as part of the royal collection,\u201d they said. \u201cEven when works of art are privately held by members of the royal family, they are frequently lent to public exhibitions.\u201d</p> \n<p>The palace declined to say why none of the artworks were contained in the royal collection.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-atom\"> <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"bcd01839-2ba7-49bf-83a4-819906029401\" data-atom-type=\"guide\"> \n  <div>\n   <div class=\"atom-Guide\">\n    <p><strong></strong></p>\n    <p></p>\n    <p> Cost of the crown is an investigation into royal wealth and finances. The series, published ahead of the coronation of King Charles III, is seeking to overcome centuries of secrecy to better understand how the royal family is funded, the extent to which individual members have profited from their public roles, and the dubious origins of some of their wealth. The Guardian believes it is in the public interest to clarify what can legitimately be called private wealth, what belongs to the British people, and what, as so often is the case, straddles the two.</p>\n    <p>\u2022 <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/05/how-the-british-royal-family-hides-its-wealth-from-public-scrutiny\">Read more about the investigation</a></p>\n    <p></p>\n   </div>\n  </div>\n </gu-atom> \n</figure> \n<h2><strong>Haggling over prices</strong></h2> \n<p>The royal collection contains 5,600 paintings, including works by Mantegna, Rubens, Rembrandt and Canaletto. The royals have the privilege of borrowing items in the collection free of charge to hang in their private residences, while others appear in Windsor Castle and Buckingham Palace.</p> \n<p>But Philip, who married into the monarchy with very little wealth of his own, was said to have found the art of the royal collection stuffy. Unimpressed, he began to collect more contemporary artists, perhaps drawing on his wife\u2019s funds to do so.</p> \n<p>\u201cWe could have borrowed, of course,\u201d he said in a 1994 interview<strong> </strong>with the Scotsman, \u201cbut I thought it would be more fun to have our own.\u201d</p> \n<p>Of the 392 works identified by the Guardian, 80 were bought privately by either Philip or the queen mother \u2013 and are, in that sense, indisputably theirs.</p> \n<p>Philip, in particular, liked a bargain, boasting of his James Morrison oil paintings: \u201cI bought them, I don\u2019t know, for \u00a31,000 or something. I don\u2019t know what he charges now, about \u00a330,000 or something.\u201d (The record price for a Morrison was set in 2014 at \u00a381,000.)</p> \n<p>Letters between Philip and Feliks Topolski, a Polish-born artist whom he considered a friend, <a href=\"https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/prince-philips-secret-letters-to-painter-reveal-love-of-modern-art-67jzz5t9r\">show Philip haggling</a> over the price of an equestrian portrait for two years. He eventually drove down the price and got the work for \u00a3834 \u2013 the equivalent of<strong> </strong>\u00a312,000 in today\u2019s money. This was a 63% discount on what experts had told him it should be worth.</p> \n<p>Philip and the queen mother are known to have taken advantage of trips to the Commonwealth to add to their private collections, which, for example, contain 27 works by Australian and Indigenous artists.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"4a3dee53f78524d9a749e051d045fc3774f0d61f\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/4a3dee53f78524d9a749e051d045fc3774f0d61f/7_1052_4642_2785/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip in Adelaide, Australia, in 1963.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip in Adelaide, Australia, in 1963.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Reginald Davis/Rex/Shutterstock</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>The most valuable of those is Home Leave by Russell Drysdale, which was acquired by the queen mother and is now worth an estimated \u00a31.7m. Philip bought works by Sidney Nolan and was given two paintings by William Dobell, which together are now worth in the region of \u00a3570,000.</p> \n<p>Jane Raffan, an Australian art expert and valuer, said that in the 1950s and 60s royal visitors behaved like \u201cupper-level tourists in that they were looking to acquire something, a souvenir from their trip, but they were not buying something from a tourist tat shop \u2026 in many ways it was a case of right time and place in regard to the Dobells, the Nolans and the Drysdales.\u201d</p> \n<h2><strong>\u2018I cannot resist it\u2019</strong></h2> \n<p>Another blurred line around the Windsors\u2019 private collection relates to works produced by artists who accompany them on official tours. Philip befriended Edward Seago over the years and the Norfolk-based artist gave him and the queen mother many paintings. Sixty of those came from a trip Seago took with Philip on the Royal Yacht Britannia, when, after a state visit to Australia in 1956, they sailed on to the Antarctic.</p> \n<p>\u201cHe painted all these pictures and said: \u2018You can have them\u2019,\u201d Philip told the Scotsman newspaper. While the two men were friends at that point, the paintings were made and presented as part of an official royal trip. Yet none of them are in the royal collection. The trove of oils passed to the royals by Seago could now be worth as much as \u00a32.6m.</p> \n<p>Charles has also been known to take artists on royal tours overseas; a palace spokesperson stressed they were \u201cpersonally funded\u201d by him. Artists including John Ward, Susannah Fiennes, Robbie Wraith and Warwick Fuller accompanied Charles, when he was Prince of Wales, to various destinations, from Oman to South Africa.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"61ccd83d8c71ac717fe26f8d479e2036e3b4b208\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/61ccd83d8c71ac717fe26f8d479e2036e3b4b208/0_312_4096_2458/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Charles painting in the Bhutan Himalayas, while trekking to a monastery on a 1998 visit.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Charles painting in the Bhutan Himalayas, while trekking to a monastery on a 1998 visit.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: John Stillwell/PA</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>In 1989, Charles explicitly said that the practice of taking artists with him overseas would benefit the public collection of art held in trust for the benefit of the nation. \u201cIt is such a good way of providing a record, adding to the royal collection, obtaining some tips on painting, and meeting other artists, that I cannot resist it,\u201d he said.</p> \n<p>The Guardian has identified 25 pieces produced by artists on such foreign trips. None are in the royal collection. They have, presumably, been incorporated into the king\u2019s private assets. Buckingham Palace declined to say where they were being kept, or why they were not in the royal collection. The locations of the works given to the royal family by Dal\u00ed, Chagall and Freud also remain a mystery. </p> \n<figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/from-tool/generic/index.html?vertical=News&amp;opinion-tint=false&amp;title=Story%20tips%3F&amp;description=Do%20you%20have%20information%20about%20this%20story%3F%20Email%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22mailto%3Ainvestigations%40theguardian.com%22%3Einvestigations%40theguardian.com%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20or%20use%20Signal%20or%20WhatsApp%20to%20message%20(UK)%20%2B44%207584%20640566%20or%20(US)%20%2B1%20646%20886%208761.%20For%20the%20most%20secure%20communications%2C%20use%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22nothttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fsecuredrop%22%3ESecureDrop%3C%2Fa%3E%20or%20see%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fhelp%2Fng-interactive%2F2017%2Fmar%2F17%2Fcontact-the-guardian-securely%22%3Eour%20guide%3C%2Fa%3E.&amp;link=false\" data-alt=\"Do you have information about this story? Email investigations@theguardian.com, or use Signal or WhatsApp to message (UK) +44 7584 640566 or (US) +1 646 886 8761.\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/from-tool/generic/index.html?vertical=News&amp;opinion-tint=false&amp;title=Story%20tips%3F&amp;description=Do%20you%20have%20information%20about%20this%20story%3F%20Email%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22mailto%3Ainvestigations%40theguardian.com%22%3Einvestigations%40theguardian.com%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20or%20use%20Signal%20or%20WhatsApp%20to%20message%20(UK)%20%2B44%207584%20640566%20or%20(US)%20%2B1%20646%20886%208761.%20For%20the%20most%20secure%20communications%2C%20use%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22nothttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fsecuredrop%22%3ESecureDrop%3C%2Fa%3E%20or%20see%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fhelp%2Fng-interactive%2F2017%2Fmar%2F17%2Fcontact-the-guardian-securely%22%3Eour%20guide%3C%2Fa%3E.&amp;link=false\">Interactive</a> \n</figure>", "newspaperPageNumber": "14", "wordcount": "2486", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:30Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T05:00:30Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-17T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/ntbtt", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/d6c3303152d2c092a00bc45462cc82ec4d276562/0_0_5000_3000/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Prince Philip was accompanying Queen Elizabeth II on an official visit to Denmark when the venerated modernist painter Marc Chagall pressed a gift into his hands. It was 1960 and the pair had just met at a ceremony where Chagall was presented with the prestigious Erasmus prize. Philip would later recall the artist\u2019s \u201cjocular attitude\u201d as he showed him around his exhibition. \u201cHe gave me this Bible he has illustrated, just out of the blue. He was a very strange man,\u201d Philip reportedly said. It was also something of a strange gift. Inside the Bible, Chagall had daubed colourful illustrations in watercolours, chalk and ink. Those two illustrations could now be worth as much as \u00a360,000. As contemporary artworks go, that is not a huge sum. However, the Chagall Bible is one of an extraordinary collection of almost 400 artworks, some worth much more, that have been exhibited by the Windsors in \u201cpersonal\u201d or \u201cprivate\u201d collections. They are, in total, likely to be worth tens of millions of pounds, possibly more, and include pieces by Salvador Dal\u00ed, LS Lowry, Claude Monet and Lucian Freud. Many of the items, however, raise questions for the Windsors about whether all of these artworks should really belong to them. Royal art can broadly be separated into two categories. Most of it is part of the royal collection, more than a million items that are held in trust by the sovereign for the benefit of the nation. Described as one of the greatest art collections in the world, it is the nearest the UK has to a public custodian of royal-linked art. The second, much more elusive category is that which the royals treat as their own: the Windsors\u2019 private collection. There is no public register of these works and Buckingham Palace refuses to comment in any detail on what it regards as private wealth. However, items such as the Chagall Bible raise questions about what falls under that definition. Not in the royal collection, the artwork casually given to Philip on a state visit appears to have been absorbed into his own collection. At a special exhibition in Holyrood Palace in 1994, the Chagall piece was on display as part of the prince\u2019s \u201cpersonal collection\u201d. Buckingham Palace\u2019s gift policy, introduced the following year, distinguishes between \u201cofficial gifts\u201d, which are generally those received in the course of formal duties and functions, and \u201cpersonal gifts\u201d, from people whom members of the royal family know personally. The policy adds: \u201cIn all cases, and particularly on official overseas trips, organisations and individuals should be discouraged from offering extravagant gifts, ie gifts of high monetary value.\u201d Contacted by the Guardian, the palace declined to comment on the ownership status of the Chagall or more than a dozen other artworks that would appear to have been official gifts but have been exhibited as part of the Windsors\u2019 personal or private collections. \u201cIt is incorrect to suggest that the artworks you list were all official gifts,\u201d a spokesperson said. \u201cWe would not comment on the value of works of art.\u201d A Monet worth millions A watercolour artist himself, King Charles III is an aficionado of fine art. The four floors of his London residence, Clarence House, are filled with artwork, much of which is unequivocally the private property of the Windsors. Charles can largely thank his grandmother for the art adorning the walls of Clarence House. An avid private collector, Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother bought dozens of valuable artworks between the 1930s and 1950s, when prices were lower because of the war, and bargains could be found in the frequent country house sales of the time. Over the years, the queen mother filled Clarence House, then her London residence, with a collection worthy of any great gallery, although its presentation was more homely. In the corner of the Morning Room, behind a side table covered with family photographs and the shade of a table lamp, hangs what is probably the most valuable of all the art in the royals\u2019 private collection: Claude Monet\u2019s Study of Rocks; Creuse: Le Bloc. The painting was bought by the queen mother in 1945, at the Wildenstein gallery in Paris. The second world war had dampened art prices and she snapped it up for \u00a32,000, the equivalent of \u00a3110,000 today. Susan Orringe, of Prestige Valuations, told the Guardian the painting could fetch up to \u00a320m if it were sold today. However, she clarified that the estimated price was highly speculative and the paucity of Monets on the market, coupled with the fact that it had hung for decades in the queen mother\u2019s front room, could raise its value much higher. Clarence House, which used to be open to the public, has been closed since 2019. The Monet and other artworks can be seen in a virtual tour of the residence. The artworks also include Fylde Farm by LS Lowry, worth about \u00a3120,000, and a portrait of George Bernard Shaw by Augustus John, worth about \u00a370,000. Elsewhere in the house are multiple other works, including paintings by Paul Nash, Raffaellino del Garbo and Alfred Sisley. The Eve of St Agnes by John Everett Millais, which the queen mother bought at auction in 1942 for \u00a3630, could be worth about \u00a31.5m today. Charles moved into Clarence House in 2003, after the death of the queen mother the previous year. He has previously said that among his favourite works are a moody series of paintings of Windsor Castle by John Piper. They hang on the wall of his dining room. The queen mother paid \u00a310 each for them (equivalent to \u00a3646 in today\u2019s money). Today the set could be worth \u00a3150,000. It is assumed Charles has inherited almost all of the artwork previously owned by the queen mother, the queen and Prince Philip. As monarch, he is exempt from the inheritance tax that would be due on any high-value bequests to his siblings. However, it is impossible to know precisely who owns which pieces in the Windsors\u2019 private collection, and how much it may all be worth. The Guardian consulted experts on the value of 60 of the most significant works on a list of 392 identified as being privately owned by the Windsors. The total value of the 60 was estimated to be at least \u00a324m. But that valuation is based on only a fraction of a much larger collection. In 2020, the historian David McClure estimated that the queen mother\u2019s private collection, said to have comprised 1,200 prints, paintings and drawings, was worth \u00a330m. He concluded that Prince Philip\u2019s collection, said to include more than 1,500 items, was worth \u00a32m. In 2001, the art expert Robin Simon valued the queen\u2019s collection for the Mail on Sunday and concluded it was worth \u00a3150m (the equivalent of \u00a3261m today). That would suggest the Windsors\u2019 private collection could be worth more than \u00a3290m. However, the lack of any public register of these works means all of these estimates are speculative. It is impossible to say anything with certainty about the value of the private art collection, although there is no doubt it is worth many millions of pounds. Dal\u00ed and Freud The value of the private collection matters because while much of the Windsors\u2019 private art is unequivocally theirs, some of it might be better described as belonging to the nation. The royal policy on accepting gifts states that items presented on official duties, by people not considered close personal friends, \u201care not the private property of the member of the royal family who receives them\u201d. More than a third of the 392 pieces identified by the Guardian in private royal collections appear to have been gifts of one sort or another. Some were wedding presents, while others were official gifts on overseas trips, including from artists themselves. All were displayed in exhibitions of \u201cpersonal\u201d art collections. None are part of the public royal collection. One such instance was a gift from the Spanish surrealist Salvador Dal\u00ed, whom Philip met in 1972 while staying near Avignon on a state visit to the south of France. Not much is known about that meeting, but at some point Dal\u00ed presented Philip with an etching called Hommage, as well as a special edition of his book adorned with sketches in ballpoint pen. Those gifts could be worth in the region of \u00a310,000 today. Philip included them in an exhibition of work described as his personal collection in 1994. A watercolour painting by Charles Decimus Barraud, given to the queen mother by the mayor of Auckland, New Zealand, in 1958 was included in a list of her collection, which passed to the queen on her death. Haggling over prices The royal collection contains 5,600 paintings, including works by Mantegna, Rubens, Rembrandt and Canaletto. The Guardian has identified 25 pieces produced by artists on such foreign trips. None are in the royal collection. They have, presumably, been incorporated into the king\u2019s private assets. Buckingham Palace declined to say where they were being kept, or why they were not in the royal collection. The locations of the works given to the royal family by Dal\u00ed, Chagall and Freud also remain a mystery.", "charCount": "14437", "shouldHideReaderRevenue": "false", "showAffiliateLinks": "false", "", "attributes": {}, "published": true, "createdDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:30Z", "firstPublishedDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:30Z", "publishedDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:30Z", "lastModifiedDate": "2023-04-13T13:49:23Z", "contributors": [], "elements": [{"type": "image", "assets": [{"type": "image", "mimeType": "image/jpeg", "file": "image", "mimeType": "image/jpeg", "file": "https://media.guim.co.uk/d6c3303152d2c092a00bc45462cc82ec4d276562/0_0_5000_3000/140.jpg", "typeData": {"aspectRatio": "5:3", "width": 140, "height": 84}}, {"type": "image", "mimeType": "image/jpeg", "file": "https://media.guim.co.uk/d6c3303152d2c092a00bc45462cc82ec4d276562/0_0_5000_3000/5000.jpg", "typeData": {"aspectRatio": "5:3", "width": 5000, "5:3", "width": 5000, "height": 3000, "isMaster": true}}], "imageTypeData": {"caption": "It is assumed that Charles has inherited almost all of the artwork previously owned by the queen, Prince Philip
