illustration", "mediaId": "d6c3303152d2c092a00bc45462cc82ec4d276562", "mediaApiUri": "https://api.media.gutools.co.uk/images/d6c3303152d2c092a00bc45462cc82ec4d276562", "imageType": "Composite", "role": "showcase"}}]}, "body": [{"id": "641a1bac8f08b6360ce316c1", "bodyHtml": "<p>Prince Philip was accompanying Queen Elizabeth II on an official visit to Denmark when the venerated modernist painter Marc Chagall pressed a gift into his hands. It was 1960 and the pair had just met at a ceremony where Chagall was presented with the prestigious Erasmus prize. Philip would later recall the artist\u2019s \u201cjocular attitude\u201d as he showed him around his exhibition.</p> <p>\u201cHe gave me this Bible he has illustrated, just out of the blue. He was a very strange man,\u201d Philip reportedly said. It was also something of a strange gift. Inside the Bible, Chagall had daubed colourful illustrations in watercolours, chalk and ink. Those two illustrations could now be worth as much as \u00a360,000.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"ffaabfc8f6de80dd694e32abe14f603e57f10b2d\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/ffaabfc8f6de80dd694e32abe14f603e57f10b2d/59_27_3973_2938/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Image from Chagall\u2019s Bible given to Prince Philip.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"739\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Image from Chagall\u2019s Bible given to Prince Philip.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: His Majesty King Charles III 2023</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>As contemporary artworks go, that is not a huge sum. However, the Chagall Bible is one of an extraordinary collection of almost 400 artworks, some worth much more, that have been exhibited by the Windsors in \u201cpersonal\u201d or \u201cprivate\u201d collections.</p> <p>They are, in total, likely to be worth tens of millions of pounds, possibly more, and include pieces by Salvador Dal\u00ed, LS Lowry, Claude Monet and Lucian Freud.</p> <p>Many of the items, however, raise questions for the Windsors about whether all of these artworks should really belong to them. </p> <p>Royal art can broadly be separated into two categories. Most of it is part of the royal collection, more than a million items that are held in trust by the sovereign for the benefit of the nation. Described as one of the greatest art collections in the world, it is the nearest the UK has to a public custodian of royal-linked art.</p> <p>The second, much more elusive category is that which the royals treat as their own: the Windsors\u2019 private collection. There is no public register of these works and Buckingham Palace refuses to comment in any detail on what it regards as private wealth. However, items such as the Chagall Bible raise questions about what falls under that definition.</p> <p>Not in the royal collection, the artwork casually given to Philip on a state visit appears to have been absorbed into his own collection. At a special exhibition in Holyrood Palace in 1994, the Chagall piece was on display as part of the prince\u2019s \u201cpersonal collection\u201d.</p> <p>Buckingham Palace\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/07/what-are-the-rules-on-gifts-for-the-royal-family\">gift policy</a>, introduced the following year, distinguishes between \u201cofficial gifts\u201d, which are generally those received in the course of formal duties and functions, and \u201cpersonal gifts\u201d, from people whom members of the royal family know personally. The policy adds: \u201cIn all cases, and particularly on official overseas trips, organisations and individuals should be discouraged from offering extravagant gifts, ie gifts of high monetary value.\u201d</p> <p>Contacted by the Guardian, the palace declined to comment on the ownership status of the Chagall or more than a dozen other artworks that would appear to have been official gifts but have been exhibited as part of the Windsors\u2019 personal or private collections. \u201cIt is incorrect to suggest that the artworks you list were all official gifts,\u201d a spokesperson said. \u201cWe would not comment on the value of works of art.\u201d</p> <h2><strong>A Monet worth millions</strong></h2> <p>A watercolour artist himself, King Charles III is an aficionado of fine art.<strong> </strong>The four floors of his London residence, Clarence House, are filled with artwork, much of which is unequivocally the private property of the Windsors.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"f1458aaefe7828e2fbfc71c9835725ce445e362c\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/f1458aaefe7828e2fbfc71c9835725ce445e362c/0_0_2795_1677/1000.jpg\" alt=\"TV presenter Claire Balding (L) talks to Camilla, the Queen Consort, during an event at Clarence House in April 2010.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">TV presenter Claire Balding (L) talks to Camilla, the Queen Consort, during an event at Clarence House in April 2010.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Leon Neal/AFP/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Charles can largely thank his grandmother for the art adorning the walls of Clarence House. An avid private collector, Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother bought dozens of valuable artworks between the 1930s and 1950s, when prices were lower because of the war, and bargains could be found in the frequent country house sales of the time.</p> <p>Over the years, the queen mother filled Clarence House, then her London residence, with a collection worthy of any great gallery, although its presentation was more homely.</p> <p>In the corner of the Morning Room, behind a side table covered with family photographs and the shade of a table lamp, hangs what is probably the most valuable of all the art in the royals\u2019 private collection: Claude Monet\u2019s Study of Rocks; Creuse: Le Bloc. The painting was bought by the queen mother in 1945, at the Wildenstein gallery in Paris. The second world war had dampened art prices and she snapped it up for \u00a32,000, the equivalent of \u00a3110,000 today.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"eec13dd10300d7b5746927244fdf325b8e000650\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/eec13dd10300d7b5746927244fdf325b8e000650/0_0_4096_2458/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Camilla meeting the broadcaster Chris Evans at Clarence House in 2015 with Monet\u2019s Study of Rocks; Creuse: Le Bloc hanging on the wall behind her.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Camilla meeting the broadcaster Chris Evans at Clarence House in 2015 with Monet\u2019s Study of Rocks; Creuse: Le Bloc hanging on the wall behind her.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Heathcliff O\u2019Malley/Shutterstock</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Susan Orringe, of Prestige Valuations, told the Guardian the painting could fetch up to \u00a320m if it were sold today. However, she clarified that the estimated price was highly speculative and the paucity of Monets on the market, coupled with the fact that it had hung for decades in the queen mother\u2019s front room, could raise its value much higher.</p> <p>Clarence House, which used to be open to the public, has been closed since 2019. The Monet and other artworks can be seen in a <a href=\"https://artsandculture.google.com/story/inside-clarence-house-clarence-house/dgXRGpeByJlLJg?hl=en-GB\">virtual tour</a> of the residence.</p> <p>The artworks also include Fylde Farm by LS Lowry, worth about \u00a3120,000, and a portrait of George Bernard Shaw by Augustus John, worth about \u00a370,000<strong>. </strong>Elsewhere in the house are multiple other works, including paintings by Paul Nash, Raffaellino del Garbo and Alfred Sisley. The Eve of St Agnes by John Everett Millais, which the queen mother bought at auction in 1942 for \u00a3630, could be worth about \u00a31.5m today.</p> <p>Charles moved into Clarence House in 2003, after the death of the queen mother the previous year. He has previously said that among his favourite works are a moody series of paintings of Windsor Castle by John Piper. They hang on the wall of his dining room. The queen mother paid \u00a310 each for them (equivalent to \u00a3646 in today\u2019s money). Today the set could be worth \u00a3150,000.</p> <p>It is assumed Charles has inherited almost all of the artwork previously owned by the queen mother, the queen and Prince Philip. As monarch, he is exempt from the inheritance tax that would be due on any high-value bequests to his siblings.</p> <p>However, it is impossible to know precisely who owns which pieces in the Windsors\u2019 private collection, and how much it may all be worth. </p> <p>The Guardian consulted experts on the value of 60 of the most significant works on a list of 392 identified as being privately owned by the Windsors. The total value of the 60 was estimated to be at least \u00a324m. But that valuation is based on only a fraction of a much larger collection.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-atom\"> <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"a58417ce-9d40-4395-ab38-0bf2ace661d9\"         data-atom-type=\"guide\"    > </gu-atom> </figure>   <p>In 2020, the historian David McClure estimated that the queen mother\u2019s private collection, said to have comprised 1,200 prints, paintings and drawings, was worth \u00a330m. He concluded that Prince Philip\u2019s collection, said to include more than 1,500 items, was worth \u00a32m. In 2001, the art expert Robin Simon valued the queen\u2019s collection for the Mail on Sunday and concluded it was worth \u00a3150m (the equivalent of \u00a3261m today).</p> <p>That would suggest the Windsors\u2019 private collection could be worth more than \u00a3290m. However, the lack of any public register of these works means all of these estimates are speculative. It is impossible to say anything with certainty about the value of the private art collection, although there is no doubt it is worth many millions of pounds.</p> <h2><strong>Dal\u00ed and Freud</strong></h2> <p>The value of the private collection matters because while much of the Windsors\u2019 private art is unequivocally theirs, some of it might be better described as belonging to the nation. The royal policy on accepting gifts states that items presented on official duties, by people not considered close personal friends, \u201care not the private property of the member of the royal family who receives them\u201d.</p> <p>More than a third of the 392 pieces identified by the Guardian in private royal collections appear to have been gifts of one sort or another. Some were wedding presents, while others were official gifts on overseas trips, including from artists themselves. All were displayed in exhibitions of \u201cpersonal\u201d art collections. None are part of the public royal collection.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"415a0a6f9e9fcf05e6e4119899717453acd4ab11\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/415a0a6f9e9fcf05e6e4119899717453acd4ab11/0_0_4135_2481/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Charles presents the Prince of Wales medals for arts philanthropy at Clarence House in November 2011.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Charles presents the Prince of Wales medals for arts philanthropy at Clarence House in November 2011.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Anwar Hussein/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>One such instance was a gift from the Spanish surrealist Salvador Dal\u00ed, whom Philip met in 1972 while staying near Avignon on a state visit to the south of France. Not much is known about that meeting, but at some point Dal\u00ed presented Philip with an etching called Hommage, as well as a special edition of his book adorned with sketches in ballpoint pen.</p> <p>Those gifts could be worth in the region of \u00a310,000 today. Philip included them in an exhibition of work described as his personal collection in 1994.</p> <p>An infamous portrait of Queen Elizabeth II by Lucian Freud is another example of a direct gift from an artist. The 2001 work divided opinion, prompting the Sun\u2019s royal photographer Arthur Edwards to declare: \u201cFreud should be locked in the Tower [of London] for this.\u201d</p> <p>But it would appear that the queen liked it enough to adopt it as part of her personal collection. The small oil painting has now passed into the possession of the king, who loaned it to a Freud exhibition late last year.</p> <p>The painting joins another by Freud, Small Fern, which was given to Charles for his 50th birthday in 1998 and exhibited as one of his privately owned works in 2018. Oils by Freud are considered extremely valuable; Orringe estimated the botanical painting could fetch up to \u00a3600,000.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"17ce326c914790b3e78520d2e5ad0c44d6faab0d\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/17ce326c914790b3e78520d2e5ad0c44d6faab0d/0_215_3500_2101/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A curator dusts a portrait by Lucian Freud of Queen Elizabeth II as part of the exhibition The Queen: Portraits of a Monarch at Windsor Castle in 2012.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A curator dusts a portrait by Lucian Freud of Queen Elizabeth II as part of the exhibition The Queen: Portraits of a Monarch at Windsor Castle in 2012.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Steve Parsons/PA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Other artworks given to the royals on state visits include a watercolour of an Australian bird by Carol O\u2019Connor, presented to Philip on an official visit to Perth in 1990; an acrylic on masonite of pelicans by Robert Bateman, given to Philip in 1987 to mark 100 years of national parks in Canada; both were exhibited as part of Prince Philip\u2019s \u201cpersonal collection\u201d. A watercolour painting by Charles Decimus Barraud, given to the queen mother by the mayor of Auckland, New Zealand, in 1958 was included in a list of her collection, which passed to the queen on her death.</p> <p>In their statement, the palace spokesperson did not shed any light on whether specific artworks exhibited in private collections were regarded as official or personal gifts.</p> <p>\u201cOfficial gifts are not the personal property of the member of the royal family who receives them, but may be held by the sovereign in right of the crown or designated in due course as part of the royal collection,\u201d they said. \u201cEven when works of art are privately held by members of the royal family, they are frequently lent to public exhibitions.\u201d</p> <p>The palace declined to say why none of the artworks were contained in the royal collection.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-atom\"> <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"bcd01839-2ba7-49bf-83a4-819906029401\"         data-atom-type=\"guide\"    > </gu-atom> </figure>   <h2><strong>Haggling over prices</strong></h2> <p>The royal collection contains 5,600 paintings, including works by Mantegna, Rubens, Rembrandt and Canaletto. The royals have the privilege of borrowing items in the collection free of charge to hang in their private residences, while others appear in Windsor Castle and Buckingham Palace.</p> <p>But Philip, who married into the monarchy with very little wealth of his own, was said to have found the art of the royal collection stuffy. Unimpressed, he began to collect more contemporary artists, perhaps drawing on his wife\u2019s funds to do so.</p> <p>\u201cWe could have borrowed, of course,\u201d he said in a 1994 interview<strong> </strong>with the Scotsman, \u201cbut I thought it would be more fun to have our own.\u201d</p> <p>Of the 392 works identified by the Guardian, 80 were bought privately by either Philip or the queen mother \u2013 and are, in that sense, indisputably theirs.</p> <p>Philip, in particular, liked a bargain, boasting of his James Morrison oil paintings: \u201cI bought them, I don\u2019t know, for \u00a31,000 or something. I don\u2019t know what he charges now, about \u00a330,000 or something.\u201d (The record price for a Morrison was set in 2014 at \u00a381,000.)</p> <p>Letters between Philip and Feliks Topolski, a Polish-born artist whom he considered a friend, <a href=\"https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/prince-philips-secret-letters-to-painter-reveal-love-of-modern-art-67jzz5t9r\">show Philip haggling</a> over the price of an equestrian portrait for two years. He eventually drove down the price and got the work for \u00a3834 \u2013 the equivalent of<strong> </strong>\u00a312,000 in today\u2019s money. This was a 63% discount on what experts had told him it should be worth.</p> <p>Philip and the queen mother are known to have taken advantage of trips to the Commonwealth to add to their private collections, which, for example, contain 27 works by Australian and Indigenous artists.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"4a3dee53f78524d9a749e051d045fc3774f0d61f\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/4a3dee53f78524d9a749e051d045fc3774f0d61f/7_1052_4642_2785/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip in Adelaide, Australia, in 1963.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip in Adelaide, Australia, in 1963.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Reginald Davis/Rex/Shutterstock</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The most valuable of those is Home Leave by Russell Drysdale, which was acquired by the queen mother and is now worth an estimated \u00a31.7m. Philip bought works by Sidney Nolan and was given two paintings by William Dobell, which together are now worth in the region of \u00a3570,000.</p> <p>Jane Raffan, an Australian art expert and valuer, said that in the 1950s and 60s royal visitors behaved like \u201cupper-level tourists in that they were looking to acquire something, a souvenir from their trip, but they were not buying something from a tourist tat shop \u2026 in many ways it was a case of right time and place in regard to the Dobells, the Nolans and the Drysdales.\u201d</p> <h2><strong>\u2018I cannot resist it\u2019</strong></h2> <p>Another blurred line around the Windsors\u2019 private collection relates to works produced by artists who accompany them on official tours. Philip befriended Edward Seago over the years and the Norfolk-based artist gave him and the queen mother many paintings. Sixty of those came from a trip Seago took with Philip on the Royal Yacht Britannia, when, after a state visit to Australia in 1956, they sailed on to the Antarctic.</p> <p>\u201cHe painted all these pictures and said: \u2018You can have them\u2019,\u201d Philip told the Scotsman newspaper. While the two men were friends at that point, the paintings were made and presented as part of an official royal trip. Yet none of them are in the royal collection. The trove of oils passed to the royals by Seago could now be worth as much as \u00a32.6m.</p> <p>Charles has also been known to take artists on royal tours overseas; a palace spokesperson stressed they were \u201cpersonally funded\u201d by him. Artists including John Ward, Susannah Fiennes, Robbie Wraith and Warwick Fuller accompanied Charles, when he was Prince of Wales, to various destinations, from Oman to South Africa.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"61ccd83d8c71ac717fe26f8d479e2036e3b4b208\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/61ccd83d8c71ac717fe26f8d479e2036e3b4b208/0_312_4096_2458/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Charles painting in the Bhutan Himalayas, while trekking to a monastery on a 1998 visit.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Charles painting in the Bhutan Himalayas, while trekking to a monastery on a 1998 visit.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: John Stillwell/PA</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>In 1989, Charles explicitly said that the practice of taking artists with him overseas would benefit the public collection of art held in trust for the benefit of the nation. \u201cIt is such a good way of providing a record, adding to the royal collection, obtaining some tips on painting, and meeting other artists, that I cannot resist it,\u201d he said.</p> <p>The Guardian has identified 25 pieces produced by artists on such foreign trips. None are in the royal collection. They have, presumably, been incorporated into the king\u2019s private assets. Buckingham Palace declined to say where they were being kept, or why they were not in the royal collection. The locations of the works given to the royal family by Dal\u00ed, Chagall and Freud also remain a mystery. </p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/from-tool/generic/index.html?vertical=News&amp;opinion-tint=false&amp;title=Story%20tips%3F&amp;description=Do%20you%20have%20information%20about%20this%20story%3F%20Email%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22mailto%3Ainvestigations%40theguardian.com%22%3Einvestigations%40theguardian.com%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20or%20use%20Signal%20or%20WhatsApp%20to%20message%20(UK)%20%2B44%207584%20640566%20or%20(US)%20%2B1%20646%20886%208761.%20For%20the%20most%20secure%20communications%2C%20use%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22nothttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fsecuredrop%22%3ESecureDrop%3C%2Fa%3E%20or%20see%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fhelp%2Fng-interactive%2F2017%2Fmar%2F17%2Fcontact-the-guardian-securely%22%3Eour%20guide%3C%2Fa%3E.&amp;link=false\" data-alt=\"Do you have information about this story? Email investigations@theguardian.com, or use Signal or WhatsApp to message (UK) +44 7584 640566 or (US) +1 646 886 8761.\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/from-tool/generic/index.html?vertical=News&opinion-tint=false&title=Story%20tips%3F&description=Do%20you%20have%20information%20about%20this%20story%3F%20Email%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22mailto%3Ainvestigations%40theguardian.com%22%3Einvestigations%40theguardian.com%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20or%20use%20Signal%20or%20WhatsApp%20to%20message%20(UK)%20%2B44%207584%20640566%20or%20(US)%20%2B1%20646%20886%208761.%20For%20the%20most%20secure%20communications%2C%20use%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22nothttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fsecuredrop%22%3ESecureDrop%3C%2Fa%3E%20or%20see%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fhelp%2Fng-interactive%2F2017%2Fmar%2F17%2Fcontact-the-guardian-securely%22%3Eour%20guide%3C%2Fa%3E.&link=false\">Interactive</a> </figure>", "bodyTextSummary": "Prince Philip was accompanying Queen Elizabeth II on an official visit to Denmark when the venerated modernist painter Marc Chagall pressed a gift into his hands. It was 1960 and the pair had just met at a ceremony where Chagall was presented with the prestigious Erasmus prize. Philip would later recall the artist\u2019s \u201cjocular attitude\u201d as he showed him around his exhibition. \u201cHe gave me this Bible he has illustrated, just out of the blue. He was a very strange man,\u201d Philip reportedly said. It was also something of a strange gift. Inside the Bible, Chagall had daubed colourful illustrations in watercolours, chalk and ink. Those two illustrations could now be worth as much as \u00a360,000.\nAs contemporary artworks go, that is not a huge sum. However, the Chagall Bible is one of an extraordinary collection of almost 400 artworks, some worth much more, that have been exhibited by the Windsors in \u201cpersonal\u201d or \u201cprivate\u201d collections. They are, in total, likely to be worth tens of millions of pounds, possibly more, and include pieces by Salvador Dal\u00ed, LS Lowry, Claude Monet and Lucian Freud. Many of the items, however, raise questions for the Windsors about whether all of these artworks should really belong to them. Royal art can broadly be separated into two categories. Most of it is part of the royal collection, more than a million items that are held in trust by the sovereign for the benefit of the nation. Described as one of the greatest art collections in the world, it is the nearest the UK has to a public custodian of royal-linked art. The second, much more elusive category is that which the royals treat as their own: the Windsors\u2019 private collection. There is no public register of these works and Buckingham Palace refuses to comment in any detail on what it regards as private wealth. However, items such as the Chagall Bible raise questions about what falls under that definition. Not in the royal collection, the artwork casually given to Philip on a state visit appears to have been absorbed into his own collection. At a special exhibition in Holyrood Palace in 1994, the Chagall piece was on display as part of the prince\u2019s \u201cpersonal collection\u201d. Buckingham Palace\u2019s gift policy, introduced the following year, distinguishes between \u201cofficial gifts\u201d, which are generally those received in the course of formal duties and functions, and \u201cpersonal gifts\u201d, from people whom members of the royal family know personally. The policy adds: \u201cIn all cases, and particularly on official overseas trips, organisations and individuals should be discouraged from offering extravagant gifts, ie gifts of high monetary value.\u201d Contacted by the Guardian, the palace declined to comment on the ownership status of the Chagall or more than a dozen other artworks that would appear to have been official gifts but have been exhibited as part of the Windsors\u2019 personal or private collections. \u201cIt is incorrect to suggest that the artworks you list were all official gifts,\u201d a spokesperson said. \u201cWe would not comment on the value of works of art.\u201d A Monet worth millions A watercolour artist himself, King Charles III is an aficionado of fine art. The four floors of his London residence, Clarence House, are filled with artwork, much of which is unequivocally the private property of the Windsors.\nCharles can largely thank his grandmother for the art adorning the walls of Clarence House. An avid private collector, Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother bought dozens of valuable artworks between the 1930s and 1950s, when prices were lower because of the war, and bargains could be found in the frequent country house sales of the time. Over the years, the queen mother filled Clarence House, then her London residence, with a collection worthy of any great gallery, although its presentation was more homely. In the corner of the Morning Room, behind a side table covered with family photographs and the shade of a table lamp, hangs what is probably the most valuable of all the art in the royals\u2019 private collection: Claude Monet\u2019s Study of Rocks; Creuse: Le Bloc. The painting was bought by the queen mother in 1945, at the Wildenstein gallery in Paris. The second world war had dampened art prices and she snapped it up for \u00a32,000, the equivalent of \u00a3110,000 today.\nSusan Orringe, of Prestige Valuations, told the Guardian the painting could fetch up to \u00a320m if it were sold today. However, she clarified that the estimated price was highly speculative and the paucity of Monets on the market, coupled with the fact that it had hung for decades in the queen mother\u2019s front room, could raise its value much higher. Clarence House, which used to be open to the public, has been closed since 2019. The Monet and other artworks can be seen in a virtual tour of the residence. The artworks also include Fylde Farm by LS Lowry, worth about \u00a3120,000, and a portrait of George Bernard Shaw by Augustus John, worth about \u00a370,000. Elsewhere in the house are multiple other works, including paintings by Paul Nash, Raffaellino del Garbo and Alfred Sisley. The Eve of St Agnes by John Everett Millais, which the queen mother bought at auction in 1942 for \u00a3630, could be worth about \u00a31.5m today. Charles moved into Clarence House in 2003, after the death of the queen mother the previous year. He has previously said that among his favourite works are a moody series of paintings of Windsor Castle by John Piper. They hang on the wall of his dining room. The queen mother paid \u00a310 each for them (equivalent to \u00a3646 in today\u2019s money). Today the set could be worth \u00a3150,000. It is assumed Charles has inherited almost all of the artwork previously owned by the queen mother, the queen and Prince Philip. As monarch, he is exempt from the inheritance tax that would be due on any high-value bequests to his siblings. However, it is impossible to know precisely who owns which pieces in the Windsors\u2019 private collection, and how much it may all be worth. The Guardian consulted experts on the value of 60 of the most significant works on a list of 392 identified as being privately owned by the Windsors. The total value of the 60 was estimated to be at least \u00a324m. But that valuation is based on only a fraction of a much larger collection.\nIn 2020, the historian David McClure estimated that the queen mother\u2019s private collection, said to have comprised 1,200 prints, paintings and drawings, was worth \u00a330m. He concluded that Prince Philip\u2019s collection, said to include more than 1,500 items, was worth \u00a32m. In 2001, the art expert Robin Simon valued the queen\u2019s collection for the Mail on Sunday and concluded it was worth \u00a3150m (the equivalent of \u00a3261m today). That would suggest the Windsors\u2019 private collection could be worth more than \u00a3290m. However, the lack of any public register of these works means all of these estimates are speculative. It is impossible to say anything with certainty about the value of the private art collection, although there is no doubt it is worth many millions of pounds. Dal\u00ed and Freud The value of the private collection matters because while much of the Windsors\u2019 private art is unequivocally theirs, some of it might be better described as belonging to the nation. The royal policy on accepting gifts states that items presented on official duties, by people not considered close personal friends, \u201care not the private property of the member of the royal family who receives them\u201d. More than a third of the 392 pieces identified by the Guardian in private royal collections appear to have been gifts of one sort or another. Some were wedding presents, while others were official gifts on overseas trips, including from artists themselves. All were displayed in exhibitions of \u201cpersonal\u201d art collections. None are part of the public royal collection.\nOne such instance was a gift from the Spanish surrealist Salvador Dal\u00ed, whom Philip met in 1972 while staying near Avignon on a state visit to the south of France. Not much is known about that meeting, but at some point Dal\u00ed presented Philip with an etching called Hommage, as well as a special edition of his book adorned with sketches in ballpoint pen. Those gifts could be worth in the region of \u00a310,000 today. Philip included them in an exhibition of work described as his personal collection in 1994. An infamous portrait of Queen Elizabeth II by Lucian Freud is another example of a direct gift from an artist. The 2001 work divided opinion, prompting the Sun\u2019s royal photographer Arthur Edwards to declare: \u201cFreud should be locked in the Tower [of London] for this.\u201d But it would appear that the queen liked it enough to adopt it as part of her personal collection. The small oil painting has now passed into the possession of the king, who loaned it to a Freud exhibition late last year. The painting joins another by Freud, Small Fern, which was given to Charles for his 50th birthday in 1998 and exhibited as one of his privately owned works in 2018. Oils by Freud are considered extremely valuable; Orringe estimated the botanical painting could fetch up to \u00a3600,000.\nOther artworks given to the royals on state visits include a watercolour of an Australian bird by Carol O\u2019Connor, presented to Philip on an official visit to Perth in 1990; an acrylic on masonite of pelicans by Robert Bateman, given to Philip in 1987 to mark 100 years of national parks in Canada; both were exhibited as part of Prince Philip\u2019s \u201cpersonal collection\u201d. A watercolour painting by Charles Decimus Barraud, given to the queen mother by the mayor of Auckland, New Zealand, in 1958 was included in a list of her collection, which passed to the queen on her death. In their statement, the palace spokesperson did not shed any light on whether specific artworks exhibited in private collections were regarded as official or personal gifts. \u201cOfficial gifts are not the personal property of the member of the royal family who receives them, but may be held by the sovereign in right of the crown or designated in due course as part of the royal collection,\u201d they said. \u201cEven when works of art are privately held by members of the royal family, they are frequently lent to public exhibitions.\u201d The palace declined to say why none of the artworks were contained in the royal collection.\nHaggling over prices The royal collection contains 5,600 paintings, including works by Mantegna, Rubens, Rembrandt and Canaletto. The royals have the privilege of borrowing items in the collection free of charge to hang in their private residences, while others appear in Windsor Castle and Buckingham Palace. But Philip, who married into the monarchy with very little wealth of his own, was said to have found the art of the royal collection stuffy. Unimpressed, he began to collect more contemporary artists, perhaps drawing on his wife\u2019s funds to do so. \u201cWe could have borrowed, of course,\u201d he said in a 1994 interview with the Scotsman, \u201cbut I thought it would be more fun to have our own.\u201d Of the 392 works identified by the Guardian, 80 were bought privately by either Philip or the queen mother \u2013 and are, in that sense, indisputably theirs. Philip, in particular, liked a bargain, boasting of his James Morrison oil paintings: \u201cI bought them, I don\u2019t know, for \u00a31,000 or something. I don\u2019t know what he charges now, about \u00a330,000 or something.\u201d (The record price for a Morrison was set in 2014 at \u00a381,000.) Letters between Philip and Feliks Topolski, a Polish-born artist whom he considered a friend, show Philip haggling over the price of an equestrian portrait for two years. He eventually drove down the price and got the work for \u00a3834 \u2013 the equivalent of \u00a312,000 in today\u2019s money. This was a 63% discount on what experts had told him it should be worth. Philip and the queen mother are known to have taken advantage of trips to the Commonwealth to add to their private collections, which, for example, contain 27 works by Australian and Indigenous artists.\nThe most valuable of those is Home Leave by Russell Drysdale, which was acquired by the queen mother and is now worth an estimated \u00a31.7m. Philip bought works by Sidney Nolan and was given two paintings by William Dobell, which together are now worth in the region of \u00a3570,000. Jane Raffan, an Australian art expert and valuer, said that in the 1950s and 60s royal visitors behaved like \u201cupper-level tourists in that they were looking to acquire something, a souvenir from their trip, but they were not buying something from a tourist tat shop \u2026 in many ways it was a case of right time and place in regard to the Dobells, the Nolans and the Drysdales.\u201d \u2018I cannot resist it\u2019 Another blurred line around the Windsors\u2019 private collection relates to works produced by artists who accompany them on official tours. Philip befriended Edward Seago over the years and the Norfolk-based artist gave him and the queen mother many paintings. Sixty of those came from a trip Seago took with Philip on the Royal Yacht Britannia, when, after a state visit to Australia in 1956, they sailed on to the Antarctic. \u201cHe painted all these pictures and said: \u2018You can have them\u2019,\u201d Philip told the Scotsman newspaper. While the two men were friends at that point, the paintings were made and presented as part of an official royal trip. Yet none of them are in the royal collection. The trove of oils passed to the royals by Seago could now be worth as much as \u00a32.6m. Charles has also been known to take artists on royal tours overseas; a palace spokesperson stressed they were \u201cpersonally funded\u201d by him. Artists including John Ward, Susannah Fiennes, Robbie Wraith and Warwick Fuller accompanied Charles, when he was Prince of Wales, to various destinations, from Oman to South Africa.\nIn 1989, Charles explicitly said that the practice of taking artists with him overseas would benefit the public collection of art held in trust for the benefit of the nation. \u201cIt is such a good way of providing a record, adding to the royal collection, obtaining some tips on painting, and meeting other artists, that I cannot resist it,\u201d he said. The Guardian has identified 25 pieces produced by artists on such foreign trips. None are in the royal collection. They have, presumably, been incorporated into the king\u2019s private assets. Buckingham Palace declined to say where they were being kept, or why they were not in the royal collection. The locations of the works given to the royal family by Dal\u00ed, Chagall and Freud also remain a mystery. </p>"}}, {"type": "interactive", "assets": [], "interactiveTypeData": {"originalUrl": "https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/from-tool/generic/index.html?vertical=News&opinion-tint=false&title=Story%20tips%3F&description=Do%20you%20have%20information%20about%20this%20story%3F%20Email%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22mailto%3Ainvestigations%40theguardian.com%22%3Einvestigations%40theguardian.com%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20or%20use%20Signal%20or%20WhatsApp%20to%20message%20(UK)%20%2B44%207584%20640566%20or%20(US)%20%2B1%20646%20886%208761.%20For%20the%20most%20secure%20communications%2C%20use%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22nothttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fsecuredrop%22%3ESecureDrop%3C%2Fa%3E%20or%20see%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fhelp%2Fng-interactive%2F2017%2Fmar%2F17%2Fcontact-the-guardian-securely%22%3Eour%20guide%3C%2Fa%3E.&link=false", "source": "Guardian", "alt": "Do you have information about this story? "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/uk-news", "editions": [{"id": "uk-news", "webTitle": "UK news", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/uk-news", "code": "default"}]}, "isHosted": false, "pillarId": "pillar/news", "pillarName": "News"}, {"id": "film/2023/apr/17/how-to-blow-up-a-pipeline-oil-extreme-action-eco-terrorism-self-defence", "type": "article", "sectionId": "film", "sectionName": "Film", "webPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:30Z", "webTitle": "Is eco-terrorism now self-defence? Inside explosive film How to Blow Up a Pipeline", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/film/2023/apr/17/how-to-blow-up-a-pipeline-oil-extreme-action-eco-terrorism-self-defence", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/film/2023/apr/17/how-to-blow-up-a-pipeline-oil-extreme-action-eco-terrorism-self-defence", "fields": {"headline": "Is eco-terrorism now self-defence? Inside explosive film How to Blow Up a Pipeline", "standfirst": "<p>Peaceful protest hasn\u2019t stopped the climate crisis, so what should happen next? The makers of a new nerve-jangling film about eight young saboteurs talk about oil, extreme action and morality</p>", "trailText": "Peaceful protest hasn\u2019t stopped the climate crisis, so what should happen next? The makers of a new nerve-jangling film about eight young saboteurs talk about oil, extreme action and morality", "byline": "Simran Hans", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"4193c30327e9fd40c7031c3d71136c47bfd787b5\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/4193c30327e9fd40c7031c3d71136c47bfd787b5/211_0_3089_1856/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Target engaged \u2026 an image from How to Blow Up a Pipeline.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Target engaged \u2026 an image from How to Blow Up a Pipeline.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Neon</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>In the baking heat of the west Texas desert, a young man is making a bomb. Hands trembling, sweat fogging his goggles, he slowly assembles the explosive. A knife-blade of powder is painstakingly poured into a tiny tube. Wires are shakily glued together. With infinite care, the delicate, deadly contraption takes shape. Outside the tin shack where this is all unfolding, another young man paces, remembering his friend\u2019s instructions: \u201cDon\u2019t come in unless I tell you to. Unless you see fire.\u201d He looks as if he\u2019s about to be sick. The audience knows how he feels.</p> <p>This is the tense setup at the heart of How to Blow Up a Pipeline, a propulsive, nerve-jangling thriller about eight young people who want to send a message about the urgency of the climate crisis by sabotaging an oil pipeline. The film takes its cues from its heroes: aiming to excite audiences into action instead of hectoring them into submission. It is one hell of a ride. After its premiere at Toronto last year, the New York Times pronounced How to Blow Up a Pipeline \u201ca cultural landmark\u201d for its sympathetic take on eco-terrorism, while the Washington City Paper described its youthful cast as \u201ca much more intense, combustible version of The Breakfast Club\u201d.</p> <p>What director, co-writer and producer Daniel Goldhaber \u2013 one of its four key film-makers \u2013 wanted to make, he says via video call, was a thriller: \u201cOcean\u2019s Eleven about environmental activism.\u201d It\u2019s an ingenious pitch. Regardless of your feelings about their approach, you root for the gang to succeed as much as you do for hardened gangsters poring over blueprints to pull off a bank heist. \u201cThe idea of empathising with characters who take action like this, without ever condemning them for taking it too far, is something I don\u2019t see in the media,\u201d says Ariela Barer, who co-wrote, produced and also stars in the film.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"57da70ae0953ca2cce30850c8927a456ed88ed7b\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/57da70ae0953ca2cce30850c8927a456ed88ed7b/21_0_3600_2160/1000.jpg\" alt=\"\u2018I only get to be 49?\u2019 \u2026 Ariela Barer in the film.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">\u2018I only get to be 49?\u2019 \u2026 Ariela Barer in the film.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Neon</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The pair first had the idea for the project while isolating in an LA apartment in January 2021. Their other flatmate, co-writer Jordan Sjol, had got hold of a book provocatively entitled How to Blow Up a Pipeline. It was a manifesto by Swedish academic Andreas Malm that made a rousing case for property destruction as a tactic in the pursuit of climate justice. The volume was excitedly passed around. Goldhaber had the idea of dramatising its ideas, turning them into a movie. But how to adapt a work of theory into a mainstream blockbuster? None of them wanted to make a hand-wringing documentary, or an apocalyptic disaster flick in the mould of The Day After Tomorrow or Don\u2019t Look Up. They wanted it to be credible, but also appealing \u2013 optimistic even.</p> <p>For Goldhaber, films that now possess that last quality tend to have major vested interests \u2013 and budgets to match. \u201cWe have traded the ability for hopeful moviemaking for movies like Top Gun,\u201d he says, \u201cwhich is a good piece of film-making but undoubtedly a piece of American military propaganda.\u201d Yet tapping into the same emotional beats \u2013 underdog narrative, heart-pounding action \u2013 and using them to talk about acts of sabotage and resistance is, he says, \u201ca totally valid and important thing for the progressive movement to engage with\u201d. </p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>The Dakota Access Pipeline activists did everything right \u2013 and nothing happened. The pipeline got built</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>It\u2019s true: watching the gang plant the explosive, or Michael, the young man in that pivotal scene, cook it up in the first place, the job at the centre of How to Blow Up a Pipeline shares more DNA with tense Hollywood heist movies like Thief or Inside Man. \u201cWhat they\u2019re doing is pretty dangerous,\u201d says the film\u2019s editor Daniel Garber, who rounds out the quartet, each of them<strong> </strong>billed equally in the credits as makers (like their characters, they are a collective). \u201cThat\u2019s what provokes this stomach-churning feeling of, \u2018Oh my God, are they going to blow themselves up?\u2019\u201d</p> <p>Once you create a certain level of tension, he says, it buys you time to digress. \u201cThe heist,\u201d he adds, \u201cis a Trojan horse into which we can sneak all of these other concepts.\u201d Those concepts are explored in flashbacks, each one detailing how the individual characters came to be involved with the cause.</p> <p>The team spent two months interviewing climate activists and pipeline experts about their experiences. Some became characters. Clarissa Thibeaux, Barer\u2019s friend and a credited consultant, partly inspired Theo, played by American Honey\u2019s Sasha Lane, whose leukaemia diagnosis she ascribes to growing up near to a chemical plant. They also drew from the story of <a href=\"https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/culture-features/dakota-access-pipeline-eco-sabotage-jessica-reznicek-ruby-montoya-1173735/\">Jessica Reznicek and Ruby Montoya</a>, who were imprisoned for terrorism after they vandalised the Dakota Access Pipeline with an acetylene torch, despite there being no oil running through it.</p> <p>Barer had campaigned against its construction as a teenager. \u201cThe pipeline got built,\u201d she says, \u201cand nothing really happened, despite the activists doing everything right.\u201d This failure, after immaculate campaigning, was one of the reasons she was so drawn to Malm\u2019s book: \u201cIt felt like an unapologetic push for a radical flank.\u201d The book also detailed acts of sabotage sometimes wrongly remembered as non-violent, such as women\u2019s suffrage. \u201cReading theory like this reinvigorated me,\u201d she says.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"7307e43d0a1ad5b511a84b83efef8d3011e1cd35\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/7307e43d0a1ad5b511a84b83efef8d3011e1cd35/240_0_3600_2160/1000.jpg\" alt=\"\u2018A kaleidoscope\u2019 \u2026 two of the eight saboteurs.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">\u2018A kaleidoscope\u2019 \u2026 two of the eight saboteurs.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Neon</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The film-makers also wanted to more accurately represent the communities affected by the climate crisis, bringing in Indigenous actor Forrest Goodluck (who played Leonardo DiCaprio\u2019s son in The Revenant) to consult on the film as well as star as bomb-maker Michael. Their on-screen ensemble is predominantly made up of people of colour and includes working-class voices, Malm\u2019s book having described movements such as Extinction Rebellion as \u201cpersistently aloof from factors of class and race\u201d. Goldhaber says that, while the film does acknowledge the sort of activist often criticised for skewing white and privileged, it is designed as \u201ca kaleidoscope of all the different kinds of folks involved in the movement\u201d. The idea was to offer broad access points for the audience. This also explains the film\u2019s subtly comic moments: while the characters are taken seriously, they do not do so themselves. Two even fool around while waiting for a timer to go off. </p> <p>\u201cIt would be totally alienating if it was all melodrama,\u201d says Barer. \u201cIf it were me and my friends, we would get drunk the night before. We would be idiots about it, because it\u2019s so scary. Even with \u2018the perfect plan\u2019 they have, there\u2019s so much risk and personal sacrifice.\u201d The intention was provocation, adds Goldhaber, not propaganda, not just \u201criling people who already believe in what you\u2019re saying\u201d. Instead, they wanted to shift the conversation from the decision whether to take action to actual tactics and strategy<strong> </strong>once you do. </p> <p>Earlier this year in the UK, more than 120 lawyers <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/mar/24/top-lawyers-defy-bar-declare-will-not-prosecute-peaceful-climate-protesters\">defied bar rules</a> and arguably engaged in an act of civil disobedience by signing a declaration stating that they would not prosecute peaceful climate activists, nor defend companies pursuing fossil fuel projects. But what about the non-peaceful activists? If pipelines are morally indefensible, is there a moral obligation to destroy them? \u201cIf you see how this is self-defence for these eight characters,\u201d says Goldhaber, \u201cthat opens up a whole world of questions and possibilities for the future of the climate movement.\u201d</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>The Teton glacier was a little smaller every year \u2013 until it was very, very nearly vanished</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>All four film-makers have their own stories to tell regarding their way into activism. Goldhaber\u2019s seems the most conventional: parents who worked in the field, a childhood spent \u201cwith the doom of climate change hanging over me\u201d. He worked on the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/dec/13/chasing-ice-review\">2012 documentary Chasing Ice</a>, about crumbling glaciers, but was disillusioned by the fact that the film triggered precious little change.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--supporting\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2021/nov/18/moral-case-destroying-fossil-fuel-infrastructure\">The moral case for destroying fossil fuel infrastructure | Andreas Malm</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Sjol, who grew up in rural Wyoming, tells me about hiking the jagged peaks of the Tetons as a child during the summer, climbing up to one of the range\u2019s glacial lakes. \u201cThe glacier would be a little smaller every year,\u201d he says, \u201cuntil it was very, very nearly vanished.\u201d</p> <p>Barer is the youngest of the group and perhaps the most passionate. She was raised in Los Angeles by a mother who \u201ccame from the hippy movement in Mexico\u201d and preached a gospel of \u201creduce, reuse, recycle\u201d. When she was nine, the family visited Disneyland. In the queue for the rollercoaster, she overheard an adult saying that the planet was dying. Devastated, she asked how long it had left. They reckoned about 40 years. \u201cI was like, \u2018I only get to be 49? That\u2019s it?\u2019\u201d</p> <p>Barer, now 24, remains haunted by the exchange. \u201cI\u2019ve thought about that number ever since.\u201d</p> <p>\u2022 How to Blow Up a Pipeline is released in UK cinemas on 21 April</p>", "newspaperPageNumber": "8", "wordcount": "1418", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T05:00:30Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T05:00:31Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-17T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/njjxn", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/4193c30327e9fd40c7031c3d71136c47bfd787b5/211_0_3089_1856/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "In the baking heat of the west Texas desert, a young man is making a bomb. "credit": "Photograph: Neon", "source": "Neon", "alt": "Target engaged \u2026 an image from How to Blow Up a Pipeline.", "mediaId": "4193c30327e9fd40c7031c3d71136c47bfd787b5", "mediaApiUri": "https://api.media.gutools.co.uk/images/4193c30327e9fd40c7031c3d71136c47bfd787b5", "imageType": "Photograph", "role": "showcase"}}]}, "body": [{"id": "6422c5cc8f083e10680fb356", "bodyHtml": "<p>In the baking heat of the west Texas desert, a young man is making a bomb. Hands trembling, sweat fogging his goggles, he slowly assembles the explosive. A knife-blade of powder is painstakingly poured into a tiny tube. Wires are shakily glued together. With infinite care, the delicate, deadly contraption takes shape. Outside the tin shack where this is all unfolding, another young man paces, remembering his friend\u2019s instructions: \u201cDon\u2019t come in unless I tell you to. Unless you see fire.\u201d He looks as if he\u2019s about to be sick. The audience knows how he feels.</p> <p>This is the tense setup at the heart of How to Blow Up a Pipeline, a propulsive, nerve-jangling thriller about eight young people who want to send a message about the urgency of the climate crisis by sabotaging an oil pipeline. The film takes its cues from its heroes: aiming to excite audiences into action instead of hectoring them into submission. It is one hell of a ride. After its premiere at Toronto last year, the New York Times pronounced How to Blow Up a Pipeline \u201ca cultural landmark\u201d for its sympathetic take on eco-terrorism, while the Washington City Paper described its youthful cast as \u201ca much more intense, combustible version of The Breakfast Club\u201d.</p> <p>What director, co-writer and producer Daniel Goldhaber \u2013 one of its four key film-makers \u2013 wanted to make, he says via video call, was a thriller: \u201cOcean\u2019s Eleven about environmental activism.\u201d It\u2019s an ingenious pitch. Regardless of your feelings about their approach, you root for the gang to succeed as much as you do for hardened gangsters poring over blueprints to pull off a bank heist. \u201cThe idea of empathising with characters who take action like this, without ever condemning them for taking it too far, is something I don\u2019t see in the media,\u201d says Ariela Barer, who co-wrote, produced and also stars in the film.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"57da70ae0953ca2cce30850c8927a456ed88ed7b\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/57da70ae0953ca2cce30850c8927a456ed88ed7b/21_0_3600_2160/1000.jpg\" alt=\"\u2018I only get to be 49?\u2019 \u2026 Ariela Barer in the film.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">\u2018I only get to be 49?\u2019 \u2026 Ariela Barer in the film.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Neon</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The pair first had the idea for the project while isolating in an LA apartment in January 2021. Their other flatmate, co-writer Jordan Sjol, had got hold of a book provocatively entitled How to Blow Up a Pipeline. It was a manifesto by Swedish academic Andreas Malm that made a rousing case for property destruction as a tactic in the pursuit of climate justice. The volume was excitedly passed around. Goldhaber had the idea of dramatising its ideas, turning them into a movie. But how to adapt a work of theory into a mainstream blockbuster? None of them wanted to make a hand-wringing documentary, or an apocalyptic disaster flick in the mould of The Day After Tomorrow or Don\u2019t Look Up. They wanted it to be credible, but also appealing \u2013 optimistic even.</p> <p>For Goldhaber, films that now possess that last quality tend to have major vested interests \u2013 and budgets to match. \u201cWe have traded the ability for hopeful moviemaking for movies like Top Gun,\u201d he says, \u201cwhich is a good piece of film-making but undoubtedly a piece of American military propaganda.\u201d Yet tapping into the same emotional beats \u2013 underdog narrative, heart-pounding action \u2013 and using them to talk about acts of sabotage and resistance is, he says, \u201ca totally valid and important thing for the progressive movement to engage with\u201d. </p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>The Dakota Access Pipeline activists did everything right \u2013 and nothing happened. The pipeline got built</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>It\u2019s true: watching the gang plant the explosive, or Michael, the young man in that pivotal scene, cook it up in the first place, the job at the centre of How to Blow Up a Pipeline shares more DNA with tense Hollywood heist movies like Thief or Inside Man. \u201cWhat they\u2019re doing is pretty dangerous,\u201d says the film\u2019s editor Daniel Garber, who rounds out the quartet, each of them<strong> </strong>billed equally in the credits as makers (like their characters, they are a collective). \u201cThat\u2019s what provokes this stomach-churning feeling of, \u2018Oh my God, are they going to blow themselves up?\u2019\u201d</p> <p>Once you create a certain level of tension, he says, it buys you time to digress. \u201cThe heist,\u201d he adds, \u201cis a Trojan horse into which we can sneak all of these other concepts.\u201d Those concepts are explored in flashbacks, each one detailing how the individual characters came to be involved with the cause.</p> <p>The team spent two months interviewing climate activists and pipeline experts about their experiences. Some became characters. Clarissa Thibeaux, Barer\u2019s friend and a credited consultant, partly inspired Theo, played by American Honey\u2019s Sasha Lane, whose leukaemia diagnosis she ascribes to growing up near to a chemical plant. They also drew from the story of <a href=\"https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/culture-features/dakota-access-pipeline-eco-sabotage-jessica-reznicek-ruby-montoya-1173735/\">Jessica Reznicek and Ruby Montoya</a>, who were imprisoned for terrorism after they vandalised the Dakota Access Pipeline with an acetylene torch, despite there being no oil running through it.</p> <p>Barer had campaigned against its construction as a teenager. \u201cThe pipeline got built,\u201d she says, \u201cand nothing really happened, despite the activists doing everything right.\u201d This failure, after immaculate campaigning, was one of the reasons she was so drawn to Malm\u2019s book: \u201cIt felt like an unapologetic push for a radical flank.\u201d The book also detailed acts of sabotage sometimes wrongly remembered as non-violent, such as women\u2019s suffrage. \u201cReading theory like this reinvigorated me,\u201d she says.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"7307e43d0a1ad5b511a84b83efef8d3011e1cd35\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/7307e43d0a1ad5b511a84b83efef8d3011e1cd35/240_0_3600_2160/1000.jpg\" alt=\"\u2018A kaleidoscope\u2019 \u2026 two of the eight saboteurs.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">\u2018A kaleidoscope\u2019 \u2026 two of the eight saboteurs.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Neon</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The film-makers also wanted to more accurately represent the communities affected by the climate crisis, bringing in Indigenous actor Forrest Goodluck (who played Leonardo DiCaprio\u2019s son in The Revenant) to consult on the film as well as star as bomb-maker Michael. Their on-screen ensemble is predominantly made up of people of colour and includes working-class voices, Malm\u2019s book having described movements such as Extinction Rebellion as \u201cpersistently aloof from factors of class and race\u201d. Goldhaber says that, while the film does acknowledge the sort of activist often criticised for skewing white and privileged, it is designed as \u201ca kaleidoscope of all the different kinds of folks involved in the movement\u201d. The idea was to offer broad access points for the audience. This also explains the film\u2019s subtly comic moments: while the characters are taken seriously, they do not do so themselves. Two even fool around while waiting for a timer to go off. </p> <p>\u201cIt would be totally alienating if it was all melodrama,\u201d says Barer. \u201cIf it were me and my friends, we would get drunk the night before. We would be idiots about it, because it\u2019s so scary. Even with \u2018the perfect plan\u2019 they have, there\u2019s so much risk and personal sacrifice.\u201d The intention was provocation, adds Goldhaber, not propaganda, not just \u201criling people who already believe in what you\u2019re saying\u201d. Instead, they wanted to shift the conversation from the decision whether to take action to actual tactics and strategy<strong> </strong>once you do. </p> <p>Earlier this year in the UK, more than 120 lawyers <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/mar/24/top-lawyers-defy-bar-declare-will-not-prosecute-peaceful-climate-protesters\">defied bar rules</a> and arguably engaged in an act of civil disobedience by signing a declaration stating that they would not prosecute peaceful climate activists, nor defend companies pursuing fossil fuel projects. But what about the non-peaceful activists? If pipelines are morally indefensible, is there a moral obligation to destroy them? \u201cIf you see how this is self-defence for these eight characters,\u201d says Goldhaber, \u201cthat opens up a whole world of questions and possibilities for the future of the climate movement.\u201d</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>The Teton glacier was a little smaller every year \u2013 until it was very, very nearly vanished</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>All four film-makers have their own stories to tell regarding their way into activism. Goldhaber\u2019s seems the most conventional: parents who worked in the field, a childhood spent \u201cwith the doom of climate change hanging over me\u201d. He worked on the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/dec/13/chasing-ice-review\">2012 documentary Chasing Ice</a>, about crumbling glaciers, but was disillusioned by the fact that the film triggered precious little change.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--supporting\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2021/nov/18/moral-case-destroying-fossil-fuel-infrastructure\">The moral case for destroying fossil fuel infrastructure | Andreas Malm</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Sjol, who grew up in rural Wyoming, tells me about hiking the jagged peaks of the Tetons as a child during the summer, climbing up to one of the range\u2019s glacial lakes. \u201cThe glacier would be a little smaller every year,\u201d he says, \u201cuntil it was very, very nearly vanished.\u201d</p> <p>Barer is the youngest of the group and perhaps the most passionate. She was raised in Los Angeles by a mother who \u201ccame from the hippy movement in Mexico\u201d and preached a gospel of \u201creduce, reuse, recycle\u201d. When she was nine, the family visited Disneyland. In the queue for the rollercoaster, she overheard an adult saying that the planet was dying. Devastated, she asked how long it had left. They reckoned about 40 years. \u201cI was like, \u2018I only get to be 49? That\u2019s it?\u2019\u201d</p> <p>Barer, now 24, remains haunted by the exchange. \u201cI\u2019ve thought about that number ever since.\u201d</p> <p>\u2022 How to Blow Up a Pipeline is released in UK cinemas on 21 April</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "In the baking heat of the west Texas desert, a young man is making a bomb. Hands trembling, sweat fogging his goggles, he slowly assembles the explosive. A knife-blade of powder is painstakingly poured into a tiny tube. Wires are shakily glued together. With infinite care, the delicate, deadly contraption takes shape. Outside the tin shack where this is all unfolding, another young man paces, remembering his friend\u2019s instructions: \u201cDon\u2019t come in unless I tell you to. Unless you see fire.\u201d He looks as if he\u2019s about to be sick. The audience knows how he feels. This is the tense setup at the heart of How to Blow Up a Pipeline, a propulsive, nerve-jangling thriller about eight young people who want to send a message about the urgency of the climate crisis by sabotaging an oil pipeline. The film takes its cues from its heroes: aiming to excite audiences into action instead of hectoring them into submission. It is one hell of a ride. After its premiere at Toronto last year, the New York Times pronounced How to Blow Up a Pipeline \u201ca cultural landmark\u201d for its sympathetic take on eco-terrorism, while the Washington City Paper described its youthful cast as \u201ca much more intense, combustible version of The Breakfast Club\u201d. What director, co-writer and producer Daniel Goldhaber \u2013 one of its four key film-makers \u2013 wanted to make, he says via video call, was a thriller: \u201cOcean\u2019s Eleven about environmental activism.\u201d It\u2019s an ingenious pitch. Regardless of your feelings about their approach, you root for the gang to succeed as much as you do for hardened gangsters poring over blueprints to pull off a bank heist. \u201cThe idea of empathising with characters who take action like this, without ever condemning them for taking it too far, is something I don\u2019t see in the media,\u201d says Ariela Barer, who co-wrote, produced and also stars in the film.\nThe pair first had the idea for the project while isolating in an LA apartment in January 2021. Their other flatmate, co-writer Jordan Sjol, had got hold of a book provocatively entitled How to Blow Up a Pipeline. It was a manifesto by Swedish academic Andreas Malm that made a rousing case for property destruction as a tactic in the pursuit of climate justice. The volume was excitedly passed around. Goldhaber had the idea of dramatising its ideas, turning them into a movie. But how to adapt a work of theory into a mainstream blockbuster? None of them wanted to make a hand-wringing documentary, or an apocalyptic disaster flick in the mould of The Day After Tomorrow or Don\u2019t Look Up. They wanted it to be credible, but also appealing \u2013 optimistic even. For Goldhaber, films that now possess that last quality tend to have major vested interests \u2013 and budgets to match. \u201cWe have traded the ability for hopeful moviemaking for movies like Top Gun,\u201d he says, \u201cwhich is a good piece of film-making but undoubtedly a piece of American military propaganda.\u201d Yet tapping into the same emotional beats \u2013 underdog narrative, heart-pounding action \u2013 and using them to talk about acts of sabotage and resistance is, he says, \u201ca totally valid and important thing for the progressive movement to engage with\u201d.\nIt\u2019s true: watching the gang plant the explosive, or Michael, the young man in that pivotal scene, cook it up in the first place, the job at the centre of How to Blow Up a Pipeline shares more DNA with tense Hollywood heist movies like Thief or Inside Man. \u201cWhat they\u2019re doing is pretty dangerous,\u201d says the film\u2019s editor Daniel Garber, who rounds out the quartet, each of them billed equally in the credits as makers (like their characters, they are a collective). \u201cThat\u2019s what provokes this stomach-churning feeling of, \u2018Oh my God, are they going to blow themselves up?\u2019\u201d Once you create a certain level of tension, he says, it buys you time to digress. \u201cThe heist,\u201d he adds, \u201cis a Trojan horse into which we can sneak all of these other concepts.\u201d Those concepts are explored in flashbacks, each one detailing how the individual characters came to be involved with the cause. The team spent two months interviewing climate activists and pipeline experts about their experiences. Some became characters. Clarissa Thibeaux, Barer\u2019s friend and a credited consultant, partly inspired Theo, played by American Honey\u2019s Sasha Lane, whose leukaemia diagnosis she ascribes to growing up near to a chemical plant. They also drew from the story of Jessica Reznicek and Ruby Montoya, who were imprisoned for terrorism after they vandalised the Dakota Access Pipeline with an acetylene torch, despite there being no oil running through it. Barer had campaigned against its construction as a teenager. \u201cThe pipeline got built,\u201d she says, \u201cand nothing really happened, despite the activists doing everything right.\u201d This failure, after immaculate campaigning, was one of the reasons she was so drawn to Malm\u2019s book: \u201cIt felt like an unapologetic push for a radical flank.\u201d The book also detailed acts of sabotage sometimes wrongly remembered as non-violent, such as women\u2019s suffrage. \u201cReading theory like this reinvigorated me,\u201d she says.\nThe film-makers also wanted to more accurately represent the communities affected by the climate crisis, bringing in Indigenous actor Forrest Goodluck (who played Leonardo DiCaprio\u2019s son in The Revenant) to consult on the film as well as star as bomb-maker Michael. Their on-screen ensemble is predominantly made up of people of colour and includes working-class voices, Malm\u2019s book having described movements such as Extinction Rebellion as \u201cpersistently aloof from factors of class and race\u201d. Goldhaber says that, while the film does acknowledge the sort of activist often criticised for skewing white and privileged, it is designed as \u201ca kaleidoscope of all the different kinds of folks involved in the movement\u201d. The idea was to offer broad access points for the audience. This also explains the film\u2019s subtly comic moments: while the characters are taken seriously, they do not do so themselves. Two even fool around while waiting for a timer to go off. \u201cIt would be totally alienating if it was all melodrama,\u201d says Barer. \u201cIf it were me and my friends, we would get drunk the night before. We would be idiots about it, because it\u2019s so scary. Even with \u2018the perfect plan\u2019 they have, there\u2019s so much risk and personal sacrifice.\u201d The intention was provocation, adds Goldhaber, not propaganda, not just \u201criling people who already believe in what you\u2019re saying\u201d. Instead, they wanted to shift the conversation from the decision whether to take action to actual tactics and strategy once you do. Earlier this year in the UK, more than 120 lawyers defied bar rules and arguably engaged in an act of civil disobedience by signing a declaration stating that they would not prosecute peaceful climate activists, nor defend companies pursuing fossil fuel projects. But what about the non-peaceful activists? If pipelines are morally indefensible, is there a moral obligation to destroy them? \u201cIf you see how this is self-defence for these eight characters,\u201d says Goldhaber, \u201cthat opens up a whole world of questions and possibilities for the future of the climate movement.\u201d\nAll four film-makers have their own stories to tell regarding their way into activism. Goldhaber\u2019s seems the most conventional: parents who worked in the field, a childhood spent \u201cwith the doom of climate change hanging over me\u201d. He worked on the 2012 documentary Chasing Ice, about crumbling glaciers, but was disillusioned by the fact that the film triggered precious little change.\nSjol, who grew up in rural Wyoming, tells me about hiking the jagged peaks of the Tetons as a child during the summer, climbing up to one of the range\u2019s glacial lakes. \u201cThe glacier would be a little smaller every year,\u201d he says, \u201cuntil it was very, very nearly vanished.\u201d Barer is the youngest of the group and perhaps the most passionate. She was raised in Los Angeles by a mother who \u201ccame from the hippy movement in Mexico\u201d and preached a gospel of \u201creduce, reuse, recycle\u201d. When she was nine, the family visited Disneyland. In the queue for the rollercoaster, she overheard an adult saying that the planet was dying. Devastated, she asked how long it had left. They reckoned about 40 years. \u201cI was like, \u2018I only get to be 49? Hands trembling, sweat fogging his goggles, he slowly assembles the explosive. A knife-blade of powder is painstakingly poured into a tiny tube. Wires are shakily glued together. With infinite care, the delicate, deadly contraption takes shape. Outside the tin shack where this is all unfolding, another young man paces, remembering his friend\u2019s instructions: \u201cDon\u2019t come in unless I tell you to. Unless you see fire.\u201d He looks as if he\u2019s about to be sick. The audience knows how he feels.</p> \n<p>This is the tense setup at the heart of How to Blow Up a Pipeline, a propulsive, nerve-jangling thriller about eight young people who want to send a message about the urgency of the climate crisis by sabotaging an oil pipeline. The film takes its cues from its heroes: aiming to excite audiences into action instead of hectoring them into submission. It is one hell of a ride. After its premiere at Toronto last year, the New York Times pronounced How to Blow Up a Pipeline \u201ca cultural landmark\u201d for its sympathetic take on eco-terrorism, while the Washington City Paper described its youthful cast as \u201ca much more intense, combustible version of The Breakfast Club\u201d.</p> \n<p>What director, co-writer and producer Daniel Goldhaber \u2013 one of its four key film-makers \u2013 wanted to make, he says via video call, was a thriller: \u201cOcean\u2019s Eleven about environmental activism.\u201d It\u2019s an ingenious pitch. Regardless of your feelings about their approach, you root for the gang to succeed as much as you do for hardened gangsters poring over blueprints to pull off a bank heist. \u201cThe idea of empathising with characters who take action like this, without ever condemning them for taking it too far, is something I don\u2019t see in the media,\u201d says Ariela Barer, who co-wrote, produced and also stars in the film.</p>"}}, {"type": "image", "assets": [{"type": "image", "mimeType": "image/jpeg", "file": for the project while isolating in an LA apartment in January 2021. Their other flatmate, co-writer Jordan Sjol, had got hold of a book provocatively entitled How to Blow Up a Pipeline. It was a manifesto by Swedish academic Andreas Malm that made a rousing case for property destruction as a tactic in the pursuit of climate justice. The volume was excitedly passed around. Goldhaber had the idea of dramatising its ideas, turning them into a movie. But how to adapt a work of theory into a mainstream blockbuster? None of them wanted to make a hand-wringing documentary, or an apocalyptic disaster flick in the mould of The Day After Tomorrow or Don\u2019t Look Up. They wanted it to be credible, but also appealing \u2013 optimistic even.</p> \n<p>For Goldhaber, films that now possess that last quality tend to have major vested interests \u2013 and budgets to match. \u201cWe have traded the ability for hopeful moviemaking for movies like Top Gun,\u201d he says, \u201cwhich is a good piece of film-making but undoubtedly a piece of American military propaganda.\u201d Yet tapping into the same emotional beats \u2013 underdog narrative, heart-pounding action \u2013 and using them to talk about acts of sabotage and resistance is, he says, \u201ca totally valid and important thing for the progressive movement to engage with\u201d. </p>"}}, {"type": "pullquote", "assets": [], "pullquoteTypeData": {"html": "The Dakota Access Pipeline activists did everything right \u2013 and nothing happened. Some became characters. The idea was to offer broad access points for the audience. This also explains the film\u2019s subtly comic moments: while the characters are taken seriously, they do not do so themselves. \u201cHave you seen the wild boar yet?\u201d It was no April fool. My neck of the woods, near Dalbeattie, just north of the Solway Firth, is a hot spot for wild boar (<em>Sus scrofa</em>). And yet, despite the males weighing in at around 150kg, it is possible to miss them, many times over in fact. So I had to say no.</p> <p>On several more occasions, I returned to try to find these denizens of the deep woods. There are two separate groups in Dumfries and Galloway, descendants of farm escapees (both accidental and deliberate), and with their ability to produce up to 10 piglets at the time, the two groups are likely to meet soon. The UK population stands at between 500 and 2,000, and their overall impact on woodland diversity is not yet clear. There are concerns about the transmission of foot and mouth disease, and swine fever, and they can certainly cause agricultural damage, though at low densities it appears they can be useful ecosystem engineers.</p> <p>So how to see one? Thankfully they are noisy eaters, often heard long before they are seen, grunting and snuffling, grubbing for roots or digging scrapes in which to wallow. I know from spotting them in Poland, Belarus and Tuscany that going by ear not eye can be the best tactic.</p> <p>After six more forays without sight, sound or sniff, I finally hear a squeal and catch the distinctive, musty whiff of wild boar on the air. The welcome sun has steam rising from the damp canopy as it lights up the lichens, mosses and the white anemones below.</p> <p>I follow the aroma and hurdle a broken barbed-wire fence that holds telltale clumps of boar hair with their pale and unmistakable split ends. Surprisingly there was a large boar present \u2013 they normally shirk nursery duties.
