"Photograph"}}]}, "body": [{"id": "5e74b1208f08bbd83c9f59dc", "bodyHtml": "<p>On entering the Galloway Forest on 1 April, wood anemones flowering already and bluebells ready to burst, I was asked by a local forester: \u201cHave you seen the wild boar yet?\u201d It was no April fool. My neck of the woods, near Dalbeattie, just north of the Solway Firth, is a hot spot for wild boar (<em>Sus scrofa</em>). And yet, despite the males weighing in at around 150kg, it is possible to miss them, many times over in fact. So I had to say no.</p> <p>On several more occasions, I returned to try to find these denizens of the deep woods. There are two separate groups in Dumfries and Galloway, descendants of farm escapees (both accidental and deliberate), and with their ability to produce up to 10 piglets at the time, the two groups are likely to meet soon. The UK population stands at between 500 and 2,000, and their overall impact on woodland diversity is not yet clear. There are concerns about the transmission of foot and mouth disease, and swine fever, and they can certainly cause agricultural damage, though at low densities it appears they can be useful ecosystem engineers.</p> <p>So how to see one? Thankfully they are noisy eaters, often heard long before they are seen, grunting and snuffling, grubbing for roots or digging scrapes in which to wallow. I know from spotting them in Poland, Belarus and Tuscany that going by ear not eye can be the best tactic.</p> <p>After six more forays without sight, sound or sniff, I finally hear a squeal and catch the distinctive, musty whiff of wild boar on the air. The welcome sun has steam rising from the damp canopy as it lights up the lichens, mosses and the white anemones below.</p> <p>I follow the aroma and hurdle a broken barbed-wire fence that holds telltale clumps of boar hair with their pale and unmistakable split ends. Breaking the skyline (always a mistake when wildlife-stalking), I manage to surprise a \u201csounder\u201d, a whole family of wild boar. Surprisingly there was a large boar present \u2013 they normally shirk nursery duties. He trudged off, followed by six or seven piglets, a couple of yearlings and two sows.</p> <p>A brief encounter, but nevertheless, the first wild boar that I have seen in this area, and my sightings have been added to the national database.</p> <p>\u2022 Country diary is on Twitter at <a href=\"https://twitter.com/gdncountrydiary?lang=en\" title=\"\">@gdncountrydiary</a></p>", "bodyTextSummary": "On entering the Galloway Forest on 1 April, wood anemones flowering already and bluebells ready to burst, I was asked by a local forester: \u201cHave you seen the wild boar yet?\u201d It was no April fool. My neck of the woods, near Dalbeattie, just north of the Solway Firth, is a hot spot for wild boar (<em>Sus scrofa</em>). And yet, despite the males weighing in at around 150kg, it is possible to miss them, many times over in fact. There are two separate groups in Dumfries and Galloway, descendants of farm escapees (both accidental and deliberate), and with their ability to produce up to 10 piglets at the time, the two groups are likely to meet soon. The UK population stands at between 500 and 2,000, and their overall impact on woodland diversity is not yet clear. There are concerns about the transmission of foot and mouth disease, and swine fever, and they can certainly cause agricultural damage, though at low densities it appears they can be useful ecosystem engineers.</p> \n<p>So how to see one? Thankfully they are noisy eaters, often heard long before they are seen, grunting and snuffling, grubbing for roots or digging scrapes in which to wallow. I know from spotting them in Poland, Belarus and Tuscany that going by ear not eye can be the best tactic.</p> \n<p>After six more forays without sight, sound or sniff, I finally hear a squeal and catch the distinctive, musty whiff of wild boar on the air. "byline": "Angus Fontaine", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"d5355ba17bf4bfda6fd5c7386aa77f27c7fc264e\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/d5355ba17bf4bfda6fd5c7386aa77f27c7fc264e/16_42_1008_605/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Faith Thomas, the first indigenous woman to play Test Cricket for Australia, has passed away passed away aged 90.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Darrian Traynor/CA/Cricket Australia/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>Australian cricket is mourning the death of Aunty Faith Thomas, the first Aboriginal woman to play Test cricket for Australia, who passed away at the weekend aged 90. Thomas (nee Coulthard) played her groundbreaking Test for Australia against England at Melbourne\u2019s Junction Oval in February 1958, when she became the first Indigenous woman to represent an Australian sports team.</p> <p>Thomas was awarded the Order of Australia in 2019 for her services to cricket and her dedication to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in a long nursing career. Retrospectively awarded a baggy green cap as the 48<sup>th</sup> Australian woman to play Test cricket, Thomas is honoured every year by the Adelaide Strikers playing for the Faith Thomas Trophy in the WBBL. Her legacy also lives on in Adelaide Oval\u2019s Avenue of Honour as a great of the game.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/jan/23/teammates-back-ashleigh-gardner-over-indigenous-cricketers-26-january-criticism\">Teammates back Ashleigh Gardner over Indigenous cricketer\u2019s 26 January criticism</a> </p> </aside>  <p>\u201cFaith Thomas made a wonderful and groundbreaking contribution to cricket and the community,\u201d Cricket Australia chief executive Nick Hockley said. \u201cAs the first Aboriginal woman to represent Australia in Test cricket, Faith was an inspiration to those who have followed and she leaves an indelible mark on the game.\u201d<br><br>Born in 1933 in Nepabunna, Thomas was born Tinnipha, the daughter of an Adnyamathanha mother and German father. As Faith Coulthard, she was brought by her mother to Colebrook Home in Quorn in South Australia\u2019s Flinders Ranges where she began playing improvised cricket on dirt roads using a homemade bat and a rock if there was no ball.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"2286dace37d7c12601a45720a4caf6e64d7cf05e\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/2286dace37d7c12601a45720a4caf6e64d7cf05e/170_622_4324_2595/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Faith Thomas, first indigenous woman to play Tests for Australia, in a 2015 portrait.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Faith Thomas, first indigenous woman to play Tests for Australia, in a 2015 portrait.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Darrian Traynor/CA/Cricket Australia/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>A fast bowler, Thomas joked that her fearsome speed was the result of \u201cchucking stones at galahs\u201d, but only in her late teens did she learn women played organised cricket. Thomas was invited to participate in a club game in Adelaide and the power she generated from just a few paces of run-up made her an immediate star. In her first season with Windsor she took a hat trick and 6/20, and in one famous game against Adelaide Teachers College returned the remarkable figures of six wickets for no runs.</p> <p>After just three club matches, Thomas was selected to represent South Australia and then chosen in a side to play the touring English team in a warmup game in Brisbane. There, a legend was born. Thomas bowled a delivery to dismiss English captain Mary Duggan that was so fast the middle stump was sent cartwheeling and Duggan sat on the pitch laughing at her helplessness against the pace.</p> <p>The following year, in 1958, Thomas made her Test debut. The Sydney Test was washed out and in Melbourne she was bowled sparingly. After carrying the drinks in Adelaide her career quietly ended. Although chosen to tour England and New Zealand, Thomas was a desert woman uncomfortable at sea so baulked at the overseas tour.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"5a615f0ef73b95f4bb7fcc5eab438261a5070735\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/5a615f0ef73b95f4bb7fcc5eab438261a5070735/0_70_5081_3051/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Faith Thomas poses with Megan Schutt and the Faith Thomas Trophy in Alice Springs ahead of a Women\u2019s Big Bash League in 2018.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Faith Thomas poses with Megan Schutt and the Faith Thomas Trophy in Alice Springs ahead of a Women\u2019s Big Bash League in 2018.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Jason McCawley/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Instead, she went to the docks to wave off the team and dedicated herself to a nursing career. As a girl at Colebrook, Thomas had been inspired by two caring woman she called Sister Hyde and Sister Rutter. \u201cThose two women trying to look after all those little blackfellas, I don\u2019t know how they didn\u2019t go mad,\u201d she later recalled. \u201cI used to think things just happened or were coincidence but now I look back, I\u2019ve seen a lot of miracles.\u201d</p> <p>In the early 1950s Thomas was among the first group of Indigenous nurses trained at the Royal Adelaide Hospital and became the first State Public Servant with Aboriginal heritage. As one of the inaugural Indigenous college graduates in the country, Thomas took her skills to Raukkan at the top of the Coorong to work with the Ngarrindjeri mob. She married Bernard Thomas and had a family as her nursing work took her back north where she toiled in remote areas and communities, driving an old Land Rover with a shotgun for company and having a profound impact on thousands of patients who hailed her an inspiring advocate for positive change. <br><br>\u201cFaith Thomas\u2019s story is as inspiring as it is incredible,\u201d SACA President William Rayner said. \u201cA leader across medicine, sport, reconciliation and so much more, Aunty Faith created footprints that others have had the opportunity to follow in the decades since. A brilliantly unique and successful cricketer, Aunty Faith\u2019s journey was never simply about personal achievement \u2013 instead she always sought ways to improve the lives of others.\u201d</p> <p>Thomas herself believed her extraordinary life was possible because the only word banned at Colebrook was \u201ccan\u2019t\u201d.</p> <p>\u201cI remember when we were nursing you would see a job advertisement for a double certificate nurse, and you would apply, and the job would go to a single certificate white nursing sister,\u201d she reflected. \u201cSister Hyde would say that\u2019s a door not meant to open so knock on another one. It was a faith instilled in us - don\u2019t ever give up.\u201d</p>", "wordcount": "795", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T04:21:20Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T05:17:23Z", "productionOffice": "AUS", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnej3", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/d5355ba17bf4bfda6fd5c7386aa77f27c7fc264e/16_42_1008_605/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Australian cricket is mourning the death of Aunty Faith Thomas, the first Aboriginal woman to play Test cricket for Australia, who passed away at the weekend aged 90. Thomas (nee Coulthard) played her groundbreaking Test for Australia against England at Melbourne\u2019s Junction Oval in February 1958, when she became the first Indigenous woman to represent an Australian sports team. Thomas was awarded the Order of Australia in 2019 for her services to cricket and her dedication to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in a long nursing career. Retrospectively awarded a baggy green cap as the 48th Australian woman to play Test cricket, Thomas is honoured every year by the Adelaide Strikers playing for the Faith Thomas Trophy in the WBBL. Her legacy also lives on in Adelaide Oval\u2019s Avenue of Honour as a great of the game. \u201cFaith Thomas made a wonderful and groundbreaking contribution to cricket and the community,\u201d Cricket Australia chief executive Nick Hockley said. \u201cAs the first Aboriginal woman to represent Australia in Test cricket, Faith was an inspiration to those who have followed and she leaves an indelible mark on the game.\u201d Born in 1933 in Nepabunna, Thomas was born Tinnipha, the daughter of an Adnyamathanha mother and German father. As Faith Coulthard, she was brought by her mother to Colebrook Home in Quorn in South Australia\u2019s Flinders Ranges where she began playing improvised cricket on dirt roads using a homemade bat and a rock if there was no ball. A fast bowler, Thomas joked that her fearsome speed was the result of \u201cchucking stones at galahs\u201d, but only in her late teens did she learn women played organised cricket. Thomas was invited to participate in a club game in Adelaide and the power she generated from just a few paces of run-up made her an immediate star. In her first season with Windsor she took a hat trick and 6/20, and in one famous game against Adelaide Teachers College returned the remarkable figures of six wickets for no runs. After just three club matches, Thomas was selected to represent South Australia and then chosen in a side to play the touring English team in a warmup game in Brisbane. There, a legend was born. Thomas bowled a delivery to dismiss English captain Mary Duggan that was so fast the middle stump was sent cartwheeling and Duggan sat on the pitch laughing at her helplessness against the pace. The following year, in 1958, Thomas made her Test debut. The Sydney Test was washed out and in Melbourne she was bowled sparingly. After carrying the drinks in Adelaide her career quietly ended. Although chosen to tour England and New Zealand, Thomas was a desert woman uncomfortable at sea so baulked at the overseas tour. Instead, she went to the docks to wave off the team and dedicated herself to a nursing career. As a girl at Colebrook, Thomas had been inspired by two caring woman she called Sister Hyde and Sister Rutter. \u201cThose two women trying to look after all those little blackfellas, I don\u2019t know how they didn\u2019t go mad,\u201d she later recalled. \u201cI used to think things just happened or were coincidence but now I look back, I\u2019ve seen a lot of miracles.\u201d In the early 1950s Thomas was among the first group of Indigenous nurses trained at the Royal Adelaide Hospital and became the first State Public Servant with Aboriginal heritage. As one of the inaugural Indigenous college graduates in the country, Thomas took her skills to Raukkan at the top of the Coorong to work with the Ngarrindjeri mob. She married Bernard Thomas and had a family as her nursing work took her back north where she toiled in remote areas and communities, driving an old Land Rover with a shotgun for company and having a profound impact on thousands of patients who hailed her an inspiring advocate for positive change. \u201cFaith Thomas\u2019s story is as inspiring as it is incredible,\u201d SACA President William Rayner said. \u201cA leader across medicine, sport, reconciliation and so much more, Aunty Faith created footprints that others have had the opportunity to follow in the decades since. A brilliantly unique and successful cricketer, Aunty Faith\u2019s journey was never simply about personal achievement \u2013 instead she always sought ways to improve the lives of others.\u201d Thomas herself believed her extraordinary life was possible because the only word banned at Colebrook was \u201ccan\u2019t\u201d. \u201cI remember when we were nursing you would see a job advertisement for a double certificate nurse, and you would apply, and the job would go to a single certificate white nursing sister,\u201d she reflected. \u201cSister Hyde would say that\u2019s a door not meant to open so knock on another one. "bodyHtml": "<p>Australian cricket is mourning the death of Aunty Faith Thomas, the first Aboriginal woman to play Test cricket for Australia, who passed away at the weekend aged 90. Thomas (nee Coulthard) played her groundbreaking Test for Australia against England at Melbourne\u2019s Junction Oval in February 1958, when she became the first Indigenous woman to represent an Australian sports team.</p> <p>Thomas was awarded the Order of Australia in 2019 for her services to cricket and her dedication to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in a long nursing career. Retrospectively awarded a baggy green cap as the 48<sup>th</sup> Australian woman to play Test cricket, Thomas is honoured every year by the Adelaide Strikers playing for the Faith Thomas Trophy in the WBBL. Her legacy also lives on in Adelaide Oval\u2019s Avenue of Honour as a great of the game.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/jan/23/teammates-back-ashleigh-gardner-over-indigenous-cricketers-26-january-criticism\">Teammates back Ashleigh Gardner over Indigenous cricketer\u2019s 26 January criticism</a> </p> </aside>  <p>\u201cFaith Thomas made a wonderful and groundbreaking contribution to cricket and the community,\u201d Cricket Australia chief executive Nick Hockley said. \u201cAs the first Aboriginal woman to represent Australia in Test cricket, Faith was an inspiration to those who have followed and she leaves an indelible mark on the game.\u201d<br><br>Born in 1933 in Nepabunna, Thomas was born Tinnipha, the daughter of an Adnyamathanha mother and German father. As Faith Coulthard, she was brought by her mother to Colebrook Home in Quorn in South Australia\u2019s Flinders Ranges where she began playing improvised cricket on dirt roads using a homemade bat and a rock if there was no ball.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"2286dace37d7c12601a45720a4caf6e64d7cf05e\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/2286dace37d7c12601a45720a4caf6e64d7cf05e/170_622_4324_2595/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Faith Thomas, first indigenous woman to play Tests for Australia, in a 2015 portrait.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Faith Thomas, first indigenous woman to play Tests for Australia, in a 2015 portrait.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Darrian Traynor/CA/Cricket Australia/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>A fast bowler, Thomas joked that her fearsome speed was the result of \u201cchucking stones at galahs\u201d, but only in her late teens did she learn women played organised cricket. Thomas was invited to participate in a club game in Adelaide and the power she generated from just a few paces of run-up made her an immediate star. In her first season with Windsor she took a hat trick and 6/20, and in one famous game against Adelaide Teachers College returned the remarkable figures of six wickets for no runs.</p> <p>After just three club matches, Thomas was selected to represent South Australia and then chosen in a side to play the touring English team in a warmup game in Brisbane. There, a legend was born. Thomas bowled a delivery to dismiss English captain Mary Duggan that was so fast the middle stump was sent cartwheeling and Duggan sat on the pitch laughing at her helplessness against the pace.</p> <p>The following year, in 1958, Thomas made her Test debut. The Sydney Test was washed out and in Melbourne she was bowled sparingly. After carrying the drinks in Adelaide her career quietly ended. Although chosen to tour England and New Zealand, Thomas was a desert woman uncomfortable at sea so baulked at the overseas tour.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"5a615f0ef73b95f4bb7fcc5eab438261a5070735\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/5a615f0ef73b95f4bb7fcc5eab438261a5070735/0_70_5081_3051/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Faith Thomas poses with Megan Schutt and the Faith Thomas Trophy in Alice Springs ahead of a Women\u2019s Big Bash League in 2018.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Faith Thomas poses with Megan Schutt and the Faith Thomas Trophy in Alice Springs ahead of a Women\u2019s Big Bash League in 2018.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Jason McCawley/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Instead, she went to the docks to wave off the team and dedicated herself to a nursing career. As a girl at Colebrook, Thomas had been inspired by two caring woman she called Sister Hyde and Sister Rutter. \u201cThose two women trying to look after all those little blackfellas, I don\u2019t know how they didn\u2019t go mad,\u201d she later recalled. \u201cI used to think things just happened or were coincidence but now I look back, I\u2019ve seen a lot of miracles.\u201d</p> <p>In the early 1950s Thomas was among the first group of Indigenous nurses trained at the Royal Adelaide Hospital and became the first State Public Servant with Aboriginal heritage. As one of the inaugural Indigenous college graduates in the country, Thomas took her skills to Raukkan at the top of the Coorong to work with the Ngarrindjeri mob. She married Bernard Thomas and had a family as her nursing work took her back north where she toiled in remote areas and communities, driving an old Land Rover with a shotgun for company and having a profound impact on thousands of patients who hailed her an inspiring advocate for positive change. <br><br>\u201cFaith Thomas\u2019s story is as inspiring as it is incredible,\u201d SACA President William Rayner said. \u201cA leader across medicine, sport, reconciliation and so much more, Aunty Faith created footprints that others have had the opportunity to follow in the decades since. A brilliantly unique and successful cricketer, Aunty Faith\u2019s journey was never simply about personal achievement \u2013 instead she always sought ways to improve the lives of others.\u201d</p> <p>Thomas herself believed her extraordinary life was possible because the only word banned at Colebrook was \u201ccan\u2019t\u201d.</p> <p>\u201cI remember when we were nursing you would see a job advertisement for a double certificate nurse, and you would apply, and the job would go to a single certificate white nursing sister,\u201d she reflected. \u201cSister Hyde would say that\u2019s a door not meant to open so knock on another one. It was a faith instilled in us - don\u2019t ever give up.\u201d</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "Australian cricket is mourning the death of Aunty Faith Thomas, the first Aboriginal woman to play Test cricket for Australia, who passed away at the weekend aged 90. Thomas (nee Coulthard) played her groundbreaking Test for Australia against England at Melbourne\u2019s Junction Oval in February 1958, when she became the first Indigenous woman to represent an Australian sports team. Thomas was awarded the Order of Australia in 2019 for her services to cricket and her dedication to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in a long nursing career. Retrospectively awarded a baggy green cap as the 48th Australian woman to play Test cricket, Thomas is honoured every year by the Adelaide Strikers playing for the Faith Thomas Trophy in the WBBL. Her legacy also lives on in Adelaide Oval\u2019s Avenue of Honour as a great of the game.\n\u201cFaith Thomas made a wonderful and groundbreaking contribution to cricket and the community,\u201d Cricket Australia chief executive Nick Hockley said. \u201cAs the first Aboriginal woman to represent Australia in Test cricket, Faith was an inspiration to those who have followed and she leaves an indelible mark on the game.\u201d Born in 1933 in Nepabunna, Thomas was born Tinnipha, the daughter of an Adnyamathanha mother and German father. As Faith Coulthard, she was brought by her mother to Colebrook Home in Quorn in South Australia\u2019s Flinders Ranges where she began playing improvised cricket on dirt roads using a homemade bat and a rock if there was no ball.\nA fast bowler, Thomas joked that her fearsome speed was the result of \u201cchucking stones at galahs\u201d, but only in her late teens did she learn women played organised cricket. Thomas was invited to participate in a club game in Adelaide and the power she generated from just a few paces of run-up made her an immediate star. In her first season with Windsor she took a hat trick and 6/20, and in one famous game against Adelaide Teachers College returned the remarkable figures of six wickets for no runs. After just three club matches, Thomas was selected to represent South Australia and then chosen in a side to play the touring English team in a warmup game in Brisbane. There, a legend was born. Thomas bowled a delivery to dismiss English captain Mary Duggan that was so fast the middle stump was sent cartwheeling and Duggan sat on the pitch laughing at her helplessness against the pace. The following year, in 1958, Thomas made her Test debut. The Sydney Test was washed out and in Melbourne she was bowled sparingly. After carrying the drinks in Adelaide her career quietly ended. Although chosen to tour England and New Zealand, Thomas was a desert woman uncomfortable at sea so baulked at the overseas tour.\nInstead, she went to the docks to wave off the team and dedicated herself to a nursing career. As a girl at Colebrook, Thomas had been inspired by two caring woman she called Sister Hyde and Sister Rutter. \u201cThose two women trying to look after all those little blackfellas, I don\u2019t know how they didn\u2019t go mad,\u201d she later recalled. \u201cI used to think things just happened or were coincidence but now I look back, I\u2019ve seen a lot of miracles.\u201d In the early 1950s Thomas was among the first group of Indigenous nurses trained at the Royal Adelaide Hospital and became the first State Public Servant with Aboriginal heritage. As one of the inaugural Indigenous college graduates in the country, Thomas took her skills to Raukkan at the top of the Coorong to work with the Ngarrindjeri mob. She married Bernard Thomas and had a family as her nursing work took her back north where she toiled in remote areas and communities, driving an old Land Rover with a shotgun for company and having a profound impact on thousands of patients who hailed her an inspiring advocate for positive change. \u201cFaith Thomas\u2019s story is as inspiring as it is incredible,\u201d SACA President William Rayner said. \u201cA leader across medicine, sport, reconciliation and so much more, Aunty Faith created footprints that others have had the opportunity to follow in the decades since. A brilliantly unique and successful cricketer, Aunty Faith\u2019s journey was never simply about personal achievement \u2013 instead she always sought ways to improve the lives of others.\u201d Thomas herself believed her extraordinary life was possible because the only word banned at Colebrook was \u201ccan\u2019t\u201d. \u201cI remember when we were nursing you would see a job advertisement for a double certificate nurse, and you would apply, and the job would go to a single certificate white nursing sister,\u201d she reflected. \u201cSister Hyde would say that\u2019s a door not meant to open so knock on another one. It was a faith instilled in us - don\u2019t ever give up.\u201d", "attributes": {}, "published": true, "createdDate": "2023-04-17T04:21:20Z", "firstPublishedDate": "2023-04-17T04:21:20Z", "publishedDate": "2023-04-17T04:35:50Z", "lastModifiedDate": "2023-04-17T04:35:49Z", "contributors": [], "elements": [{"type": "text", "assets": [], "textTypeData": {"html": "<p>Australian cricket is mourning the death of Aunty Faith Thomas, the first Aboriginal woman to play Test cricket for Australia, who passed away at the weekend aged 90. data-media-id=\"94da62ece44edf644a583b641b0a1249e047f456\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/94da62ece44edf644a583b641b0a1249e047f456/0_0_7360_4415/1000.jpg\" alt=\"View of the excavated winery There were also marble-lined treading areas where enslaved workers would stamp down the newly harvested fruit, while the emperor perhaps looked on as he feasted with his retinue.</p> <p>The winery, just beyond the city limits of Rome during antiquity, was set in what was once a landscape of orchards and agricultural lands, dotted with monumental tombs \u2013 and the villas of the super rich.</p> <p>\u201c[The Villa of the Quintilii] was an amazing mini city completed by a luxury winery for the emperor himself to indulge his Bacchic tendencies,\u201d said archaeologist Dr Emlyn Dodd, assistant director at the <a href=\"https://bsr.ac.uk/\">British School at Rome</a> and an expert on ancient wine production. He has published the archaeologists\u2019 findings in an article for the scholarly journal Antiquity.</p> <p>The discovery of the ancient Roman winery came by chance, when archaeologists from the Italian ministry of culture were trying to find one of the starting posts for the villa\u2019s arena. The chariot-racing track was built by the emperor Commodus, who reigned from AD177-192. The later winery, it turned out, had been built over one of these starting gates.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"4a68fde6896b2971573dab8fd611ffe98769e474\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/4a68fde6896b2971573dab8fd611ffe98769e474/0_158_4753_2852/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Multicoloured decorative marble flooring from one of the dining rooms set around the winery.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Multicoloured decorative marble flooring from one of the dining rooms set around the winery.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Stefano Castellani</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>It was the notoriously violent Commodus who had the original owners of the villa, the wealthy Quintilii brothers, killed in AD182-3. After that the imperial rulers took personal ownership of the complex, expanding and modifying it over the centuries.</p> <p>The fact that the name Gordian is stamped into a vast wine-collection vat means that the emperor likely either built the winery or renovated it. That would almost certainly be Gordian III, giving a date of AD238-244, since the first and second emperors of that name reigned only for a matter of days.</p> <p>At the villa, which is open to the public, Dodd pointed out the recently excavated rectangular wine-treading areas.</p> <p>\u201cUsually these treading areas would be covered in a waterproof concrete,\u201d he said. \u201cBut these were covered in red marble. Which isn\u2019t ideal, as marble gets incredibly slippery when wet. But it shows that whoever built this was prioritising the extravagant nature of the winery over practical considerations.\u201d</p> <p>After being trodden, the crushed grapes were then taken to the two mechanical presses, 2 metres in diameter, that stood nearby. The resulting grape must was then sent into three fountains, which gushed out of semicircular niches set into a courtyard wall. There were in fact five fountains, with two outer spouts producing water. </p> <p>The grape must, having cascaded out of the fountains, then flowed along open channels into vast ceramic <em>dolia,</em> or storage jars, set into the ground \u2013 a standard winemaking technique in ancient Rome, since they created a stable microenvironment in which fermentation would take place.</p> <p>Covered dining rooms with wide, open entrances were set around three sides of this open courtyard area. Dodd\u2019s hypothesis is that here the emperor would have feasted and enjoyed the full theatrical spectacle of wine production. </p> <p>Only one of these dining rooms is excavated \u2013 Dodd would like to find funding to uncover them all \u2013 and its walls and floors were covered in multicoloured inlaid marble veneers in elaborate geometrical patterns.</p> <p>The whole facility seems to have been designed with both the practical matter of wine production and the sheer theatre of it in mind. </p> <p>Letters by a previous emperor, Marcus Aurelius, attest to his having banqueted while watching the work of winemaking going on \u2013 perhaps at a luxury winemaking facility at the Villa Magna 30 miles away to the south-east, which is the only parallel to the newly discovered winery in the archaeological record.</p> <p>Dodd\u2019s hypothesis is that the emperor and his retinue might have visited the Villa of the Quintilii annually to inaugurate that year\u2019s vintage with a ritual and a spectacular \u2013 and surely drunken \u2013 banquet.</p>", "newspaperPageNumber": "25", "wordcount": "747", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T04:00:29Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T04:00:29Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-17T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nk7fn", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/94da62ece44edf644a583b641b0a1249e047f456/0_0_7360_4415/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Of all the Roman ruins that populate what is now a pleasant landscape of pine trees and meadows, under the distant gaze of the Alban Hills, the Villa of the Quintilii is perhaps the most impressive \u2013 almost a city in miniature, covering up to 24 hectares. Lying on the ancient Appian Way as it runs south-east from Rome, the villa had its own theatre, an arena for chariot races and a baths complex with walls and floors lined in sumptuous marble. But the story of the villa, whose origins lie in the second century AD, has just become even more remarkable, with the discovery of an elaborate winery unparalleled in the Roman world for lavishness. The facility included a series of luxurious dining rooms with a view on to fountains gushing with young wine. There were also marble-lined treading areas where enslaved workers would stamp down the newly harvested fruit, while the emperor perhaps looked on as he feasted with his retinue. The winery, just beyond the city limits of Rome during antiquity, was set in what was once a landscape of orchards and agricultural lands, dotted with monumental tombs \u2013 and the villas of the super rich. \u201c[The Villa of the Quintilii] was an amazing mini city completed by a luxury winery for the emperor himself to indulge his Bacchic tendencies,\u201d said archaeologist Dr Emlyn Dodd, assistant director at the British School at Rome and an expert on ancient wine production. He has published the archaeologists\u2019 findings in an article for the scholarly journal Antiquity. The discovery of the ancient Roman winery came by chance, when archaeologists from the Italian ministry of culture were trying to find one of the starting posts for the villa\u2019s arena. The chariot-racing track was built by the emperor Commodus, who reigned from AD177-192. The later winery, it turned out, had been built over one of these starting gates. It was the notoriously violent Commodus who had the original owners of the villa, the wealthy Quintilii brothers, killed in AD182-3. After that the imperial rulers took personal ownership of the complex, expanding and modifying it over the centuries. The fact that the name Gordian is stamped into a vast wine-collection vat means that the emperor likely either built the winery or renovated it. That would almost certainly be Gordian III, giving a date of AD238-244, since the first and second emperors of that name reigned only for a matter of days. At the villa, which is open to the public, Dodd pointed out the recently excavated rectangular wine-treading areas. \u201cUsually these treading areas would be covered in a waterproof concrete,\u201d he said. \u201cBut these were covered in red marble. Which isn\u2019t ideal, as marble gets incredibly slippery when wet. But it shows that whoever built this was prioritising the extravagant nature of the winery over practical considerations.\u201d After being trodden, the crushed grapes were then taken to the two mechanical presses, 2 metres in diameter, that stood nearby. The resulting grape must was then sent into three fountains, which gushed out of semicircular niches set into a courtyard wall. There were in fact five fountains, with two outer spouts producing water. The grape must, having cascaded out of the fountains, then flowed along open channels into vast ceramic dolia, or storage jars, set into the ground \u2013 a standard winemaking technique in ancient Rome, since they created a stable microenvironment in which fermentation would take place. Covered dining rooms with wide, open entrances were set around three sides of this open courtyard area. Dodd\u2019s hypothesis is that here the emperor would have feasted and enjoyed the full theatrical spectacle of wine production. Only one of these dining rooms is excavated \u2013 Dodd would like to find funding to uncover them all \u2013 and its walls and floors were covered in multicoloured inlaid marble veneers in elaborate geometrical patterns. The whole facility seems to have been designed with both the practical matter of wine production and the sheer theatre of it in mind. Letters by a previous emperor, Marcus Aurelius, attest to his having banqueted while watching the work of winemaking going on \u2013 perhaps at a luxury winemaking facility at the Villa Magna 30 miles away to the south-east, which is the only parallel to the newly discovered winery in the archaeological record. Lying on the ancient Appian Way as it runs south-east from Rome, the villa had its own theatre, an arena for chariot races and a baths complex with walls and floors lined in sumptuous marble. But the story of the villa, whose origins lie in the second century AD, has just become even more remarkable, with the discovery of an elaborate winery unparalleled in the Roman world for lavishness. The facility included a series of luxurious dining rooms with a view on to fountains gushing with young wine. There were also marble-lined treading areas where enslaved workers would stamp down the newly harvested fruit, while the emperor perhaps looked on as he feasted with his retinue. The winery, just beyond the city limits of Rome during antiquity, was set in what was once a landscape of orchards and agricultural lands, dotted with monumental tombs \u2013 and the villas of the super rich. \u201c[The Villa of the Quintilii] was an amazing mini city completed by a luxury winery for the emperor himself to indulge his Bacchic tendencies,\u201d said archaeologist Dr Emlyn Dodd, assistant director at the British School at Rome and an expert on ancient wine production. He has published the archaeologists\u2019 findings in an article for the scholarly journal Antiquity. The discovery of the ancient Roman winery came by chance, when archaeologists from the Italian ministry of culture were trying to find one of the starting posts for the villa\u2019s arena. The chariot-racing track was built by the emperor Commodus, who reigned from AD177-192. The later winery, it turned out, had been built over one of these starting gates.\nIt was the notoriously violent Commodus who had the original owners of the villa, the wealthy Quintilii brothers, killed in AD182-3. After that the imperial rulers took personal ownership of the complex, expanding and modifying it over the centuries. The fact that the name Gordian is stamped into a vast wine-collection vat means that the emperor likely either built the winery or renovated it. That would almost certainly be Gordian III, giving a date of AD238-244, since the first and second emperors of that name reigned only for a matter of days. At the villa, which is open to the public, Dodd pointed out the recently excavated rectangular wine-treading areas. \u201cUsually these treading areas would be covered in a waterproof concrete,\u201d he said. \u201cBut these were covered in red marble. Which isn\u2019t ideal, as marble gets incredibly slippery when wet. But it shows that whoever built this was prioritising the extravagant nature of the winery over practical considerations.\u201d After being trodden, the crushed grapes were then taken to the two mechanical presses, 2 metres in diameter, that stood nearby. The resulting grape must was then sent into three fountains, which gushed out of semicircular niches set into a courtyard wall. There were in fact five fountains, with two outer spouts producing water. The grape must, having cascaded out of the fountains, then flowed along open channels into vast ceramic dolia, or storage jars, set into the ground \u2013 a standard winemaking technique in ancient Rome, since they created a stable microenvironment in which fermentation would take place. Covered dining rooms with wide, open entrances were set around three sides of this open courtyard area. Dodd\u2019s hypothesis is that here the emperor would have feasted and enjoyed the full theatrical spectacle of wine production. Only one of these dining rooms is excavated \u2013 Dodd would like to find funding to uncover them all \u2013 and its walls and floors were covered in multicoloured inlaid marble veneers in elaborate geometrical patterns. The whole facility seems to have been designed with both the practical matter of wine production and the sheer theatre of it in mind. Letters by a previous emperor, Marcus Aurelius, attest to his having banqueted while watching the work of winemaking going on \u2013 perhaps at a luxury winemaking facility at the Villa Magna 30 miles away to the south-east, which is the only parallel to the newly discovered winery in the archaeological record. Dodd\u2019s hypothesis is that the emperor and his retinue might have visited the Villa of the Quintilii annually to inaugurate that year\u2019s vintage with a ritual and a spectacular \u2013 and surely drunken \u2013 banquet.", "attributes": {}, "published": true, "createdDate": "2023-04-17T04:00:29Z", "firstPublishedDate": "2023-04-17T04:00:29Z", "publishedDate": "2023-04-17T04:00:29Z", "lastModifiedDate": "2023-04-16T17:22:06Z", "contributors": [], "elements": [{"type": "text", "assets": [], "textTypeData": {"html": "<p>Of all the Roman ruins that populate what is now a pleasant landscape of pine trees and meadows, under the distant gaze of the Alban Hills, the Villa of the Quintilii is perhaps the most impressive \u2013 almost a city in miniature, covering up to 24 hectares.</p> \n<p>Lying on the ancient Appian Way as it runs south-east from Rome, the villa had its own theatre, an arena for chariot races and a baths complex with walls and floors lined in sumptuous marble.</p> \n<p>But the story of the villa, whose origins lie in the second century AD, has just become even more remarkable, with the discovery of an elaborate winery unparalleled in the Roman world for lavishness.</p> \n<p>The facility included a series of luxurious dining rooms with a view on to fountains gushing with young wine. There were also marble-lined treading areas where enslaved workers would stamp down the newly harvested fruit, while the emperor perhaps looked on as he feasted with his retinue.</p> \n<p>The winery, just beyond the city limits of Rome during antiquity, was set in what was once a landscape of orchards and agricultural lands, dotted with monumental tombs \u2013 and the villas of the super rich.</p> \n<p>\u201c[The Villa of the Quintilii] was an amazing mini city completed by a luxury winery for the emperor himself to indulge his Bacchic tendencies,\u201d said archaeologist Dr Emlyn Dodd, assistant director at the <a href=\"https://bsr.ac.uk/\">British School at Rome</a> and an expert on ancient wine production. He has published the archaeologists\u2019 findings in an article for the scholarly journal Antiquity.</p> \n<p>The discovery of the ancient Roman winery came by chance, when archaeologists from the Italian ministry of culture were trying to find one of the starting posts for the villa\u2019s arena. The chariot-racing track was built by the emperor Commodus, who reigned from AD177-192. The later winery, it turned out, had been built over one of these starting gates.</p>"}}, {"type": "image", "assets": [{"type": "image", "mimeType": "image/jpeg", "file": "Andaluc\u00eda accused of pandering to far right over plans for Spanish wetlands", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/17/spanish-wetlands-donana-andalucia-far-right", "apiUrl": href=\"https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/685/\">Unesco-listed national park</a>, have declined drastically over the past 30 years because of <a </aside>  <p>Last week, however, the regional government shrugged off such concerns \u2013 as well as warnings from Unesco and the European Commission \u2013 and began fast-tracking a new law that will increase the amount of irrigable land around Do\u00f1ana by 800 hectares. The legislation, proposed by the ruling conservative People\u2019s party (PP) and the far-right Vox party, will also serve as an amnesty to the strawberry farmers who have already sunk illegal wells there.</p> <p>Spain\u2019s environment minister, Teresa Ribera, has described the move as damaging, disingenuous and divisive. \u201cI think it\u2019s a dangerous decision because there\u2019s never going to be extra water there,\u201d she said.</p> <p>\u201cIt generates expectations and poses a difficult threat to the area. Do\u00f1ana is a nature sanctuary that is under many pressures \u2026 The last thing we need is for new pressures to emerge.\u201d</p> <p>Environmental groups have long campaigned to protect the area, which sustains millions of migrating birds and is also home to a major population of endangered Iberian lynxes, pointing out that the illegal wells sunk to feed the region\u2019s numerous soft fruit farms are stressing the aquifer.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"fc22cba0f81997cb840530bbd075b4f1582f1113\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/fc22cba0f81997cb840530bbd075b4f1582f1113/0_190_2398_1440/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Do\u00f1ana is one of the last refuges of the Iberian Lynx\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Do\u00f1ana is one of the last refuges of the Iberian lynx.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: EyeEm/Alamy</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Juan Manuel Moreno Bonilla, the PP president of the region, says \u201cregularising\u201d the land is the only way to help the hundreds of farmers currently working the land illegally. I think [regional government] is coming under a lot of pressure from the far right, from Vox, who want to tub-thump to capitalise on the fears of the local population.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"06d389a56b9683d129c35b3125e66713757bed03\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/06d389a56b9683d129c35b3125e66713757bed03/125_0_3750_2250/1000.jpg\" alt=\"The dried out lagoon of Santa Olalla pictured in August 2022\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The dried out lagoon of Santa Olalla pictured in August 2022.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Estacion Biologica de Donana/Reuters</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Ribera said the PP\u2019s desire to compete with Vox for what she termed \u201cthe fear vote\u201d would only give people false hope, and harm both the environment and Spanish democracy.</p> <p>\u201cWe need to be honest,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019ve seen that some social groups have compared this to the demagoguery of Bolsonaro and Trump, and I think that\u2019s right. We shouldn\u2019t allow a degradation of our democratic system or our institutional system by keeping quiet in the face of such serious attacks.\u201d</p> <p>She said the central government would take the matter to the constitutional court if the Andaluc\u00edan authorities failed to drop the plan, and appealed to Moreno Bonilla to stop peddling \u201ca mirage\u201d and to focus instead on plans to diversify the local economy.</p> <p>\u201cThe regional government hasn\u2019t been serious when it comes to finding alternatives and to diversifying and generating something that offers stable and enduring answers,\u201d she said.</p> <p>Ribera also said the decision would not only harm Do\u00f1ana, but could also damage those growing soft fruit legally as it could provoke a consumer-led backlash: \u201cThey could be affected by seller boycotts of strawberries from Do\u00f1ana or from Huelva.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"1a8af8c9294513bf922037d072782dbb81c54787\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/1a8af8c9294513bf922037d072782dbb81c54787/0_357_8367_5020/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Temporary workers plant strawberries on farm in Almonte on the edge of the national park\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Temporary workers plant strawberries on farm in Almonte on the edge of the national park.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Bernat Armangu\u00e9/AP</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>\u201cThat would mean money would have to be invested in traceability to differentiate between what\u2019s legal and what isn\u2019t; between who\u2019s using water legally and who isn\u2019t. I think it\u2019s a very big miscalculation on the part of the regional government and I think that it\u2019s a simplistic reading of the situation.\u201d</p> <p>Carlos D\u00e1vila, head of the Do\u00f1ana office of the environmental NGO SEO/BirdLife, has accused the PP of risking the future of the area \u201cfor a handful of votes\u201d.</p> <p>\u201cIt\u2019s worth remembering that what we\u2019re talking about here is an area that, like the Alhambra in Granada, is a world heritage site,\u201d he said. \u201cThe law the Andaluc\u00edan government is proposing would be like knocking down a big chunk of the Alhambra to put up a shopping centre.\u201d</p> <p>Greenpeace Spain has described the law as \u201can insult to science\u201d and warned that \u201cour country\u2019s most emblematic park \u2013 and one of the most important in terms of Europe and Africa\u2019s biodiversity \u2013 could disappear as we know it\u201d.</p> <p>Maribel Mora, a leftwing opposition MP, <a href=\"https://www.lasexta.com/noticias/nacional/bronca-parlamento-andaluz-maribel-mora-adelante-andalucia-arroja-arena-donana-escano-juanma-moreno_202304126436ca572f8deb00014a2487.html\">was reprimanded earlier this week after pouring sand on Moreno Bonilla\u2019s empty seat in the Andaluc\u00edan parliament to show that his plans could turn Do\u00f1ana into a desert</a>.</p> <p>Both the European Commission and Unesco are keeping a close eye on the situation and have said Spain could face penalties for failing to safeguard Do\u00f1ana.</p> <p>The European court of justice ruled in 2021 that <a href=\"https://curia.europa.eu/jcms/upload/docs/application/pdf/2021-06/cp210113es.pdf\">Spain had not fulfilled its obligations</a> on preventing illegal water extraction around Do\u00f1ana and had failed to take the measures needed to stop \u201csignificant alterations\u201d to its protected habitats.</p> <p>The European Commission has said it is \u201cdeeply worried\u201d at the possible impacts of the proposed changes and has not ruled out taking Spain to the court of justice again. Unesco <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/jun/28/strawberry-spain-donana-wildlife-iberian-lynx\">has previously said the situation could jeopardise Do\u00f1ana\u2019s world heritage status</a>.</p>", "newspaperPageNumber": "25", "wordcount": "947", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T04:00:29Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T04:00:29Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-17T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nmm2z", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/eaa25593db7573710ddbfa1df2619cde41143264/379_72_2605_1563/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Spain\u2019s environment minister has accused the Andaluc\u00edan regional government of engaging in \u201cshort-term electoral demagoguery\u201d and playing into the hands of the far right by pressing ahead with irrigation plans for strawberry farms that could threaten the survival of one of Europe\u2019s most important wetlands. Water supplies to the Do\u00f1ana Natural Space, whose marshes, forests and dunes extend across almost 130,000 hectares (320,000 acres) and include a Unesco-listed national park, have declined drastically over the past 30 years because of climate breakdown, farming, mining pollution and marsh drainage. Last week, however, the regional government shrugged off such concerns \u2013 as well as warnings from Unesco and the European Commission \u2013 and began fast-tracking a new law that will increase the amount of irrigable land around Do\u00f1ana by 800 hectares. The legislation, proposed by the ruling conservative People\u2019s party (PP) and the far-right Vox party, will also serve as an amnesty to the strawberry farmers who have already sunk illegal wells there. Spain\u2019s environment minister, Teresa Ribera, has described the move as damaging, disingenuous and divisive. \u201cI think it\u2019s a dangerous decision because there\u2019s never going to be extra water there,\u201d she said. \u201cIt generates expectations and poses a difficult threat to the area. Do\u00f1ana is a nature sanctuary that is under many pressures \u2026 The last thing we need is for new pressures to emerge.\u201d Environmental groups have long campaigned to protect the area, which sustains millions of migrating birds and is also home to a major population of endangered Iberian lynxes, pointing out that the illegal wells sunk to feed the region\u2019s numerous soft fruit farms are stressing the aquifer. Juan Manuel Moreno Bonilla, the PP president of the region, says \u201cregularising\u201d the land is the only way to help the hundreds of farmers currently working the land illegally. He has also previously vowed that Andaluc\u00eda\u2019s \u201cnatural jewels\u201d will not be eroded \u201cby as much as a millimetre\u201d. A recent report from Spain\u2019s national research council noted that 59% of Do\u00f1ana\u2019s large lakes hadn\u2019t been full since at least 2013, and that the area was in \u201ccritical condition\u201d. Do\u00f1ana\u2019s largest permanent lake dried up last year for the third time in half a century, shrinking to a small puddle. Ribera, who is also one of Spain\u2019s three deputy prime ministers, said she believed the proposed law had more to do with May\u2019s local elections \u2013 in which the PP is keen not to cede any seats to Vox \u2013 than with coherent policymaking. \u201cI think it\u2019s short-term electoral demagoguery. I think [regional government] is coming under a lot of pressure from the far right, from Vox, who want to tub-thump to capitalise on the fears of the local population.\u201d Ribera said the PP\u2019s desire to compete with Vox for what she termed \u201cthe fear vote\u201d would only give people false hope, and harm both the environment and Spanish democracy. \u201cWe need to be honest,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019ve seen that some social groups have compared this to the demagoguery of Bolsonaro and Trump, and I think that\u2019s right. We shouldn\u2019t allow a degradation of our democratic system or our institutional system by keeping quiet in the face of such serious attacks.\u201d She said the central government would take the matter to the constitutional court if the Andaluc\u00edan authorities failed to drop the plan, and appealed to Moreno Bonilla to stop peddling \u201ca mirage\u201d and to focus instead on plans to diversify the local economy. \u201cThe regional government hasn\u2019t been serious when it comes to finding alternatives and to diversifying and generating something that offers stable and enduring answers,\u201d she said. Ribera also said the decision would not only harm Do\u00f1ana, but could also damage those growing soft fruit legally as it could provoke a consumer-led backlash: \u201cThey could be affected by seller boycotts of strawberries from Do\u00f1ana or from Huelva. \u201cThat would mean money would have to be invested in traceability to differentiate between what\u2019s legal and what isn\u2019t; between who\u2019s using water legally and who isn\u2019t. I think it\u2019s a very big miscalculation on the part of the regional government and I think that it\u2019s a simplistic reading of the situation.\u201d Carlos D\u00e1vila, head of the Do\u00f1ana office of the environmental NGO SEO/BirdLife, has accused the PP of risking the future of the area \u201cfor a handful of votes\u201d. \u201cIt\u2019s worth remembering that what we\u2019re talking about here is an area that, like the Alhambra in Granada, is a world heritage site,\u201d he said. \u201cThe law the Andaluc\u00edan government is proposing would be like knocking down a big chunk of the Alhambra to put up a shopping centre.\u201d Greenpeace Spain has described the law as \u201can insult to science\u201d and warned that \u201cour country\u2019s most emblematic park \u2013 and one of the most important in terms of Europe and Africa\u2019s biodiversity \u2013 could disappear as we know it\u201d. Maribel Mora, a leftwing opposition MP, was reprimanded earlier this week after pouring sand on Moreno Bonilla\u2019s empty seat in the Andaluc\u00edan parliament to show that his plans could turn Do\u00f1ana into a desert. Both the European Commission and Unesco are keeping a close eye on the situation and have said Spain could face penalties for failing to safeguard Do\u00f1ana. The European court of justice ruled in 2021 that Spain had not fulfilled its obligations on preventing illegal water extraction around Do\u00f1ana and had failed to take the measures needed to stop \u201csignificant alterations\u201d to its protected habitats. The European Commission has said it is \u201cdeeply worried\u201d at the possible impacts of the proposed changes and has not ruled out taking Spain to the court of justice again. "Photograph"}}]}, "body": [{"id": "6437e9738f0885230b2d9fbe", "bodyHtml": "<p>Spain\u2019s environment minister has accused the Andaluc\u00edan regional government of engaging in \u201cshort-term electoral demagoguery\u201d and playing into the hands of the far right by pressing ahead with irrigation plans for strawberry farms that could threaten the survival of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/feb/08/bitter-fruit-strawberry-boom-water-plan-raises-fears-for-spanish-wetlands\">one of Europe\u2019s most important wetlands</a>.</p> <p>Water supplies to the Do\u00f1ana Natural Space, whose marshes, forests and dunes extend across almost 130,000 hectares (320,000 acres) and include a <a href=\"https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/685/\">Unesco-listed national park</a>, have declined drastically over the past 30 years because of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/sep/15/spain-could-be-first-eu-country-with-national-park-listed-as-in-danger\">climate breakdown, farming, mining pollution and marsh drainage</a>.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/feb/08/bitter-fruit-strawberry-boom-water-plan-raises-fears-for-spanish-wetlands\">Illegal strawberry farms threaten future of Spanish wetlands</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Last week, however, the regional government shrugged off such concerns \u2013 as well as warnings from Unesco and the European Commission \u2013 and began fast-tracking a new law that will increase the amount of irrigable land around Do\u00f1ana by 800 hectares. The legislation, proposed by the ruling conservative People\u2019s party (PP) and the far-right Vox party, will also serve as an amnesty to the strawberry farmers who have already sunk illegal wells there.</p> <p>Spain\u2019s environment minister, Teresa Ribera, has described the move as damaging, disingenuous and divisive. \u201cI think it\u2019s a dangerous decision because there\u2019s never going to be extra water there,\u201d she said.</p> <p>\u201cIt generates expectations and poses a difficult threat to the area. Do\u00f1ana is a nature sanctuary that is under many pressures \u2026 The last thing we need is for new pressures to emerge.\u201d</p> <p>Environmental groups have long campaigned to protect the area, which sustains millions of migrating birds and is also home to a major population of endangered Iberian lynxes, pointing out that the illegal wells sunk to feed the region\u2019s numerous soft fruit farms are stressing the aquifer.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"fc22cba0f81997cb840530bbd075b4f1582f1113\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/fc22cba0f81997cb840530bbd075b4f1582f1113/0_190_2398_1440/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Do\u00f1ana is one of the last refuges of the Iberian Lynx\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Do\u00f1ana is one of the last refuges of the Iberian lynx.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: EyeEm/Alamy</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Juan Manuel Moreno Bonilla, the PP president of the region, says \u201cregularising\u201d the land is the only way to help the hundreds of farmers currently working the land illegally. He has also <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/feb/10/protests-over-wetlands-after-amnesty-vote-for-spanish-strawberry-farmers\">previously vowed that Andaluc\u00eda\u2019s \u201cnatural jewels\u201d will not be eroded \u201cby as much as a millimetre\u201d</a>.</p> <p>A <a href=\"https://www.csic.es/es/actualidad-del-csic/donana-en-estado-critico-mas-de-la-mitad-de-sus-lagunas-han-desaparecido\">recent report from Spain\u2019s national research council</a> noted that 59% of Do\u00f1ana\u2019s large lakes hadn\u2019t been full since at least 2013, and that the area was in \u201ccritical condition\u201d. <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/sep/05/santa-olalla-lake-dries-up-in-vital-spanish-wetland-blamed-on-overexploitation\">Do\u00f1ana\u2019s largest permanent lake dried up</a> last year for the third time in half a century, shrinking to a small puddle.</p> <p>Ribera, who is also one of Spain\u2019s three deputy prime ministers, said she believed the proposed law had more to do with May\u2019s local elections \u2013 in which the PP is keen not to cede any seats to Vox \u2013 than with coherent policymaking.</p> <p>\u201cI think it\u2019s short-term electoral demagoguery. I think [regional government] is coming under a lot of pressure from the far right, from Vox, who want to tub-thump to capitalise on the fears of the local population.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"06d389a56b9683d129c35b3125e66713757bed03\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/06d389a56b9683d129c35b3125e66713757bed03/125_0_3750_2250/1000.jpg\" alt=\"The dried out lagoon of Santa Olalla pictured in August 2022\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The dried out lagoon of Santa Olalla pictured in August 2022.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Estacion Biologica de Donana/Reuters</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Ribera said the PP\u2019s desire to compete with Vox for what she termed \u201cthe fear vote\u201d would only give people false hope, and harm both the environment and Spanish democracy.</p> <p>\u201cWe need to be honest,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019ve seen that some social groups have compared this to the demagoguery of Bolsonaro and Trump, and I think that\u2019s right. We shouldn\u2019t allow a degradation of our democratic system or our institutional system by keeping quiet in the face of such serious attacks.\u201d</p> <p>She said the central government would take the matter to the constitutional court if the Andaluc\u00edan authorities failed to drop the plan, and appealed to Moreno Bonilla to stop peddling \u201ca mirage\u201d and to focus instead on plans to diversify the local economy.</p> <p>\u201cThe regional government hasn\u2019t been serious when it comes to finding alternatives and to diversifying and generating something that offers stable and enduring answers,\u201d she said.</p> <p>Ribera also said the decision would not only harm Do\u00f1ana, but could also damage those growing soft fruit legally as it could provoke a consumer-led backlash: \u201cThey could be affected by seller boycotts of strawberries from Do\u00f1ana or from Huelva.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"1a8af8c9294513bf922037d072782dbb81c54787\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/1a8af8c9294513bf922037d072782dbb81c54787/0_357_8367_5020/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Temporary workers plant strawberries on farm in Almonte on the edge of the national park\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Temporary workers plant strawberries on farm in Almonte on the edge of the national park.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Bernat Armangu\u00e9/AP</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>\u201cThat would mean money would have to be invested in traceability to differentiate between what\u2019s legal and what isn\u2019t; between who\u2019s using water legally and who isn\u2019t. I think it\u2019s a very big miscalculation on the part of the regional government and I think that it\u2019s a simplistic reading of the situation.\u201d</p> <p>Carlos D\u00e1vila, head of the Do\u00f1ana office of the environmental NGO SEO/BirdLife, has accused the PP of risking the future of the area \u201cfor a handful of votes\u201d.</p> <p>\u201cIt\u2019s worth remembering that what we\u2019re talking about here is an area that, like the Alhambra in Granada, is a world heritage site,\u201d he said. \u201cThe law the Andaluc\u00edan government is proposing would be like knocking down a big chunk of the Alhambra to put up a shopping centre.\u201d</p> <p>Greenpeace Spain has described the law as \u201can insult to science\u201d and warned that \u201cour country\u2019s most emblematic park \u2013 and one of the most important in terms of Europe and Africa\u2019s biodiversity \u2013 could disappear as we know it\u201d.</p> <p>Maribel Mora, a leftwing opposition MP, <a href=\"https://www.lasexta.com/noticias/nacional/bronca-parlamento-andaluz-maribel-mora-adelante-andalucia-arroja-arena-donana-escano-juanma-moreno_202304126436ca572f8deb00014a2487.html\">was reprimanded earlier this week after pouring sand on Moreno Bonilla\u2019s empty seat in the Andaluc\u00edan parliament to show that his plans could turn Do\u00f1ana into a desert</a>.</p> <p>Both the European Commission and Unesco are keeping a close eye on the situation and have said Spain could face penalties for failing to safeguard Do\u00f1ana.</p> <p>The European court of justice ruled in 2021 that <a href=\"https://curia.europa.eu/jcms/upload/docs/application/pdf/2021-06/cp210113es.pdf\">Spain had not fulfilled its obligations</a> on preventing illegal water extraction around Do\u00f1ana and had failed to take the measures needed to stop \u201csignificant alterations\u201d to its protected habitats.</p> <p>The European Commission has said it is \u201cdeeply worried\u201d at the possible impacts of the proposed changes and has not ruled out taking Spain to the court of justice again. Unesco <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/jun/28/strawberry-spain-donana-wildlife-iberian-lynx\">has previously said the situation could jeopardise Do\u00f1ana\u2019s world heritage status</a>.</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "Spain\u2019s environment minister has accused the Andaluc\u00edan regional government of engaging in \u201cshort-term electoral demagoguery\u201d and playing into the hands of the far right by pressing ahead with irrigation plans for strawberry farms that could threaten the survival of one of Europe\u2019s most important wetlands. Water supplies to the Do\u00f1ana Natural Space, whose marshes, forests and dunes extend across almost 130,000 hectares (320,000 acres) and include a Unesco-listed national park, have declined drastically over the past 30 years because of climate breakdown, farming, mining pollution and marsh drainage.\nLast week, however, the regional government shrugged off such concerns \u2013 as well as warnings from Unesco and the European Commission \u2013 and began fast-tracking a new law that will increase the amount of irrigable land around Do\u00f1ana by 800 hectares. The legislation, proposed by the ruling conservative People\u2019s party (PP) and the far-right Vox party, will also serve as an amnesty to the strawberry farmers who have already sunk illegal wells there. A recent report from Spain\u2019s national research council noted that 59% of Do\u00f1ana\u2019s large lakes hadn\u2019t been full since at least 2013, and that the area was in \u201ccritical condition\u201d. Do\u00f1ana\u2019s largest permanent lake dried up last year for the third time in half a century, shrinking to a small puddle. allegations.</p> <p>The last parliamentary inquiry sparked a statewide manhunt for Ellis and Jean-Claude Perrottet. A previous upper house inquiry, launched after allegations aired in parliament by NSW Liberal MP Ray Williams about senior members of his own party, became a focal point of the recent election campaign when it sparked a manhunt for one of former premier Dominic Perrottet\u2019s brothers.\nA spokesperson for the premier, Chris Minns, confirmed the government would not be commencing a new public inquiry in this term of government. \u201cAt the request of Icac, the government will not be proceeding with a public inquiry into the Hills Shire council at this stage as it may impact on an investigation being conducted by the commission,\u201d the spokesperson said. Sign up for Guardian Australia\u2019s free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup The premier has been considering how else to act on the allegations, including placing the council into administration. The Sunday Telegraph reported that homes of past and present NSW Liberal party members have been raided as part of the investigation, with laptops and phones seized during the raids. The matters were referred to Icac by then-premier Perrottet in June of last year after Williams alleged in NSW parliament that senior members of the Liberal party were \u201cpaid significant funds\u201d by prominent property developer Jean Nassif to install new councillors to push development applications through. Williams told parliament that the incoming members had allegedly been brought in to green-light developments from Toplace \u2013 owned by Nassif \u2013 which, he alleged, is a client of Liberal powerbroker and lobbyist Christian Ellis. Williams told parliament that, before the council elections, Nassif had \u201capparently\u201d met with Ellis and other members of the Liberal party who were \u201cpaid significant funds in order to arrange to put new councillors\u201d at the council to be \u201csupportive of future Toplace development applications\u201d. Nassif has repeatedly denied the allegations. The last parliamentary inquiry sparked a statewide manhunt for Ellis and Jean-Claude Perrottet. In a letter to the inquiry Perrottet denied all allegations and accused it of being a way to further \u201cpolitical ends\u201d in advance of the state election. Nassif declined to appear because he was in rural Lebanon. Charles Perrottet was also asked to appear but could not be compelled because he lives in Victoria. In March, Dominic Perrottet said the Liberal party would conduct an internal investigation into the claims after the allegations were tabled as part of a parliamentary report. \u201cThe Liberal party will look at those matters and any wrongdoing that is found, if any, appropriate action will be taken,\u201d he said. Earlier this year, in separate and unrelated proceedings, Nassif\u2019s daughter Ashlyn was arrested and charged with dishonestly obtaining a financial advantage by deception and publishing false or misleading material to obtain an advantage as part of a major fraud investigation into a controversial multimillion development in the city\u2019s north-west. The surprise in that run: The US won the inaugural Olympic gold in 1998.</p> <p>The US took its first world title in 2005. Canada reclaimed the mantle in 2007, following its second straight Olympic gold.</p> <p>Then followed a decade of US dominance, winning eight of the next nine: 2008, 2009, 2011, 2013, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2019. The US also won Olympic gold in 2018, breaking Canada\u2019s streak of four straight.</p> <p>But Canada has taken the last two world championships and the 2022 Olympic gold.</p> <p>Puck drop!</p> </div>   <p class=\"block-time updated-time\">Updated <time datetime=\"2023-04-16T23:11:35.203Z\">at 12.11am BST</time></p>  </div> <div id=\"block-643c7a328f08791e579d63c6\" class=\"block\" data-block-contributor=\"\"> <p class=\"block-time published-time\"> <time datetime=\"2023-04-16T22:53:31.531Z\">11.53pm <span class=\"timezone\">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class=\"block-elements\">  <p>Canada can counter with collegiate stars, though. Princeton\u2019s <strong>Sarah Fillier </strong>is the leading goal-scorer in the tournament with seven goals in six games. <strong>Emma Maltais </strong>was on the Ohio State team that lost to Wisconsin in the NCAA final.</p> <p>But US fans may be more likely to fear <strong>Marie-Philip Poulin</strong>, who is happier to stick the dagger in the US like Arya Stark facing off with the Night King. She scored the overtime winner in 2021 and netted twice in the 2022 Olympic final, becoming the first hockey player to score in <a href=\"https://olympics.com/en/news/marie-philip-poulin-scores-in-historic-fourth-straight-ice-hockey\">four straight Olympic finals</a>.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-tweet\" data-canonical-url=\"https://twitter.com/HockeyCanada/status/1647721299056181252\">  <blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\"><p lang=\"fr\" dir=\"ltr\">The last dance. \ud83c\udde8\ud83c\udde6 <br> <br>Dernier tour de piste. \ud83c\udde8\ud83c\udde6 <br> <a href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/WomensWorlds?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#WomensWorlds</a> | <a href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/MondialF%C3%A9minin?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#MondialF\u00e9minin</a> <a href=\"https://t.co/FtvVo6xJ2D\">pic.twitter.com/FtvVo6xJ2D</a></p>&mdash; Hockey Canada (@HockeyCanada) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/HockeyCanada/status/1647721299056181252?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">April 16, 2023</a></blockquote>  </figure> </div>   </div> <div id=\"block-643c76a98f08791e579d63b2\" class=\"block\" data-block-contributor=\"\"> <p class=\"block-time published-time\"> <time datetime=\"2023-04-16T22:42:42.577Z\">11.42pm <span class=\"timezone\">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class=\"block-elements\">  <p>Four weeks ago, four US players celebrated a championship. <strong>Caroline Harvey, Britta Curl, Lacey Eden </strong>and <strong>Nicole LaMantia</strong> won the NCAA championship with Wisconsin, which tends to win a lot of national championships. (LaMantia is not in uniform tonight.)</p> <p>Plenty of their national teammates were also chasing a collegiate championship, as were three Canadian players. (For those in Canada, because it came up in one of my last live appearances \u2013 \u201ccollege\u201d means \u201cuniversity.\u201d) The US team has a potent forward line (see lineup below) of Penn State teen phenom <strong>Tessa Janecke</strong>, Minnesota center (centre) <strong>Taylor Heise</strong> and Boston College\u2019s <strong>Hannah Bilke</strong>.</p> <p>Every player on these two teams played at a US college (university) at some point.
