But it\u2019s a bit unusual for one team to have so many players who are also in college.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-tweet\" data-canonical-url=\"https://twitter.com/usahockey/status/1647721531425050624\">  <blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\"><p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Here&#39;s how we&#39;re lining up for the <a href=\"https://twitter.com/hashtag/WomensWorlds?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#WomensWorlds</a> gold-medal game!<br><br>Preview \u2192 <a href=\"https://t.co/tyTspdfZTm\">https://t.co/tyTspdfZTm</a><a href=\"https://twitter.com/WinmarkResale?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@WinmarkResale</a> <a href=\"https://t.co/ilMKXXuUQe\">pic.twitter.com/ilMKXXuUQe</a></p>&mdash; USA Hockey (@usahockey) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/usahockey/status/1647721531425050624?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">April 16, 2023</a></blockquote>  </figure> </div>   </div> <div id=\"block-643c716c8f0885230b2dc30c\" class=\"block\" data-block-contributor=\"\"> <p class=\"block-time published-time\"> <time datetime=\"2023-04-16T22:24:29.997Z\">11.24pm <span class=\"timezone\">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class=\"block-elements\">  <p>Those who don\u2019t remember the past, we\u2019re told, are condemned to repeat it.</p> <p>US women\u2019s hockey coach John Wroblewski is banking on the opposite.</p> <p>After three straight losses to Canada in world championship or Olympic finals, the worst run for the US since Canada\u2019s dominance of the sport\u2019s first 15 years (1998 Olympics notwithstanding), Wroblekski has embarked on a youth movement. Maybe his players don\u2019t remember winning Olympic gold in 2018 or the world championship in 2019, the only world championship final Canada has ever missed, but they also don\u2019t remember losing in the 2021 worlds, the 2022 Olympics or the fall 2022 worlds. </p> <p>It\u2019s not a total clearout by any means. Eight-time world champion <strong>Hilary Knight </strong>is still here to captain the US. Fellow 30something <strong>Amanda Kessel </strong>is also in the attack. Alternate captains <strong>Alex Carpenter</strong> and <strong>Lee Stecklein </strong>are no stranger to this stage.</p> <p>But the goaltender is no longer <strong>Maddie Rooney</strong>, who played well beyond her 20 years to win gold in 2018, or <strong>Alex Cavallini</strong>, the 2022 goalie. It\u2019s 23-year-old <strong>Aerin Frankel</strong>.</p> <p>The Canadian team, on the other hand, boasts several of the all-time greats. <strong>Ann-Renee Desbiens. Marie-Philip Poulin. Jocelyn Larocque.</strong></p> <p>You\u2019d think Canada would have the edge here. But their matchup earlier in these championships went to a shootout, with Canada scraping by to win. And the young, feisty US absolutely demolished Czechia, which won the bronze medal earlier today, with a 9-1 decision in the semis, as mentioned below. </p> </div>   </div> <div id=\"block-643b29818f0891526bb435bc\" class=\"block\" data-block-contributor=\"\"> <p class=\"block-time published-time\"> <time datetime=\"2023-04-16T22:00:21.843Z\">11.00pm <span class=\"timezone\">BST</span></time> </p>    <div class=\"block-elements\">  <p><strong>Beau will be here shortly.</strong> In the meantime <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/apr/15/usa-canada-women-world-hockey-championships\">here\u2019s a look back</a> at the United States\u2019 semi-final win over the Czech Republic. </p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/apr/15/usa-canada-women-world-hockey-championships\">USA women put nine past Czech Republic in world ice hockey semi-final</a> </p> </aside> </div>   </div>", "wordcount": "2755", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-16T22:00:21Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T02:30:28Z", "liveBloggingNow": "false", "productionOffice": "US", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nn8t2", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/3e0426f79d3f7db2a72b3d357daeeabd8cf05c0c/0_204_7136_4284/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Seems like just a few minutes ago that I was writing the wrapup post in my head. \u201cGood learning experience for this young US team,\u201d I was thinking. \u201cThey\u2019ll use this as a stepping stone for a possible world championship or Olympic gold down the line.\u201d Apparently, that time is now. Quick history lesson \u2026 Canada won the first eight world championships: 1990, 1992, 1994, 1997, 1999, 2000, 2001 and 2004. The surprise in that run: The US won the inaugural Olympic gold in 1998. The US took its first world title in 2005. Canada reclaimed the mantle in 2007, following its second straight Olympic gold. Then followed a decade of US dominance, winning eight of the next nine: 2008, 2009, 2011, 2013, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2019. The US also won Olympic gold in 2018, breaking Canada\u2019s streak of four straight. But Canada has taken the last two world championships and the 2022 Olympic gold. Puck drop! Canada can counter with collegiate stars, though. Princeton\u2019s Sarah Fillier is the leading goal-scorer in the tournament with seven goals in six games. Emma Maltais was on the Ohio State team that lost to Wisconsin in the NCAA final. But US fans may be more likely to fear Marie-Philip Poulin, who is happier to stick the dagger in the US like Arya Stark facing off with the Night King. She scored the overtime winner in 2021 and netted twice in the 2022 Olympic final, becoming the first hockey player to score in four straight Olympic finals. Four weeks ago, four US players celebrated a championship. Caroline Harvey, Britta Curl, Lacey Eden and Nicole LaMantia won the NCAA championship with Wisconsin, which tends to win a lot of national championships. (LaMantia is not in uniform tonight.) Plenty of their national teammates were also chasing a collegiate championship, as were three Canadian players. (For those in Canada, because it came up in one of my last live appearances \u2013 \u201ccollege\u201d means \u201cuniversity.\u201d) The US team has a potent forward line (see lineup below) of Penn State teen phenom Tessa Janecke, Minnesota center (centre) Taylor Heise and Boston College\u2019s Hannah Bilke. Every player on these two teams played at a US college (university) at some point. Many a US college roster has included players from both sides of the border. But it\u2019s a bit unusual for one team to have so many players who are also in college. Those who don\u2019t remember the past, we\u2019re told, are condemned to repeat it. US women\u2019s hockey coach John Wroblewski is banking on the opposite. After three straight losses to Canada in world championship or Olympic finals, the worst run for the US since Canada\u2019s dominance of the sport\u2019s first 15 years (1998 Olympics notwithstanding), Wroblekski has embarked on a youth movement. Maybe his players don\u2019t remember winning Olympic gold in 2018 or the world championship in 2019, the only world championship final Canada has ever missed, but they also don\u2019t remember losing in the 2021 worlds, the 2022 Olympics or the fall 2022 worlds. It\u2019s not a total clearout by any means. Eight-time world champion Hilary Knight is still here to captain the US. Fellow 30something Amanda Kessel is also in the attack. Alternate captains Alex Carpenter and Lee Stecklein are no stranger to this stage. But the goaltender is no longer Maddie Rooney, who played well beyond her 20 years to win gold in 2018, or Alex Cavallini, the 2022 goalie. It\u2019s 23-year-old Aerin Frankel. The Canadian team, on the other hand, boasts several of the all-time greats. Ann-Renee Desbiens. Marie-Philip Poulin. Jocelyn Larocque. You\u2019d think Canada would have the edge here. But their matchup earlier in these championships went to a shootout, with Canada scraping by to win. And the young, feisty US absolutely demolished Czechia, which won the bronze medal earlier today, with a 9-1 decision in the semis, as mentioned below. Beau will be here shortly. His first trial was abandoned due to juror misconduct and the director of public prosecutions, Shane Drumgold, decided not to pursue a second due to fears for Higgins\u2019 mental health.</p> <p>On Monday Longbottom told the inquiry, presided over by a retired judge of the Queensland court of appeal, Walter Sofronoff, that it was \u201cimportant to emphasise that this is not an inquiry into the allegations made by Ms Higgins against Mr Lehrmann\u201d.</p> <p>Rather it would consider the conduct of ACT police, the DPP and the victims of crime commissioner in the performance of their duties, newsletters for your daily news roundup</a></strong></p></li> </ul> <p>Longbottom noted that the Lehrmann prosecution had drawn \u201cintense media and public interest\u201d in part because the alleged offence occurred at Parliament House but also because it came at \u201ca time of intense public discussion about sexual violence against women, [and] in light of the #MeToo movement.</p> <p>\u201cAnd, specifically in the ACT, media reports of low rates of sexual assault trials and convictions despite increases in reports to victims\u2019 services and police.</p> <p>\u201cThat context seemingly affected the police charged with the responsibility of investigating allegations made against Mr Lehrmann, as well as the DPP and the victims of crime commissioner.</p> <p>\u201cThat context also brought into question the threshold for charging, and continuing the prosecution of an allegation of sexual intercourse without consent, and the significance of the credit of the complainant in those decisions.\u201d</p> <p>Longbottom noted that on 1 November Drumgold had written to the ACT chief of police, Neil Gaughan, complaining of alleged \u201cinappropriate\u201d interference by police in the case.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/dec/08/bruce-lehrmann-trial-brittany-higgins-dpp-director-public-prosecution-shane-drumgold-act-police\">Guardian Australia revealed the content of that letter</a> in December, after it was released pursuant to a freedom of information request.</p> <p>Counsel assisting told the inquiry that the relationship between ACT police and the DPP had been \u201cbeset by tension\u201d.</p> <p>The \u201cpoints of conflict\u201d include:</p> <ul> <li><p>Whether it was proper for ACT police to conduct a second evidence in chief interview with Higgins on 26 May 2021;</p></li> <li><p>\u201cConfusion about whether Mr Lehrmann should be charged and how matters affecting the credibility of Ms Higgins were to be treated by police in deciding whether to charge Mr Lehrmann, and by the DPP in deciding whether to present an indictment\u201d;</p></li> <li><p>Delivery of the brief of evidence to Lehrmann\u2019s lawyers on 6 August, after he was charged but before a plea was entered, which included counselling notes about Higgins; and</p></li> <li><p>\u201cThe apparent close engagement\u201d between investigating officers and lawyers for Lehrmann during the trial \u201cwhich led to some distrust between police and the DPP\u201d.</p></li> </ul> <p>Longbottom said Sofronoff would be required to consider whether police and the DPP had breached their duties and, if so, to discover their reasons and motives.</p> <p>Counsel for parties including Drumgold, the AFP and the victims of crime commissioner all pledged to give the inquiry their full cooperation.</p> <p>Sofronoff asked counsel for the victims of crime commissioner if the commissioner generally accepted \u201ca person\u2019s claim to be a victim\u201d and \u201cin practical terms would only turn away a claimant if she were satisfied that person is not a victim\u201d.</p> <p>Counsel replied that this was broadly correct, that the commissioner offered a \u201cvictim-focused\u201d approach that is \u201cseparate from the criminal justice system\u201d.</p> <p>Longbottom said counsel assisting expected substantive "https://media.guim.co.uk/722efded39631299a4870e70aeacccd9d31359e0/0_87_3894_2337/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "true", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "The #MeToo movement and \u201cintense public discussions\u201d about low rates of convictions \u201cseemingly affected\u201d decisions made to investigate and prosecute Bruce Lehrmann for the alleged sexual assault of Brittany Higgins, an inquiry has heard. Erin Longbottom, counsel assisting the inquiry into the Australian Capital Territory criminal justice system\u2019s handling of the case, made that submission on Monday morning at the inquiry\u2019s first hearing. Lehrmann has denied raping Higgins and pleaded not guilty to a charge of sexual intercourse without consent. His first trial was abandoned due to juror misconduct and the director of public prosecutions, Shane Drumgold, decided not to pursue a second due to fears for Higgins\u2019 mental health. On Monday Longbottom told the inquiry, presided over by a retired judge of the Queensland court of appeal, Walter Sofronoff, that it was \u201cimportant to emphasise that this is not an inquiry into the allegations made by Ms Higgins against Mr Lehrmann\u201d. Rather it would consider the conduct of ACT police, the DPP and the victims of crime commissioner in the performance of their duties, she said. Sign up for Guardian Australia\u2019s free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup Longbottom noted that the Lehrmann prosecution had drawn \u201cintense media and public interest\u201d in part because the alleged offence occurred at Parliament House but also because it came at \u201ca time of intense public discussion about sexual violence against women, [and] in light of the #MeToo movement. \u201cAnd, specifically in the ACT, media reports of low rates of sexual assault trials and convictions despite increases in reports to victims\u2019 services and police. \u201cThat context seemingly affected the police charged with the responsibility of investigating allegations made against Mr Lehrmann, as well as the DPP and the victims of crime commissioner. \u201cThat context also brought into question the threshold for charging, and continuing the prosecution of an allegation of sexual intercourse without consent, and the significance of the credit of the complainant in those decisions.\u201d Longbottom noted that on 1 November Drumgold had written to the ACT chief of police, Neil Gaughan, complaining of alleged \u201cinappropriate\u201d interference by police in the case. Guardian Australia revealed the content of that letter in December, after it was released pursuant to a freedom of information request. Counsel assisting told the inquiry that the relationship between ACT police and the DPP had been \u201cbeset by tension\u201d. The \u201cpoints of conflict\u201d include: Whether it was proper for ACT police to conduct a second evidence in chief interview with Higgins on 26 May 2021; \u201cConfusion about whether Mr Lehrmann should be charged and how matters affecting the credibility of Ms Higgins were to be treated by police in deciding whether to charge Mr Lehrmann, and by the DPP in deciding whether to present an indictment\u201d; Delivery of the brief of evidence to Lehrmann\u2019s lawyers on 6 August, after he was charged but before a plea was entered, which included counselling notes about Higgins; and \u201cThe apparent close engagement\u201d between investigating officers and lawyers for Lehrmann during the trial \u201cwhich led to some distrust between police and the DPP\u201d. Longbottom said Sofronoff would be required to consider whether police and the DPP had breached their duties and, if so, to discover their reasons and motives. Counsel for parties including Drumgold, the AFP and the victims of crime commissioner all pledged to give the inquiry their full cooperation. Sofronoff asked counsel for the victims of crime commissioner if the commissioner generally accepted \u201ca person\u2019s claim to be a victim\u201d and \u201cin practical terms would only turn away a claimant if she were satisfied that person is not a victim\u201d. Counsel replied that this was broadly correct, that the commissioner offered a \u201cvictim-focused\u201d approach that is \u201cseparate from the criminal justice system\u201d. Longbottom said counsel assisting expected substantive hearings to begin on 1 May, with initial witnesses from the DPP including Drumgold. discussions\u201d about low rates of convictions \u201cseemingly affected\u201d decisions made to investigate and prosecute Bruce Lehrmann for the alleged sexual assault of Brittany Higgins, an inquiry has heard. Erin Longbottom, counsel assisting the inquiry into the Australian Capital Territory criminal justice system\u2019s handling of the case, made that submission on Monday morning at the inquiry\u2019s first hearing.\nLehrmann has denied raping Higgins and pleaded not guilty to a charge of sexual intercourse without consent. His first trial was abandoned due to juror misconduct and the director of public prosecutions, Shane Drumgold, decided not to pursue a second due to fears for Higgins\u2019 mental health. On Monday Longbottom told the inquiry, presided over by a retired judge of the Queensland court of appeal, Walter Sofronoff, that it was \u201cimportant to emphasise that this is not an inquiry into the allegations made by Ms Higgins against Mr Lehrmann\u201d. Rather it would consider the conduct of ACT police, the DPP and the victims of crime commissioner in the performance of their duties, she said. Sign up for Guardian Australia\u2019s free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup Longbottom noted that the Lehrmann prosecution had drawn \u201cintense media and public interest\u201d in part because the alleged offence occurred at Parliament House but also because it came at \u201ca time of intense public discussion about sexual violence against women, [and] in light of the #MeToo movement. \u201cAnd, specifically in the ACT, media reports of low rates of sexual assault trials and convictions despite increases in reports to victims\u2019 services and police. \u201cThat context seemingly affected the police charged with the responsibility of investigating allegations made against Mr Lehrmann, as well as the DPP and the victims of crime commissioner. \u201cThat context also brought into question the threshold for charging, and continuing the prosecution of an allegation of sexual intercourse without consent, and the significance of the credit of the complainant in those decisions.\u201d Longbottom noted that on 1 November Drumgold had written to the ACT chief of police, Neil Gaughan, complaining of alleged \u201cinappropriate\u201d interference by police in the case. Guardian Australia revealed the content of that letter in December, after it was released pursuant to a freedom of information request. Counsel assisting told the inquiry that the relationship between ACT police and the DPP had been \u201cbeset by tension\u201d. The \u201cpoints of conflict\u201d include: Whether it was proper for ACT police to conduct a second evidence in chief interview with Higgins on 26 May 2021; \u201cConfusion about whether Mr Lehrmann should be charged and how matters affecting the credibility of Ms Higgins were to be treated by police in deciding whether to charge Mr Lehrmann, and by the DPP in deciding whether to present an indictment\u201d; Delivery of the brief of evidence to Lehrmann\u2019s lawyers on 6 August, after he was charged but before a plea was entered, which included counselling notes about Higgins; and \u201cThe apparent close engagement\u201d between investigating officers and lawyers for Lehrmann during the trial \u201cwhich led to some distrust between police and the DPP\u201d. Longbottom said Sofronoff would be required to consider whether police and the DPP had breached their duties and, if so, to discover their reasons and motives. Counsel for parties including Drumgold, the AFP and the victims of crime commissioner all pledged to give the inquiry their full cooperation. Sofronoff asked counsel for the victims of crime commissioner if the commissioner generally accepted \u201ca person\u2019s claim to be a victim\u201d and \u201cin practical terms would only turn away a claimant if she were satisfied that person is not a victim\u201d. Counsel replied that this was broadly correct, that the commissioner offered a \u201cvictim-focused\u201d approach that is \u201cseparate from the criminal justice system\u201d. Longbottom said counsel assisting expected substantive hearings to begin on 1 May, with initial witnesses from the DPP including Drumgold. Every week she appears on Channel 10\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2023/feb/02/taskmaster-comes-to-australia-i-am-better-than-greg-davies-make-that-the-headline\">Taskmaster</a>, and has previously been part of ABC\u2019s Utopia and Tonightly with Tom Ballard. She has writing credits for animated series Koala Man and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2023/mar/16/class-of-07-review-apocalyptic-high-school-reunion-comedy-gets-better-as-it-goes\"> Class of \u201907</a> , and is the co-creator of SBS\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2022/nov/30/latecomers-new-sbs-tv-series-sex-and-disability-on-screen\">Latecomers</a>.</p> <p>Next month Oyama is swapping the screen for the stage at the <a href=\"https://www.sydneycomedyfest.com.au/event/we-should-hang-out-with-nina-oyama-jude-perl/\">Sydney comedy festival</a>, alongside Jude Perl. But whatever the venue, the Sydneysider relies on one item to keep her comedy career running smoothly: her backpack, which is stuffed with everything she (or anyone around her) could need in a pinch. Here, Oyama tells us why she can\u2019t function without that <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2023/mar/30/succession-burberry-bag-bridget\">capacious bag</a>, as well as the stories behind two other personal belongings.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2023/apr/10/three-things-with-andrew-hansen-a-knee-pillow-is-the-definition-of-luxury\">Three things with Andrew Hansen: \u2018A knee pillow is the definition of luxury\u2019</a> </p> </aside>  <h2>What I\u2019d save from my house in a fire</h2> <p>I\u2019m the most unsentimental person. I store everything on the internet, which means when the robot apocalypse comes and all our data is deleted, I will have no tangible items to save. Except for one: my <a href=\"https://www.longboarderlabs.com/product/loaded-dervish-sama-carving-pumping-complete-9-x-42-8-flex-1-170-270-lbs/\">Loaded longboard</a>.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"1d207aa53c80a82a92aad237d8977d5e28584ea4\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/1d207aa53c80a82a92aad237d8977d5e28584ea4/442_0_1757_1170/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A woman in a black cap, white T-shirt and orange pants sitting on a longboard. \" width=\"1000\" height=\"666\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">\u2018It is one of my few possessions that has made me actively cooler and dumber at the same time\u2019: Nina Oyama with her longboard</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Supplied</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>I freakin\u2019 love this thing, man. During lockdown I went to Tempe Reserve and practised <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cEpidBW1wkE&amp;t=25s\">longboard dancing</a> every day. I am not very good, and I usually fall off and nearly die at least once every few sessions. I have hurt my head and arse so many times but I always just get back on the damn thing and keep practising the trick. I feel like Evel Knievel, even though I am usually just doing low-skill-level balancing steps in a very boring suburban park.</p> <p>This longboard cost $500 and it makes me feel truly alive. It is one of my few possessions that has made me actively cooler and dumber at the same time.</p> <h2>My most useful object</h2> <p>My backpack \u2013 I can\u2019t live without it. There\u2019s a tweet floating around somewhere that says something like \u201cevery comedian has an emotional support backpack\u201d and this rings so true to me.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>When I die, I want to be buried with [my backpack] like a pharaoh</p> <footer> <cite>Nina Oyama</cite> </footer> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>My bag is quite compact but somehow fits in everything. It\u2019s got my laptop, every single type of phone and laptop charger, a small makeup kit, an umbrella, snacks and all sorts of medicine. That said, all the stuff is completely loose inside the main chamber, so it\u2019s impossible to locate anything without tipping the entire contents on to the floor.</p> <p>Ask me for a Hydralyte, Panadol, a Band-Aid \u2013 I have it all. Yes, it will take 10 minutes of extremely frustrating rummaging, but it will eventually appear. The bag is also nice and small and has lumbar support. When I die, I want to be buried with it like a pharaoh, so I can carry my stupid bag to the afterlife \u2013 just in case Cleopatra needs a tampon.</p> <h2>The item I most regret losing</h2> <p>I used to be obsessed with this book called Too Close to the Falls by Catherine Gildiner, which I stole from my mum when I was a kid. I used to get bullied for bringing it to primary school because it had a \u201cWomen\u2019s Weekly recommended\u201d sticker on it, and kids would call me \u201cNeeny Peeny Women\u2019s Weekly\u201d. Not a great rhyme but still hurtful and ultimately character building. </p> <p>The book is a memoir about this little girl with ADHD called Cathy whose dad works as a pharmacist in Niagara Falls. To quell her hyperactivity, Cathy gets up at 5am every day to deliver medicine to townspeople, alongside an ex-con delivery driver called Roy. On their travels, Cathy sees heaps of messed-up stuff which she doesn\u2019t entirely understand, but it\u2019s written from the perspective of a child, so there are a lot of details you sort of have to decipher when you read it back as an adult.</p> <p>Anyway, I loved this book. I used to read heaps and swap books with friends, and I\u2019m fairly sure I lent it to a mate who never gave it back. This is why nobody should read books. What I\u2019d save from my house in a fire I\u2019m the most unsentimental person. I store everything on the internet, which means when the robot apocalypse comes and all our data is deleted, I will have no tangible items to save. Except for one: my Loaded longboard. I freakin\u2019 love this thing, man. During lockdown I went to Tempe Reserve and practised longboard dancing every day. I am not very good, and I usually fall off and nearly die at least once every few sessions. I have hurt my head and arse so many times but I always just get back on the damn thing and keep practising the trick. I feel like Evel Knievel, even though I am usually just doing low-skill-level balancing steps in a very boring suburban park. This longboard cost $500 and it makes me feel truly alive. It is one of my few possessions that has made me actively cooler and dumber at the same time. My most useful object My backpack \u2013 I can\u2019t live without it. There\u2019s a tweet floating around somewhere that says something like \u201cevery comedian has an emotional support backpack\u201d and this rings so true to me. My bag is quite compact but somehow fits in everything. It\u2019s got my laptop, every single type of phone and laptop charger, a small makeup kit, an umbrella, snacks and all sorts of medicine. That said, all the stuff is completely loose inside the main chamber, so it\u2019s impossible to locate anything without tipping the entire contents on to the floor. Ask me for a Hydralyte, Panadol, a Band-Aid \u2013 I have it all. Yes, it will take 10 minutes of extremely frustrating rummaging, but it will eventually appear. The bag is also nice and small and has lumbar support. When I die, I want to be buried with it like a pharaoh, so I can carry my stupid bag to the afterlife \u2013 just in case Cleopatra needs a tampon. The item I most regret losing I used to be obsessed with this book called Too Close to the Falls by Catherine Gildiner, which I stole from my mum when I was a kid. Not a great rhyme but still hurtful and ultimately character building. The book is a memoir about this little girl with ADHD called Cathy whose dad works as a pharmacist in Niagara Falls. Anyway, I loved this book. I used to read heaps and swap books with friends, and I\u2019m fairly sure I lent it to a mate who never gave it back. This is why nobody should read books. "6438fa608f0891526bb423c2", "bodyHtml": "<p>Nina Oyama is responsible for a lot of funny television. Every week she appears on Channel 10\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2023/feb/02/taskmaster-comes-to-australia-i-am-better-than-greg-davies-make-that-the-headline\">Taskmaster</a>, and has previously been part of ABC\u2019s Utopia and Tonightly with Tom Ballard. She has writing credits for animated series Koala Man and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2023/mar/16/class-of-07-review-apocalyptic-high-school-reunion-comedy-gets-better-as-it-goes\"> Class of \u201907</a> , and is the co-creator of SBS\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2022/nov/30/latecomers-new-sbs-tv-series-sex-and-disability-on-screen\">Latecomers</a>.</p> <p>Next month Oyama is swapping the screen for the stage at the <a href=\"https://www.sydneycomedyfest.com.au/event/we-should-hang-out-with-nina-oyama-jude-perl/\">Sydney comedy festival</a>, alongside Jude Perl. But whatever the venue, the Sydneysider relies on one item to keep her comedy career running smoothly: her backpack, which is stuffed with everything she (or anyone around her) could need in a pinch. Here, Oyama tells us why she can\u2019t function without that <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2023/mar/30/succession-burberry-bag-bridget\">capacious bag</a>, as well as the stories behind two other personal belongings.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2023/apr/10/three-things-with-andrew-hansen-a-knee-pillow-is-the-definition-of-luxury\">Three things with Andrew Hansen: \u2018A knee pillow is the definition of luxury\u2019</a> </p> </aside>  <h2>What I\u2019d save from my house in a fire</h2> <p>I\u2019m the most unsentimental person. I store everything on the internet, which means when the robot apocalypse comes and all our data is deleted, I will have no tangible items to save. Except for one: my <a href=\"https://www.longboarderlabs.com/product/loaded-dervish-sama-carving-pumping-complete-9-x-42-8-flex-1-170-270-lbs/\">Loaded longboard</a>.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"1d207aa53c80a82a92aad237d8977d5e28584ea4\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/1d207aa53c80a82a92aad237d8977d5e28584ea4/442_0_1757_1170/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A woman in a black cap, white T-shirt and orange pants sitting on a longboard. \" width=\"1000\" height=\"666\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">\u2018It is one of my few possessions that has made me actively cooler and dumber at the same time\u2019: Nina Oyama with her longboard</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Supplied</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>I freakin\u2019 love this thing, man. During lockdown I went to Tempe Reserve and practised <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cEpidBW1wkE&amp;t=25s\">longboard dancing</a> every day. I am not very good, and I usually fall off and nearly die at least once every few sessions. I have hurt my head and arse so many times but I always just get back on the damn thing and keep practising the trick. I feel like Evel Knievel, even though I am usually just doing low-skill-level balancing steps in a very boring suburban park.</p> <p>This longboard cost $500 and it makes me feel truly alive. It is one of my few possessions that has made me actively cooler and dumber at the same time.</p> <h2>My most useful object</h2> <p>My backpack \u2013 I can\u2019t live without it. There\u2019s a tweet floating around somewhere that says something like \u201cevery comedian has an emotional support backpack\u201d and this rings so true to me.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>When I die, I want to be buried with [my backpack] like a pharaoh</p> <footer> <cite>Nina Oyama</cite> </footer> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>My bag is quite compact but somehow fits in everything. It\u2019s got my laptop, every single type of phone and laptop charger, a small makeup kit, an umbrella, snacks and all sorts of medicine. That said, all the stuff is completely loose inside the main chamber, so it\u2019s impossible to locate anything without tipping the entire contents on to the floor.</p> <p>Ask me for a Hydralyte, Panadol, a Band-Aid \u2013 I have it all. Yes, it will take 10 minutes of extremely frustrating rummaging, but it will eventually appear. The bag is also nice and small and has lumbar support. When I die, I want to be buried with it like a pharaoh, so I can carry my stupid bag to the afterlife \u2013 just in case Cleopatra needs a tampon.</p> <h2>The item I most regret losing</h2> <p>I used to be obsessed with this book called Too Close to the Falls by Catherine Gildiner, which I stole from my mum when I was a kid. I used to get bullied for bringing it to primary school because it had a \u201cWomen\u2019s Weekly recommended\u201d sticker on it, and kids would call me \u201cNeeny Peeny Women\u2019s Weekly\u201d. Not a great rhyme but still hurtful and ultimately character building. </p> <p>The book is a memoir about this little girl with ADHD called Cathy whose dad works as a pharmacist in Niagara Falls. To quell her hyperactivity, Cathy gets up at 5am every day to deliver medicine to townspeople, alongside an ex-con delivery driver called Roy. On their travels, Cathy sees heaps of messed-up stuff which she doesn\u2019t entirely understand, but it\u2019s written from the perspective of a child, so there are a lot of details you sort of have to decipher when you read it back as an adult.</p> <p>Anyway, I loved this book. I used to read heaps and swap books with friends, and I\u2019m fairly sure I lent it to a mate who never gave it back. This is why nobody should read books. Or have friends!</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "Nina Oyama is responsible for a lot of funny television. Every week she appears on Channel 10\u2019s Taskmaster, and has previously been part of ABC\u2019s Utopia and Tonightly with Tom Ballard. She has writing credits for animated series Koala Man and Class of \u201907 , and is the co-creator of SBS\u2019s Latecomers. Next month Oyama is swapping the screen for the stage at the Sydney comedy festival, alongside Jude Perl. But whatever the venue, the Sydneysider relies on one item to keep her comedy career running smoothly: her backpack, which is stuffed with everything she (or anyone around her) could need in a pinch. Here, Oyama tells us why she can\u2019t function without that capacious bag, as well as the stories behind two other personal belongings.\nWhat I\u2019d save from my house in a fire I\u2019m the most unsentimental person. I store everything on the internet, which means when the robot apocalypse comes and all our data is deleted, I will have no tangible items to save. Except for one: my Loaded longboard.\nI freakin\u2019 love this thing, man. During lockdown I went to Tempe Reserve and practised longboard dancing every day. I am not very good, and I usually fall off and nearly die at least once every few sessions. I have hurt my head and arse so many times but I always just get back on the damn thing and keep practising the trick. I feel like Evel Knievel, even though I am usually just doing low-skill-level balancing steps in a very boring suburban park. This longboard cost $500 and it makes me feel truly alive. It is one of my few possessions that has made me actively cooler and dumber at the same time. My most useful object My backpack \u2013 I can\u2019t live without it. There\u2019s a tweet floating around somewhere that says something like \u201cevery comedian has an emotional support backpack\u201d and this rings so true to me.\nMy bag is quite compact but somehow fits in everything. It\u2019s got my laptop, every single type of phone and laptop charger, a small makeup kit, an umbrella, snacks and all sorts of medicine. That said, all the stuff is completely loose inside the main chamber, so it\u2019s impossible to locate anything without tipping the entire contents on to the floor. Ask me for a Hydralyte, Panadol, a Band-Aid \u2013 I have it all. Yes, it will take 10 minutes of extremely frustrating rummaging, but it will eventually appear. The bag is also nice and small and has lumbar support. When I die, I want to be buried with it like a pharaoh, so I can carry my stupid bag to the afterlife \u2013 just in case Cleopatra needs a tampon. The item I most regret losing I used to be obsessed with this book called Too Close to the Falls by Catherine Gildiner, which I stole from my mum when I was a kid. I used to get bullied for bringing it to primary school because it had a \u201cWomen\u2019s Weekly recommended\u201d sticker on it, and kids would call me \u201cNeeny Peeny Women\u2019s Weekly\u201d. Not a great rhyme but still hurtful and ultimately character building. The book is a memoir about this little girl with ADHD called Cathy whose dad works as a pharmacist in Niagara Falls. To quell her hyperactivity, Cathy gets up at 5am every day to deliver medicine to townspeople, alongside an ex-con delivery driver called Roy. On their travels, Cathy sees heaps of messed-up stuff which she doesn\u2019t entirely understand, but it\u2019s written from the perspective of a child, so there are a lot of details you sort of have to decipher when you read it back as an adult. Anyway, I loved this book. I used to read heaps and swap books with friends, and I\u2019m fairly sure I lent it to a mate who never gave it back. This is why nobody should read books. "body": "<p>Matthew Fitzpatrick has claimed his first win since last year\u2019s US Open, winning the RBC Heritage at the third playoff hole at Harbour Town, after a thrilling duel with three-time major winner Jordan Spieth for the title.</p> <p>Fitzpatrick became the first Englishman to win the tournament since Nick Faldo in 1984 after Spieth cruelly lipped out a $5.4 million putt to fall heartbreakingly short of becoming just the tournament\u2019s fourth-ever back-to-back winner.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/mar/10/matt-fitzpatrick-concerned-at-state-of-link-between-pga-and-dp-tours\">Matt Fitzpatrick concerned at state of link between PGA and DP tours</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Spieth long looked in the ascendancy but couldn\u2019t close out birdie putts at both the first and second playoff holes that would\u2019ve claimed the win. At the third playoff hole, Fitzpatrick almost holed out from the fairway to leave himself with just a tap-in for birdie.</p> <p>Spieth couldn\u2019t respond, making Englishman the winner of the $3.6 million (A$5.4m) top prize. The American had to settle for second and a cheque for $2.2 million. Americans Patrick Cantlay came third at 16-under, missing the playoff by one shot, followed by Xander Schaffuele one shot further back.</p> <p>Fitzpatrick, the 2022 US Open champion, triumphed in the town where he spent many of his family vacations after first visiting as a six-year-old.</p> <p>\u201cIt\u2019s hard to describe,\u201d the 28-year-old from Sheffield said. \u201cI said to (caddie) Billy (Foster), it doesn\u2019t get better than this \u2013 walking down here, just looking around. It\u2019s a course I dreamed of playing when I was young.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"d83716ac4b2f379d053dc8fd2fae68953d6c07ac\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/d83716ac4b2f379d053dc8fd2fae68953d6c07ac/0_221_4576_2746/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Matt Fitzpatrick and Jordan Spieth shake hands\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Matt Fitzpatrick and Jordan Spieth shake hands after Fitzpatrick won the playoff on the third hole.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Kevin C Cox/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>\u201cI managed to play a couple of times with my dad and yes, this one means more than anything.\u201d Fitzpatrick\u2019s family was at Harbour Town to share the victory with him.</p> <p>Spieth had made four birdies in the opening six holes but he missed a short putt for bogey on the par-three 14th and left the door open for Fitzpatrick.</p> <p>The Englishman then made birdies on the 15th and 16th to grab a share of the lead and could have won it at the death if Spieth hadn\u2019t made a tricky six-footer to force the playoff.</p> <p>\u201cIt was a really good round. I got off to a dream start and then just kind of hung in there for a little while and then made a nice putt to get into the playoff, and then played the playoff really well,\u201d said Spieth.</p> <p>\u201cSomeone was going to make a birdie. It wasn\u2019t going to be a bogey to lose that playoff the way that we were both playing today. He just did what he needed to do on 15 in, when it had been kind of me and Patrick for a little while there. </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>Vladimir Putin and China\u2019s defence minister Li Shangfu have vowed to deepen military cooperation between China and Russia after the men met in Moscow over the weekend.</p> <p>Li, who met the Russian president on Sunday on his first trip overseas in the role, said China was willing to work with Russia to have close strategic communications between their militaries.</p> <p>He said China was prepared to strengthen multilateral coordination and cooperation with Russia, according to state-run CCTV news.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/apr/14/china-agreed-secretly-arm-russia-leaked-pentagon-documents-reveal\">China agreed to secretly arm Russia, leaked Pentagon documents reveal</a> </p> </aside>  <p>\u201cChina is willing to work with Russia to make new contributions to the maintenance of world and regional security and stability,\u201d Li said, according to the report.</p> <p>He said ties between Russia and China \u201csurpass the military-political alliances of the cold war era\u201d, in translated remarks broadcast on Russian TV.</p> <p>\u201cThis is my first overseas visit since taking over as China\u2019s defence minister. I specifically chose Russia for this in order to emphasise the special nature and strategic importance of our bilateral ties,\u201d Li said.</p> <p>After the meeting, which was also attended by Russian defence minister Sergei Shoigu, Putin and Li hailed military cooperation between the two nations, which have declared a \u201cno limits\u201d partnership.</p> <p>Footage of the meeting showed Putin shaking hands with Li and then sitting down at a table.</p> <p>\u201cWe are working actively through our military departments, regularly exchange useful information, work together in the field of military-technical cooperation, and hold joint exercises,\u201d Putin said.</p> <p>The exercises, he added, had been held in the Far East as well as Europe and involved ground, naval and air forces.</p> <p>\u201cUndoubtedly, this is another crucial area that strengthens the extremely trusting, strategic nature of our relations,\u201d Putin said.</p> <p>Ukrainian forces are finding a growing number of components from China in Russian weapons used in Ukraine, a senior official in Kyiv said on Friday. China has repeatedly denied sending military equipment to Russia.</p> <p>Last week, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/apr/14/china-agreed-secretly-arm-russia-leaked-pentagon-documents-reveal\">leaked US government documents</a> said China approved the provision of lethal aid to Russia for its war in <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/ukraine\">Ukraine</a> but wanted any shipments to remain a secret.</p> <p>Nato and the United States say they have seen no signs yet that Beijing is supplying arms to Moscow.</p> <p>Li\u2019s trip to Russia, which will last until 19 April, comes weeks after an official visit to Moscow of China\u2019s leader Xi Jinping last month.</p> <p>During two days of talks, Putin and Xi hailed a \u201cnew era\u201d in their relationship and discussed Beijing\u2019s proposals to end the Ukraine conflict.</p> <p>Beijing had announced Li\u2019s visit to Moscow last week, saying he would meet defence officials, but made no mention of a meeting with Putin.</p> <p>Li has been under US sanctions since 2018 over the purchase of combat aircraft and equipment from Russia\u2019s main arms exporter, Rosoboronexport.</p> <p><em>With Reuters and Agence France-Presse</em></p>", "wordcount": "457", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T01:28:41Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T12:54:14Z", "productionOffice": "AUS", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nne94", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/8bfcd76e7c004a5753349040a0fba867d859f280/0_384_7456_4475/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Vladimir Putin and China\u2019s defence minister Li Shangfu have vowed to deepen military cooperation between China and Russia after the men met in Moscow over the weekend. Li, who met the Russian president on Sunday on his first trip overseas in the role, said China was willing to work with Russia to have close strategic communications between their militaries. He said China was prepared to strengthen multilateral coordination and cooperation with Russia, according to state-run CCTV news. \u201cChina is willing to work with Russia to make new contributions to the maintenance of world and regional security and stability,\u201d Li said, according to the report. The exercises, he added, had been held in the Far East as well as Europe and involved ground, naval and air forces. \u201cUndoubtedly, this is another crucial area that strengthens the extremely trusting, strategic nature of our relations,\u201d Putin said. data-media-id=\"21321957a3cfb2d62c76f6fbb02eda3ee6d73ff2\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/21321957a3cfb2d62c76f6fbb02eda3ee6d73ff2/514_278_4777_2866/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Melbourne City\u2019s Jordan City won a third-straight ALM premiership the next day.<br></span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Bianca de Marchi/AAP</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>In the end, it was a rather nondescript way for Melbourne City to make history. Able to secure the A-League Men premiership for a record-setting third straight season by defeating Central Coast on Saturday, Rado Vido\u0161i\u0107\u2019s side was forced to settle for a 1-1 draw, only to then have the crown fall into their laps a day later when Western United upset Adelaide, making City\u2019s eight-point lead atop the table an unassailable one.</p> <p>It meant there were no scenes of jubilationat the final whistle or confetti cascading around a joyous Scott Jamieson lifting the premiers\u2019 plate. That will have to wait until this week, City\u2019s captain instead having to make do with <a href=\"https://twitter.com/ScottJamieson/status/1647524927992631296?s=20\">tweeting a celebratory Kobe Bryant gif</a>. History made, but quietly.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/2023/apr/06/aiden-oneill-settles-melbourne-derby-three-months-after-scoring-opening-goal\">Aiden O\u2019Neill settles Melbourne derby three months after scoring opening goal</a> </p> </aside>  <p>No team in the 18 years of ALM has ever ended the regular season atop the mountain in back-to-back-to-back years. The feat has only ever been accomplished once before in Australian men\u2019s national league history, when Sydney City won three straight between 1980 and 1982 in the National Soccer League. It is one of the greatest feats of consistent excellence in Australian football history.</p> <p>City\u2019s 14 wins this season equals their 2021-22 campaign, with two more opportunities to better their best-ever total of 15 from 2020-21. Defeated just three times, they are guaranteed to record the fewest defeats in a single season in club history. Their 55 goals scored stands alongside their total from 2021-22 and is just two adrift of the campaign prior. Shipping 29 goals the other way, they can afford to concede at least three in looming clashes with Western United and Western Sydney before they exceed the club record of 32 set in 2018-19 and 2020-21.</p> <p>City are putting together one of the best-ever ALM seasons in both a statistical and narrative sense. Somehow they are improved on 2021 and \u201822 despite being forced to adapt to a mid-season coaching change from Patrick Kisnorbo to Vido\u0161i\u0107, Jamie Maclaren\u2019s imminent fourth-straight Golden Boot, Mat Leckie looking like the best player in the league, or the soon-to-be off-to-Europe Marco Tilio, Jordan Bos, and Aiden O\u2019Neill establishing themselves as Socceroos.</p> <p>At the same time, City\u2019s run to a third-straight crown feels the least remarkable of the three, despite it being anything but. The most obvious contributor is that the league as a whole has been starved of coverage of late and that when column inches have been devoted, it\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2022/dec/20/melbourne-victory-face-reckoning-after-years-of-hard-work-disappear-with-one-throw-of-a-bucket\">been to more salacious subjects</a>. </p> <p>City\u2019s recent stumbles and Adelaide\u2019s 12-game unbeaten run provided the League with something approaching a horse race. It\u2019s no fun to just write and talk about City relentlessly marching towards yet another trophy: you want a contest, a loveable underdog to City\u2019s all-conquering, CFG-backed behemoth. The Reds offered that with their combination of a pumping Hindmarsh Stadium, young local talent, and Socceroos\u2019 hero Craig Goodwin creating an environment where, as a neutral, you wanted them to succeed.</p> <p>Conversely, once you get past them playing the best football in the League, there\u2019s very little in this City side to engender them to all but the most front-running of neutrals. This is the best team in the A-Leagues: well-credentialed Australian veterans supplemented by a well-funded academy pumping out prospect after prospect, and a global scouting and recruitment network finding gems their rivals couldn\u2019t. Buoyed by CFG resources, topping the ALM table is a base expectation. </p> <p>City is expected to win. <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2023/apr/12/manchester-city-appear-unbeatable-with-erling-haaland-in-total-control\">As its Manchester-based cousin looks to complete club football in Europe</a>, with all the existential questions that raises, the Melbourne outpost of the CFG continues to march towards a similar model on an Australian scale. It\u2019s why the thought of City not doing so is a novelty and, as cynical as the outlook is, how it curses moments such as a third-straight premiership to not carry the same impact as it would for other sides. In a way, it\u2019s the ultimate compliment you can give City: the presupposition that they will win any game they play.</p> <p>Now, the coming finals series presents a new challenge. City has been to three-straight grand finals but has only lifted the trophy once. As long as Australia crowns its champions via an end-of-season playoff, this will hamper legacy.</p> <p>But the comparison between Melbourne and Manchester is where the next real frontier lies: the continent. Hampered by COVID, City has only once had a chance to compete in the Asian Champions League and, in that hub-based campaign, they failed to progress from their group. With Australian history made, Asia looms over any legacy in Melbourne, much as the UEFA Champions League serves as the elephant in the room whenever talking about Manchester.</p>", "wordcount": "772", "commentCloseDate": "2023-04-20T01:30:00Z", "commentable": "true", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T01:23:54Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-18T22:08:40Z", "productionOffice": "AUS", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nndq8", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/21321957a3cfb2d62c76f6fbb02eda3ee6d73ff2/514_278_4777_2866/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "In the end, it was a rather nondescript way for Melbourne City to make history. No team in the 18 years of ALM has ever ended the regular season atop the mountain in back-to-back-to-back years. The feat has only ever been accomplished once before in Australian men\u2019s national league history, when Sydney City won three straight between 1980 and 1982 in the National Soccer League. It is one of the greatest feats of consistent excellence in Australian football history. City\u2019s 14 wins this season equals their 2021-22 campaign, with two more opportunities to better their best-ever total of 15 from 2020-21. Defeated just three times, they are guaranteed to record the fewest defeats in a single season in club history. Their 55 goals scored stands alongside their total from 2021-22 and is just two adrift of the campaign prior. Shipping 29 goals the other way, they can afford to concede at least three in looming clashes with Western United and Western Sydney before they exceed the club record of 32 set in 2018-19 and 2020-21. At the same time, City\u2019s run to a third-straight crown feels the least remarkable of the three, despite it being anything but. The most obvious contributor is that the league as a whole has been starved of coverage of late and that when column inches have been devoted, it\u2019s been to more salacious subjects. City\u2019s recent stumbles and Adelaide\u2019s 12-game unbeaten run provided the League with something approaching a horse race. Conversely, once you get past them playing the best football in the League, there\u2019s very little in this City side to engender them to all but the most front-running of neutrals. This is the best team in the A-Leagues: well-credentialed Australian veterans supplemented by a well-funded academy pumping out prospect after prospect, and a global scouting and recruitment network finding gems their rivals couldn\u2019t. Somehow they are improved on 2021 and \u201822 despite being forced to adapt to a mid-season coaching change from Patrick Kisnorbo to Vido\u0161i\u0107, Jamie Maclaren\u2019s imminent fourth-straight Golden Boot, Mat Leckie looking like the best player in the league, or the soon-to-be off-to-Europe Marco Tilio, Jordan Bos, and Aiden O\u2019Neill establishing themselves as Socceroos.</p> \n<p>At the same time, City\u2019s run to a third-straight crown feels the least remarkable of the three, despite it being anything but. The most obvious contributor is that the league as a whole has been starved of coverage of late and that when column inches have been devoted, it\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2022/dec/20/melbourne-victory-face-reckoning-after-years-of-hard-work-disappear-with-one-throw-of-a-bucket\">been to more salacious subjects</a>. </p> \n<p>City\u2019s recent stumbles and Adelaide\u2019s 12-game unbeaten run provided the League with something approaching a horse race. It\u2019s no fun to just write and talk about City relentlessly marching towards yet another trophy: you want a contest, a loveable underdog to City\u2019s all-conquering, CFG-backed behemoth. The Reds offered that with their combination of a pumping Hindmarsh Stadium, young local talent, and Socceroos\u2019 hero Craig Goodwin creating an environment where, as a neutral, you wanted them to succeed.</p> \n<p>Conversely, once you get past them playing the best football in the League, there\u2019s very little in this City side to engender them to all but the most front-running of neutrals. This is the best team in the A-Leagues: well-credentialed Australian veterans supplemented by a well-funded academy pumping out prospect after prospect, and a global scouting and recruitment network finding gems their rivals couldn\u2019t. Buoyed by CFG resources, topping the ALM table is a base expectation. </p> \n<p>City is expected to win. <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2023/apr/12/manchester-city-appear-unbeatable-with-erling-haaland-in-total-control\">As its Manchester-based cousin looks to complete club football in Europe</a>, with all the existential questions that raises, the Melbourne outpost of the CFG continues to march towards a similar model on an Australian scale. It\u2019s why the thought of City not doing so is a novelty and, as cynical as the outlook is, how it curses moments such as a third-straight premiership to not carry the same impact as it would for other sides. In a way, it\u2019s the ultimate compliment you can give City: the presupposition that they will win any game they play.</p> \n<p>Now, the coming finals series presents a new challenge. City has been to three-straight grand finals but has only lifted the trophy once. As long as Australia crowns its champions via an end-of-season playoff, this will hamper legacy.</p> \n<p>But the comparison between Melbourne and Manchester is where the next real frontier lies: the continent. Hampered by COVID, City has only once had a chance to compete in the Asian Champions League and, in that hub-based campaign, they failed to progress from their group. With Australian history made, Asia looms over any legacy in Melbourne, much as the UEFA Champions League serves as the elephant in the room whenever talking about Manchester.</p>"}}]}], "totalBodyBlocks": 1}, "rights": {"syndicatable": "true", "subscriptionDatabases": "true", "developerCommunity": "true"}, "section": {"id": "football", "webTitle": "Football", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/football", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/football", "editions": [{"id": "football", "webTitle": "Football", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/football", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/football", "code": "default"}]}, "isHosted": false, "pillarId": "pillar/sport", "pillarName": "Sport"}, {"id": "music/2023/apr/17/ahmad-jamal-influential-jazz-pianist-dies-aged-92", "type": "article", "sectionId": "music", "sectionName": "Music", "webPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T01:13:51Z", "webTitle": "Ahmad Jamal, influential jazz pianist, dies aged 92", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/music/2023/apr/17/ahmad-jamal-influential-jazz-pianist-dies-aged-92", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/music/2023/apr/17/ahmad-jamal-influential-jazz-pianist-dies-aged-92", "fields": {"headline": "Ahmad Jamal, influential jazz pianist, dies aged 92", "standfirst": "<p>Over a career spanning seven decades, musician was hailed for his ability to transcend genres </p>", "trailText": "Over a career spanning seven decades, musician was hailed for his ability to transcend genres", "byline": "Sian Cain", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"99d7ff2113b0fb94ed0cb7c2c5ea02c1f9fb9458\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/99d7ff2113b0fb94ed0cb7c2c5ea02c1f9fb9458/44_351_6914_4148/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Ahmad Jamal in 2013\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Ahmad Jamal in 2013. The jazz piano great has died at the age of 92.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Sarah Lee/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>Ahmad Jamal, the influential jazz pianist, composer and band leader, has died at the age of 92.</p> <p>His daughter, Sumayah Jamal, confirmed to the New York Times that the cause of death was prostate cancer.</p> <p>Embarking on a professional music career from the age of 14, over seven decades Jamal forged a unique sound that leapt over genre boundaries. Minimalism, classical, modernism, pop: Ahmad was sometimes likened to <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1982/02/18/thelonious-monk-63-jazz-pianist-composer-dies/38da7e4a-ca2a-4647-8259-52b1ae2a662c/?itid=lk_inline_manual_44\">Thelonious Monk</a> in terms of his ability to innovate and influence other musicians: his piano would be sampled by the likes of De La Soul, Jay-Z, Common and Nas. The trumpeter Miles Davis once said: \u201cAll my inspiration comes from Ahmad Jamal,\u201d writing in his memoir that his friend had \u201cknocked me out with his concept of space, his lightness of touch, and the way he phrases notes and chords and passages\u201d.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/feb/01/ahmad-jamal-discover-mozart-in-you\">Ahmad Jamal: \u2018After a time you discover the Mozart in you\u2019</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Born Frederick Russell Jones in Pittsburgh in 1930, Jamal began playing music at three when an uncle challenged him to copy him on the family piano. He devoured \u201creams of sheet music\u201d in all genres donated by his aunt and began receiving formal training when he was seven, then was composing at the age of 10. He found himself drawn to works by the French classical composers Maurice Ravel and Claude Debussy. By his early teens he was performing in nightclubs. \u201cI\u2019d do algebra during intermission, between sets,\u201d he once told Down Beat magazine.</p> <p>After marrying, he settled in Chicago in 1950 and converted to Islam from the Baptist faith of his family, becoming one of the first African American performers to publicly speak of his Muslim faith. Talking to Time magazine about going by the name Ahmad Jamal, he said: \u201cI haven\u2019t adopted a name. It\u2019s a part of my ancestral background and heritage. I have re-established my original name. I have gone back to my own vine and fig tree.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"ef1cad2449efe9097f189d57fa00a00c834a7fcd\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/ef1cad2449efe9097f189d57fa00a00c834a7fcd/4_993_3703_2223/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Jamal Ahmad performs in 2016 at the Marciac jazz festival in France\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Jamal Ahmad performs in 2016 at the Marciac jazz festival in France.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: R\u00e9my Gabalda/AFP/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Jamal performed jazz, which he called \u201cAmerican classical music\u201d all his life, in the house band for Chicago\u2019s Pershing Hotel lounge \u2013 a Black-owned favourite of the likes of Sammy Davis Jr and Billie Holiday, and where he recorded his 1958 breakthrough album, Ahmad Jamal at the Pershing: But Not For Me. The album sold 1m copies and remained on the Billboard magazine charts for more than 100 weeks, making Jamal a household name when rock\u2019n\u2019roll was on the up and jazz was beginning to wane.</p> <p>He and his always-rotating lineup continued performing in nightclubs across the US to devoted audiences: Jamal bought a mansion and started his own nightclub, the Alhambra (which served no alcohol, as per his religious beliefs): the club was one in a series of unsuccessful business ventures that eventually left him saddled with debt.</p> <p>His first marriage ended in divorce in 1962 and he was hospitalised in 1963 after an apparent overdose. He didn\u2019t resume touring and recording until 1964, having moved to New York for a long residency at the Village Gate nightclub.</p> <p>His <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aZTUFoD2UN8\">keyboard version</a> of the theme from M*A*S*H was critically acclaimed in 1970 and was followed by another significant album, The Awakening, with the bassist Jamil Nasser and the drummer Frank Gant.</p> <p>\u201cI used to do 20% my own pieces and 80% other people\u2019s; now it\u2019s turned the other way,\u201d he told the Guardian in 2013. \u201cAfter a certain time you discover the Mozart in you, the Duke Ellington or Billy Strayhorn in you. It takes time to discover yourself. You also have to find and keep players who are in tune with what you\u2019re doing; you have that empathy, the quality of breathing together.\u201d</p>       <figure class=\"element element-video\" data-canonical-url=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2DCpApGVXWg\"                                                                        >  <iframe height=\"480\" width=\"854\" src=\"https://www.youtube-nocookie.com/embed/2DCpApGVXWg?wmode=opaque&feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen ></iframe> </figure>   <p>In the 1980s and 90s, Jamal continued to perform relentlessly and released several live albums, shoring up his reputation as one of the best living jazz performers. He was named Jazz Master in 1994 by the National Endowment for the Arts and won a lifetime achievement Grammy in 2017.</p> <p>His first daughter Mumeenah Counts died in 1979. He is survived by his third ex-wife and manager, Laura Hess-Hay; Sumayah, his daughter with his second ex-wife; and two grandchildren.</p> <p>Speaking about his ability to continue performing and touring in his 80s, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/feb/01/ahmad-jamal-discover-mozart-in-you\">he told the Guardian</a>: \u201cIt\u2019s a divine gift, that\u2019s all I can tell you. We don\u2019t create, we discover \u2013 and the process of discovery gives you energy \u2026 Rhythm is very important in music, and your life has to have rhythms too. </p> <p>\u201cYou can exercise properly, eat properly \u2013 but the most important thing of all is thinking properly. Things are in a mess, and that\u2019s an understatement; so much is being lost because of greed. </p> <p>\u201cThere are very few authentic, pure approaches to life now. But this music is one of them, and it continues to be.\u201d</p>", "newspaperPageNumber": "25", "wordcount": "785", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T01:13:51Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T20:13:27Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-18T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "AUS", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nndpx", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/99d7ff2113b0fb94ed0cb7c2c5ea02c1f9fb9458/44_351_6914_4148/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Ahmad Jamal, the influential jazz pianist, composer and band leader, has died at the age of 92. He found himself drawn to works by the French classical composers Maurice Ravel and Claude Debussy. By his early teens he was performing in nightclubs. \u201cI\u2019d do algebra during intermission, between sets,\u201d he once told Down Beat magazine.</p> <p>After marrying, he settled in Chicago in 1950 and converted to Islam from the Baptist faith of his family, becoming one of the first African American performers to publicly speak of his Muslim faith. Talking to Time magazine about going by the name Ahmad Jamal, he said: \u201cI haven\u2019t adopted a name. It\u2019s a part of my ancestral background and heritage. I have re-established my original name. I have gone back to my own vine and fig tree.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"ef1cad2449efe9097f189d57fa00a00c834a7fcd\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/ef1cad2449efe9097f189d57fa00a00c834a7fcd/4_993_3703_2223/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Jamal Ahmad performs in 2016 at the Marciac jazz festival in France\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Jamal Ahmad performs in 2016 at the Marciac jazz festival in France.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: R\u00e9my Gabalda/AFP/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Jamal performed jazz, which he called \u201cAmerican classical music\u201d all his life, in the house band for Chicago\u2019s Pershing Hotel lounge \u2013 a Black-owned favourite of the likes of Sammy Davis Jr and Billie Holiday, and where he recorded his 1958 breakthrough album, Ahmad Jamal at the Pershing: But Not For Me. The album sold 1m copies and remained on the Billboard magazine charts for more than 100 weeks, making Jamal a household name when rock\u2019n\u2019roll was on the up and jazz was beginning to wane.</p> <p>He and his always-rotating lineup continued performing in nightclubs across the US to devoted audiences: Jamal bought a mansion and started his own nightclub, the Alhambra (which served no alcohol, as per his religious beliefs): the club was one in a series of unsuccessful business ventures that eventually left him saddled with debt.</p> <p>His first marriage ended in divorce in 1962 and he was hospitalised in 1963 after an apparent overdose. He didn\u2019t resume touring and recording until 1964, having moved to New York for a long residency at the Village Gate nightclub.</p> <p>His <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aZTUFoD2UN8\">keyboard version</a> of the theme from M*A*S*H was critically acclaimed in 1970 and was followed by another significant album, The Awakening, with the bassist Jamil Nasser and the drummer Frank Gant.</p> <p>\u201cI used to do 20% my own pieces and 80% other people\u2019s; now it\u2019s turned the other way,\u201d he told the Guardian in 2013. \u201cAfter a certain time you discover the Mozart in you, the Duke Ellington or Billy Strayhorn in you. It takes time to discover yourself. You also have to find and keep players who are in tune with what you\u2019re doing; you have that empathy, the quality of breathing together.\u201d</p>       <figure class=\"element element-video\" data-canonical-url=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2DCpApGVXWg\"                                                                        >  <iframe height=\"480\" width=\"854\" src=\"https://www.youtube-nocookie.com/embed/2DCpApGVXWg?wmode=opaque&feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen ></iframe> </figure>   <p>In the 1980s and 90s, Jamal continued to perform relentlessly and released several live albums, shoring up his reputation as one of the best living jazz performers. He was named Jazz Master in 1994 by the National Endowment for the Arts and won a lifetime achievement Grammy in 2017.</p> <p>His first daughter Mumeenah Counts died in 1979. He is survived by his third ex-wife and manager, Laura Hess-Hay; Sumayah, his daughter with his second ex-wife; and two grandchildren.</p> <p>Speaking about his ability to continue performing and touring in his 80s, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/feb/01/ahmad-jamal-discover-mozart-in-you\">he told the Guardian</a>: \u201cIt\u2019s a divine gift, that\u2019s all I can tell you. We don\u2019t create, we discover \u2013 and the process of discovery gives you energy \u2026 Rhythm is very important in music, and your life has to have rhythms too. </p> <p>\u201cYou can exercise properly, eat properly \u2013 but the most important thing of all is thinking properly. Things are in a mess, and that\u2019s an understatement; so much is being lost because of greed. </p> <p>\u201cThere are very few authentic, pure approaches to life now. But this music is one of them, and it continues to be.\u201d</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "Ahmad Jamal, the influential jazz pianist, composer and band leader, has died at the age of 92. His daughter, Sumayah Jamal, confirmed to the New York Times that the cause of death was prostate cancer. Embarking on a professional music career from the age of 14, over seven decades Jamal forged a unique sound that leapt over genre boundaries. Minimalism, classical, modernism, pop: Ahmad was sometimes likened to Thelonious Monk in terms of his ability to innovate and influence other musicians: his piano would be sampled by the likes of De La Soul, Jay-Z, Common and Nas. The trumpeter Miles Davis once said: \u201cAll my inspiration comes from Ahmad Jamal,\u201d writing in his memoir that his friend had \u201cknocked me out with his concept of space, his lightness of touch, and the way he phrases notes and chords and passages\u201d.\nBorn Frederick Russell Jones in Pittsburgh in 1930, Jamal began playing music at three when an uncle challenged him to copy him on the family piano. He devoured \u201creams of sheet music\u201d in all genres donated by his aunt and began receiving formal training when he was seven, then was composing at the age of 10. He found himself drawn to works by the French classical composers Maurice Ravel and Claude Debussy. By his early teens he was performing in nightclubs. \u201cI\u2019d do algebra during intermission, between sets,\u201d he once told Down Beat magazine. After marrying, he settled in Chicago in 1950 and converted to Islam from the Baptist faith of his family, becoming one of the first African American performers to publicly speak of his Muslim faith. Talking to Time magazine about going by the name Ahmad Jamal, he said: \u201cI haven\u2019t adopted a name. It\u2019s a part of my ancestral background and heritage. I have re-established my original name. I have gone back to my own vine and fig tree.\u201d\nJamal performed jazz, which he called \u201cAmerican classical music\u201d all his life, in the house band for Chicago\u2019s Pershing Hotel lounge \u2013 a Black-owned favourite of the likes of Sammy Davis Jr and Billie Holiday, and where he recorded his 1958 breakthrough album, Ahmad Jamal at the Pershing: But Not For Me. The album sold 1m copies and remained on the Billboard magazine charts for more than 100 weeks, making Jamal a household name when rock\u2019n\u2019roll was on the up and jazz was beginning to wane. He and his always-rotating lineup continued performing in nightclubs across the US to devoted audiences: Jamal bought a mansion and started his own nightclub, the Alhambra (which served no alcohol, as per his religious beliefs): the club was one in a series of unsuccessful business ventures that eventually left him saddled with debt. His first marriage ended in divorce in 1962 and he was hospitalised in 1963 after an apparent overdose. He didn\u2019t resume touring and recording until 1964, having moved to New York for a long residency at the Village Gate nightclub. His keyboard version of the theme from M*A*S*H was critically acclaimed in 1970 and was followed by another significant album, The Awakening, with the bassist Jamil Nasser and the drummer Frank Gant. \u201cI used to do 20% my own pieces and 80% other people\u2019s; now it\u2019s turned the other way,\u201d he told the Guardian in 2013. \u201cAfter a certain time you discover the Mozart in you, the Duke Ellington or Billy Strayhorn in you. It takes time to discover yourself. You also have to find and keep players who are in tune with what you\u2019re doing; you have that empathy, the quality of breathing together.\u201d\nIn the 1980s and 90s, Jamal continued to perform relentlessly and released several live albums, shoring up his reputation as one of the best living jazz performers. He was named Jazz Master in 1994 by the National Endowment for the Arts and won a lifetime achievement Grammy in 2017. His first daughter Mumeenah Counts died in 1979. He is survived by his third ex-wife and manager, Laura Hess-Hay; Sumayah, his daughter with his second ex-wife; and two grandchildren. Speaking about his ability to continue performing and touring in his 80s, he told the Guardian: \u201cIt\u2019s a divine gift, that\u2019s all I can tell you. We don\u2019t create, we discover \u2013 and the process of discovery gives you energy \u2026 Rhythm is very important in music, and your life has to have rhythms too. \u201cYou can exercise properly, eat properly \u2013 but the most important thing of all is thinking properly. Things are in a mess, and that\u2019s an understatement; so much is being lost because of greed. \u201cThere are very few authentic, pure approaches to life now. But this music is one of them, and it continues to be.\u201d", "attributes": {}, "published": true, "createdDate": "2023-04-17T01:13:51Z", "firstPublishedDate": "2023-04-17T01:13:51Z", "publishedDate": "2023-04-17T01:13:51Z", "lastModifiedDate": "2023-04-17T01:08:09Z", "contributors": [], "elements": [{"type": "text", "assets": [], "textTypeData": {"html": "<p>Ahmad Jamal, the influential jazz pianist, composer and band leader, has died at the age of 92.</p> \n<p>His daughter, Sumayah Jamal, confirmed to the New York Times that the cause of death was prostate cancer.</p> \n<p>Embarking on a professional music career from the age of 14, over seven decades Jamal forged a unique sound that leapt over genre boundaries.
