government over the future of its Liddell power station in 2017<a href=\"https://www.agl.com.au/about-agl/media-centre/asx-and-media-releases/2017/december/agl-announces-plans-for-liddell-power-station#:~:text=The%20NSW%20Generation%20Plan%20proposes,at%20Liddell%20into%20synchronous%20condensers.\">, it drew up an extensive scheme</a> listing how it would replace the coal-fired plant with equivalent generation capacity.</p> <p>The Generation Plan proposed a mix of renewable energy, gas-peaking plants and battery storage, some of which would be on or near Liddell\u2019s site in the New South Wales Hunter Valley. Its sister coal-fired power station, Bayswater, would also get an upgrade.</p> <ul> <li><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/oct/29/email-newsletters-guardian-australia-best-daily-news-emails-newsletter-free-sign-up-inbox-subscribe-headlines?CMP=copyembed\">Sign up for Guardian Australia\u2019s free morning and afternoon</a></strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/oct/29/email-newsletters-guardian-australia-best-daily-news-emails-newsletter-free-sign-up-inbox-subscribe-headlines?CMP=copyembed\"> </a><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/oct/29/email-newsletters-guardian-australia-best-daily-news-emails-newsletter-free-sign-up-inbox-subscribe-headlines?CMP=copyembed\">email newsletters for your daily news roundup</a></strong></p></li> </ul>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"631fc4f94953d5da09231ad8c8011d7d37025b9b\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/631fc4f94953d5da09231ad8c8011d7d37025b9b/0_0_8192_5464/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Worker\u2019s belongings in the workshop at Liddell Power Station\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Bayswater power station will provide 100 jobs for the 140 employed by Liddell. The rest will retire or leave the industry.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Blake Sharp-Wiggins/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>AGL\u2019s then chief executive, Andy Vesey, estimated the capital investment would total almost $1.4bn, with the new assets operating for as long as 30 years. By contrast, extending Liddell\u2019s life beyond its planned 2022 closure would cost $920m and only add five years to a plant then almost 50 years old.</p> <p>As events transpired, the then prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, and Vesey both got rolled on the same day, 24 August 2018. \u201cThey lost their PM over energy and we lost a CEO,\u201d one AGL insider says.</p> <p>With Liddell finally shutting on 28 April, business leaders and local officials are hopeful alternative generation projects and manufacturing will eventually fill the site even if few of AGL\u2019s proposed ventures have progressed.</p> <p>\u201cThere was initially a level of \u2018this is going to be a bit of a shock to the system\u2019,\u201d says Danny Eather, president of Business Singleton, which represents about 180 local businesses. \u201cLiddell is really beyond its lifespan as a facility, and I think there\u2019s a general acceptance within the community that this is what had to happen.\u201d</p> <p>Mike Kelly, president of the Muswellbrook Chamber of Commerce and Industry, further up the Hunter Valley, says it\u2019s still unclear what will replace Liddell.</p> <p>\u201cDespite the early notice [of Liddell\u2019s demise], driven by government policy, there is still a lot of uncertainty and cynicism,\u201d Kelly says. </p> <p>\u201cYou wouldn\u2019t turn off the town water supply to your house if you were planning to put in big tanks next year,\u201d he says. \u201cAnd you wouldn\u2019t turn off the grid main supply if you\u2019re planning to put solar panels and wind turbines on your property in the next year or two or five.\u201d</p> <p>Authorities, though, are confident Liddell\u2019s shutdown won\u2019t disrupt the power grid. The Australian Energy Market Operator forecasts the state \u201cwill maintain a reliable power supply\u201d, says Penny Sharpe, the state\u2019s new energy minister.</p> <p>\u201cLiddell is now more than 50 years old. It\u2019s been unreliable for many years, and not operating at its rated capacity,\u201d Sharpe says. \u201cIn 2022, Liddell made around 1,260 megawatts available, a fraction of its 2,000MW rated capacity, and generated only around 7,000 gigawatt-hours across the year.\u201d</p> <p>Vesey\u2019s successor at AGL, Brett Redman, became much more cautious about the rush to invest in new renewables. Plans for a gas-peaker plant near Goulburn and one in the lower Hunter were scrapped altogether, while investments in new batteries and pumped hydro plants at Liddell or nearby have taken longer than expected, insiders say.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"9b56076d572ded1c7a6050e9f20a64a9315966bf\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/9b56076d572ded1c7a6050e9f20a64a9315966bf/0_0_8192_5464/1000.jpg\" alt=\"AGL COO Markus Brokhof outside Liddell Power Station\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">AGL chief operating officer, Markus Brokhof, says people should forget about the earlier plan for the Liddell power station: \u2018It is history.\u2019</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Blake Sharp-Wiggins/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"a37b556ba019091f8380971f4f00f311c1af7b03\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/a37b556ba019091f8380971f4f00f311c1af7b03/0_0_8192_5464/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Mayor Steve Reynolds on the shores of Lake Liddell with the Lake Liddell Power Station in the background.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Steve Reynolds, mayor of Muswellbrook, worries the community won\u2019t be ready for the changes that will transform the area.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Blake Sharp-Wiggins/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Management wanted \u201cno additional risk\u201d for coal generation, one of them says. \u201cWhat was happening in the background was that the business was haemorrhaging cash.\u201d</p> <p>Also disrupting AGL\u2019s intentions were interventions in the market by the Turnbull and then Morrison governments, not least Snowy Hydro\u2019s giant Snowy 2.0 pumped hydro project and then its Kurri Kurri gas plant in NSW. These threw the whole Generation Plan \u201cout of the window\u201d, they say.</p> <p>Markus Brokhof, AGL\u2019s chief operating officer, is keen to see people move on from that earlier plan. \u201cForget about this, it is history,\u201d he said during a recent visit to Liddell.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/mar/30/australia-finally-has-a-policy-that-will-cut-emissions-and-thats-a-cold-hard-fact\">A climate policy that actually cuts emissions? It\u2019s the reality that fossil fuel bosses and News Corp commentators can\u2019t see | Temperature Check</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Brokhof is proud Bayswater has been able to absorb 100 of Liddell\u2019s 140 staff, meaning AGL kept its promise there would be no forced redundancies. The rest will retire or leave the industry.</p> <p>Bayswater\u2019s crew of 460 will swell to 560, with contractors and sub-contractors being cut to make way for the newcomers.</p> <p>AGL aims to make a final investment decision on a 500MW battery for Liddell \u201cprobably in the second half of this year\u201d, Brokhof says. A second battery of the same size may be a future option for a site near the Tomago aluminium smelter, AGL\u2019s biggest customer, also in the Hunter region.</p> <p>A 250MW pumped hydro project about 11km from Liddell that would use a deep coalmine void created by Japan\u2019s Idemitsu Corporation remains at the feasibility study stage. \u201cWe are exploring double that [size],\u201d Brokhof says.</p> <p>Hydrogen production is another option for a post-Liddell future. AGL <a href=\"https://www.agl.com.au/about-agl/media-centre/asx-and-media-releases/2022/august/agl-and-fortescue-future-industries--green-hydrogen-feasibility-\">last year expanded a feasibility study</a> involving Andrew Forrest\u2019s Fortescue Future Industries and other partners to explore development of a green hydrogen and ammonia production facility.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"4bf43d91d777ff839a78774fcd7e39dc3628ac67\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/4bf43d91d777ff839a78774fcd7e39dc3628ac67/0_0_7409_4942/1000.jpg\" alt=\"One of the smoke stacks at Liddell Power Station.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> </figure>  <p>Luring other manufacturers to a site well-served with high voltage transmission, roads and railway is another aim of AGL\u2019s. Agriculture may even feature, Brokhof says.</p> <p>A mining engineer by training, Brokhof hails from Dusseldorf, part of the Ruhr region of Germany that has been navigating a transition off mining and heavy industry for decades.</p> <p>\u201cThere are thousands of templates\u201d about how to help communities adjust, he said, while walking near Lake Liddell. \u201cAustralia is not an island. It\u2019s a bit annoying.\u201d</p> <p>Another insider says locals should expect news of a \u201cbig deal\u201d later this year about other companies willing to bring investments.</p> <p>AGL\u2019s Liddell-Bayswater site, bought from the state government for $1.5bn in 2014, covers 10,000 hectares and also about 40% of the high-security water rights in the Hunter. The water licences, linked to the power stations, are among the largest in Australia and roughly equal the total water available to farms and mines in the valley.</p> <p>However, the area\u2019s transition away from fossil fuels may need to speed up, particularly if Bayswater\u2019s closure is brought forward and the mines start to shut. \u201cThe latest is 2033,\u201d Brokhof says, referring to the shutdown timing of the 2,640MW plant.</p> <p>The end of a relatively low-cost coal contract in 2028, however, could challenge Bayswater\u2019s economics before then. A reduced operation, such as retaining just one or more of the four units, may be the result, people familiar with the plant say.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--immersive\" data-media-id=\"527d8dcffa3484b431281804c641de09162b2513\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/527d8dcffa3484b431281804c641de09162b2513/0_0_8192_5464/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Bayswater Power Station seen from the upper floors of Liddell Power Station.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> </figure>  <p>Steve Reynolds, mayor of Muswellbrook, worries the community won\u2019t be ready for what is coming.</p> <p>\u201cWe\u2019re in for a turbulent time, there\u2019s no doubt, with the transformation that is going to happen across this region,\u201d Reynolds says.</p> <p>\u201cWe really need that person from the state government, specifically, that\u2019s going to assist us because there\u2019s so many different departments that are siloed under environmental minister, the mining regulator [and so on],\u201d he says. \u201cIf we miss this boat, it will be the generations to come that will pay for their failures.\u201d</p> <p>Michele O\u2019Neil, the Australian Council of Trade Unions president, says a national energy transition authority is required to improve coordination.</p> <p>\u201cThis is something we should have done at least a decade ago and we\u2019ve left many communities without the support needed,\u201d she says.</p> <p>Such a body could help diversify the economy \u201cand create good secure long-term jobs well before closures happen\u201d, O\u2019Neil says. \u201cIt can\u2019t just be left up to the market\u201d.</p>", "wordcount": "1189", "commentCloseDate": "2023-04-20T01:00:25Z", "commentable": "true", "displayHint": "immersive", with the Turnbull government over the future of its Liddell power station in 2017, it drew up an extensive scheme listing how it would replace the coal-fired plant with equivalent generation capacity. The Generation Plan proposed a mix of renewable energy, gas-peaking plants and battery storage, some of which would be on or near Liddell\u2019s site in the New South Wales Hunter Valley. Its sister coal-fired power station, Bayswater, would also get an upgrade. Sign up for Guardian Australia\u2019s free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup AGL\u2019s then chief executive, Andy Vesey, estimated the capital investment would total almost $1.4bn, with the new assets operating for as long as 30 years. By contrast, extending Liddell\u2019s life beyond its planned 2022 closure would cost $920m and only add five years to a plant then almost 50 years old. As events transpired, the then prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, and Vesey both got rolled on the same day, 24 August 2018. \u201cThey lost their PM over energy and we lost a CEO,\u201d one AGL insider says. With Liddell finally shutting on 28 April, business leaders and local officials are hopeful alternative generation projects and manufacturing will eventually fill the site even if few of AGL\u2019s proposed ventures have progressed. \u201cThere was initially a level of \u2018this is going to be a bit of a shock to the system\u2019,\u201d says Danny Eather, president of Business Singleton, which represents about 180 local businesses. \u201cLiddell is really beyond its lifespan as a facility, and I think there\u2019s a general acceptance within the community that this is what had to happen.\u201d Mike Kelly, president of the Muswellbrook Chamber of Commerce and Industry, further up the Hunter Valley, says it\u2019s still unclear what will replace Liddell. \u201cDespite the early notice [of Liddell\u2019s demise], driven by government policy, there is still a lot of uncertainty and cynicism,\u201d Kelly says. \u201cYou wouldn\u2019t turn off the town water supply to your house if you were planning to put in big tanks next year,\u201d he says. \u201cAnd you wouldn\u2019t turn off the grid main supply if you\u2019re planning to put solar panels and wind turbines on your property in the next year or two or five.\u201d Authorities, though, are confident Liddell\u2019s shutdown won\u2019t disrupt the power grid. The Australian Energy Market Operator forecasts the state \u201cwill maintain a reliable power supply\u201d, says Penny Sharpe, the state\u2019s new energy minister. \u201cLiddell is now more than 50 years old. It\u2019s been unreliable for many years, and not operating at its rated capacity,\u201d Sharpe says. \u201cIn 2022, Liddell made around 1,260 megawatts available, a fraction of its 2,000MW rated capacity, and generated only around 7,000 gigawatt-hours across the year.\u201d Vesey\u2019s successor at AGL, Brett Redman, became much more cautious about the rush to invest in new renewables. Plans for a gas-peaker plant near Goulburn and one in the lower Hunter were scrapped altogether, while investments in new batteries and pumped hydro plants at Liddell or nearby have taken longer than expected, insiders say. Brokhof is proud Bayswater has been able to absorb 100 of Liddell\u2019s 140 staff, meaning AGL kept its promise there would be no forced redundancies. The rest will retire or leave the industry. Bayswater\u2019s crew of 460 will swell to 560, with contractors and sub-contractors being cut to make way for the newcomers. AGL aims to make a final investment decision on a 500MW battery for Liddell \u201cprobably in the second half of this year\u201d, Brokhof says. A second battery of the same size may be a future option for a site near the Tomago aluminium smelter, AGL\u2019s biggest customer, also in the Hunter region. A 250MW pumped hydro project about 11km from Liddell that would use a deep coalmine void created by Japan\u2019s Idemitsu Corporation remains at the feasibility study stage. \u201cWe are exploring double that [size],\u201d Brokhof says. Hydrogen production is another option for a post-Liddell future. AGL last year expanded a feasibility study involving Andrew Forrest\u2019s Fortescue Future Industries and other partners to explore development of a green hydrogen and ammonia production facility. Luring other manufacturers to a site well-served with high voltage transmission, roads and railway is another aim of AGL\u2019s. Agriculture may even feature, Brokhof says. A mining engineer by training, Brokhof hails from Dusseldorf, part of the Ruhr region of Germany that has been navigating a transition off mining and heavy industry for decades. \u201cThere are thousands of templates\u201d about how to help communities adjust, he said, while walking near Lake Liddell. \u201cAustralia is not an island. It\u2019s a bit annoying.\u201d Another insider says locals should expect news of a \u201cbig deal\u201d later this year about other companies willing to bring investments. However, the area\u2019s transition away from fossil fuels may need to speed up, particularly if Bayswater\u2019s closure is brought forward and the mines start to shut. \u201cThe latest is 2033,\u201d Brokhof says, referring to the shutdown timing of the 2,640MW plant. The end of a relatively low-cost coal contract in 2028, however, could challenge Bayswater\u2019s economics before then. A reduced operation, such as retaining just one or more of the four units, may be the result, people familiar with the plant say. By contrast, extending Liddell\u2019s life beyond its planned 2022 closure would cost $920m and only add five years to a plant then almost 50 years old.</p> <p>As events transpired, the then prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, and Vesey both got rolled on the same day, 24 August 2018. \u201cThey lost their PM over energy and we lost a CEO,\u201d one AGL insider says.</p> <p>With Liddell finally shutting on 28 April, business leaders and local officials are hopeful alternative generation projects and manufacturing will eventually fill the site even if few of AGL\u2019s proposed ventures have progressed.</p> <p>\u201cThere was initially a level of \u2018this is going to be a bit of a shock to the system\u2019,\u201d says Danny Eather, president of Business Singleton, which represents about 180 local businesses. \u201cLiddell is really beyond its lifespan as a facility, and I think there\u2019s a general acceptance within the community that this is what had to happen.\u201d</p> <p>Mike Kelly, president of the Muswellbrook Chamber of Commerce and Industry, further up the Hunter Valley, says it\u2019s still unclear what will replace Liddell.</p> <p>\u201cDespite the early notice [of Liddell\u2019s demise], driven by government policy, there is still a lot of uncertainty and cynicism,\u201d Kelly says. </p> <p>\u201cYou wouldn\u2019t turn off the town water supply to your house if you were planning to put in big tanks next year,\u201d he says. \u201cAnd you wouldn\u2019t turn off the grid main supply if you\u2019re planning to put solar panels and wind turbines on your property in the next year or two or five.\u201d</p> <p>Authorities, though, are confident Liddell\u2019s shutdown won\u2019t disrupt the power grid. The Australian Energy Market Operator forecasts the state \u201cwill maintain a reliable power supply\u201d, says Penny Sharpe, the state\u2019s new energy minister.</p> <p>\u201cLiddell is now more than 50 years old. It\u2019s been unreliable for many years, and not operating at its rated capacity,\u201d Sharpe says. \u201cIn 2022, Liddell made around 1,260 megawatts available, a fraction of its 2,000MW rated capacity, and generated only around 7,000 gigawatt-hours across the year.\u201d</p> <p>Vesey\u2019s successor at AGL, Brett Redman, became much more cautious about the rush to invest in new renewables. Plans for a gas-peaker plant near Goulburn and one in the lower Hunter were scrapped altogether, while investments in new batteries and pumped hydro plants at Liddell or nearby have taken longer than expected, insiders say.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"9b56076d572ded1c7a6050e9f20a64a9315966bf\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/9b56076d572ded1c7a6050e9f20a64a9315966bf/0_0_8192_5464/1000.jpg\" alt=\"AGL COO Markus Brokhof outside Liddell Power Station\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">AGL chief operating officer, Markus Brokhof, says people should forget about the earlier plan for the Liddell power station: \u2018It is history.\u2019</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Blake Sharp-Wiggins/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"a37b556ba019091f8380971f4f00f311c1af7b03\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/a37b556ba019091f8380971f4f00f311c1af7b03/0_0_8192_5464/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Mayor Steve Reynolds on the shores of Lake Liddell with the Lake Liddell Power Station in the background.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Steve Reynolds, mayor of Muswellbrook, worries the community won\u2019t be ready for the changes that will transform the area.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Blake Sharp-Wiggins/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Management wanted \u201cno additional risk\u201d for coal generation, one of them says. \u201cWhat was happening in the background was that the business was haemorrhaging cash.\u201d</p> <p>Also disrupting AGL\u2019s intentions were interventions in the market by the Turnbull and then Morrison governments, not least Snowy Hydro\u2019s giant Snowy 2.0 pumped hydro project and then its Kurri Kurri gas plant in NSW. These threw the whole Generation Plan \u201cout of the window\u201d, they say.</p> <p>Markus Brokhof, AGL\u2019s chief operating officer, is keen to see people move on from that earlier plan. \u201cForget about this, it is history,\u201d he said during a recent visit to Liddell.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/mar/30/australia-finally-has-a-policy-that-will-cut-emissions-and-thats-a-cold-hard-fact\">A climate policy that actually cuts emissions? It\u2019s the reality that fossil fuel bosses and News Corp commentators can\u2019t see | Temperature Check</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Brokhof is proud Bayswater has been able to absorb 100 of Liddell\u2019s 140 staff, meaning AGL kept its promise there would be no forced redundancies. The rest will retire or leave the industry.</p> <p>Bayswater\u2019s crew of 460 will swell to 560, with contractors and sub-contractors being cut to make way for the newcomers.</p> <p>AGL aims to make a final investment decision on a 500MW battery for Liddell \u201cprobably in the second half of this year\u201d, Brokhof says. A second battery of the same size may be a future option for a site near the Tomago aluminium smelter, AGL\u2019s biggest customer, also in the Hunter region.</p> <p>A 250MW pumped hydro project about 11km from Liddell that would use a deep coalmine void created by Japan\u2019s Idemitsu Corporation remains at the feasibility study stage. \u201cWe are exploring double that [size],\u201d Brokhof says.</p> <p>Hydrogen production is another option for a post-Liddell future. AGL <a href=\"https://www.agl.com.au/about-agl/media-centre/asx-and-media-releases/2022/august/agl-and-fortescue-future-industries--green-hydrogen-feasibility-\">last year expanded a feasibility study</a> involving Andrew Forrest\u2019s Fortescue Future Industries and other partners to explore development of a green hydrogen and ammonia production facility.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"4bf43d91d777ff839a78774fcd7e39dc3628ac67\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/4bf43d91d777ff839a78774fcd7e39dc3628ac67/0_0_7409_4942/1000.jpg\" alt=\"One of the smoke stacks at Liddell Power Station.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> </figure>  <p>Luring other manufacturers to a site well-served with high voltage transmission, roads and railway is another aim of AGL\u2019s. Agriculture may even feature, Brokhof says.</p> <p>A mining engineer by training, Brokhof hails from Dusseldorf, part of the Ruhr region of Germany that has been navigating a transition off mining and heavy industry for decades.</p> <p>\u201cThere are thousands of templates\u201d about how to help communities adjust, he said, while walking near Lake Liddell. \u201cAustralia is not an island. It\u2019s a bit annoying.\u201d</p> <p>Another insider says locals should expect news of a \u201cbig deal\u201d later this year about other companies willing to bring investments.</p> <p>AGL\u2019s Liddell-Bayswater site, bought from the state government for $1.5bn in 2014, covers 10,000 hectares and also about 40% of the high-security water rights in the Hunter. The water licences, linked to the power stations, are among the largest in Australia and roughly equal the total water available to farms and mines in the valley.</p> <p>However, the area\u2019s transition away from fossil fuels may need to speed up, particularly if Bayswater\u2019s closure is brought forward and the mines start to shut. \u201cThe latest is 2033,\u201d Brokhof says, referring to the shutdown timing of the 2,640MW plant.</p> <p>The end of a relatively low-cost coal contract in 2028, however, could challenge Bayswater\u2019s economics before then. A reduced operation, such as retaining just one or more of the four units, may be the result, people familiar with the plant say.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--immersive\" data-media-id=\"527d8dcffa3484b431281804c641de09162b2513\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/527d8dcffa3484b431281804c641de09162b2513/0_0_8192_5464/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Bayswater Power Station seen from the upper floors of Liddell Power Station.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> </figure>  <p>Steve Reynolds, mayor of Muswellbrook, worries the community won\u2019t be ready for what is coming.</p> <p>\u201cWe\u2019re in for a turbulent time, there\u2019s no doubt, with the transformation that is going to happen across this region,\u201d Reynolds says.</p> <p>\u201cWe really need that person from the state government, specifically, that\u2019s going to assist us because there\u2019s so many different departments that are siloed under environmental minister, the mining regulator [and so on],\u201d he says. \u201cIf we miss this boat, it will be the generations to come that will pay for their failures.\u201d</p> <p>Michele O\u2019Neil, the Australian Council of Trade Unions president, says a national energy transition authority is required to improve coordination.</p> <p>\u201cThis is something we should have done at least a decade ago and we\u2019ve left many communities without the support needed,\u201d she says.</p> <p>Such a body could help diversify the economy \u201cand create good secure long-term jobs well before closures happen\u201d, O\u2019Neil says. \u201cIt can\u2019t just be left up to the market\u201d.</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "When AGL Energy was in a tangle with the Turnbull government over the future of its Liddell power station in 2017, it drew up an extensive scheme listing how it would replace the coal-fired plant with equivalent generation capacity. The Generation Plan proposed a mix of renewable energy, gas-peaking plants and battery storage, some of which would be on or near Liddell\u2019s site in the New South Wales Hunter Valley. Its sister coal-fired power station, Bayswater, would also get an upgrade. Sign up for Guardian Australia\u2019s free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup\nAGL\u2019s then chief executive, Andy Vesey, estimated the capital investment would total almost $1.4bn, with the new assets operating for as long as 30 years. By contrast, extending Liddell\u2019s life beyond its planned 2022 closure would cost $920m and only add five years to a plant then almost 50 years old. As events transpired, the then prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, and Vesey both got rolled on the same day, 24 August 2018. \u201cThey lost their PM over energy and we lost a CEO,\u201d one AGL insider says. With Liddell finally shutting on 28 April, business leaders and local officials are hopeful alternative generation projects and manufacturing will eventually fill the site even if few of AGL\u2019s proposed ventures have progressed. \u201cThere was initially a level of \u2018this is going to be a bit of a shock to the system\u2019,\u201d says Danny Eather, president of Business Singleton, which represents about 180 local businesses. \u201cLiddell is really beyond its lifespan as a facility, and I think there\u2019s a general acceptance within the community that this is what had to happen.\u201d Mike Kelly, president of the Muswellbrook Chamber of Commerce and Industry, further up the Hunter Valley, says it\u2019s still unclear what will replace Liddell. \u201cDespite the early notice [of Liddell\u2019s demise], driven by government policy, there is still a lot of uncertainty and cynicism,\u201d Kelly says. \u201cYou wouldn\u2019t turn off the town water supply to your house if you were planning to put in big tanks next year,\u201d he says. \u201cAnd you wouldn\u2019t turn off the grid main supply if you\u2019re planning to put solar panels and wind turbines on your property in the next year or two or five.\u201d Authorities, though, are confident Liddell\u2019s shutdown won\u2019t disrupt the power grid. The Australian Energy Market Operator forecasts the state \u201cwill maintain a reliable power supply\u201d, says Penny Sharpe, the state\u2019s new energy minister. \u201cLiddell is now more than 50 years old. It\u2019s been unreliable for many years, and not operating at its rated capacity,\u201d Sharpe says. \u201cIn 2022, Liddell made around 1,260 megawatts available, a fraction of its 2,000MW rated capacity, and generated only around 7,000 gigawatt-hours across the year.\u201d Vesey\u2019s successor at AGL, Brett Redman, became much more cautious about the rush to invest in new renewables. Plans for a gas-peaker plant near Goulburn and one in the lower Hunter were scrapped altogether, while investments in new batteries and pumped hydro plants at Liddell or nearby have taken longer than expected, insiders say.\nManagement wanted \u201cno additional risk\u201d for coal generation, one of them says. \u201cWhat was happening in the background was that the business was haemorrhaging cash.\u201d Also disrupting AGL\u2019s intentions were interventions in the market by the Turnbull and then Morrison governments, not least Snowy Hydro\u2019s giant Snowy 2.0 pumped hydro project and then its Kurri Kurri gas plant in NSW. These threw the whole Generation Plan \u201cout of the window\u201d, they say. Markus Brokhof, AGL\u2019s chief operating officer, is keen to see people move on from that earlier plan. \u201cForget about this, it is history,\u201d he said during a recent visit to Liddell.\nBrokhof is proud Bayswater has been able to absorb 100 of Liddell\u2019s 140 staff, meaning AGL kept its promise there would be no forced redundancies. The rest will retire or leave the industry. Bayswater\u2019s crew of 460 will swell to 560, with contractors and sub-contractors being cut to make way for the newcomers. AGL aims to make a final investment decision on a 500MW battery for Liddell \u201cprobably in the second half of this year\u201d, Brokhof says. A second battery of the same size may be a future option for a site near the Tomago aluminium smelter, AGL\u2019s biggest customer, also in the Hunter region. A 250MW pumped hydro project about 11km from Liddell that would use a deep coalmine void created by Japan\u2019s Idemitsu Corporation remains at the feasibility study stage. \u201cWe are exploring double that [size],\u201d Brokhof says. Hydrogen production is another option for a post-Liddell future. AGL last year expanded a feasibility study involving Andrew Forrest\u2019s Fortescue Future Industries and other partners to explore development of a green hydrogen and ammonia production facility.\nLuring other manufacturers to a site well-served with high voltage transmission, roads and railway is another aim of AGL\u2019s. Agriculture may even feature, Brokhof says. A mining engineer by training, Brokhof hails from Dusseldorf, part of the Ruhr region of Germany that has been navigating a transition off mining and heavy industry for decades. \u201cThere are thousands of templates\u201d about how to help communities adjust, he said, while walking near Lake Liddell. \u201cAustralia is not an island. It\u2019s a bit annoying.\u201d Another insider says locals should expect news of a \u201cbig deal\u201d later this year about other companies willing to bring investments. AGL\u2019s Liddell-Bayswater site, bought from the state government for $1.5bn in 2014, covers 10,000 hectares and also about 40% of the high-security water rights in the Hunter. The water licences, linked to the power stations, are among the largest in Australia and roughly equal the total water available to farms and mines in the valley. However, the area\u2019s transition away from fossil fuels may need to speed up, particularly if Bayswater\u2019s closure is brought forward and the mines start to shut. \u201cThe latest is 2033,\u201d Brokhof says, referring to the shutdown timing of the 2,640MW plant. The end of a relatively low-cost coal contract in 2028, however, could challenge Bayswater\u2019s economics before then. A reduced operation, such as retaining just one or more of the four units, may be the result, people familiar with the plant say.\nSteve Reynolds, mayor of Muswellbrook, worries the community won\u2019t be ready for what is coming. \u201cWe\u2019re in for a turbulent time, there\u2019s no doubt, with the transformation that is going to happen across this region,\u201d Reynolds says. \u201cWe really need that person from the state government, specifically, that\u2019s going to assist us because there\u2019s so many different departments that are siloed under environmental minister, the mining regulator [and so on],\u201d he says. \u201cIf we miss this boat, it will be the generations to come that will pay for their failures.\u201d Michele O\u2019Neil, the Australian Council of Trade Unions president, says a national energy transition authority is required to improve coordination. \u201cThis is something we should have done at least a decade ago and we\u2019ve left many communities without the support needed,\u201d she says. "https://content.guardianapis.com/commentisfree/2023/apr/17/im-raising-my-children-in-a-flat-and-the-community-that-comes-with-it-is-worth-it", "fields": {"headline": "I\u2019m raising my children in "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"7731c877006ee42d42b8cb9257f24cc9e24e308e\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/7731c877006ee42d42b8cb9257f24cc9e24e308e/125_0_5750_3453/1000.jpg\" alt=\"In Europe, where almost half the population lives in flats, raising children this way is normal. So why is it still not considered so in Australia?</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: klyaksun/Getty Images/iStockphoto</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>My father lives in the next suburb, but I can count the times he\u2019s been inside my home on one hand. Two fingers, actually: after the birth of my son and after the birth of my daughter. It\u2019s not because we don\u2019t get on \u2013 I love Dad and he loves me. But he is a boomer who bought a four-bedroom, three-garden house for $2 in 1974, and I am pushing 40 and live in a flat. Let me repeat: a <em>flat. </em>When he steps inside my front door, I know what he\u2019s thinking.</p> <p>How \u2013 he wonders, administering the polite amount of baby cuddles before racing for the exit \u2013 can my seemingly intelligent daughter, mother of two, whose private school fees I paid for, live in this hellhole?</p> <p>Career choices aside \u2013 IT versus writing, no prizes for guessing the more lucrative \u2013 it\u2019s not what my younger self expected either. The Great Australian Dream is still home ownership and, more specifically, <em>house </em>ownership. Growing up in middle-class inner Melbourne in the 80s and 90s, none of my friends lived in flats and I assumed that by the time I had children, I too would live in a house of my own. But \u2013 who knew? \u2013 the keys don\u2019t emerge with the baby in a kind of painful-but-convenient two-for-one deal.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>Is my generation ashamed of the comparatively small size of our homes?</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>Like it or not, higher-density living is the future of our cities and families in flats are becoming more common. Living cheek by jowl has its obvious downsides (wafting smoke out of a neighbour\u2019s window, for instance, and don\u2019t get me started on the window-rattling sex in the bedroom above) but there are positives to living so close to one\u2019s fellow man.</p> <p>Sandwiched above, below and to one side by other apartments, our place is cool in summer and warm in winter. A neighbour can easily pop up the back stairs and crack a can of Fancy Feast for our cat when we\u2019re away.</p> <ul> <li><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/dec/21/sign-up-for-five-great-reads-guardian-australias-wrap-of-our-best-summer-stories\">Sign up for a weekly email featuring our best reads</a></strong></p></li> </ul> <p>During lockdowns, the woman next door left gifts on the mat for our toddler: piles of shells, helicopter leaves, the latest supermarket collectible. When I take my son down to play in the communal courtyard, we never know whom we\u2019ll meet \u2013 Jeff hanging up his Y-fronts? Chris watering the ferns? \u2013 which keeps things interesting.</p> <p>Is my generation ashamed of the comparatively small size of our homes? In the 1980s, when I was born, Mum\u2019s new mothers group met at someone\u2019s home \u2013 they all lived in houses, with plenty of space to chat and play.</p> <p>Not any more. My group of inner-city parents meet in public \u2013 parks, libraries and community centres mostly, with the odd trip to the museum thrown in. At almost five, my son has attended countless birthday parties, but not one has been at someone\u2019s home. His own parties have all been in parks except one, his first, which we held in my parents\u2019 garden.</p> <p>That day I eavesdropped on a group of dads, professional men in their 30s and 40s, sipping beer and talking about \u2013 what else? \u2013 real estate. \u201cWe can\u2019t afford anything like this,\u201d said one, gesturing at the large leafy garden. \u201cA proper<em> </em>home for a family.\u201d</p> <p>But what is a proper home? My dad\u2019s disdain for where I live is blinkered by a limited experience of what constitutes \u201cnormal\u201d.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/grogonomics/2023/apr/13/young-australians-never-stood-a-chance-for-decades-the-controls-have-been-set-to-favour-older-generations\">Young Australians never stood a chance. For decades the controls have been set to favour older generations | Greg Jericho</a> </p> </aside>  <p>In Europe, where 46.2% of people live in flats, raising children this way is unremarkable.<strong> </strong>I lived in Nanjing, China, for a year, where owning a house would be unthinkable for all but the uber-rich. Everyone lives in apartments and at night, rather than staying cooped up inside, people headed out to the streets, often in pyjamas, to chat, eat, play cards, dance. The streets became \u70ed\u95f9 <em>r\u00e8n\u00e0o, </em>a term that means lively, bustling. I once showed a Chinese friend around our Melbourne suburb. \u201cIt\u2019s beautiful, but so quiet,\u201d she said. \u201cWhere\u2019s the <em>r\u00e8n\u00e0o?</em>\u201d</p> <p>Our suburb may not be <em>r\u00e8n\u00e0o</em>, but raising kids in a flat forces you out and out is where you meet people. Before I had children, I knew very few neighbours. But when you\u2019re roaming the nature strip with a mushroom-seeking toddler, people stop for a chat. Children, like dogs, are a social lubricant and I can\u2019t go out for a walk any more without bumping into someone I know.</p> <p>I have no study, so I work at a communal studio where I\u2019ve made countless friends. I have no garden of my own, so I grow veggies at the local community plot. We often spend entire Saturdays down there: it\u2019s become our village square, where kids run wild and adults meet and mingle. For Easter, we had a big hot cross bun cook-up with some other gardeners and it was loads of fun. Would we have done that if we lived in a house?</p> <p>At times I debate a move to the country, to a place of our own. But at what price? All those precious networks uprooted: social, professional, family. The need to start again. No. My kids will be flat kids, with all that that entails. I reckon they\u2019ll turn out just fine.</p> <p>\u2022 <a href=\"https://isabelrobinson.net/\">Isabel Robinson</a> is a Melbourne-based freelance writer who has been published in the Age, the Sydney Morning Herald and the Victorian Writer</p>", "wordcount": "877", "commentCloseDate": "2023-04-20T00:24:49Z", "commentable": "true", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T00:24:49Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-17T02:45:04Z", "productionOffice": "AUS", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nmk83", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/7731c877006ee42d42b8cb9257f24cc9e24e308e/125_0_5750_3453/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "My father lives in the next suburb, but I can count the times he\u2019s been inside my home on one hand. Two fingers, actually: after the birth of my son and after the birth of my daughter. It\u2019s not because we don\u2019t get on \u2013 I love Dad and he loves me. But he is a boomer who bought a four-bedroom, three-garden house for $2 in 1974, and I am pushing 40 and live in a flat. Let me repeat: a <em>flat. </em>When he steps inside my front door, I know what he\u2019s thinking.</p> <p>How \u2013 he wonders, administering the polite amount of baby cuddles before racing for the exit \u2013 can my seemingly intelligent daughter, mother of two, whose private school fees I paid for, live in this hellhole?</p> <p>Career choices aside \u2013 IT versus writing, no prizes for guessing the more lucrative \u2013 it\u2019s not what my younger self expected either. The Great Australian Dream is still home ownership and, more specifically, <em>house </em>ownership. Growing up in middle-class inner Melbourne in the 80s and 90s, none of my friends lived in flats and I assumed that by the time I had children, I too would live in a house of my own. But \u2013 who knew? \u2013 the keys don\u2019t emerge with the baby in a kind of painful-but-convenient two-for-one deal.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>Is my generation ashamed of the comparatively small size of our homes?</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>Like it or not, higher-density living is the future of our cities and families in flats are becoming more common. Living cheek by jowl has its obvious downsides (wafting smoke out of a neighbour\u2019s window, for instance, and don\u2019t get me started on the window-rattling sex in the bedroom above) but there are positives to living so close to one\u2019s fellow man.</p> <p>Sandwiched above, below and to one side by other apartments, our place is cool in summer and warm in winter. A neighbour can easily pop up the back stairs and crack a can of Fancy Feast for our cat when we\u2019re away.</p> <ul> <li><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/dec/21/sign-up-for-five-great-reads-guardian-australias-wrap-of-our-best-summer-stories\">Sign up for a weekly email featuring our best reads</a></strong></p></li> </ul> <p>During lockdowns, the woman next door left gifts on the mat for our toddler: piles of shells, helicopter leaves, the latest supermarket collectible. When I take my son down to play in the communal courtyard, we never know whom we\u2019ll meet \u2013 Jeff hanging up his Y-fronts? Chris watering the ferns? \u2013 which keeps things interesting.</p> <p>Is my generation ashamed of the comparatively small size of our homes? In the 1980s, when I was born, Mum\u2019s new mothers group met at someone\u2019s home \u2013 they all lived in houses, with plenty of space to chat and play.</p> <p>Not any more. My group of inner-city parents meet in public \u2013 parks, libraries and community centres mostly, with the odd trip to the museum thrown in. At almost five, my son has attended countless birthday parties, but not one has been at someone\u2019s home. His own parties have all been in parks except one, his first, which we held in my parents\u2019 garden.</p> <p>That day I eavesdropped on a group of dads, professional men in their 30s and 40s, sipping beer and talking about \u2013 what else? \u2013 real estate. \u201cWe can\u2019t afford anything like this,\u201d said one, gesturing at the large leafy garden. \u201cA proper<em> </em>home for a family.\u201d</p> <p>But what is a proper home? My dad\u2019s disdain for where I live is blinkered by a limited experience of what constitutes \u201cnormal\u201d.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/grogonomics/2023/apr/13/young-australians-never-stood-a-chance-for-decades-the-controls-have-been-set-to-favour-older-generations\">Young Australians never stood a chance. For decades the controls have been set to favour older generations | Greg Jericho</a> </p> </aside>  <p>In Europe, where 46.2% of people live in flats, raising children this way is unremarkable.<strong> </strong>I lived in Nanjing, China, for a year, where owning a house would be unthinkable for all but the uber-rich. Everyone lives in apartments and at night, rather than staying cooped up inside, people headed out to the streets, often in pyjamas, to chat, eat, play cards, dance. The streets became \u70ed\u95f9 <em>r\u00e8n\u00e0o, </em>a term that means lively, bustling. I once showed a Chinese friend around our Melbourne suburb. \u201cIt\u2019s beautiful, but so quiet,\u201d she said. \u201cWhere\u2019s the <em>r\u00e8n\u00e0o?</em>\u201d</p> <p>Our suburb may not be <em>r\u00e8n\u00e0o</em>, but raising kids in a flat forces you out and out is where you meet people. Before I had children, I knew very few neighbours. But when you\u2019re roaming the nature strip with a mushroom-seeking toddler, people stop for a chat. Children, like dogs, are a social lubricant and I can\u2019t go out for a walk any more without bumping into someone I know.</p> <p>I have no study, so I work at a communal studio where I\u2019ve made countless friends. I have no garden of my own, so I grow veggies at the local community plot. We often spend entire Saturdays down there: it\u2019s become our village square, where kids run wild and adults meet and mingle. For Easter, we had a big hot cross bun cook-up with some other gardeners and it was loads of fun. Would we have done that if we lived in a house?</p> <p>At times I debate a move to the country, to a place of our own. But at what price? All those precious networks uprooted: social, professional, family. The need to start again. No. My kids will be flat kids, with all that that entails. I reckon they\u2019ll turn out just fine.</p> <p>\u2022 <a href=\"https://isabelrobinson.net/\">Isabel Robinson</a> is a Melbourne-based freelance writer who has been published in the Age, the Sydney Morning Herald and the Victorian Writer</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "My father lives in the next suburb, but I can count the times he\u2019s been inside my home on one hand. Two fingers, actually: after the birth of my son and after the birth of my daughter. It\u2019s not because we don\u2019t get on \u2013 I love Dad and he loves me. But he is a boomer who bought a four-bedroom, three-garden house for $2 in 1974, and I am pushing 40 and live in a flat. Let me repeat: a flat. When he steps inside my front door, I know what he\u2019s thinking. How \u2013 he wonders, administering the polite amount of baby cuddles before racing for the exit \u2013 can my seemingly intelligent daughter, mother of two, whose private school fees I paid for, live in this hellhole? Career choices aside \u2013 IT versus writing, no prizes for guessing the more lucrative \u2013 it\u2019s not what my younger self expected either. The Great Australian Dream is still home ownership and, more specifically, house ownership. Growing up in middle-class inner Melbourne in the 80s and 90s, none of my friends lived in flats and I assumed that by the time I had children, I too would live in a house of my own. But \u2013 who knew? \u2013 the keys don\u2019t emerge with the baby in a kind of painful-but-convenient two-for-one deal.\nLike it or not, higher-density living is the future of our cities and families in flats are becoming more common. Living cheek by jowl has its obvious downsides (wafting smoke out of a neighbour\u2019s window, for instance, and don\u2019t get me started on the window-rattling sex in the bedroom above) but there are positives to living so close to one\u2019s fellow man. Sandwiched above, below and to one side by other apartments, our place is cool in summer and warm in winter. A neighbour can easily pop up the back stairs and crack a can of Fancy Feast for our cat when we\u2019re away. Sign up for a weekly email featuring our best reads During lockdowns, the woman next door left gifts on the mat for our toddler: piles of shells, helicopter leaves, the latest supermarket collectible. When I take my son down to play in the communal courtyard, we never know whom we\u2019ll meet \u2013 Jeff hanging up his Y-fronts? Chris watering the ferns? \u2013 which keeps things interesting. Is my generation ashamed of the comparatively small size of our homes? In the 1980s, when I was born, Mum\u2019s new mothers group met at someone\u2019s home \u2013 they all lived in houses, with plenty of space to chat and play. Not any more. My group of inner-city parents meet in public \u2013 parks, libraries and community centres mostly, with the odd trip to the museum thrown in. At almost five, my son has attended countless birthday parties, but not one has been at someone\u2019s home. His own parties have all been in parks except one, his first, which we held in my parents\u2019 garden. That day I eavesdropped on a group of dads, professional men in their 30s and 40s, sipping beer and talking about \u2013 what else? \u2013 real estate. \u201cWe can\u2019t afford anything like this,\u201d said one, gesturing at the large leafy garden. \u201cA proper home for a family.\u201d But what is a proper home? My dad\u2019s disdain for where I live is blinkered by a limited experience of what constitutes \u201cnormal\u201d.\nIn Europe, where 46.2% of people live in flats, raising children this way is unremarkable. I lived in Nanjing, China, for a year, where owning a house would be unthinkable for all but the uber-rich. Everyone lives in apartments and at night, rather than staying cooped up inside, people headed out to the streets, often in pyjamas, to chat, eat, play cards, dance. The streets became \u70ed\u95f9 r\u00e8n\u00e0o, a term that means lively, bustling. I once showed a Chinese friend around our Melbourne suburb. \u201cIt\u2019s beautiful, but so quiet,\u201d she said. \u201cWhere\u2019s the r\u00e8n\u00e0o?\u201d Our suburb may not be r\u00e8n\u00e0o, but raising kids in a flat forces you out and out is where you meet people. Before I had children, I knew very few neighbours. But when you\u2019re roaming the nature strip with a mushroom-seeking toddler, people stop for a chat. Children, like dogs, are a social lubricant and I can\u2019t go out for a walk any more without bumping into someone I know. I have no study, so I work at a communal studio where I\u2019ve made countless friends. I have no garden of my own, so I grow veggies at the local community plot. We often spend entire Saturdays down there: it\u2019s become our village square, where kids run wild and adults meet and mingle. For Easter, we had a big hot cross bun cook-up with some other gardeners and it was loads of fun. Would we have done that if we lived in a house? At times I debate a move to the country, to a place of our own. But at what price? All those precious networks uprooted: social, professional, family. The need to start again. It finished in the gathering gloom of the Adelaide Oval with a mad scramble in St Kilda\u2019s front half, and the mother of all frights for Collingwood.</p> <p>In between, we saw a swaggering Adelaide and a cranky Richmond. We saw two excellent wins in the slop from Essendon and Port Adelaide. We saw the ultimate players\u2019 coach fly the flag for his young star who had tilted the game Port\u2019s way. And we saw a belated apology from the Collingwood Football Club to Nicky Winmar and Gilbert McAdam.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/mar/14/gil-mclachlan-enters-final-quarter-with-afl-facing-some-of-its-biggest-ever-threats\">Gil McLachlan enters final quarter with AFL facing some of its biggest ever threats | Jonathan Horn</a> </p> </aside>  <p>When it comes to AFL initiatives, I tend toward the cynical side. And after a day or so, the eagerness of the commentariat to spruik the all-encompassing magnificence of the Festival of Football started to grate. But there\u2019s no point being a Negative Nellie about things. Gather Round was a triumph. The two local teams stood up in marquee games that had real weight. South Australians are football people. They turn up. They live and breathe the sport. They deserved the three-year extension.</p> <p>The final game was one of the most highly anticipated. But there were none of the fireworks of the opening night. It was a clogged and confusing game. We shouldn\u2019t have expected anything else. The Magpies were allowed to play their own way for the first three weeks. But you don\u2019t get that free rein for long.</p> <p>In this competition, there\u2019s always a Ross Lyon waiting with a baseball bat. And for all the talk of a new Ross, a cuddlier Ross, a more attacking Ross, some things never change. This is a man who once said \u201cit\u2019s easier to destruct than to create\u201d. Indeed, St Kilda\u2019s opening month was one of the most miserly in the history of the game, conceding just 56 goals.</p> <p>And so, unsurprisingly, one of the most attacking teams in the game was constantly thwarted and frustrated. They were denied the corridor. Their high balls were picked off by St Kilda\u2019s tall defenders. They had injuries and illnesses. They had to win ugly. They had an inordinate number of smothers. And they had Nick Daicos. There\u2019s a school of thought that Daicos is \u2018stat padding\u2019, that he gets too many cheap kicks, and that he doesn\u2019t win his own ball. It\u2019s a peculiar hill to die on. True, he just zips about \u2013 smooth, smart, neat. But he had 42 possessions yesterday. He\u2019s pretty handy, as Lyon would say.</p> <p>Whenever Daicos has the ball, the possibilities up the field open up. The forwards can lead to spots they\u2019d otherwise never venture. They know he\u2019ll find them. Jason Dunstall used to say that about leading to Darren Jarman. He was never more confident on a football field as when Jarman had the ball and was loping in his direction. Nick Daicos isn\u2019t as good a kick as Darren Jarman. No one is. But he almost never misses. He\u2019s now the Brownlow Medal favourite. He\u2019s also 20 years old.</p> <p>Another 20-year-old made a welcome return yesterday. I felt a bit for Jack Ginnivan in recent months. When his drug scandal broke, Channel 7 seemed to have assigned three dozen reporters to the story. They all addressed the camera like it was a giant pork chop. Jack is a smart footballer. But off the field, the frontal cortex is still forming. A cursory survey of young men at the Torquay Hotel in the middle of summer is not going to showcase a gender and a generation at the top of its game.</p> <p>In the end, it was 24-hours of \u2018value swaps\u2019, a little bit of tut-tutting but mainly shoulder shrugging from a generation disinclined to let a Channel 7 journalist or a footy club play moral arbiter. Ginnivan looked a bit subdued yesterday, but still did some clever things, kicking a clutch goal early in the final term and forcing a key turnover.</p> <p>And he reminded us, as Ken Hinkley did on Saturday night when he defended Jason Horne-Francis, that we\u2019re pitiless on our young players. \u201cSome people who put pressure on kids in this game need to take a good hard look at themselves,\u201d he said. Indeed, there\u2019s a cottage industry of former footballers, newshounds and anonymous trolls who delight in tearing these kids to shreds.</p> <p>But with apologies to the South Australian Premier, it was the kids who owned Gather Round. It was Rankine, Josh Rachele, Horne-Francis and Daicos who put on the show, who lit up the Adelaide Oval, and who will dominate this competition for years to come.</p>", "wordcount": "787", "commentCloseDate": "2023-04-20T00:08:57Z", "commentable": "true", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-17T00:08:57Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-18T22:09:18Z", "productionOffice": "AUS", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nndnq", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/9547d3b60dfda90a7c51fda9b01632f677c8ca2b/0_119_3556_2134/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Gather Round started with Izak Rankine, who played senior SANFL football as a sixteen-year-old and who was racially abused by troglodytes a few days ago, curling a goal within the first thirty seconds. And we saw a belated apology from the Collingwood Football Club to Nicky Winmar and Gilbert McAdam.</p>"}}, {"type": "rich-link", "assets": [], "richLinkTypeData": {"url": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/mar/14/gil-mclachlan-enters-final-quarter-with-afl-facing-some-of-its-biggest-ever-threats", "originalUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/mar/14/gil-mclachlan-enters-final-quarter-with-afl-facing-some-of-its-biggest-ever-threats", "linkText": "Gil McLachlan enters final quarter with AFL facing some of its biggest ever threats | Jonathan Horn", "linkPrefix": "Related: ", "role": "thumbnail"}}, {"type": "text", "assets": [], "textTypeData": {"html": "<p>When it comes to AFL initiatives, I tend toward the cynical side. And after a day or so, the eagerness of the commentariat to spruik the all-encompassing magnificence of the Festival of Football started to grate. But there\u2019s no point being a Negative Nellie about things. Gather Round was a triumph. The two local teams stood up in marquee games that had real weight. South Australians are football people. They turn up. They live and breathe the sport. They deserved the three-year extension.</p> \n<p>The final game was one of the most highly anticipated. But there were none of the fireworks of the opening night. It was a clogged and confusing game. We shouldn\u2019t have expected anything else. The Magpies were allowed to play their own way for the first three weeks. But you don\u2019t get that free rein for long.</p> \n<p>In this competition, there\u2019s always a Ross Lyon waiting with a baseball bat. And for all the talk of a new Ross, a cuddlier Ross, a more attacking Ross, some things never change. This is a man who once said \u201cit\u2019s easier to destruct than to create\u201d. Indeed, St Kilda\u2019s opening month was one of the most miserly in the history of the game, conceding just 56 goals.</p> \n<p>And so, unsurprisingly, one of the most attacking teams in the game was constantly thwarted and frustrated. They were denied the corridor. Their high balls were picked off by St Kilda\u2019s tall defenders. They had injuries and illnesses. They had to win ugly. They had an inordinate number of smothers. And they had Nick Daicos. There\u2019s a school of thought that Daicos is \u2018stat padding\u2019, that he gets too many cheap kicks, and that he doesn\u2019t win his own ball. It\u2019s a peculiar hill to die on. True, he just zips about \u2013 smooth, smart, neat. But he had 42 possessions yesterday. He\u2019s pretty handy, as Lyon would say.</p> \n<p>Whenever Daicos has the ball, the possibilities up the field open up. The forwards can lead to spots they\u2019d otherwise never venture. They know he\u2019ll find them. Jason Dunstall used to say that about leading to Darren Jarman. He was never more confident on a football field as when Jarman had the ball and was loping in his direction. Nick Daicos isn\u2019t as good a kick as Darren Jarman. No one is. But he almost never misses. He\u2019s now the Brownlow Medal favourite. He\u2019s also 20 years old.</p> \n<p>Another 20-year-old made a welcome return yesterday. I felt a bit for Jack Ginnivan in recent months. When his drug scandal broke, Channel 7 seemed to have assigned three dozen reporters to the story. They all addressed the camera like it was a giant pork chop. Jack is a smart footballer. But off the field, the frontal cortex is still forming. A cursory survey of young men at the Torquay Hotel in the middle of summer is not going to showcase a gender and a generation at the top of its game.</p> \n<p>In the end, it was 24-hours of \u2018value swaps\u2019, a little bit of tut-tutting but mainly shoulder shrugging from a generation disinclined to let a Channel 7 journalist or a footy club play moral arbiter. Ginnivan looked a bit subdued yesterday, but still did some clever things, kicking a clutch goal early in the final term and forcing a key turnover.</p> \n<p>And he reminded us, as Ken Hinkley did on Saturday night when he defended Jason Horne-Francis, that we\u2019re pitiless on our young players. \u201cSome people who put pressure on kids in this game need to take a good hard look at themselves,\u201d he said. Indeed, there\u2019s a cottage industry of former footballers, newshounds and anonymous trolls who delight in tearing these kids to shreds.</p> \n<p>But with apologies to the South Australian Premier, it was the kids who owned Gather Round. It was Rankine, Josh Rachele, Horne-Francis and Daicos who put on the show, who lit up the Adelaide Oval, and who will dominate this competition for years to come.</p>"}}]}], "totalBodyBlocks": 1}, "rights": {"syndicatable": "true", "subscriptionDatabases": "true", "developerCommunity": "true"}, "section": {"id": "sport", "webTitle": "Sport", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/sport", "editions": [{"id": "sport", "webTitle": "Sport", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/sport", "code": "default"}, {"id": "uk/sport", "webTitle": "Sport", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/uk/sport", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/uk/sport", "code": "uk"}, {"id": "us/sport", "webTitle": "Sport", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/us/sport", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/us/sport", "code": "us"}, {"id": "au/sport", "webTitle": "Sport", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/au/sport", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/au/sport", "code": "au"}]}, "isHosted": false, "pillarId": "pillar/sport", "pillarName": "Sport"}]}}
